text:
IN THE end, a trade war was averted. In Geneva on June 28th Mickey Kantor, America's trade representative, was ready to strike. Come midnight he would smite 13 Japanese luxury-car models with tariffs of 100%, effectively cutting them out of America's markets. But, with half a day left on the clock, a deal was cut. Mr Kantor, like many American trade warriors before him, laid down his shinai without striking a blow.
So has America got what it wanted? It likes to think so. Bill Clinton hailed the deal as a "major step forward for free trade" and claimed that the deal was "specific" and "measurable". According to the Americans, the Japanese have offered to deregulate the market for replacement car parts and repairs. American car makers will also get better access to Japanese car dealerships: by the end of 1996, Mr Kantor expects that American cars will be sold in another 200 dealerships in Japan; by 2000, that number will rise to 1,000. Moreover, by 1998 the Japanese will increase the number of cars they build in the United States from 2.1m to 2.65m, and spend an extra $9 billion on American-made parts.
But closer inspection suggests that America is deluding itself. Take the deregulation of car repairs. Japan's offer to cut the minimum number of mechanics at "certified" garages, for example, was on the table long ago. And how firm are Mr Kantor's numbers? Ryutaro Hashimoto, Japan's trade minister, was adamant that "we have successfully excluded all numerical targets". The carmakers deny that they have made any commitments. Words such as "forecast", "plan" and "goal" pepper the American summary. But America will have no redress if its expectations are not met.
Other bits of the deal also look value. A promise from the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) to write to Japanese dealers "affirming their freedom" to sell foreign cars will do little to stop the tactics that some Japanese car makers use to keep their dealers loyal (see box on next page). And the Japanese government says that it will "increase support" for its antitrust authorities and "take into account" American suggestions for better enforcement of its competition law. Well, big deal.
Moreover, Japanese car makers were already planning to shift production abroad in response to the strong yen. And it is unlikely that trade frictions between Japan and America will disappear--even if Japan's trade surplus at last begins to shrink in dollar as well as yen terms (see chart on next page). (Chart omitted) Previous deals have led to rancour because the two sides interpreted them differently. This one will be no exception: Mr Kantor is spouting numbers; Mr Hashimoto recognises none. Many Americans will continue to believe that the Japanese are protectionists.
The prosecutor's case
But are they right? To be sure, there are many juicy tales of Japanese perfidy. By July 2nd Mr Kantor is supposed to decide whether to bring another action against Japan under Section 301 of America's trade law, this time on behalf of Eastman Kodak, a maker of photographic film. Outside Japan, Kodak has more than half the world's film market. But in Japan it has a puny 9%.
The reason? Kodak says that in the late 1960s and early 1970s Fuji, Japan's largest film maker, gained control of the four largest distributors of film. Kodak was squeezed out. According to Alan Wolff, Kodak's lawyer, distributors and retailers are still kept in check by "secret, discriminatory and remarkably progressive" rebates for selling Fuji film. That, he says, contravenes Japan's own anti-monopoly law; but the antitrust authorities have taken no action. The result is that Fuji has around 70% of the market.
Yet there is also evidence that Japanese markets can be cracked. Foreigners' share of the car market is still small, but it is climbing. And as for finding dealers, on June 27th Chrysler said that it was paying Seibu, a vast Japanese group that owns everything from a credit-card business to department stores, over $100m for outright ownership of ten Japanese dealerships and access to 108 more (where Chryslers will be sold alongside other makes). It is difficult to credit this to Mr Kantor's sword-waving. Seibu, keen to "refocus" its business (and, along the way, to sell some assets) had been talking to Chrysler for about a year. Chrysler's sales in Japan, which climbed from 1,600 in 1992 to 13,600 last year, have reached a level where such an investment is worthwhile.
How might a disinterested economist gauge the openness of Japan? Not, as the Clinton administration is fond of doing, by pointing to international differences in the ratio of imports to GDP, Or to importers' shares of individual markets. Japan imports fewer cars than America or the European Union. But what of it? If Japan has a comparative advantage in car making, how low an import share is too low? Add distorting trade deals, such as restrictions on Japanese exports to Europe, and the question becomes knottier still.
Robert Lawrence, an economist at Harvard University, argues that prices area better guide: if entry into Japanese markets were free, international differences in prices would be narrowed by canny traders buying goods abroad and reselling them in Japan; if not, they would persist.
Such comparisons were undertaken by America's Department of Commerce and MITI as part of the Structural Impediments Initiative, the Bush administration's bid to prise Japan open. These indicated that in the early 1990s, for two-thirds of the goods surveyed, Japanese prices were higher. A study this year by the Institute for International Economics, a Washington, DC, think-tank, found a big gap between the wholesale prices of many Japanese goods and the price of imports at the dockside. And figures compiled by Japan's Economic Planning Agency indicate that the gap between the prices of food, clothing and consumer durables in Tokyo and prices in New York, far from shrinking, widened between 1990 and 1994. So, on Mr Lawrence's test, Japan has a case to answer.
Japan's efforts to deregulate its economy, however, may be changing this. In the car business, where retailers need specialist expertise, manufacturers still have tight control of sales networks. In the case of cheaper goods, where rules governing large shops have been relaxed, discounters have sprung up selling just about anything, foreign or Japanese, at lower prices. A can of beer can now be bought for Y139 ($1.65), compared with Y230 in an off-licence.
But deregulation is still slow. And that, paradoxically, is why this week's trade deal should be viewed warily. If Japan's car makers can be browbeaten into changing their suppliers, whether by America's government or by their own, that hardly represents a step towards a freer Japanese economy--or, indeed, towards freer trade.

text:
TOKYO
NO MATTER who wins, this month's election campaign in Japan will have produced something interesting. Political change is pushing Japan's politicians towards a new assertiveness. Casting about for a way to seize voters' imagination, campaigners from all main parties have denounced France's planned nuclear tests in the South Pacific.
On July 14th Toshiki Kaifu, leader of the opposition New Frontier Party, called for a consumer boycott of French imports. Three days later he was echoed by Masayoshi Takemura, finance minister and leader of one of the coalition's three parties. Yohei Kono, the leader of the Liberal Democrats, another of the coalition partners, lent his support to the idea of a parliamentary resolution criticising France. Tomiichi Murayama, the prime minister and leader of the Social Democrats, announced that Japan will propose a UN resolution calling for an end to all nuclear testing.
Since 1993, when the Liberal Democrats lost their monopoly on power, pluralism has forced politicians to woo voters with exciting notions. Vested interests frustrate bold reform at home, so the easiest way to be exciting is in foreign policy. Until this week, the clearest sign of this had been in trade negotiations. Ryutaro Hashimoto, the trade minister, became a national hero last month by defying American demands that Japan rig its car market in favour of imports.
In the past, Mr Hashimoto's populism might have backfired, since the barons of his party would have resented it. These days, however, all parties want leaders who can win votes: nearly everyone describes Mr Hashimoto as a future prime minister. Another rising Liberal Democratic star is Makiko Tanaka, the science minister. Last month, when France announced it would conduct nuclear tests, she suggested that these should be carried out in Paris. This month's election campaign, together with anti-nuclear emotion aroused by the 50th anniversary next month of the bombing of Hiroshima, has heightened nationalism.
Which issue will be next to reflect this mood? Some Japanese are starting to mutter about their military alliance with America. The latest edition of Aera, a political weekly, carries a letter suggesting that the treaty be scrapped. This was prompted by an article published in the wake of the car talks with America, about the cost to Japan of keeping American troops on its territory. Its author, Shunji Taoka, claims that American troops do little to defend Japan, not least because they are concentrated in Okinawa, miles south of Japan's main islands.
In time, Japan's rising nationalism promises great change. For the moment, however, the French have little to worry about. A consumer boycott might, in theory, discomfort French fashion firms, which are masters at persuading Japanese consumers to surrender ridiculous sums of money. The share price of LVMH, which owns brands such as Louis Vuitton, fell after a Japanese boycott was mooted. And on July 19th an association of 50,000 atom-bomb survivors announced that they would stop bung French goods. Yet the truth is that the vast majority of Japan's consumers have no tradition of boycotts, protests, or other politically correct deeds. It will be a while before Japanese ladies stamp on their Louis Vuitton handbags.

text:
UNTIL this year, it seemed reasonable to hope that the 50th anniversary of defeat in the Pacific war would prod Japan to newly frank apologies. A generation of Japanese was growing up free of guilty memories; it was apparently more willing to acknowledge Japan's past aggression and brutality. An election in 1993 doubled the number of parliamentarians in the Diet's lower house born after the war. That August the new prime minister went further down the road to apology than his predecessors, calling Japan's invasion of Asia a "war of aggression". There was talk that in 1995 the Diet would pass a resolution of apology. The stage was set for a cathartic half-centenary.
Then the stage was bulldozed. Instead of providing an occasion for remorse, the Diet resolution galvanised an alliance opposed to the very idea of apology. More than 5m people, and a quarter of the members of the Diet, signed a petition aimed at blocking the resolution. An astonishing 70% of Diet members belonging to the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), which dominates the coalition government, endorsed the campaign. In the end a much-watered-down resolution scraped through. It expressed a "sense of deep remorse" about the suffering of the war, but it also emphasised that Japan was not the sole aggressor. Individual politicians--even the prime minister--can apologise. The nation as a whole cannot.
The campaign's success depended in part on a collective rasp of history that is weak, to say the least. The leaders of the anti-apology campaign got away with denying that Japan colonised Korea (it did, between 1910 and 1945), or that it invaded other Asian states (it overran most of them). But there is more to this than simple amnesia--or, to put it another way, this amnesia is not so simple. The refusal to apologise shows up the threads that bind today's peaceful Japan to the pugnacious place of the 1930s.
Tied up
The first thread is anti-western feeling. The Japan that went to war felt encircled by a predatory West, a West which had hypocritically colonised Asia while frowning upon Japan's own colonialist desires. The Japan of today still feels put upon by the West, a West which urges nuclear nonproliferation while conducting nuclear tests, which preaches fair trade while threatening unilaterally to break the rules of the international trading system.
Japan's mistrust of the westerners' view of the war is most evident when it comes to the atomic bomb. According to a recent poll, only 3% of Japanese accept the common American claim that the obliteration of Hiroshima and Nagasaki saved lives on both sides by ending the war early. Fully 66% disagree, maintaining--as do some (but far from all) respectable western historians--that America used the bomb because of its racist contempt for Japanese, or because it wanted to intimidate the Soviet Union at the outset of the cold war.
This understandable suspicion of the West provided the ground on which the debate over the apology resolution was held--ground that was far from level. The no-apology side could get away with dismissing western critics of Japan's war-time conduct because ordinary Japanese see double-standards in so much of the West's rhetoric.
The second thread tying the present to the past is closely interwoven with the first. Japan's political suspicion of Americans and Europeans is matched by a cultural fear. Now, just as in the 1930s, the Japanese are torn between emulation of the West and a horror of becoming too western. The more some people import fashions and ideas, the more others grow obsessed with the supposedly unique features of their own culture. Both before and since the war, the Japanese have been fascinated by nihonjinron, a field of study that attempts to define the essence of Japaneseness.
Again, this cultural defensiveness was evident in the no-apology campaign. In the campaigners' view, Japan's self-respect was undermined by America's post-war occupation, which imposed an American constitution and American ideas, and during which improbably tall GIS took advantage of Japanese women. Since the Americans also forced Japan to say sorry for the war, cultural westernisation and contrition have come to be linked. In the minds of many Japanese, apology is tantamount to a betrayal of Japan's identity.
These continuing political and cultural insecurities are not too alarming. The country has changed so much in the past 50 years that a repeat of the 1930s is unimaginable. The Japanese are immeasurably more educated and free than the generation that went to war; they are richer; and they are governed by a constitution that the Americans designed precisely to bury militarism. All this has happened, despite the constant threads of nationalist sentiment, because other circumstances have changed beyond recognition. So why, apart from the inexorable cycling of the calendar, do those constant threads deserve attention now?
The answer is that the circumstances will continue to change. 'The next half century will be different from the past one. Economic success has made Japan the world's biggest supplier of cross-border investment and foreign aid. Japanese officials head the UN'S efforts to help refugees, protect the world's health and deal with the Bosnian war--and, unsurprisingly, Japan wants a permanent seat on the security council. Japan's military stance is evolving from a sub missive acceptance of American protection. The country is paying more and more towards the cost of keeping American troops on its soil, and sooner or later it may want to divert some of this money to its own armed men. Doubts about America's commitment to underwrite Asia's security will hasten that day.
The bigger Japan's influence in the world, the more disquieting a xenophobic undercurrent in Japan. That is especially so when the undercurrent can exert real institutional force--and the no-apology protests have shown that this undercurrent can. The no-apology activists emphasise devotion to the emperor, and have strong links with Shinto shrines--just like their pre-war predecessors. The conquering Americans thought they had tamed these rallying points of nationalism during the occupation. But their influence survived; it is now growing.
Veterans and Shinto
On the roof of Tokyo's Kudan Kaikan building young people drink beer served by girls in bunny outfits. Down in the basement, Sakae Suehiro fulminates against such decadence. Mr Suehiro is a big wheel in the Association of Bereaved Families, which was founded to honour Japan's war dead and to see to the repatriation of their remains. Gradually, however, the association has assumed new roles. Honouring the war dead has come to mean defending the cause for which they fell, and lambasting modern indifference to Japan's traditional virtues.
Mr Suehiro and his colleagues set much store by the Imperial Rescript on Education, promulgated in 1890. It laid down that qualities deemed especially Japanese should be instilled into the nation's youth, that it might serve the emperor gloriously. Accordingly, the first lesson of each day was to be devoted to moral training. There was much emphasis on loyalty and filial piety. Pupils recited oaths to sacrifice their lives gladly for the emperor.
The rescript was denounced during the American occupation--a denunciation Mr Suehiro denounces in his turn. The postwar Tokyo Trials, in which foreign judges condemned Japanese leaders, taught the Japanese that they were wrong: wrong in starting the war, and wrong in their pre-war values. The truth, Mr Suehiro maintains, is that Japan did not so much colonise Asian states as liberate them from white dominance, thus bringing the rage of the West down upon a Japan that it had sought to stymie. It is time, he concludes, for Japanese to feel proud of themselves. That is why his association campaigned against the apology resolution.
Mr Suehiro should not be taken lightly. His association claims a membership of 1m households; 150,000 of these loyalists are also LDP members. It is rich enough to employ 380 full-time staff, and to make itself helpful to friendly politicians. In last month's election for the upper house of the Diet, the association claims to have mustered 2m votes on behalf of its favourite candidate The association's chairman is Ryutaro Hashimoto, who is currently Japan's trade minister. Next month Mr Hashimoto hopes to be elected president of the LDP; he could become prime minister.
On top of these political links, the association has quietly joined hands with the top brass of Shintoism. The no-apology campaign was partly organised by Yoshinari Mori, the deputy chief priest of Meiji shrine, which stands at the centre of a majestic wood in central Tokyo. Mr Mori is a handsome, confident man in his 50s; he produces his business card from the sleeve of his kimono. Like the older Mr Suehiro, he has much to say about national pride. But his favourite subject is the emperor.
Japan, he says, is not merely a country. It is a race, almost a family. At the head of this clan there is the emperor, who is descended directly from Amaterasu, the sun goddess. The unbroken imperial line is a symbol of Japan's ethnic coherence; naturally it should be worshipped. And, since the war was fought in the emperor's name, to apologise for it would be unthinkable.
Mr Mori regrets that, after the war, the Americans forced the emperor to renounce his divinity. He says it would be better if the emperor still had the power to issue edicts and commands, since their wisdom would strengthen the emperor's popular following. The constitution drafted by the Americans should be revised to recognise the emperor as Japan's sovereign, not merely its symbol. Mr Mori also deplores the constitution's pacifist clause, saying that Japan will only recover its self-respect when it can defend itself.
Yasukuni poetry
America tried to sever the links between Shintoism and politics--links which were, after all, fairly new. It was only a hundred years ago that, at the time of the Imperial Rescript on Education, Japan's nationalists bean turning Shintoism from a harmless nature-worshipping faith into an ideology of Japaneseness. The Americans thought they could undo this change by way of institutions. Their constitution stipulated a strict division between religion and the state. The government ministry that administered Shintoism was closed; a Shinto university that had turned out cohorts of ideologues was shut down also. But the links remain, and the institutions have returned.
Tokyo's great Shinto shrines could scarcely exist without promoting nationalism. Meiji is a fine example. It has no place in the nature-worshipping past; it was built to enshrine the soul of the Meiji emperor, whose reign from 1867 to 1912 marked the emergence of Shinto-centred nationalism. A pamphlet explains that, after the death of the Meiji emperor and his wife, the shrine was put up in response to "the entire nation's passionate desire to worship the holy spirit of the imperial couple, and to adore and respect their saintly virtue eternally."
Behind its spectacular gateway, Tokyo's Yasukuni shrine is even more nationalistic. It was built in the Meiji period to enshrine the souls of Japan's war dead, and until 1945 its priests were appointed by the war ministry, and enjoyed the rank of colonel. Among the cherry trees in the rounds there is an exhibit of uniforms and military paraphernalia, particularly suicide weapons: a torpedo guided by a human crew; a mine attached to a bamboo that was hand-delivered by a diver; various types of suicide aircraft. The 6,000 who died in such contraptions were "incomparable in their tragic bravery," explains an inscription in the shrine museum, and "engulfed the entire country in tears of gratitude."
The nationalism of these shrines has grown more obvious as the American occupation has receded. The Americans briefly closed Yasukuni after the war, and insisted that its overt militarism be tempered. After they had left, bronze engravings celebrating Japanese military victories were restored, and the spirits of Japan's executed war criminals were enshrined. The inscription honouring the cult of suicide was put up in 1985, to mark the war's 40th anniversary. And this year Yasukuni brought out a book of poems written by soldiers at the front. One, dated 1944, is chalked up on a blackboard in the shrine's rounds. "I devote myself to the country. This is my highest pleasure ... We will colour history with our blood."
The unravelling of America's post-war design is also evident at Ise, a small town near Osaka remarkable only for its shrine and for a theme park that allows locals to visit Spain without the inconvenience of air travel. Like the Meiji shrine, Ise is devoted to the imperial cult, and particularly to the sun goddess Amaterasu. Only the emperor is allowed to pass through the four gates leading to the inner shrine, but this does not seem to hurt Ise's growing popularity among ordinary pilgrims. Last year 8.3m came to wash their hands in the purifying river that runs through the shrine's park, and to buy amulets from its kiosks.
Outside the park is Kogakkan, the Shinto university that the Americans closed down. Like Yasukuni, it was soon reopened. It now has 20,000 students. Its senior professor, Katsunoshin Sakurai, recites the familiar nationalist line: Japan's culture and pride must be restored, Japan needs a bier army. The university's pamphlet explains that students are taught to "uphold high ideals of the true Japanese". Two students assailing each other with kendo swords illustrate the point.
The government's Shinto affairs department, which the Americans also closed down, has been resurrected as the Association of Shinto Shrines. During the debate over the war apology, its officials spoke to the top Liberal Democrats in the Diet at least once a day. Indeed, politicians always make a point of listening to the association's views, not least because its staff oblige by organising campaign meeting in local shrines before elections. Roughly one in four Diet members owes his job partly to the shrines' support.
Nationalism, old and new
The power of nationalistic pressure groups, whose leaders are intimate with senior politicians, is rarely as evident as it was when the apology resolution was blocked. Most of the changes they help bring about are symbolic and little noticed beyond Japan's shores. National Foundation Day, the commemoration of Japan's birth from a union of two gods, was struck from the list of public holidays by the Americans; it is now reinstated. The use of the imperial calendar, which counts years from the date of the reigning emperor's coronation (this year, for example, is known as Heisei seven) is now compulsory in public life. The state paid for the current emperor to be enthroned with full Shinto rites.
The question is how long this modesty will endure. Most nationalists want to step up the fight over the past; the shrines' association this year won approval for a history book from the education ministry's censors. Some nationalists talk of rolling back the separation of religion and state in much bolder ways: by having Shintoism taught in schools, or by forging an anti-crime alliance between the local shrines and police. And just about all nationalists would like a stronger army, despite the pacifist constitution.
Up to a point, these desires are natural. After the war, Japan had no choice about accepting its new constitution. It is hardly surprising that, 50 years on, some Japanese should want to revise it. UNTIL this year , it seemed reasonable to hope that the 50th anniversary of defeat in the Pacific war would prod Japan to newly frank apologies . A generation of Japanese was growing up free of guilty memories ; it was apparently more willing to acknowledge Japan 's past aggression and brutality . An election in 1993 doubled the number of parliamentarians in the Diet 's lower house born after the war . That August the new prime minister went further down the road to apology than his predecessors , calling Japan 's invasion of Asia a " war of aggression " . There was talk that in 1995 the Diet would pass a resolution of apology . The stage was set for a cathartic half - centenary . 
 Then the stage was bulldozed . Instead of providing an occasion for remorse , the Diet resolution galvanised an alliance opposed to the very idea of apology . More than 5 m people , and a quarter of the members of the Diet , signed a petition aimed at blocking the resolution . An astonishing 70 % of Diet members belonging to the Liberal Democratic Party ( LDP ) , which dominates the coalition government , endorsed the campaign . In the end a much - watered - down resolution scraped through . It expressed a " sense of deep remorse " about the suffering of the war , but it also emphasised that Japan was not the sole aggressor . Individual politicians -- even the prime minister -- can apologise . The nation as a whole can not . 
 The campaign 's success depended in part on a collective rasp of history that is weak , to say the least . The leaders of the anti - apology campaign got away with denying that Japan colonised Korea ( it did , between 1910 and 1945 ) , or that it invaded other Asian states ( it overran most of them ) . But there is more to this than simple amnesia -- or , to put it another way , this amnesia is not so simple . The refusal to apologise shows up the threads that bind today 's peaceful Japan to the pugnacious place of the 1930s . 
 Tied up 
 The first thread is anti - western feeling . The Japan that went to war felt encircled by a predatory West , a West which had hypocritically colonised Asia while frowning upon Japan 's own colonialist desires . The Japan of today still feels put upon by the West , a West which urges nuclear nonproliferation while conducting nuclear tests , which preaches fair trade while threatening unilaterally to break the rules of the international trading system . 
 Japan 's mistrust of the westerners ' view of the war is most evident when it comes to the atomic bomb . According to a recent poll , only 3 % of Japanese accept the common American claim that the obliteration of Hiroshima and Nagasaki saved lives on both sides by ending the war early . Fully 66 % disagree , maintaining -- as do some ( but far from all ) respectable western historians -- that America used the bomb because of its racist contempt for Japanese , or because it wanted to intimidate the Soviet Union at the outset of the cold war . 
 This understandable suspicion of the West provided the ground on which the debate over the apology resolution was held -- ground that was far from level . The no - apology side could get away with dismissing western critics of Japan 's war - time conduct because ordinary Japanese see double - standards in so much of the West 's rhetoric . 
 The second thread tying the present to the past is closely interwoven with the first . Japan 's political suspicion of Americans and Europeans is matched by a cultural fear . Now , just as in the 1930s , the Japanese are torn between emulation of the West and a horror of becoming too western . The more some people import fashions and ideas , the more others grow obsessed with the supposedly unique features of their own culture . Both before and since the war , the Japanese have been fascinated by nihonjinron , a field of study that attempts to define the essence of Japaneseness . 
 Again , this cultural defensiveness was evident in the no - apology campaign . In the campaigners ' view , Japan 's self - respect was undermined by America 's post - war occupation , which imposed an American constitution and American ideas , and during which improbably tall GIS took advantage of Japanese women . Since the Americans also forced Japan to say sorry for the war , cultural westernisation and contrition have come to be linked . In the minds of many Japanese , apology is tantamount to a betrayal of Japan 's identity . 
 These continuing political and cultural insecurities are not too alarming . The country has changed so much in the past 50 years that a repeat of the 1930s is unimaginable . The Japanese are immeasurably more educated and free than the generation that went to war ; they are richer ; and they are governed by a constitution that the Americans designed precisely to bury militarism . All this has happened , despite the constant threads of nationalist sentiment , because other circumstances have changed beyond recognition . So why , apart from the inexorable cycling of the calendar , do those constant threads deserve attention now ? 
 The answer is that the circumstances will continue to change . ' The next half century will be different from the past one . Economic success has made Japan the world 's biggest supplier of cross - border investment and foreign aid . Japanese officials head the UN 'S efforts to help refugees , protect the world 's health and deal with the Bosnian war -- and , unsurprisingly , Japan wants a permanent seat on the security council . Japan 's military stance is evolving from a sub missive acceptance of American protection . The country is paying more and more towards the cost of keeping American troops on its soil , and sooner or later it may want to divert some of this money to its own armed men . Doubts about America 's commitment to underwrite Asia 's security will hasten that day . 
 The bigger Japan 's influence in the world , the more disquieting a xenophobic undercurrent in Japan . That is especially so when the undercurrent can exert real institutional force -- and the no - apology protests have shown that this undercurrent can . The no - apology activists emphasise devotion to the emperor , and have strong links with Shinto shrines -- just like their pre - war predecessors . The conquering Americans thought they had tamed these rallying points of nationalism during the occupation . But their influence survived ; it is now growing . 
 Veterans and Shinto 
 On the roof of Tokyo 's Kudan Kaikan building young people drink beer served by girls in bunny outfits . Down in the basement , Sakae Suehiro fulminates against such decadence . Mr Suehiro is a big wheel in the Association of Bereaved Families , which was founded to honour Japan 's war dead and to see to the repatriation of their remains . Gradually , however , the association has assumed new roles . Honouring the war dead has come to mean defending the cause for which they fell , and lambasting modern indifference to Japan 's traditional virtues . 
 Mr Suehiro and his colleagues set much store by the Imperial Rescript on Education , promulgated in 1890 . It laid down that qualities deemed especially Japanese should be instilled into the nation 's youth , that it might serve the emperor gloriously . Accordingly , the first lesson of each day was to be devoted to moral training . There was much emphasis on loyalty and filial piety . Pupils recited oaths to sacrifice their lives gladly for the emperor . 
 The rescript was denounced during the American occupation -- a denunciation Mr Suehiro denounces in his turn . The postwar Tokyo Trials , in which foreign judges condemned Japanese leaders , taught the Japanese that they were wrong : wrong in starting the war , and wrong in their pre - war values . The truth , Mr Suehiro maintains , is that Japan did not so much colonise Asian states as liberate them from white dominance , thus bringing the rage of the West down upon a Japan that it had sought to stymie . It is time , he concludes , for Japanese to feel proud of themselves . That is why his association campaigned against the apology resolution . 
 Mr Suehiro should not be taken lightly . His association claims a membership of 1 m households ; 150,000 of these loyalists are also LDP members . It is rich enough to employ 380 full - time staff , and to make itself helpful to friendly politicians . In last month 's election for the upper house of the Diet , the association claims to have mustered 2 m votes on behalf of its favourite candidate The association 's chairman is Ryutaro Hashimoto's . Next month Ryutaro Hashimoto hopes to be elected president of the LDP ; Ryutaro Hashimoto could become prime minister . 
 On top of these political links , the association has quietly joined hands with the top brass of Shintoism . The no - apology campaign was partly organised by Yoshinari Mori , the deputy chief priest of Meiji shrine , which stands at the centre of a majestic wood in central Tokyo . Mr Mori is a handsome , confident man in his 50s ; he produces his business card from the sleeve of his kimono . Like the older Mr Suehiro , he has much to say about national pride . But his favourite subject is the emperor . 
 Japan , he says , is not merely a country . It is a race , almost a family . At the head of this clan there is the emperor , who is descended directly from Amaterasu , the sun goddess . The unbroken imperial line is a symbol of Japan 's ethnic coherence ; naturally it should be worshipped . And , since the war was fought in the emperor 's name , to apologise for it would be unthinkable . 
 Mr Mori regrets that , after the war , the Americans forced the emperor to renounce his divinity . He says it would be better if the emperor still had the power to issue edicts and commands , since their wisdom would strengthen the emperor 's popular following . The constitution drafted by the Americans should be revised to recognise the emperor as Japan 's sovereign , not merely its symbol . Mr Mori also deplores the constitution 's pacifist clause , saying that Japan will only recover its self - respect when it can defend itself .

 America tried to sever the links between Shintoism and politics -- links which were , after all , fairly new . It was only a hundred years ago that , at the time of the Imperial Rescript on Education , Japan 's nationalists bean turning Shintoism from a harmless nature - worshipping faith into an ideology of Japaneseness . The Americans thought they could undo this change by way of institutions . Their constitution stipulated a strict division between religion and the state . The government ministry that administered Shintoism was closed ; a Shinto university that had turned out cohorts of ideologues was shut down also . But the links remain , and the institutions have returned . 
 Tokyo 's great Shinto shrines could scarcely exist without promoting nationalism . Meiji is a fine example . It has no place in the nature - worshipping past ; it was built to enshrine the soul of the Meiji emperor , whose reign from 1867 to 1912 marked the emergence of Shinto - centred nationalism . A pamphlet explains that , after the death of the Meiji emperor and his wife , the shrine was put up in response to " the entire nation 's passionate desire to worship the holy spirit of the imperial couple , and to adore and respect their saintly virtue eternally . Among the cherry trees in the rounds there is an exhibit of uniforms and military paraphernalia , particularly suicide weapons : a torpedo guided by a human crew ; a mine attached to a bamboo that was hand - delivered by a diver ; various types of suicide aircraft . text:
Force majeure
NATO launched a series of massive air raids on Serbian positions around Sarajevo and in Serb-held Bosnian territory, after the shelling of Sarajevo market by Serb gunmen in which 37 people died and at least 80 were wounded. Boris Yeltsin, the Russian president, denounced the bombardment as "cruel". The Serbian government announced that if would form a joint team with the Bosnian Serbs to hold peace negotiations.
The Georgian leader, Edward Shevardnadze, narrowly escaped assassination after a car bomb exploded in the capital, Tbilisi. He was on his way to the signing ceremony of a new constitution which gives the elected president wide new powers. Within hours, he declared he would stand for the post in November.
Alain Madelin, the newish French finance minister, who wanted to cut welfare spending and public-sector pensions, was forced to resign. He was replaced by Jean Arthuis. And after 12 years as Switzerland's finance minister, Otto Stich, is to retire, tired of fighting growing federal debts.
Germany's opposition leader, Rudolf Scharping, struggled to retain authority in his Social Democratic party. He removed his ambitious rival, Gerhard Schroder, the premier of Lower Saxony, from his post as economics spokesman for the party.
The Polish president, Lech Walesa, sacked his long-time top aide, Mieczyslaw Wachowski, his ping-pong partner and former driver accused of misconduct and intrigues. Mr Walesa hopes to silence some of his critics before his bid for re-election this autumn.
As Northern Ireland cautiously celebrated a year-long ceasefire, James Molyneaux, the 75-year-old leader of Northern Ireland's Protestant Ulster Unionist Party, resigned. Since the launch in February of the Anglo-Irish framework document for peace in Northern Ireland, which Unionists say betrayed them, Mr Molyneaux has been under pressure to go.
On the block
Pete Wilson, the governor of California, officially announced that he was running for the Republican presidential nomination. Bob Dole, shifting to the right in his own campaign, returned the money he had previously solicited from a gay Republican group.
The retrial began of Lyle and Erik Menendez, charged with murdering their parents in Beverly Hills. In 1994, two separate juries could not decide whether to convict them of murder or manslaughter.
Senator Bob Packwood, accused of sexual and official misconduct, changed his mind and called for public hearings on the subject. His wish seemed likely to be granted.
Regress and progress
Rwanda's Tutsi-dominated government rid itself of the prime minister and three other Hutu ministers (and a Tutsi). Zaire set December 31st as the date by which all Rwandan refugees (most of them Hutus) must leave the country voluntarily or be deported.
The leaders of 12 southern African countries, meeting for the first time in Johannesburg, planned to give new life to the Southern African Development Community. The aim is a free-trade zone by 2000.
Israel's attorney-general ruled that the statute of limitations barred any trials of Israeli soldiers who might be accused of killing Egyptian prisoners-of-war. A former brigadier admits ordering the killing of 49 prisoners in 1956; an Israeli historian believes 1,000 prisoners were killed in 1967. Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak, is calling for an investigation.
Jericho, the Palestinians' autonomous enclave in the West Bank, had its borders closed for six days while Israel demanded the extradition of two men it suspected of terrorism. The Palestinian Authority, which had sentenced the men to prison, refused.
Talks between Morocco and the European Union on fishing rights in Moroccan waters broke down. Morocco had wanted a 65% cut in EU catches of octopus and squid; the EU offered 25% over three years.
Hopes of peace in Liberia: a new ruling council took power that incorporates leaders of the three main factions whose civil war has torn the country apart.
Beijing's foreigners
Tens of thousands of women arrived in Beijing for the fourth United Nations World Conference on Women. The associated gathering for non-governmental organisations is being held well away from the capital. Local officials warned delegates that demonstrations would be tolerated only at the conference site, and not even there if they were directed at China.
Yohei Kono, Japan's foreign minister, will not seek re-election as president of the Liberal Democratic Party, the largest group in the ruling coalition. He is likely to be succeeded by Ryutaro Hashimoto, the trade minister.
A car bomb killed Beant Singh, the chief minister of Punjab, in Chandigarh, the capital of the states of Punjab and Haryana. Mr Singh, a member of the ruling Congress Party, was a close ally of Narasimha Rao, the Indian prime minister. He had been chief minister since 1992.

Boris Yeltsin, the Russian president, denounced the bombardment as "cruel". The Serbian government announced that if would form a joint team with the Bosnian Serbs to hold peace negotiations.
The Georgian leader, Edward Shevardnadze, narrowly escaped assassination after a car bomb exploded in the capital, Tbilisi. He was on his way to the signing ceremony of a new constitution which gives the elected president wide new powers. Within hours, he declared he would stand for the post in November.
Alain Madelin, the newish French finance minister, who wanted to cut welfare spending and public-sector pensions, was forced to resign. He was replaced by Jean Arthuis. And after 12 years as Switzerland's finance minister, Otto Stich, is to retire, tired of fighting growing federal debts.
Germany's opposition leader, Rudolf Scharping, struggled to retain authority in his Social Democratic party. He removed his ambitious rival, Gerhard Schroder, the premier of Lower Saxony, from his post as economics spokesman for the party.
The Polish president, Lech Walesa, sacked his long-time top aide, Mieczyslaw Wachowski, his ping-pong partner and former driver accused of misconduct and intrigues. Mr Walesa hopes to silence some of his critics before his bid for re-election this autumn.
As Northern Ireland cautiously celebrated a year-long ceasefire, James Molyneaux, the 75-year-old leader of Northern Ireland's Protestant Ulster Unionist Party, resigned. Since the launch in February of the Anglo-Irish framework document for peace in Northern Ireland, which Unionists say betrayed them, Mr Molyneaux has been under pressure to go.
On the block
Pete Wilson, the governor of California, officially announced that he was running for the Republican presidential nomination. Bob Dole, shifting to the right in his own campaign, returned the money he had previously solicited from a gay Republican group.
The retrial began of Lyle and Erik Menendez, charged with murdering their parents in Beverly Hills. In 1994, two separate juries could not decide whether to convict them of murder or manslaughter.
Senator Bob Packwood, accused of sexual and official misconduct, changed his mind and called for public hearings on the subject. His wish seemed likely to be granted.
Regress and progress
Rwanda's Tutsi-dominated government rid itself of the prime minister and three other Hutu ministers (and a Tutsi). Zaire set December 31st as the date by which all Rwandan refugees (most of them Hutus) must leave the country voluntarily or be deported.
The leaders of 12 southern African countries, meeting for the first time in Johannesburg, planned to give new life to the Southern African Development Community. The aim is a free-trade zone by 2000.
Israel's attorney-general ruled that the statute of limitations barred any trials of Israeli soldiers who might be accused of killing Egyptian prisoners-of-war. A former brigadier admits ordering the killing of 49 prisoners in 1956; an Israeli historian believes 1,000 prisoners were killed in 1967. Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak, is calling for an investigation.
Jericho, the Palestinians' autonomous enclave in the West Bank, had its borders closed for six days while Israel demanded the extradition of two men it suspected of terrorism. The Palestinian Authority, which had sentenced the men to prison, refused.
Talks between Morocco and the European Union on fishing rights in Moroccan waters broke down. Morocco had wanted a 65% cut in EU catches of octopus and squid; the EU offered 25% over three years.
Hopes of peace in Liberia: a new ruling council took power that incorporates leaders of the three main factions whose civil war has torn the country apart.
Beijing's foreigners
Tens of thousands of women arrived in Beijing for the fourth United Nations World Conference on Women. The associated gathering for non-governmental organisations is being held well away from the capital. Local officials warned delegates that demonstrations would be tolerated only at the conference site, and not even there if they were directed at China.
Yohei Kono, Japan's foreign minister, will not seek re-election as president of the Liberal Democratic Party, the largest group in the ruling coalition. He is likely to be succeeded by Ryutaro Hashimoto, the trade minister.
A car bomb killed Beant Singh, the chief minister of Punjab, in Chandigarh, the capital of the states of Punjab and Haryana. Mr Singh, a member of the ruling Congress Party, was a close ally of Narasimha Rao, the Indian prime minister. He had been chief minister since 1992.

text:
TOKYO
LIKE Mike Tyson's comeback fight, it was over before it began. Barring the intervention of a surprise candidate, Ryutaro Hashimoto, the minister for trade and industry, has won by default the contest to lead the Liberal Democratic Party. Since the LDP is the governing coalition's largest member, Mr Hashimoto is, according to every political pundit from boardroom to barroom, prime-minister-in-waiting, The pundits may be right. But he could still be waiting a while.
Mr Hashimoto's victory came on August 28th when Yohei Kono, Japan's foreign minister and the LDP's current leader, threw in the towel without even officially declaring his candidacy. Victory's foundations, however, were laid two months earlier with Japan's trade deal on cars and car parts with America. Then, Mr Hashimoto successfully fended off an American threat to place a huge tariff on imports of luxury cars from Japan, without conceding any quantifiable promises in return. This triumph boosted Mr Hashimoto's already high popularity with the voters in general, and with ordinary members of the LDP in particular. Since those ordinary members command 151 of the 461 votes in the electoral college for the party's presidency, Mr Kono started to look vulnerable.
Mr Hashimoto rode his wave of popularity superbly, using it to break up the existing pattern of factions in the LDP and change it more to his liking. Though the party's five factions were formally abolished last year, they are still very much alive. Mr Kono had the backing of three of them, giving him 164 supposedly safe votes.
Some backbenchers, however, feared Mr Kono might cost them their seats (the latest opinion poll suggests 27% of respondents would like to see Mr Hashimoto as the next prime minister, compared with only 11% wanting Mr Kono); they started to defect. The LDP's indifferent showing in July's election for the Diet's upper house accelerated this trend. Soon nobody wanted to be left behind. On August 22nd, 69 LDP members of the Diet formed a cross-faction group called "Hashimoto for LDP President". The two largest Kono-supporting factions lost 28 of their members and a third small one seceded altogether.
Faced with humiliation, Mr Kono pulled out. With his honour intact, he may be able to keep a reasonably senior job in the Hashimoto era. Certainly, Mr Hashimoto might be wise to hold on to him: popular as the new leader is among voters, his coalition partners despise him.
Three's company
The difficulty is that Mr Hashimoto would need the support of all three parties in the governing coalition. He may now be leader-presumptive of the strongest leg of the governing tripod (the other two are the Social Democratic Party and the New Harbinger Party), but he is not strong enough to kick the other legs away.
Mr Hashimoto's problem, at least as far as his coalition partners are concerned, is that he is a nationalist. He thinks, as his confrontation with the Americans showed, that Japan should stop clinging to America's skins and start playing a more active role in the world. He believes in revising the constitution so that the country can formally abandon the pretence of a self-effacing "Self-Defence Force". He wants Japan to have a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council. And, as chairman of the Japan War Bereaved Families Association, he is not terribly keen on official apologies for Japan's wartime activities.
Such nationalistic sentiments make him an uncomfortable partner for Tomiichi Murayama, the prime minister and leader of the Social Democrats. Mr Murayama is a pacifist who recently made what may or may not have been an unequivocal apology for Japanese misdemeanours before 1945. The third member of the triumvirate, Masayoshi Takemura (finance minister and leader of the New Harbinger Party), does not like Mr Hashimoto much either. Such different partners seem ill-suited. Yet for Mr Hashimoto to ditch his allies and go to the country might be a mistake: the latest Nikkei poll shows only 32% of respondents saying they would vote for the LDP.
In any event, engineering a rapid election to the Diet's lower house (where the power lies) would not look very statesman-like. Though given a breathing-space by the weakening of the yen, Japan's economy still looks exhausted. Any election would have to wait at least until after the second supplementary budget in October, when a fiscal stimulus of more than Y10 trillion is expected (though actual new spending is likely to be Y3 trillion-5 trillion). And by the time that is through the Diet, the summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Co-operation forum, to be held in Japan in November, would be looming. Cabinet ministers will be too busy bathing in reflected glory to campaign.
But waiting until 1996 to assume the prime ministership would be risky. If a week is a long time in politics, six months is an eternity, and there is no guarantee that even if he waits that long Mr Hashimoto's personality would carry the LDP to outright power in a general election. One event in particular could at his calculations: the coalition might collapse of its own accord. The Social Democrats have looked ready to implode for months. They might choose to do so at their convention on September 21st, leaving the prime minister without a party. If so, Mr Hashimoto would have no choice but to step into the breach, possibly patching up a coalition with the opposition New Frontier Party (NFP), the political vehicle of his old rival, Ichiro Ozawa.
If this does not happen, Mr Hashimoto will probably imitate his rival's strategy. Mr Ozawa assembled the NFP by patiently encouraging defections from the LDP. Mr Hashimoto is likely to try to pay him back by offering the possibility of real power as a lure to get some of the defectors to turn their coats again. The realignment of Japanese politics is not over yet.

text:
TOKYO
AFTER years of torpor in the face of the bad debts building up in Japan's financial sector, the Ministry of Finance is suddenly hyperactive. Last week it rushed in to close two wobbly financial institutions before market forces toppled them. Now it is talking seriously about sorting out the mess at the country's housing-loan companies (the jusen), which provide 17% of all domestic mortgages not subsidised by the government. A report on the jusen problem is to be delayed a mere month; Masayoshi Takemura, the finance minister, has announced that an interim version should be ready by October (the previous target was late September) with the final version to appear in December.
To be fair to the ministry it has not, as it has with the wider banking crisis, attempted to disguise the scale of the problem. Collectively, the seven jusen have managed to build up bad loans of some Y6.1 trillion ($62.4 billion), of which an impressive Y3.6 trillion is reckoned by the finance ministry to be irrecoverable. It estimates that the total cost of making the mess vanish will come to Y4.6 trillion. The question is who will pay for this financial disappearing trick.
The jusen were set up by Japan's big banks in the early 1970s. For a decade or so they plied their humble trade of housing the growing populations of Japan's industrial cities. Then, like so many other Japanese financial institutions, they saw the price of land rising and got greedy--lending to speculative ventures such as golf courses and car parks. It is the collapse of the collateral to these loans, rather than any failure in their basic mortgage business, that is threatening to bring them down.
That they have not failed so far is because, unlike mortgage providers in many other countries, they do not take retail deposits, so they cannot be destroyed by a panicky run, as happened with Cosmo, a credit union, in July, and was threatening to happen with Kizu, another credit union, before the finance ministry stepped in on August 30th. Instead, their creditors are institutions, such as life-insurance companies.
In other countries, regulators might have been tempted to let these investors foot the bill. The problem is that Japan's 2,600 agricultural co-operatives were also big investors in the jusen. And one of the golden Japanese political rules is: "don't monkey with the farmers" (hence the rice price-fixing racket that the government dignifies with the name "The Basic Food Law"). So it looks as though taxpayers are going to be forced to wave their magic wand.
What will probably happen, according to Mineko Sasaki-Smith, an economist at the Japanese arm of Moan Stanley, an American investment bank, is a merger of the jusen into two viable companies, with the bad debts stripped out into a Japanese equivalent of the Resolution Trust that bailed out America's thrift industry. The reason for the delay in announcing the details seems to be a power struggle between the finance and agriculture ministries. If the Ministry of Finance provides the money to bail out the co-operatives, it can dictate the terms. These are likely to include finance ministry (rather than agriculture ministry) oversight of their financial activities.
The finance ministry's bureaucrats want to await the enthronement of Ryutaro Hashimoto, the all-but-elected leader of the Liberal Democrats (the principal governing parcy), before writing the report. Mr Hashimoto just happens to be a former finance minister. The agriculture bureaucrats want action (or at least words) now. For the moment it looks as though the finance ministry is winning. The Japanese people most certainly are not.

And one of the golden Japanese political rules is : " do n't monkey with the farmers " ( hence the rice price - fixing racket that the government dignifies with the name " The Basic Food Law " ) . So it looks as though taxpayers are going to be forced to wave their magic wand . 
 What will probably happen , according to Mineko Sasaki - Smith , an economist at the Japanese arm of Moan Stanley , an American investment bank , is a merger of the jusen into two viable companies , with the bad debts stripped out into a Japanese equivalent of the Resolution Trust that bailed out America 's thrift industry . The reason for the delay in announcing the details seems to be a power struggle between the finance and agriculture ministries . If the Ministry of Finance provides the money to bail out the co - operatives , it can dictate the terms . These are likely to include finance ministry ( rather than agriculture ministry ) oversight of their financial activities . 
 The finance ministry 's bureaucrats want to await the enthronement of Ryutaro Hashimoto , before writing the report . Ryutaro Hashimoto just happens to be a former finance minister . The agriculture bureaucrats want action ( or at least words ) now . For the moment it looks as though the finance ministry is winning . The Japanese people most certainly are not .

text:
TOKYO
RYUTARO HASHIMOTO did not have to fight to launch himself in politics. When his father died in 1963, he inherited a vote-gathering machine that propelled him smoothly into Japan's parliament at the tender age of 26. His marriage, three years later, was brokered by none other than Japan's then prime minister. Powerful friends and an early start are handy assets in Japan's political world, where patronage and patience are the keys to promotion.
Mr Hashimoto held his first cabinet post in 1978. And, at mid-week, it seemed all but certain that he would be elected president of his Liberal Democratic Party on September 22nd. Since the LDP dominates the coalition government, Mr Hashimoto has become more powerful than Tomiichi Murayama, Japan's socialist prime minister. On the wall of Mr Hashimoto's office hangs a photograph of Naples, where last year's G7 summit was held. "That", he points out, "is where Mr Murayama got an upset stomach."
When he was first elected to parliament, Mr Hashimoto attended some of his first meetings accompanied by his stepmother. These days the mummy's boy has grown up. He teases visitors in a playful way, deflecting questions. As minister of trade, Mr Hashimoto to enjoyed baiting the Americans during this year's row about cars. He appeared at one meeting in a green leather suit. He said that negotiating with Mickey Kantor, his American foe, was as scaly as facing the fury of his wife when he came home late and tipsy.
Provocation, in short, is the trade minister's trademark. He swaggers rather than walks, and frequently loses his temper. Ordinary Japanese, especially women, find him lovably tough, but Mr Hashimoto's style has won him few friends among his parliamentary colleagues, even though they have chosen him as their leader. The choice reflects changes in Japan, both in domestic politics and in foreign policy.
The LDP used to avoid having flamboyant leaders. Power resided with grey faction chiefs; who pulled strings attached to faceless prime ministers. The facelessness did not matter, because the LDP had no particular need to court voters with televisual charm: it could buy support, and its socialist opponents were too extreme to be electable. In 1993, however, the LDP split. The defectors were among the founders of the New Frontier Party, which did better than the LDP in July's election for the upper house of parliament.
The new electoral challenge has shifted power from the LDP's faction chiefs to its charismatic vote-pullers. This change is reinforced by last year's reform of the electoral system for parliament's lower house. In the past, four or five candidates were elected from each constituency, the last of whom often scraped into parliament with a mere 15% of the votes. To muster such modest support, it was enough to distribute cash diligently; and marshalling cash was what the faction chiefs were good at. Under the new electoral system, by contrast, only one candidate will be elected from each constituency. It is impossible to buy that many votes. Poise and charm are necessary.
So, perhaps, are flashy policies. The local elections in April showed that voters like candidates who espouse bold ideas. The new governor of Tokyo, for example, is an independent who promised to cancel the vastly expensive Tokyo Expo, despite the protests of firms that had already poured money into the project. Over the past month Masayoshi Takemura, the finance minister, has doubled the popularity of his small party by protesting loudly against French nuclear tests. Junichiro Koizumi, Mr Hashimoto's rival for the leadership, grabbed the limelight recently by proposing the privatisation of Japan's postal savings system.
In a country renowned for consensus, radical views have become political assets. Mr Hashimoto strikes a nationalist pose. He defies Mr Kantor. He plays down the need to apologise for Japan's belligerent past. He wants to scrap the pacifist clause of Japan's constitution. In a book published two years ago, Mr Hashimoto declared that Japan and the West are separated by a "gap in national spirit".
The Japanese are in the mood to support this kind of talk. Demoralised by half a decade of economic loom, they long for strong leadership. Humiliated by the 50th anniversary of their defeat in war, they savour victories of any kindsome real, like the refusal to concede American trade demands; others imaginary, such as the film released in the week of VJ day, which showed samurai in victorious combat against American cowboys.
Mr Hashimoto plays to this feeling, but he is not a dangerous radical. Unprompted, he praises America's military role in Asia. Although prompted several times, he refuses to sound anti-western. Yet, even though he maybe moderate inside, his nationalist cloak is too useful to discard. The prime minister who fell sick in Naples seems likely to be dumped soon, and next year will probably bring a general election. If the voters' nationalism proves strong, the LDP may win enough votes to form a government of its own, with Mr Hashimoto as prime minister. Even if it does not, populism will keep Japanese politics lively.

text:
TOKYO
COUNTRIES as well as people can experience mid-life crises. Around 1900, when Britain's youthful progress gave way to relative decline, its leaders were overcome by anxiety about the physique. of the working classes. Now Japan is gripped by a similar sense that the country is in moral and physical decline. Sparked by recession, an earthquake and a murderous sect, pessimism has singed nearly all aspects of life.
Consider, for example, a survey conducted during the summer by Hakuhodo, an advertising agency. This found that popular faith in thing as various as money, the afterlife and psychic powers were all on the wane. Only 23% of respondents thought Japan was stable, down from 40% three years ago. Half reckoned the country was in decline.
Faith in government has declined fastest of all. The old confidence that bureaucrats could steer the economy has ceded to a popular hatred of regulation. Retired mandarins complain of a decline of both morale and morality within the civil service. The Japanese were recently shocked by a corruption scandal involving a top official in the Ministry of Finance--the pinnacle of the bureaucracy. Corruption is expected from politicians, but was once unheard of among top bureaucrats.
In most areas of life, people agree that Japan's post-war formula no longer works, but change makes everyone nervous. In politics, voters booted out the long-ruling Liberal Democratic Party two years ago, but many now want the old guard back again. In business, everybody knows that lifetime employment is under strain, but nobody knows how to replace it. Even dress codes are in perplexing flux. Several firms have told office workers to abandon their conformist blue suits one day a week, and to dress as individualists. Shops have set up special stalls to advise bewildered managers on how to go about this.
The symptoms of stress are as various as the causes. Newspapers lugubriously report statistics on which of Tokyo's rail lines is most popular for suicides. Therapists, hitherto rare in Japan, are multiplying. Religious sects flourish by offering disoriented Japanese a sense of purpose. Books predicting armageddon sell well. Last month a long editorial in the Yomiuri Shimbun, Japan's biggest newspaper, bemoaned the country's post-war material advance, which is "threatening to ruin our very existence". Forests have been chopped down; the air has been polluted; even the physical and mental health of Japanese is deteriorating.
In Britain it was the medical examination of conscripts for the Boer war that provoked alarm about national physique. In Japan, peacetime health tests provide the Yomiuri's pessimists with ample evidence to o on. Each year 18-year-olds are made to touch their toes and, if possible, reach beyond them. In 1984 boys stretched on average 14.4 centimetres beyond their toes; a decade later they managed only 11.4. Over the same period the strength of boys' grip has declined by 4.8%, their capacity for sit-ups by 10.6%. Eleven-year-old girls can jump a shocking ten centimetres less far than did their forebears 12 years ago.
The Yomiuri blames cultural change. Deteriorating eye-sight proves that children are playing too many video games, and that their diets are mushy--less chewing means weaker facial muscles, the paper suggests, which may impair the eye's ability to focus. General feebleness can be blamed on a deteriorating, and westernising, diet. Japan's biggest restaurant chain is McDonald's.
Likewise, allergies are on the rise. The Yomiuri says this may reflect "excessive cleanliness". Japan's traditional fondness for washing has recently reached neurotic extremes: shops tout germ-free pens, bicycle handles and telephones, all impregnated with antiseptic chemicals. Meanwhile, the declining vigour of youth betrays how examinations are crowding out hearty games. The Yomiuri's editorial commends the Boy Scout movement (which was founded in Britain in 1908 to improve the robustness of the young. But the number of Boy Scouts in Japan has plummeted from 308,000 to 235,000 since 1980.
There is doubtless reason for concern, but Japan's gloom seems exaggerated. Some evidence suggests that all is not lost: the pulse rate of 18-year-olds after a bout of stair-climbing rises less than it did a decade ago.
In part, all this gloom may reflect a traditional penchant for melancholy noticeable in Japanese literature. But a political agenda may also underlie it. If people think the nation is enfeebled, they may be keener to support tough policies and politicians. The Yomiuri, the voice of conservative Japan, is campaigning to abolish the pacifist clause in Japan's constitution which, it says, undermines the dignity of the army. A more vigorous foreign policy may need more vigorous citizens. Hence the calls for sport in schools to foster the manly virtues associated with Japan's faded martial spirit.
If any leading politician embodies this sort of thinking, it is Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Liberal Democrats' new leader. Mr Hashimoto is a tough guy, who stands up to foreigners and wants to revise the pacifist clauses of the constitution. He is also a devotee of kendo, or Japanese swordsmanship. He may thrive on Japan's sense of malaise.

text:
TRADITION requires that Japan's political leaders be chosen in smoky latenight meetings, attended by kingmakers and fixers, far from the gaze of ordinary Japanese. Tradition is being flouted. In September the leadership of the Liberal Democratic Party, which dominates the coalition government, was contested by two candidates who engaged in a spirited, partly televised debate. Now it is the turn of the opposition New Frontier Party to choose a leader. A contest of ideas and personalities-signifying a pluralism usually lacking in Japan's democracy-is set to unfold.
 Although it yielded lively argument, the Liberal Democratic contest had an element of make-believe: one of the candidates had no chance of winning, and campaigned mainly to impress voters with the spectacle of pluralism at work. The current opposition vote is more serious. The favourite is Ichiro Ozawa, second-in-command of the New Frontier Party. But his opponent, Tsutomu Hata, is a real contender. He was prime minister briefly last year; and he is backed by Morihiro Hosokawa, another former prime minister and a popular figure.
In Japan, most political contests are emptied of meaning by deals between the rivals. The victorious faction promises not to hurt the loser's interests, with the result that most kinds of innovation are rendered taboo. For years the pacifism of the Social Democratic Party, for example, was enough to stifle talk of revising Japan's war-renouncing constitution--even though the Social Democrats never came close to holding a parliamentary majority. This time, however, the urge to mollify the rival is nowhere visible. Mr Hata declares that, if elected, he will kick Mr Ozawa out of his current job as the party's secretary-general.
The winner will be announced on December 28th, after a postal poll of party members. In the LDP leadership election, the votes of rank-and-file members count for little, but the NFP gives everyone an equal say. Moreover, non-members can buy the right to vote for only Yl,000 ($10), an ease of access inspired by America's primaries. This is why Mr Ozawa is the favourite. He is backed by the Soka Gakkai, a huge Buddhist organisation. New Frontier officials expect a turnout of 1m voters. Soka Gakkai claims a membership many times that size.
An Ozawa victory would present an intriguing paradox. Mr Ozawa is an old-style party hack, adept at backroom deals and barely legal fundraising. Yet he is also the closest approximation to a statesman that Japan has, and in this he may represent the future. By leading a band of reformists out of the Liberal Democratic Party in 1993, he replaced the LDP'S unchanging domination with a two-party system. By pushing through electoral reform last year, he buried the old rules that fostered money politics and discouraged policy discussion.
If he wins the leadership contest, Mr Ozawa will be painted as the head of Soka Gakkai's electoral machine, and so a symbol of traditional interest-group politics. Yet, along with his candidacy, Mr Ozawa has announced a policy platform full of radical ideas. He promises to cut income and corporate taxes while raising the consumption tax from 3% to 10%. He wants to cut the number of government agencies and to overhaul the education system. He favours the building of a new capital, an idea approved by a government committee on December l3th. He also suggests the creation of a police unit devoted to United Nations peacekeeping and talks of opening party management to the rank and file, by holding weekly seminars on hot topics.
Mr Ozawa is the first to admit that not all these views are popular. But, by announcing them, he has confirmed the main trend in Japanese politics. Faced with low turnout and an apathetic electorate in elections earlier this year, both the big parties have searched for attention-grabbing chiefs. In September the Liberal Democrats dumped their wishy-washy president in favour of Ryutaro Hashimoto, a more assertive leader, who had risen to prominence by standing up to American trade demands. Now the New Frontier Party seems set to make a similar choice. Its outgoing leader is a soft-focus, consensus-seeking type. Mr Ozawa is brash; he imposes his will. He is, in short, a leader.

text:
Francois Mitterrand, president of France for 14 years and founder of the socialist Party, died at the age of 79.
Chechen terrorists released most of the 2,000 hostages they captured when they took over a hospital in Kizlyar, in the neighbouring republic of Dagestan. They abandoned demands for the withdrawal of all Russian soldiers from Chechnya, and headed home with 160 people, only to be stopped at the border by Russian troops, where more hostages were seized. Boris Yeltsin was left deeply embarrassed by the raid.
Mr Yeltsin appointed Yevgeny Primakov as foreign minister after Andrei Kozyrev resigned. Mr Primakov was director of the foreign intelligence service, a successor to the KGB, and gained notoriety for his role in seeking a deal with Saddam Hussein on the eve of the Gulf war.
Bosnian Serbs fired a bazooka at a tram in Sarajevo, killing one person and injuring 19. Fighting erupted between Muslims and Croats in Mostar, joint capital (with Sarajevo) of the Muslim-Croat federation.
The United Nations Security Council condemned Croatia for human-rights offences against Serbs in Krajina.
Germany's finance minister, Theo Waiel, admitted that his country's budget deficit was more than 3% of GDP in 1995, above the Maastricht criterion. German unemployment rose to 3.8m in December, the highest figure for that month since 1945.
Turkey's president asked the leader of the pro-Islamic Welfare Party, Necmettin Erbakan, to form the next government. Welfare emerged as the strongest party after the general election in December, but, with only 21% of the vote and no large parties willing to work with it, is unlikely to be able to form a government.
Lech Walesa, recently voted out as Poland's president, is to ask for another of his old jobs back--as electrician in the Gdansk shipyards.
A tougher guy
Ryutaro Hashimoto, the new leader of the LDP, became prime minister of Japan, succeeding Tomiichi Murayama, who resigned along with his cabinet. As trade minister, Mr Hashimoto gained a reputation as a tough negotiator in talks with America. Wataru Kubo, a socialist, is the new finance minister.
Thousands of Indonesians were made homeless when Jakarta, the capital, was hit by the worst floods for 20 years.
India is to hold a general election in April. Bangladesh postponed its election until February 15th.
In South Korea's spreading government scandal, the president, Kim Young Sam, admitted "wrong practices" in accepting money for political purposes, but denied taking bribes.
Blame the blizzard
Just as the United States government was going back to work, with a continuing resolution passed by Congress to ensure that federal workers would be paid, the largest snowstorm for many decades hit the east coast. Workers stayed at home, again.
The storm also caused the cancellation of budget talks between President Clinton and Republican leaders. But resumption of the talks brought no progress either.
The White House unexpectedly unearthed copies of long-missing Whitewater documents detailing work done by Hillary Rodham Clinton, when a lawyer at the Rose Law Firm in Little Rock, for a failed savings and loan association.
A federal appeals court ruled that a sexual-harassment suit against the president, filed by Paula Jones, a former Arkansas state employee, could go to trial.
In Guatemala, the pro-business candidate, Avaro Arzu, won the presidency, defeating a populist rival close to former dictator General Efrain Rios Montt. But turnout was only 37% and the margin tiny.
Ecuador and Peru, briefly at war a year ago, continued their new round of sabre-rattling and mutual accusations of an arms build-up. But their foreign ministers will meet on January 17th.
