text:
Japan needs a reforming prime minister. Unless he springs a surprise, Ryutaro Hashimoto does not look like fitting the bill. Ichiro Ozawa, his rival, just might
EVEN well-informed foreigners often find it hard to name the prime minister of Japan: incumbents tend to have a short shelf life and a weak brand image. Ryutaro Hashimoto is likely to change that. He is tough and outspoken, and has a flair for publicity (he makes much of his taste for martial arts). Japanese voters, particularly women, apparently like his swaggering ways. As prime minister and as leader of the Liberal Democractic Party (LDP), Mr Hashimoto will provide Japan with a new sense of leadership.
Unfortunately, Mr Hashimoto's novelty has more to do with style than substance. Some foreigners, noting his combative stance in trade talks with America last year and his links with Japan's ex-servicemen, worry that Mr Hashimoto will introduce a new note of nationalism into Japanese politics. In fact, in foreign policy as in everything else, Mr Hashimoto's policies are likely to lie firmly within the Japanese post-war consensus. Far from being dangerously radical, he is dangerously conservative.
Why dangerously? Because the Japanese economy and political system are in real need of reform. Four years of negligible economic growth and financial parlousness have revealed the flaws in the Japanese miracle. The iron triangle of bureaucrats, LDP politicians and lobby groups has left Japan with an overregulated, high-cost economy. Even when the Japanese system was producing supercharged economic growth, it failed to deliver many of the benefits to ordinary Japanese consumers. Now it is barely delivering growth itself.
The new Japanese prime minister faces a choice. He can continue to place his faith in the old system and take heart from the signs that the economy is picking up. Or he can take on the lobbyists and bureaucrats, deregulate the economy and decentralise the government. Mr Hashimoto says he favours deregulation. But so do all Japanese politicians these days. Compare Mr Hashimoto's writings with those of his chief political rival, Ichiro Ozawa (see page 35), and it is clear that he has a much more limited view of reform. He is the standard-bearer of those who still keep faith in the status quo.
 Defenders of the current way of doing things point out that for 30 years the Japanese system produced an economic miracle that dazzled the world. It would be absurd, they say, to indulge in radical reforms just because of one long recession.
The enduring strengths of the Japanese economy are indeed formidable: Japan is still home to many of the most competitive companies in the world (see page 59). But those who believe that clinches the argument against deregulation miss a crucial point. Japan's world-beating companies, the Toyotas and Sonys, operate in the least regulated parts of the Japanese economy. They face fierce competition and hordes of competitors, at home as well as abroad. By contrast, the least efficient industries, such as farming and telecoms, are also the most protected. Because they are cosseted, they have not kept up with world standards: witness the way Japan has fallen behind in developing multimedia products, which marry electronics and telecoms. If Japan fails to deregulate, these inefficient industries will continue to hold the economy back.
Even many of Japan's bureaucrats, who have a natural interest in retaining the regulations that are the source of their power, have begun to acknowledge the problems with the current system. Japan's Economic Planning Agency recently published two projections for economic growth over the next five years. With deregulation, it reckons that the economy will grow by 3% a year. Without deregulation, it will be just 1.75%.
 Mr Hashimoto understands the case for setting the economy free. But vigorous deregulation would mean taking on his allies: the bureaucrats at the Ministries of Finance and International Trade and Industry (both former Hashimoto fiefs) and the industrial lobbies. Industries like farming, building and transport have traditionally financed the LDP and their contributions will be needed at the next election.
A choice, at last
Such considerations are likely to mute Mr Hashimoto's enthusiasm for reform. But his elevation to the prime ministership is still welcome for another reason. Now that Mr Ozawa has become leader of the opposition, it means that Japan's two foremost political figures have stepped out of the shadows and will square up openly at the next election. Japanese voters will then face a novel and welcome situation: a real choice between two strong and articulate leaders, manipulated by no one. And that, more than anything, will open the path to change.

text:
UNLIKE most of his predecessors as prime minister of Japan, Ryutaro Hashimoto actually looks like a leader. Forceful, charismatic and with hair so heavily oiled that a typhoon could not ruffle it, he beamed telegenically when voted into the top job by Japan's ruling coalition on January 11th.
Admired for his detailed grasp of policy and his spirited defiance of the Americans in trade talks last year, Mr Hashimoto offers a pleasing contrast to Tomchi Murayama, the outgoing prime minister, who resigned on January 5th for reasons of incompetence. "I did my best... but in some ways, I've been working above the limits of my own ability," the 71-year-old socialist shrewdly observed as he stepped down.
Mr Hashimoto's rise heralds two changes, both welcome. The first is the death of Japan's socialists, who these days call themselves (in English, though not in Japanese) Social Democrats. The second, and more significant, is the gradual replacement of pork-barrel politics with genuine debate.
First, the epitaph. For almost half a century, Japan's Socialist Party was the world's most pointless opposition grouping, never winning a majority in parliament and exerting negligible influence over policy. Appealing as it did to Marxists, trade unionists, sympathisers with North Korea and other interest groups spurned by the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), the Socialist Party used to attract a small but dedicated following. But when Mr Murayama ditched virtually all its policies as the price of joining a ruling coalition with the LDP in 1994, he alienated the party's traditional supporters without gaining new ones.
The party will probably continue cynically to back the LDP-led coalition government until the next election, which must be held by July 1997. One of their number, Wataru Kubo, has been appointed finance minister in Mr Hashimoto's new administration. Socialist politicians need, after all, to save up for their dotage, and Japanese MPS are quite well paid. When the polls come, most of the socialists will be forcibly retired.
That much is clear. But who will win the next election is less so. The choice is between Mr Hashimoto's LDP and the New Frontier Party, led by Ichiro Ozawa, a former LDP strategist who defected in 1993.
Mr Ozawa's departure from the LDP brought to an end 38 years of unbroken conservative rule. It also enabled him, as the brains behind a patchwork coalition government, to pass an electoral-reform bill that replaced Japan's corrupt old multimember electoral constituencies with a mixture of single-member, first-past-thepost seats and others filled by proportional representation. Mr Ozawa's coalition fell apart in 1994 when the Socialist Party, then one of his allies, changed sides to team up with the LDP. But his electoral reforms remain in place, forcing would-be MPS to talk policy rather than pork.
 For the first time, the public has a choice between two heavyweight party leaders with clearly different manifestos. Superficially, Messrs Ozawa and Hashimoto have heaps in common. Both are the relatively young (Mr Ozawa is 53, Mr Hashimoto 58) sons of politicians, and both rose to prominence under the tutelage of a former prime minister, Kakuei Tanaka. Both have a reputation for arrogance.
Here the parallels cease. Mr Hashimoto's father was one of the know-all bureaucratic elite before becoming a politician. His son is cosy with the main ministries and sympathetic to their pleas that deregulation should be slow and gentle.
Mr Ozawa's dad was an outsider, a former rickshaw-puller who rose to ministerial office through force of intellect and a talent for raising money. Ozawa junior proved even more adept at attracting funds-he reputedly once collected Y25 billion ($238m now) in a single day. A past spent in smokefilled rooms will not appeal to the electorate, but Mr Ozawa's strength is that, unlike Mr Hashimoto, he has thought long and deep about how Japan needs to change.
 Mr Hashimoto's 1993 book, "Vision of Japan", was a limp agglomeration of self-justifying anecdotes and turgidly excessive detail, pushing no platform more radical than that of tinkering with the status quo. Mr Ozawa's "Blueprint for a New Japan", on the other hand, calls for nothing less than the demolition of the country's long tradition of bureaucratic control of more or less everything.
Mr Ozawa describes how, on a visit to the Grand Canyon, he noticed with amazement that there were no warning signs at the edge. In Japan, there would have been hundreds of signs, a stout fence and dozens of park keepers counselling caution. The Japanese have not yet learned to take responsibility for themselves, laments Mr Ozawa, and expect the government to coddle them.
"Real democracy", Mr Ozawa writes, "begins with...the autonomy of the individual." For Japan to become a "normal nation" (his phrase), it needs an accountable government and a laisser faire economy. He promises to break the rule of the mandarins, with their unignorable "advice" to business and their selfserving interpretation of ambiguously drafted regulations. Mr Hashimoto, by contrast, pays lip service to the need for deregulation, but finds horrifying the idea of, say, market forces applied to health care or an end to farm subsidies. Mr Ozawa promises radical tax reform. He would like, he says, a startling 50% reduction in income tax, offset by a rise in consumption tax from 3% to 10% over ten years. He talks of "aggressively opening Japan's own markets" and strengthening the post of prime minister to slash the power of unelected bureaucrats.
The run-up to the next election will see charge and counter-charge. The LDP will try to discredit Mr Ozawa by playing up his party's links to the rich, powerful and widely detested Soka Gakkai religious sect, whose 8m members provide the largest chunk of the New Frontier Party's support. Many voters do not like the idea of a government influenced by the Buddhist group's dictatorial leader, Daisaku Ikeda. The LDP hopes to keep Mr Ikeda in the spotlight by summoning him to give evidence in parliament about his finances.
Mr Ozawa's counter-attack will be aimed at the government's plan to use over Y600 billion in taxpayers' money to liquidate seven jusen (housing loan corporations) that were buried in bad debt when property prices collapsed in the early 1990s. The scheme is as popular as cockroach sushi, partly because it will use public funds to rescue speculators who should have known what risks they were facing, and partly because it looks as though the LDP is yet again placing rural interests above urban ones. Many of the creditors to be compensated are farm co-operatives; electorally over-represented farmers are staunch LDP supporters. Mr Hashimoto was finance minister at the time the jusen made their most disastrous loans. Mr Ozawa can be counted upon to make sure that voters remember this.

text:
Plans to help troubled Japanese banks with public money have caused a public outcry. With just cause
ASKED whether he had ever conducted the music of Karlheinz Stockhausen, the late, great Sir Thomas Beecham replied that he had not, but that he had trodden in some once. If anything, the Japanese have even less regard for their bankers, and the regulators that were supposed to oversee them, than Sir Thomas had for the avantgarde German composer.
Japanese taxpayers have become ever more furious at having to pay for the bad loans their banks made before the bursting of the country's bubble economy in 1990. Their anger has grown since December, when the finance ministry unveiled the first stage of a plan to help banks tackle these. This called for some Y685 billion ($6.5 billion) of public money to bail out seven allbut-bankrupt jusen, or mortgage lenders, to which both the banks and agricultural cooperatives had lent heavily.
Under the second stage of the bail-out, finalised this week, a new body will buy Y6.8 trillion of jusen assets that may eventually be worth something. This purchase will be paid for by raising new loans from the banks and co-ops. Only if the value of the old assets turns out to equal the cost of the new loans will there be no extra burden on the taxpayer.
This is hardly likely. Even the finance ministry admits that Y1.2 trillion of the old assets are probably irrecoverable, and the government is guaranteeing half of the new loans. So taxpayers will almost certainly have to stump up more. If none of the assets are recovered, the public will, at a conservative estimate, have had to pay Y5.5 trillion to rescue the jusen-though much of this loss would only appear in 15 years' time, when the new body is wound up. Opinion polls show that 72% of Japanese are against bailing out the jusen. Ichiro Ozawa, the new leader of the main opposition party, Shinshinto, this week urged the government of Ryutaro Hashimoto to drop the rescue package from the budget until responsibility for the losses was clarified.
One reason for the strength of public opposition is that, whereas the agricultural cooperatives, which just happen to be chummy with the Liberal Democratic Party, the largest in the coalition government, will get most of their dud loans back, the banks will have to write off all of the Y5.2 trillion they lent. Moreover, much of the jusen's lending, it transpires, was to property firms controlled by the yakuza, Japan's mafia.
Mr Hashimoto has sworn to root out and punish those responsible for the banking mess-a rash promise, since he was finance minister when the jusen lent particularly recklessly. He also promised to publish more details of the debacle. But a lengthy statistical tome on jusen lending released by the finance ministry on January 19th prompted more questions than it answered about what went wrong.
Why, for example, did the country's regulators not worry that most of the jusen loans had nothing to do with mortgages? By 1987, outstanding loans to (mostly property) companies were greater than those to individuals. Indeed, by 1994 only 8% of the loans of one jusen, Sogo Jukin, were to individuals. And, despite a ban on further property-related lending by banks in 1990, lending by mortgage companies surged: that year, their lending increased by 22%, before falling the following year, albeit slowly.
Other details, such as the names of the corporate borrowers and the fact that 38 former finance ministry officials now occupy senior positions at the mortgage lenders, have leaked out via the press. When the ministry clamped restrictions on property lending by banks, most of the jusen had either a chairman or a president who was a former finance ministry official.
The real bill
Yet the row over the rescue has obscured two big points. The first is that Japan's banking system as a whole has seen profits rise sharply. Because Japanese banks' accounts are pretty opaque, analysts generally look at the part of their books that can be least easily manipulated: operating profits. These have been soaring lately (see chart on next page). The Bank of Japan has pushed interest rates to historically low levels, which has allowed banks to borrow for almost nothing and then charge much higher rates when lending. Falling interest rates have also swelled profits on their bond portfolios and on interest-rate swaps.
The second point is that Japanese banks have been enjoying massive tax breaks. Over the past three years they have offset much of the 50% corporate tax that they would otherwise have paid on their profits with apparent, but not actual, realised losses from their non-performing loans.
The distinction is an important one. At the beginning of 1993 the banks created a body called the Co-operative Credit Purchasing Company (ccPc). This is an officially approved accounting wheeze: in order to claim tax relief on provisions against bad loans, Japanese banks have, in theory, to crystallise those losses by, for example, making borrowers bankrupt or by selling their loans. But, in many cases, they could not or did not want to do so.
By "selling" loans to the CCPC (ie, to themselves), the banks can realise losses and get the associated tax relief. By last September they had sold loans with a total face value of just under Y10 trillion to the CCPC, which paid Y4.3 trillion for them. Since all of the loss is tax-deductible, they received a Y2.9 trillion tax benefit. The CCPC'S boss expects to buy more loans with a face value of up to Y2 trillion by the end of the financial year, entitling banks to more relief.

Plans to help troubled Japanese banks with public money have caused a public outcry . With just cause 
 ASKED whether he had ever conducted the music of Karlheinz Stockhausen , the late , great Sir Thomas Beecham replied that he had not , but that he had trodden in some once . If anything , the Japanese have even less regard for their bankers , and the regulators that were supposed to oversee them , than Sir Thomas had for the avantgarde German composer . 
 Japanese taxpayers have become ever more furious at having to pay for the bad loans their banks made before the bursting of the country 's bubble economy in 1990 . Their anger has grown since December , when the finance ministry unveiled the first stage of a plan to help banks tackle these . This called for some Y685 billion ( $ 6.5 billion ) of public money to bail out seven allbut - bankrupt jusen , or mortgage lenders , to which both the banks and agricultural cooperatives had lent heavily . 
 Under the second stage of the bail - out , finalised this week , a new body will buy Y6.8 trillion of jusen assets that may eventually be worth something . This purchase will be paid for by raising new loans from the banks and co - ops . Only if the value of the old assets turns out to equal the cost of the new loans will there be no extra burden on the taxpayer . 
 This is hardly likely . Even the finance ministry admits that Y1.2 trillion of the old assets are probably irrecoverable , and Ryutaro Hashimoto is guaranteeing half of the new loans . So taxpayers will almost certainly have to stump up more . If none of the assets are recovered , the public will , at a conservative estimate , have had to pay Y5.5 trillion to rescue the jusen - though much of this loss would only appear in 15 years ' time , when the new body is wound up . Opinion polls show that 72 % of Japanese are against bailing out the jusen . text:
EVEN as Japan's prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, was packing for this weekend's California get-together with Bill Clinton, the turbulence that has beset Japan's relations with America seemed to be subsiding. Come April, when Mr Clinton travels to Tokyo for a more formal summit meeting, it should be confident smiles all round. Assuming Mr Clinton makes it this time-he had to cancel a Tokyo summit last November because of the budget deadlock in Washington-the two will jointly reaffirm the importance of the United StatesJapan alliance. The world's most powerful country and its richest ally will soon be back in easy step.
Or will they? Even as America and Japan have scrambled in recent months to recover their diplomatic poise, East Asia has been changing in ways that could spell yet more trouble ahead.
Mr Clinton and Mr Hashimoto will prefer to look on the bright side. Although there are still some legal wrinkles to the renewal of leases for America's military bases on the Japanese island of Okinawa, the wave of resentment that followed the rape of a schoolgirl last September by American servicemen is beginning to lessen. America has been working on a package of peace offerings-handing back some land on Okinawa, moving some military personnel to bases elsewhere in Japan-in the run up to the Clinton visit to Tokyo. Meanwhile, Japan's trade surplus, a persistent irritant to America, has been falling sharply: according to the Japanese finance ministry this week, Japan's trade surplus with America fell to $1.55 billion in January, down from $3.9 billion in January 1995.
But reducing the frictions in bilateral relations is the easier part. Much harder, for both governments, is to work out how their reaffirmed alliance might work.
Though the changes in East Asia since the cold war ended have taken longer to show, the region has no shortage of spatsover rocks, reefs and the fish and energy resources in the surrounding seas. Moreover, after decades sheltering securely behind America's military shield, Japan must now contend with a much less settled neighbourhood: a pugnacious China, a troublingly erratic Russia and, eventually, a united Korea. It will take more than just America's military muscle to keep the neighbourhood secure.
Asked about the role Japan's alliance with America should play in all this, officials at Japan's foreign ministry explain that it remains vital to Japan's own defence, is a great stabiliser among the complex rivalries in the region and provides the reassurance that is needed, at home and abroad, if Japan is to play a more active role in regional and global affairs. A similar case is put in the new National Defence Programme Outline, published late last year (and replacing one of 1976 vintage), that provides the rationale for an imminent streamlining of Japan's Self Defence Forces. Yet to security watchers outside the ministries all this merely restates the obvious: the alliance is important to Japan. But what, they ask, will Japan's contribution to the alliance now be?
Unlike NATO, which is built on mutual defence commitments between the United States and Canada and their European allies, the America Japan security treaty is a one-sided affair: it commits America to defend Japan, not vice versa. Over the years, Japan has attempted to take up some of the security burden, by paying for much of the upkeep of American forces in Japan, by using its aid and diplomatic clout to bolster stability in East Asia and beyond, and by contributing to United Nations peacekeeping operations, in Cambodia, Bosnia and, most recently, the Golan heights between Israel and Syria.
Beyond that, officials insist that the country's pacifist-sounding constitution rules out other sorts of collective security operations, including joint military activities with America, except where Japan's own security is directly threatened. Yet close watchers in Japan of the United States Congress fret that Japan is still doing too little to counter growing accusations of free-loading on America's defence budget. Theyworry that, in future,Japan's contribution is likely to be measured by American public opinion, not in the sort of "soft" security that Japan has specialised in thus far, but against the need for "hard" securitymeaning a readiness to use force, if necessary to cope with new threats in East Asia.
The potential for these is already in evidence. Japan may be determined to cross only words, not swords, with South Korea and China in the disputes over islands and fishing rights in the seas between them, but China's grab early last year for Philippineclaimed Mischief reef among the Spratly islands in the South China Sea showed that others will be more belligerent. China's war of words with Taiwan, which it claims as a renegade province, and its provocative military manoeuvres in the run-up to Taiwan's first democratic presidential election next month are forcing Japan to think about the hitherto almost unthinkable: what might Japan be asked by America to do, if America and China were to come to blows in the Taiwan straits?
Japan's diplomats hope fervently that China will not use force against Taiwan, and Mr Hashimoto will want to be sure that Mr Clinton takes no provocative action and keeps Japan fully informed. But it is these sorts of regional flare-ups, drawing in American military forces, that will really test Japan's commitment to the alliance with America, suggests Masashi Nishihara, of the National Institute for Defence Studies in Tokyo. Should it come to a conflict, with America's boys dying in the Taiwan straits, the professor argues, there would be strong pressure for Japan to reinterpret its narrow notion of self defence, since the alliance with America, and America's ability to play a security role in East Asia, is in the end more important to Japan than relations with China.
Yet officials claim that Japan's constitution leaves little room for manoeuvre, as they discovered three years ago when America asked Japan for logistical and other support in its confrontation with North Korea. Since then, an influential newspaper, the Yomiuri Shimun, has called for the constitution to be amended.
Such a laborious process would not be necessary, insists Hisahiko Okazaki, a former diplomat who now heads a private think-tank in Tokyo. Since the existence of Japan's Self Defence Forces is based, not on the constitution, but on any country's inherent right to self defence, all Japan needs is a prime minister determined enough to make the case that the country's security in the post-cold-war world rests not just on the narrow defence of its own territory, but also on its ability to operate collectively with America in Japan's wider security interests.
And it is not too soon to be making preparations. Leave aside any new blow-up on the Korean peninsula or a miscalculation over Taiwan, Mr Okazaki points to the imminent loss to America next year of a friendly port in Hong Kong. Along with its earlier withdrawal from Subic Bay in the Philippines, that leaves the American fleet that would respond to any new threats to vital shipping lanes in the South China Sea dependent, one way or another, on Japanese logistical support.
Without a clear effort to redefine Japan's role and allow for a greater Japanese contribution to collective security, the worry is that, come the next real military emergency, the alliance which all agree is the linchpin of security in East Asia will be tested to destruction.

text:
Japan's politicians are afraid to break up NIT, the world's biggest telecoms company. Luckily, there is another way to expose it to competition
YOU might be forgiven for asking what the fuss has been about. A year ago Japan's Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications (MPT) set up a committee to advise whether Nippon Telegraph and Telephone (NTT) should be broken up in the interests of competition. On two previous occasions-in 1985, when it was privatised, and in 1990 when a similar committee recommended a break-up-NTT had fought off threats to split it up. Many Japanese expected this round to be the clincher. Debate has raged in the newspapers; most of the expert reports to have been published argue in favour of dismemberment. On February 29th the committee will duly advise the government that NTT should be split into three: two local telephone companies and one longdistance one, which would be able to enter the international market, from which NTT has hitherto been excluded.
However, there is every sign that the government will shelve this proposal, just like the previous ones. It will no doubt put forward all the usual excuses: that Japan needs a flagship telecoms firm; that NTT's research and development play a crucial role in keeping Japan in the vanguard of the communications revolution; that the cost of breaking up the company would outweigh any benefits.
The government's true motive, however, will be that, with elections looming, neither the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP the biggest in the ruling coalition, nor the Social Democratic Party, the second biggest, wants to risk annoying NTT's 225,000 workers. Just what Ryutaro Hashimoto, Japan's prime minister and the LDP leader, thinks of the break-up can be judged by the fact that he appointed Ichiro Hino as minister of posts and telecommunications. As a previous head of the Centre for Socialist Thought, Mr Hino is not a man in whom deregulatory fervour runs deep.
For the time being, therefore, NTT will probably remain intact. How much does this matter? If you take some statistics at face value, you might conclude that Japan has little need of sharper competition in telecoms. It already possesses more than loo carriers, and foreign companies have been investing heavily. In a fit of generosity, and having indeed taken such numbers at face value, the authors of an OECD report in 1993 pronounced Japan's telecoms industry the world's most liberalised, with America and Britain a whisker behind.
The figures, however, are misleading. Since 1985 the MPT has given NTT a fairly easy time. The company has been allowed to remain in both local and long-distance businesses at a time when competitors have been restricted to one or the other. Only three rivals (DDI, Japan Telecom and Teleway), and not one of the new local companies, have so far been allowed to enter the long-distance market. The predictable result is that telephony in Japan is needlessly expensive (see table on next page). Although the cost of each local call has stayed at a manageable Y10(ten cents), the monthly rental for each line is Y1,750, and consumers have to fork out an astonishing 75,000 for each line to be connected in the first place.
Might this change even if NTT stays intact? It is possible. For some time the MPr has been denying that it ever restricted the ability of competitors to enter the long-distance market. Though this denial is nonsense (it is rejected by the Keidanren, an influential pressure group, the Fair Trade Commission and even NTT itself), it suggests that, henceforth, the ministry really will let competitors into any market they choose. At the end of January it unveiled a variety of deregulatory measures that included "a clarification of the absence of regulations on telecommunications carriers by service classification". In other words, it stuck to its claim that there never had been any barriers, while telling everybody that they had been removed.
In principle, opening the market to all comers in this way could have a bigger impact than would the dismembering of NTT. Those who advocate a break-up say that dismemberment would stop NTT using its long-distance calls to subsidise its local ones. But the evidence from the two countries which most people, who are not employed by the OECD, consider to be the most liberal in this domain is that the idea of splitting carriers into long-distance and local firms is becoming an anachronism.
The experience of Britain and America is that splitting up a giant matters less than introducing competition. In Britain, BT has not been split up; instead it has been held back in some markets and rivals allowed in. In America, when "Ma Bell" was dissolved in 1984, one result was to leave behind a string of local monopolies. Now that America is deregulating again, it has decided to let all companies (even AT&T) compete in all markets- not just local and long-distance telephony but also various forms of television and cellular services.
The trouble in Japan is that even companies that have been given the green light to compete with NTT have been put at a systematic disadvantage. NTT is the only company with the lines to Japan's 60m telephones, so any would-be local or long-distance company must, in the end, use its infrastructure. NTT has made this both difficult and expensive, forcing prospective local competitors to use its regional networks rather than its cheaper local ones. Since the cost of a local TT call is a mere Yl0, and until very recently it charged competitors 2.5 per call to connect to these regional networks, it is not surprising that NTT still has 99% of the local telephone market.
NTT's three long-distance competitors have about a third of that market, but their position is also fragile. This is because their long-distance calls must be connected at both ends by NTT lines, and paying for this eats up about half of their revenue. For its part, NTT subsidises its own long-distance operations with its local ones. Although the two aspects of its work are formally divided, many employees of NTT's nine "local" divisions are engaged in long-distance work, such as billing or capturing business from long-distance competitors.
What are the chances of forcing rr to compete on more equal terms? Steven Hughes, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, an investment bank, argues that the mere threat of a break-up has been a good way to scare the company into making life easier for its rivals. From March it will cut its longdistance rates: a three-minute call from Tokyo to Osaka will drop from Y170 to Y130; it will fall to Y100 by 2000. NTT said last September that it would open up the local network to anyone who wanted access. A month later it cut access rates for long-distance carriers from Y12.57 to Y10.46. The following month it allowed local competitors to connect to local rather than regional networks and cut the local rate to Y8.10. Although this is still probably too high to allow new entrants into the market and offer a service cheaper than its own, few believe NTT's claim that it cannot afford further reductions in the connection rate. Toru Aizeki, of the FTC, says that NTT tends to include its own marketing costs in the fee it levies from competitors using its facilities. This means, in effect, that its competitors pay for its own efforts to undermine them. But by the end of the year, says Yasuhiko Taniwaki, deputy director of the MPT, rules will be in place to make sure that NTT calculates these charges in an open and fair way. For the moment, the MPT seems serious in its intention to open the NTT network to others at realistic prices.January's clarification to allow competitors into every market creates the possibility of local, long-distance and international carriers linking up together to create a formidable rival to NTT. On February 19th it emerged that the ministry was considering allowing KDD, the formerly state-owned international carrier, to compete in the domestic markets.
Whatever the regulator may do, technology is bringing rapid change. The falling cost of cellular telephones should eventually allow rivals to bypass NTT's network altogether. Since last April, the number of users has doubled, to 8.7m. Meanwhile, the "Personal Handyphone", a less flexible but potentially much cheaper bit of equipment, has so far attracted only 700,000 subscribers thanks to a poor pricing policy. Now that NTT and DDI have started discounting Handyphones, demand could grow quickly. At this rate, Japan's politicians may never need to destroy their telecoms behemoth. Technology and competition may do the job for them.

In a fit of generosity , and having indeed taken such numbers at face value , the authors of an OECD report in 1993 pronounced Japan 's telecoms industry the world 's most liberalised , with America and Britain a whisker behind . 
 The figures , however , are misleading . Since 1985 the MPT has given NTT a fairly easy time . The company has been allowed to remain in both local and long - distance businesses at a time when competitors have been restricted to one or the other . Only three rivals ( DDI , Japan Telecom and Teleway ) , and not one of the new local companies , have so far been allowed to enter the long - distance market . The predictable result is that telephony in Japan is needlessly expensive ( see table on next page ) . Although the cost of each local call has stayed at a manageable Y10(ten cents ) , the monthly rental for each line is Y1,750 , and consumers have to fork out an astonishing 75,000 for each line to be connected in the first place . 
 Might this change even if NTT stays intact ? It is possible . For some time the MPr has been denying that it ever restricted the ability of competitors to enter the long - distance market . Though this denial is nonsense ( it is rejected by the Keidanren , an influential pressure group , the Fair Trade Commission and even NTT itself ) , it suggests that , henceforth , the ministry really will let competitors into any market they choose . At the end of January it unveiled a variety of deregulatory measures that included " a clarification of the absence of regulations on telecommunications carriers by service classification " . In other words , it stuck to its claim that there never had been any barriers , while telling everybody that they had been removed . 
 In principle , opening the market to all comers in this way could have a bigger impact than would the dismembering of NTT . Those who advocate a break - up say that dismemberment would stop NTT using its long - distance calls to subsidise its local ones . But the evidence from the two countries which most people , who are not employed by the OECD , consider to be the most liberal in this domain is that the idea of splitting carriers into long - distance and local firms is becoming an anachronism . 
 The experience of Britain and America is that splitting up a giant matters less than introducing competition . In Britain , BT has not been split up ; instead it has been held back in some markets and rivals allowed in . In America , when " Ma Bell " was dissolved in 1984 , one result was to leave behind a string of local monopolies . Now that America is deregulating again , it has decided to let all companies ( even AT&T ) compete in all markets- not just local and long - distance telephony but also various forms of television and cellular services . 
 The trouble in Japan is that even companies that have been given the green light to compete with NTT have been put at a systematic disadvantage . NTT is the only company with the lines to Japan 's 60 m telephones , so any would - be local or long - distance company must , in the end , use its infrastructure . NTT has made this both difficult and expensive , forcing prospective local competitors to use its regional networks rather than its cheaper local ones . Since the cost of a local TT call is a mere Yl0 , and until very recently it charged competitors 2.5 per call to connect to these regional networks , it is not surprising that NTT still has 99 % of the local telephone market . 
 NTT 's three long - distance competitors have about a third of that market , but their position is also fragile . This is because their long - distance calls must be connected at both ends by NTT lines , and paying for this eats up about half of their revenue . For its part , NTT subsidises its own long - distance operations with its local ones . Although the two aspects of its work are formally divided , many employees of NTT 's nine " local " divisions are engaged in long - distance work , such as billing or capturing business from long - distance competitors . 
 What are the chances of forcing rr to compete on more equal terms ? Steven Hughes , an analyst at Morgan Stanley , an investment bank , argues that the mere threat of a break - up has been a good way to scare the company into making life easier for its rivals . From March it will cut its longdistance rates : a three - minute call from Tokyo to Osaka will drop from Y170 to Y130 ; it will fall to Y100 by 2000 . NTT said last September that it would open up the local network to anyone who wanted access . A month later it cut access rates for long - distance carriers from Y12.57 to Y10.46 . The following month it allowed local competitors to connect to local rather than regional networks and cut the local rate to Y8.10 . Although this is still probably too high to allow new entrants into the market and offer a service cheaper than its own , few believe NTT 's claim that it can not afford further reductions in the connection rate . Toru Aizeki , of the FTC , says that NTT tends to include its own marketing costs in the fee it levies from competitors using its facilities . This means , in effect , that its competitors pay for its own efforts to undermine them . But by the end of the year , says Yasuhiko Taniwaki , deputy director of the MPT , rules will be in place to make sure that NTT calculates these charges in an open and fair way . For the moment , the MPT seems serious in its intention to open the NTT network to others at realistic prices . January 's clarification to allow competitors into every market creates the possibility of local , long - distance and international carriers linking up together to create a formidable rival to NTT . On February 19th it emerged that the ministry was considering allowing KDD , the formerly state - owned international carrier , to compete in the domestic markets . 
 Whatever the regulator may do , technology is bringing rapid change . The falling cost of cellular telephones should eventually allow rivals to bypass NTT 's network altogether . Since last April , the number of users has doubled , to 8.7 m. Meanwhile , the " Personal Handyphone " , a less flexible but potentially much cheaper bit of equipment , has so far attracted only 700,000 subscribers thanks to a poor pricing policy . Now that NTT and DDI have started discounting Handyphones , demand could grow quickly . At this rate , Japan 's politicians may never need to destroy their telecoms behemoth . Technology and competition may do the job for them .

text:
SANTA MONICA, CALIFORNIA
IT WAS just an hour-long chat, a chance to get acquainted. Nonetheless, Bill Clinton's meeting with Ryutaro Hashimoto, Japan's pugnacious new prime minister, in Santa Monica on February 23rd is being hailed as a stride in the right direction. Mr Clinton referred to the Japanese leader as "Roo"; Mr Hashimoto called the American president "Biru". This kind-of-first-name relationship, it is assumed, will be useful in the tricky negotiations that face the two countries. It is nice to be able to pick up the telephone and have an impromptu conversation (via the interpreters).
Mr Clinton is due to make a state visit to Japan on April 16th. The trip was originally scheduled for last November, but was postponed when the showdown with Congress over the budget kept the president tied to his desk. Feelings then were running high in Japan about the rape of a 12-year-old schoolgirl in Okinawa by three American servicemen. The new Japanese leader, it is said, feels he has to do something about the 47,000 troops the United States keeps stationed on Japanese territory.
That is one issue. The other is the fact that a perceived failure by the White House to get the Japanese to do more to open their markets to American goods will play dangerously into the hands of Pat Buchanan and his protectionist "America First" campaign. Mr Buchanan says he would "unilaterally end" Japan's trade surplus by slapping a 10% tariff on Japanese exports to the United States.
Mr Clinton used his trip t California last week to attack Mr Buchanan's trade policies and trumpet his own successes. The White House boasts that it has concluded 20 trade agreements with the Japanese government over the past three years, and that exports to Japan are up by 80% in the areas covered by these deals. As a result, 167,000 more Americans are at work today, claims Mr Clinton. Japan's trade surplus with America dropped 51% last year and is currently at its lowest level in many years.
But the Santa Monica meeting between the two leaders left several arguments unsettled, not least those about semiconductors, photographic materials, civil aviation and insurance. Both sides are anxious about the controversial 1986 semiconductor agreement, which is due to expire on July 31st. Mr Clinton is keen to renew the accord that reserves 20% of the Japanese semiconductor market for imports. Mr Hashimoto is equally adamant (at least in public) about ending the agreement
Since both men are worried about elections (Mr Hashimoto, despite having only recently got the job, must face the voters some time in the next 18 months), the semiconductors battle threatens to be as bloody as last June's dispute over car exports. When he was trade and industry minister in the previous government, Mr Hashimoto won widespread support within Japan (and, indeed, won his current job) for angrily facing down Mickey Kantor, the American trade representative, during heated discussions over opening the Japanese market to American cars, lorries and parts. Negotiations over access to Japan's insurance, aviation and photographic markets promise to be no less bitter.
In the end, though, Mr Hashimoto, one of the toughest men in Japanese politics, may quietly give Mr Clinton enough of a trade success to undermine Mr Buchanan and other protectionists-with benchmarks to be monitored by trade officials from both sides-if in return he can noisily win some concessions from America over the Okinawa bases.
In order to calm the anti-American anger caused by last September's rape, officials from the two countries have been examining ways to reduce America's quasicolonial presence on Okinawa. The Pentagon tends to see its 42 military installations on Japan's most southerly island as sacrosanct. But the mood elsewhere in Washington is moving towards a willingness to close several of the 42-including Camp Hansen, home of the three Americans involved in the rape--if this goes hand in hand with a broad-ranging agreement on trade. If some of the Americans departing from Okinawa can move to bases on the Japanese mainland, so much the better.
The Japanese have their own interest in a deal. Mr Hashimoto and his colleagues do not believe that Mr Buchanan is likely to get elected. But they do worry that his protectionist views will take root among Americans at large (and, indeed, some would argue that they already have). To guard against that, the best thing Mr Hashimoto can do is probably to reaffirm his wavering commitment to the deregulation of Japan's markets.

text:
TOKYO
IN SPORT, teams usually sack the coach only when they are on a losing streak. So it is with the Japanese economy. When the yen soared and the economy dived at the start of last year, the press was clamouring for deregulation and for the economy to be taken out of bureaucratic hands.
Since last April, the yen has dropped by 22%, interest rates have been slashed to virtually nothing and the government appears to have pumped almost 9 trillion ($86 billion) into the economy in two packages, the biggest of which was last September. So it should come as no great surprise that the economy is showing some signs of life, and that the clamour for change has died down.
Consumer spending has been inching up since last summer. Industrial production increased by 0.5% in January, growing for the fourth month in a row. Japan's Economic Planning Agency estimates that growth this year will be 2.5% and for once (it has been estimating at least that for the previous four years), private-sector economists do not regard this prediction as hopelessly optimistic.
Last year, when things looked bleak, the talk was all of reinventing the Japanese economic model; of letting markets rather than bureaucrats set prices; of slashing the red tape that enfolds the economy. Now that things are picking up, the downside of deregulation is being stressed. The trouble is that doing something about red tape, according to Nobuya Nemoto, an economist at the Nomura Research Institute, may, in the short run, produce an almighty jolt to the economy. Although foreign competition and more imports will increase productivity eventually, the immediate effect may well be more unemployment.
This has not been lost on Ryutaro Hashimoto, the new prime minister. Already unpopular, the last thing he needs is more people out of work. Unemployment, officially 3.4%, is at a record high, and elections are no more than a year and a half away. Hence the government has, at best, been lukewarm on reform. It has sat on a proposal to lift the ban on holding companies. It may do the same to a proposal to break up Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, Japan's telecommunications giant. And there is even some discussion of reversing the decision to introduce a firstpast-the-post electoral system.
Yet this timidity is unwise. The present recovery has required huge injections of taxpayers' cash to get things moving. Many economists think that the effects of this will peter out by the middle of the year. Without another fix, the economy will relapse into its previous torpid state. Some even think that the Japanese economy is on the verge of another recession. Yet public debt is rising so fast (see page 71) that the government cannot afford to carry on splurging on the economy.
As the economy falters, so unemployment will pick up again. Basking in the faint glow of an apparent economic. recovery might be the easy option, but it is not the right one.

text:
Ichiro Ozawa believes that Japan, for the third time in little over a century, needs radical reform. In this article, he explains why he finds the prospect exhilarating
NATIONS are nurtured by myths.Japan is no exception. If I mention the "third opening of Japan", most Japanese will immediately know what I mean,just as if I were citing the need for a new Magna Carta. Unless outsiders place what is happening in Japan today in the context of our history and our myths, they will find it difficult to understand the particular turningpoint we are facing in our long evolution as a nation.
Our myths arise from the fact that we are a group of narrow islands off the coast of Asia, coming only sporadically into contact with our continental neighbours down through the years. We take comfort in our homogeneity, in our capacity to absorb influences from the mainland at our own pace, in timespans measured by centuries rather than decades. For us, much more than for Britain, "the jungle begins at Calais"-in our case, the Korea Strait. In essence, we see ourselves as a cosy village society where consensus is the norm and where we all live by unspoken rules to make life tolerable in a green but crowded land with few natural resources.
The first great challenge to these myths came in 1853, when Commodore Matthew Perry and his heavily armed "black ships" dropped anchor in Tokyo (then known as Edo) Bay, and sent a message from President Millard Fillmore demanding that Japan open its doors to trade with the world. Until then, the Tokugawa Shoguns who had ruled Japan since 1603 had imposed a near-total ban on travel into or out of the country, the single exception being the port of Nagasaki, in southern Japan, where Dutch and Chinese merchants were allowed to bring in their wares.
The Shogunate officials knew that their antiquated shore batteries were no match for Perry's cannons. They had no recourse but to give way, choosing to do so as little as they could. In so doing, they set in motion a nationwide debate between advocates of continued isolation and reformers who wanted to open up the country. The debate lasted 15 years a period of great turmoil, ending only with the collapse of the Shogunate, the abolition of feudalism, and the establishment of a reform-minded central government under the direct rule of the Emperor Meiji. This series of events is known today as the first opening of Japan.
The Meiji era, which lasted for nearly half a century, was a heady time for Japan. The young reformers gathered around the emperor knew that for Japan's survival, they had to make drastic changes in the political, economic and social institutions of their country. One of the five pledges with which Meiji inaugurated his reign was to "seek knowledge throughout the world". His reformers created a modern army and navy, introduced capitalism, universal education, and a limited form of constitutional democracy, including the concept of equality under the law.
But the grafting of Western institutions and values on to traditional patterns of Japanese thought and behaviour was not achieved without great strain. The Meiji reformers were mostly bureaucrats and administrators, and, although they saw the need for elected parliaments, they preferred Bismarck to Gladstone-that is, they limited both the powers of parliament and the numbers of those able to vote for it. It was not until the early 1920s that Takashi Hara, the first commoner to become prime minister, introduced universal adult male suffrage. His reward was assassination. From the late 1920s, Japan became increasingly militaristic and authoritarian, embarking on adventures in China which led to confrontation with the United States and Britain and ended in disastrous defeat in the second world war.
Japan's surrender in 1945 and the sweeping reforms brought about during a six-year occupation by American forces under the command of General Douglas MacArthur constitute what many of us call the second opening of Japan. The second opening, like the first, began as a result of conflict with foreigners but continued differently because most of the changes took place under foreign duress. Yet the main planks of the occupation reforms embodied ideas and programmes begun in the Meiji period and were genuinely popular with voters: land reform, dissolution of the zaibatsu (giant financial and industrial trusts) freedom of speech and assembly, free trade unions and women's suffrage. A new constitution was drafted, including the famous article nine renouncing the right to go to war and banning the use of armed force. At least in form,Japan became a fully-fledged parliamentary democracy, with political power in the hands of the people's elected representatives.
Under the impetus of these reforms, and helped by the cold war which kept Japan firmly within America's orbit and under the protection of the us Japan security treaty, our people concentrated singlemindedly on economic recovery and growth. With no natural resources to speak of beyond the education and talents of our citizens, we imported raw materials from all over the world and exported manufactured goods to all the world. By the late 1960s we had outstripped West Germany as the non-communist world's second largest economy, surpassed in size only by the United States.
Our political progress, however, did not keep pace with the explosive growth of our economy. Conservative political forces quickly came together to form the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP But the opposition Socialists remained ideologically stuck in the rhetoric of the cold war, advocating the dissolution of the alliance with the United States and an unarmed neutrality that could only benefit the Soviet Union. Voters used the Socialists and other opposition parties to express dissatisfaction with the government of the day, but never in such numbers as to deprive the LDP of power. While we remained a parliamentary democracy in form, in practice the LDP was continuously in office, except for a brief period in 1947-48.
That long hold on power bred corruption, enhanced by the cosy village nature of Japanese society. Meanwhile, from outside Japan, and particularly from America and Europe, we began to hear increasingly shrill demands to open up our markets; outsiders also urged us to assume a diplomatic role in the international community commensurate with the size of our economy and its weight in the world.
The new frontier
To my mind, what these pressures building up inside and outside our country amount to is nothing less than a demand for the third opening of Japan-for changes as drastic and far-reaching as the ones brought about by the Meiji reformers and by the American occupation after 1945. That, indeed, is what my party, the New Frontier Party, stands for. If our programme succeeds, we will have brought about a revolution that will complete the work begun by the Meiji reformers more than 100 years ago. It will embody the most far-reaching changes that our country has ever known, and enable us to join the ranks of what I call the world's normal democratic states.
We have in Japan today the institutional forms of parliamentary government, but with a content rather different from what is regarded as normal in American or European democracies. Ours still reflects consensus politics and an isolationist mentality that excludes outsiders. The goal of the New Frontier Party is to break this mould and to bring about alternation in government between two political parties that will compete with each other on the basis of policy, not of factions or of personalities.
The Liberal Democrats' post-war monopoly of power was broken in July 1993, when Tsutomu Hata and I led a group of reform-minded colleagues to rebel against the party leadership and to establish a new party, the Japan Renewal Party. Together with other opposition parties, we won the general election that month and formed the Hosokawa coalition government. The following year, the Liberal Democrats made a deal with their sworn enemies, the Socialists, and returned to power. In reaction to this unholy alliance, all the main opposition parties except the Communists came together in December 1994 to establish the New Frontier Party.
Today, at least in form, we have the beginnings of a two-party system. On one side stands the government-a coalition of the LDP, the Socialists and the Sakigake or Harbingers, a minor party. The coalition was headed first by a Socialist, Tomchi Murayama, and now by a Liberal Democrat, Ryutaro Hashimoto. Despite their differences in ideological outlook, the LDP and the Socialists are essentially status quo parties. They mouth the slogans of reform, but in fact they want to keep their vested interests.
The new agenda
By contrast, our party is dedicated to the cause of reform. We call for thoroughgoing changes in politics, in the economy, in education and in society. In politics, we have been partially successful in that, during our brief year in power, we changed the election system from one of multi-seat districts to one which has 300 single-seat constituencies and 200 seats to be voted for on a proportional-representation list. It is somewhat like the German system. Each voter will have two votes and can cast his ballot both for his local candidate and for the party of his choice.
The world has not yet recognised the revolutionary nature of this change because the first election under the new system has yet to be held. At the latest, however, the next general election must be held in July 1997. It could come much soonerpossibly this summer or autumn. It may not immediately bring about a permanent two-party system but, as voters become used to the system, minor parties will fade away. The Socialist Party, recently renamed the Social Democratic Party, will be the top candidate for extinction.
 In each of the 300 single-seat constituencies, voters will have two clear points of view to choose betweenthat of the ruling coalition and that of the New Frontier Party. Many legislators, even those belonging to our party, are uncomfortable with this prospect. They want to build coalitions based on interests and personalities, as they have been doing till now, and are not sure that voters will respond to policybased appeals. I am convinced, however, that the New Frontier Party must make this sort of appeal to the voters.
Lessons from Iwate
My own constituency in Iwate is largely rural but I have insisted that farmers, like other citizens, must face the fact of international competition and not simply hide behind protective barriers. My recipe for change brings pain to my constituents but so far I have managed to be reelected with substantial majorities. I feel certain that, nationwide, voters will respond to political leadership if that leadership can provide a clear, compelling vision of the future and realistic steps to achieve it.
For us, there is no alternative to the third opening of Japan-to opening our markets wide to the international community, to chopping down the thicket of rules and regulations which are choking initiative, creativity and economic growth. I have no illusions about the difficulty of our task. Japan has been a regulated society for more than 1,000 years. We have a lot of people, little land, and few natural resources. For everyone to share in an economy of scarcity, there have to be regulations, and on the whole people have accepted these regulations. In modern times, the concept of fairness, of equality, has taken precedence over the concept of individual freedom. We are a society without vast gaps between rich and poor, management and workers. We would like to keep it so, but not at the cost of stifling personal freedom and individual initiative.
Despite my experience with voters in Iwate, I know that most Japanese still feel uncomfortable and disoriented by the prospect of living in a society with few regulations and where each person will have to be more self reliant and take greater responsibility for his or her own actions. Nevertheless there is no other way for Japan to move into the 21St century and survive. What we are embarked upon is a revolutionary process, and it will not be completed in a day.
We want lean government at the centre, and more power devolved to local entities. At the moment, Japan has a highly centralised system with no clear division between the central and local governments. Ultimately we will have about 300 local authorities nationwide small enough to be close to the voters, large enough to carry out effective government-to replace the present hodgepodge of prefectures, cities, towns and villages.
Educational reform may be the most important of the reforms we propose. Universal education was one of the great achievements of the Meiji reformers. Japan today is one of the world's most literate nations. But our education system remains stuck in the i9th century, emphasising rote learning and stuffing students with all sorts of relevant and irrelevant information. We need education that will foster self reliance and creativity. Group values like fairness and equality are important, but the primary emphasis must be on allowing the individual to develop. Education is an area in which we may not see results for ten years or more. But we must begin now, for we are already far behind the leaders in this field.
Japan and the world
Internationally, I have long advocated a much more active and participatory stance in world affairs, with the proviso that we remain in close partnership with the United States.
Some Japanese argue that, with the cold war over and with America no longer as overwhelming a military and economic superpower as it used to be, we should form closer ties with Asia, perhaps even play the role of honest broker between China and the United States. I disagree. I hope that China, as its economy grows and its people prosper, will successfully make the transition from authoritarianism to democratic government. I also hope that China and Taiwan will settle their differences peacefully on the basis of their common recognition that Taiwan is part of China. But these are not yet foregone conclusions. North Korea is an even more troubling neighbour than China. Asia needs the American security presence, and the us-Japan security treaty provides the means for America not only to protect Japan but to remain involved with Asia. Furthermore, Japan's own past record in Asia is not forgotten. We will be accepted and considered non-threatening by our Asian neighbours only to the extent that we retain a strong security relationship and economic partnership with the United States.
This does not mean that we will agree with America in all respects nor that we will fail to advance our own point of view. We may have as many disagreements with America as do Britain, France or Germany. But like them, our disagreements should always take place within the context of our basic alliance. Alliance with America is as essential for Japan as it is for Europe-perhaps more so, because in Asia we have nothing like NATO or the European Union.

Ichiro Ozawa believes that Japan, for the third time in little over a century, needs radical reform. In this article, he explains why he finds the prospect exhilarating
NATIONS are nurtured by myths.Japan is no exception. If I mention the "third opening of Japan", most Japanese will immediately know what I mean,just as if I were citing the need for a new Magna Carta. Unless outsiders place what is happening in Japan today in the context of our history and our myths, they will find it difficult to understand the particular turningpoint we are facing in our long evolution as a nation.
Our myths arise from the fact that we are a group of narrow islands off the coast of Asia, coming only sporadically into contact with our continental neighbours down through the years. We take comfort in our homogeneity, in our capacity to absorb influences from the mainland at our own pace, in timespans measured by centuries rather than decades. For us, much more than for Britain, "the jungle begins at Calais"-in our case, the Korea Strait. In essence, we see ourselves as a cosy village society where consensus is the norm and where we all live by unspoken rules to make life tolerable in a green but crowded land with few natural resources.
The first great challenge to these myths came in 1853, when Commodore Matthew Perry and his heavily armed "black ships" dropped anchor in Tokyo (then known as Edo) Bay, and sent a message from President Millard Fillmore demanding that Japan open its doors to trade with the world. Until then, the Tokugawa Shoguns who had ruled Japan since 1603 had imposed a near-total ban on travel into or out of the country, the single exception being the port of Nagasaki, in southern Japan, where Dutch and Chinese merchants were allowed to bring in their wares.
The Shogunate officials knew that their antiquated shore batteries were no match for Perry's cannons. They had no recourse but to give way, choosing to do so as little as they could. In so doing, they set in motion a nationwide debate between advocates of continued isolation and reformers who wanted to open up the country. The debate lasted 15 years a period of great turmoil, ending only with the collapse of the Shogunate, the abolition of feudalism, and the establishment of a reform-minded central government under the direct rule of the Emperor Meiji. This series of events is known today as the first opening of Japan.
The Meiji era, which lasted for nearly half a century, was a heady time for Japan. The young reformers gathered around the emperor knew that for Japan's survival, they had to make drastic changes in the political, economic and social institutions of their country. One of the five pledges with which Meiji inaugurated his reign was to "seek knowledge throughout the world". His reformers created a modern army and navy, introduced capitalism, universal education, and a limited form of constitutional democracy, including the concept of equality under the law.
But the grafting of Western institutions and values on to traditional patterns of Japanese thought and behaviour was not achieved without great strain. The Meiji reformers were mostly bureaucrats and administrators, and, although they saw the need for elected parliaments, they preferred Bismarck to Gladstone-that is, they limited both the powers of parliament and the numbers of those able to vote for it. It was not until the early 1920s that Takashi Hara, the first commoner to become prime minister, introduced universal adult male suffrage. His reward was assassination. From the late 1920s, Japan became increasingly militaristic and authoritarian, embarking on adventures in China which led to confrontation with the United States and Britain and ended in disastrous defeat in the second world war.
Japan's surrender in 1945 and the sweeping reforms brought about during a six-year occupation by American forces under the command of General Douglas MacArthur constitute what many of us call the second opening of Japan. The second opening, like the first, began as a result of conflict with foreigners but continued differently because most of the changes took place under foreign duress. Yet the main planks of the occupation reforms embodied ideas and programmes begun in the Meiji period and were genuinely popular with voters: land reform, dissolution of the zaibatsu (giant financial and industrial trusts) freedom of speech and assembly, free trade unions and women's suffrage. A new constitution was drafted, including the famous article nine renouncing the right to go to war and banning the use of armed force. At least in form,Japan became a fully-fledged parliamentary democracy, with political power in the hands of the people's elected representatives.
Under the impetus of these reforms, and helped by the cold war which kept Japan firmly within America's orbit and under the protection of the us Japan security treaty, our people concentrated singlemindedly on economic recovery and growth. With no natural resources to speak of beyond the education and talents of our citizens, we imported raw materials from all over the world and exported manufactured goods to all the world. By the late 1960s we had outstripped West Germany as the non-communist world's second largest economy, surpassed in size only by the United States.
Our political progress, however, did not keep pace with the explosive growth of our economy. Conservative political forces quickly came together to form the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP But the opposition Socialists remained ideologically stuck in the rhetoric of the cold war, advocating the dissolution of the alliance with the United States and an unarmed neutrality that could only benefit the Soviet Union. Voters used the Socialists and other opposition parties to express dissatisfaction with the government of the day, but never in such numbers as to deprive the LDP of power. While we remained a parliamentary democracy in form, in practice the LDP was continuously in office, except for a brief period in 1947-48.
That long hold on power bred corruption, enhanced by the cosy village nature of Japanese society. Meanwhile, from outside Japan, and particularly from America and Europe, we began to hear increasingly shrill demands to open up our markets; outsiders also urged us to assume a diplomatic role in the international community commensurate with the size of our economy and its weight in the world.
The new frontier
To my mind, what these pressures building up inside and outside our country amount to is nothing less than a demand for the third opening of Japan-for changes as drastic and far-reaching as the ones brought about by the Meiji reformers and by the American occupation after 1945. That, indeed, is what my party, the New Frontier Party, stands for. If our programme succeeds, we will have brought about a revolution that will complete the work begun by the Meiji reformers more than 100 years ago. It will embody the most far-reaching changes that our country has ever known, and enable us to join the ranks of what I call the world's normal democratic states.
We have in Japan today the institutional forms of parliamentary government, but with a content rather different from what is regarded as normal in American or European democracies. Ours still reflects consensus politics and an isolationist mentality that excludes outsiders. The goal of the New Frontier Party is to break this mould and to bring about alternation in government between two political parties that will compete with each other on the basis of policy, not of factions or of personalities.
The Liberal Democrats' post-war monopoly of power was broken in July 1993, when Tsutomu Hata and I led a group of reform-minded colleagues to rebel against the party leadership and to establish a new party, the Japan Renewal Party. Together with other opposition parties, we won the general election that month and formed the Hosokawa coalition government. The following year, the Liberal Democrats made a deal with their sworn enemies, the Socialists, and returned to power. In reaction to this unholy alliance, all the main opposition parties except the Communists came together in December 1994 to establish the New Frontier Party.
Today, at least in form, we have the beginnings of a two-party system. On one side stands the government-a coalition of the LDP, the Socialists and the Sakigake or Harbingers, a minor party. The coalition was headed first by a Socialist, Tomchi Murayama, and now by a Liberal Democrat, Ryutaro Hashimoto. Despite their differences in ideological outlook, the LDP and the Socialists are essentially status quo parties. They mouth the slogans of reform, but in fact they want to keep their vested interests.

By contrast, our party is dedicated to the cause of reform. We call for thoroughgoing changes in politics, in the economy, in education and in society. In politics, we have been partially successful in that, during our brief year in power, we changed the election system from one of multi-seat districts to one which has 300 single-seat constituencies and 200 seats to be voted for on a proportional-representation list. It is somewhat like the German system. Each voter will have two votes and can cast his ballot both for his local candidate and for the party of his choice.
The world has not yet recognised the revolutionary nature of this change because the first election under the new system has yet to be held. At the latest, however, the next general election must be held in July 1997. It could come much soonerpossibly this summer or autumn. It may not immediately bring about a permanent two-party system but, as voters become used to the system, minor parties will fade away. The Socialist Party, recently renamed the Social Democratic Party, will be the top candidate for extinction.

Many legislators, even those belonging to our party, are uncomfortable with this prospect. They want to build coalitions based on interests and personalities, as they have been doing till now, and are not sure that voters will respond to policybased appeals. For everyone to share in an economy of scarcity, there have to be regulations, and on the whole people have accepted these regulations. In modern times, the concept of fairness, of equality, has taken precedence over the concept of individual freedom. We are a society without vast gaps between rich and poor, management and workers. We would like to keep it so, but not at the cost of stifling personal freedom and individual initiative.

At the moment, Japan has a highly centralised system with no clear division between the central and local governments. Ultimately we will have about 300 local authorities nationwide small enough to be close to the voters, large enough to carry out effective government-to replace the present hodgepodge of prefectures, cities, towns and villages.
