text:
Chinese war games
In a new threat to Taiwan, China conducted military exercises close to the island using live ammunition. But, as the United States moved two aircraft carriers close to Taiwan, the Chinese were reported to have assured the Americans that they did not plan to invade the island. The Chinese actions have been prompted by fears that Taiwan, regarded by them as a rebel province, may declare independence. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index tumbled.
Popular support for Ryutaro Hashimoto,Japan's new prime minister, has fallen sharply in the two months since he took office as his government remains paralysed. A proposal to use government money to bail out a group of failed mortgage companies has proved deeply unpopular not only with the public but with opposition politicians, some of whom have staged a sit-in at the Diet blocking all progress on the budget, which includes the proposal to rescue the mortgage companies.
King Norodom Sihanouk said he was suffering from a brain tumour and might have to resign as Cambodia's head of state.
Tribesmen in the Indonesian province of In Jaya attacked an American-owned copper mine in Timika.
Europe's future
The European Union's 15 member countries made opening bids before the inter-governmental conference on Europe's future, due to start in Turin on March 29th. Britain said it wanted no extension of majority voting in the Council of Ministers. Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg want a more federal Union. France called for greater powers for national parliaments to decide European issues. The European Parliament protested at its exclusion from the conference--and demanded more powers.
The British government suffered an embarrassing defeat in the European Court of Justice, which ruled in favour of a plan by the European Union to introduce a maximum 48-hour working week Britain had claimed exemption under the social clause; the court ruled that it came under health and safety.
Carl Bildt, the European Union's representative in Bosnia, said the Dayton peace plan is in danger of unravelling. He suggested that NATO's implementation force should stay beyond 1996. In Britain's worst lone massacre, a gunman in Scotland shot dead 16 children aged five and six and their teacher in a primary school, and then shot himself. Another 12 children and two teachers were wounded.
The winner of this month's Spanish general election, Jose Maria Aznar, leader of the conservative People's Party, continues to search for a working majority in parliament. After a meeting with Mr Aznar, the defeated Socialist leader, Felipe Gonzalez, prime minister for more than 13 years, said that he would not seek to keep his opponent from office.
With an eye on monetary union in 1999, the finance ministers of both Germany and France announced further limits on public spending. Sluggish economies have kept tax revenues low and unemployment handouts high.
Felix Habsburg-Lothringen, a son of the last emperor of Austria, provoked a row by secretly visiting the country, from which he is banned because he has not renounced his claim to the throne. "Herr Habsburg is provoking the republic," said a senior member of Austria's ruling Social Democrats.
Dole steams on
Senator Bob Dole triumphed in the Super Tuesday primaries, bringing his total of delegates to more than 700. Steve Forbes, the flat-tax candidate, decided to quit the race, but Pat Buchanan, the populists' friend, vowed to keep on fighting. Newt Gingrich, the speaker of the House, urged all Republicans to unite. Mr Dole began to muse aloud about persuading Colin Powell, a retired general, to change his mind and be his running-mate.
Bill Clinton signed into law the Helms-Burton bill tightening trade sanctions on Cuba, and on others investing there. The European Union said it would complain to the World Trade Organisation. Canada and Mexico said they would lodge complaints through NAI;TArn. Most of Latin America reacted angrily. Cuba jeered.
Jack Kevorkian, the champion of assisted suicide and inventor of a suicide machine, was acquitted at his second trial of illegally helping patients to kill themselves. A few days earlier, a federal appeals court in San Francisco (whose decisions are binding on nine western states) ruled that there was a constitutional right to die.
Support for peace
In a bid to keep the Middle East peace process alive, Bill. Clinton and Hosni Mubarak jointly chaired a four hour summit on peace and terrorism at a Red Sea resort. Nearly 30 countries turned up, including European heads of government and representatives from the Arab Gulf states. Syria and Lebanon were notable absentees. In Israel after the summit, Mr Clinton committed $100m to an American-Israeli fight against terrorism.
Israel continued its tight blockade of the West Bank and Gaza, and said it would deport men directly connected to suicide-bombers.
Kuwait held a conference in London to remind people of the 600 Kuwaiti prisoners taken to Iraq after the 199o invasion and still unaccounted for. Iraq fuelled new suspicions by temporarily barring UN inspectors from a building they wanted to see.

text:
DESPITE its trepidation, the government of Ryutaro Hashimoto really had nothing to fear. It would have taken a disaster of momentous proportions for the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) to lose the upper-house by-election in Gifu prefecture on March 24th. In the event, Tsuyako Ono, the 62-year-old widow of an LDP member who died in office, won a nifty 50.5% of the vote. Neither of the opposition candidates came close: the New Frontier Party's Tetsuo Yoshioka picked up only 28.9% and the Communist Party's Hiroyuki Yamamoto 20.6%.
Ichiro Ozawa, the boss of the New Frontier Party (NFP), had hoped to turn the Gifu by-election into a referendum on the government's bungling of the jusen affair. Members of Mr Ozawa's party have spent the past three weeks blockading a committee room in the Diet (parliament) to prevent any debate taking place on the coming year's Y75.1 trillion ($705 billion) budgetwith Y685 billion allocated to wind up the seven all-but-bankrupt mortgage companies known as jusen (see page 70).
The N FP'S crushing defeat in Gifu put an end to its sit-in. Although 6o% of voters polled in the mountain prefecture were dead set against the use of public money in the jusen affair, they were clearly more annoyed with the opposition for its childish efforts to delay the budget and jeopardise the economy's fragile recovery.
The face-saving formula that the LDP and its two smaller coalition partners (the Social Democratic Party of Japan and the New Sakigake Party) offered Mr Ozawa and his weary troops includes a promise not to use their majority in the more important lower house to ram the budget through. The ruling party pledged instead merely to give "sincere" consideration to the opposition's demands not to use public money to help wind up the jusen, The LDP also agreed to consider questioning "those involved" in a donation to Koichi Kato, the LDP's secretary-general, from a now defunct company that borrowed heavily from a jusen.
With the opposition in attendance, the government has now passed al bills that had to clear the Diet before the end of the fiscal year on March 31st. It has also passed a stopgap budget of 11.6 trillion-enough to pay the bills until May 2oth. So what have Mr Ozawa and the NFP actually achieved with their barricade? Very little.
Some believe that, by threatening to nobble Mr Kato, the NFP has made an early election more likely. Mr Ozawa wants to strike while the government's popularity is plummeting (down to 35% from 60% in January) as a result of its decision to bail out the speculators behind the jusen fiasco. Mr Kato has been singled out for a mugging.
As the day-to-day manager of the LDP, Mr Kato has been working hard to keep the coalition intact and is determined to avoid an early general election (due by the summer of 1997). He hopes to see the jusen affair disposed of, and forgotten, first. By demanding that Mr Kato be called to give evidence before the Diet for allegedly receiving an illicit donation of Y10m, the NFP had been hoping to tie him down for a while. But it is unlikely that the ruling party's bosses will get round to putting Mr Kato on the stand.
Others say that a resurgent LDP, buoyed by its success in Gifu, must now be thinking about an early election anyway. The LDP still has enormous support in the countryside. But the party would be stupid (which the LDP most certainly is not) to draw any broad conclusions from the by-election. The constituency is an LDP fief that has been run by a local dynasty for decades.
Mrs Ono's husband himself inherited the seat from his LDP father, whose statue stands outside one of Gifu's main railway stations in gratitude for bringing a bullettrain service to the region.
With the budget all but out of the way, Mr Hashimoto has some breathing-space to resolve the jusen problem. A compromise is on the cards. The controversial Y685 billion will probably be taken out of the main budget and moved into the government's second (unofficial) budget, called the fiscal investment and loan programme. At Y71 trillion, the programme is now as big as the budget itself The problem money will be lost among all the other fudgings the government does for political purposes. That, really, is where it should have been in the first place.

But it is unlikely that the ruling party 's bosses will get round to putting Mr Kato on the stand . 
 Others say that a resurgent LDP , buoyed by its success in Gifu , must now be thinking about an early election anyway . The LDP still has enormous support in the countryside . But the party would be stupid ( which the LDP most certainly is not ) to draw any broad conclusions from the by - election . The constituency is an LDP fief that has been run by a local dynasty for decades . 
 Mrs Ono 's husband himself inherited the seat from his LDP father , whose statue stands outside one of Gifu 's main railway stations in gratitude for bringing a bullettrain service to the region . 
 With the budget all but out of the way , Mr Hashimoto has some breathing - space to resolve the jusen problem . A compromise is on the cards . The controversial Y685 billion will probably be taken out of the main budget and moved into Ryutaro Hashimoto's second ( unofficial ) budget , called the fiscal investment and loan programme . At Y71 trillion , the programme is now as big as the budget itself The problem money will be lost among all the other fudgings Ryutaro Hashimoto does for political purposes . That , really , is where it should have been in the first place .

text:
IT WAS a comfortless victory. On March 29th, after seven years of struggle, a group of Japanese haemophiliacs infected with the HIV virus, as a result of using contaminated clotting agents, finally won their court battle against five drug companies that had supplied the products and the government that had failed to stop them. They came away with an apology, Y45m ($420,000) each and the promise of a bit more money every month to cover medical expenses. But none of this can be much consolation for the 1,800 haemophiliacs that contracted HIV, about half of all hemophiliacs in Japan, still less to the 400 that have died from AIDS.
The scandal speaks volumes about the refusal of Japan's It illustrates to admit the a nasty foreign disease such as AIDS could af- fect Japanese. It illustrates the unhealthily close connections between doctors, the Ministry of Health and Welfare and the drug companies that they were supposed to be regulating.
In March 1983, America's Centers for Disease Control announced that HIV seemed to have been transmitted to haemophiliacs through unheated (ie, unsterilised) clotting agents, which were made from blood collected from donors. But not until July 1985 did the Japanese authorise heat-treated blood products. Even then, it did not order drug manufacturers to pull unheated products from the market. Both the drug companies and the ministry claimed that there was no significant risk of catching HIV from untreated products. Since then, the ministry's bureaucrats have consistently denied that they had done anything wrong. Their excuse: they did not know about the risks.
It turns out they were lying. In January, the new health minister, Naoto Kan, set up an investigation. Nine files showing that the ministry had recognised the risks-but had refused to do anything about themwere found. In July 1983, for example, a health ministry committee had even considered making emergency imports of heattreated products, but decided not to.
Yet in September 1984, Takeshi Abe, the head of Japan's AIDs research panel, found that almost half of his 48 haemophiliac patients had HIV. Three months later, the ministry found that many haemophiliacs that had been tested had HIV. Neither Mr Abe nor the ministry made these results public.
The reason seems to be that, as with other ministries, the health bureaucrats were too close to those they were supposed to be regulating. On retirement, there were plum jobs to be landed with drug firms: five senior executives at Green Cross-one of the companies involved in the casewere former ministry officials. And at that time, heated blood products were available only from foreign suppliers.
Humanitarian and health considerations seem to have played no more than a minor role. In Japan, doctors make most of their money by prescribing drugs. They stood to make more money from prescribing unheated products-which they could buy cheaply-than from expensive imported ones. Since the government fixes the price at which doctors can sell drugs, there is an incentive for the doctors to cuddle up to local drugs companies in order to get their wares more cheaply
This is not the first time that Japan has had a catastrophe of this sort. In 1979, a little known health and welfare minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, apologised to victims of a drug called quinoform, which had caused severe disabilities in 400 people. He promised to try to prevent the recur rence of such catastrophes. Mr Hashimoto is now prime minister. He has an opportunity to honour his promise.

text:
The alliance between America and Japan-the cornerstone of East Asia's security is in even worse trouble then it looks
IN EUROPE, the end of the cold war strained the North Atlantic alliance; but NATO is not in danger of collapse. In the Pacific, the American-Japanese alliance is also showing strain; and it seems natural to suppose that this partnership, too, will nonetheless survive. If NATO has weathered the bickering over Bosnia, the arguments over enlargement, and the ebbing of the Russian threat, then surely the AmericanJapanese alliance can overcome apparently equivalent obstacles. All it will take is a bit of statesmanship on both sides: a resolution to refrain from calling the other nasty names and a feel-good summit.
That will be Bill Clinton's hope as he sets off next week to visit Japan and South Korea. Having infuriated the Japanese by cancelling a trip to Osaka last November, Mr Clinton plans to be in Japan from April 16th to 18th, a longish trip by his standards. Unlike previous summits, which focused on trade, this one will dwell on security. It will try to stiffen Japan's willingness to play host to 47,ooo American troops, which has been wavering since three American servicemen raped a Japanese schoolgirl last September. Protestors calling for the Americans to withdraw mustered Japan's biggest demonstration in a quarter of a century.
To placate the Japanese, Mr Clinton will probably announce the return of some land now used by American troops. He will be the guest of the emperor, whose father the Americans nearly hanged after 1945: the perfect symbol of reconciliation. He will shake hands with Japan's prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, who only a year ago was hurling abuse at American trade negotiators. And, with stage-managed amity, he will emphasise the importance of the two countries' alliance to East Asia's security at a time of growing regional instability-witness China's bullying of Taiwan, or North Korea's recent renunciation of the armistice that ended the Korean war.
Can the partnership be patched up in this way? There are two broad reasons for supposing that it cannot, and that the comforting analogy with NATO promotes complacency. The first doubt holds that trade arguments will soon dominate the partnership again, and that the healing effect of next week's summit will therefore be fleeting. The second maintains that the alliance is doomed by forces that no summit can address: that America is gradually losing its appetite for defending allies rich enough to defend themselves, and that rich Japan is losing patience with American tutelage.
Either of these arguments, if true, could consign the alliance to gradual decay, with potentially dreadful consequences. Deprived of America's nuclear shield, Japan would develop its own nuclear weapons to stay even with China. South Korea, which has been invaded by both Japan and China in the past, would shortly follow. So might the more sophisticated South-East Asian states, whose military budgets are already growing rapidly. Pretty soon, the whole region could be nuclear and nervous.
Such an arms race would unfold on a continent far less stable than Europe at the height of the cold war. China faces a succession struggle; North Korea faces famine and possible collapse; South Korean democracy is in a tempestuous infancy. Farther south, Indonesia has succession worries of its own; Hong Kong will revert to China next year; and Taiwan is trying to stave off a similar fate. In short, if the American-Japanese alliance frays, the miracle economies of the Pacific rim could set a second record for mankind. Having pulled off history's fastest ever advance in human welfare, they could next succumb to its fastest and nastiest reversal.
Trade troubles
How real are these dangers? Consider, first the possibility that trade rows will undermine America's partnership with Japan. Such disputes have dogged the alliance for many years, and the partnership has survived. In 1992, for instance, George Bush went to Tokyo brandishing a list of trade demands, flanked by industrialists demanding better access to Japanese markets. But the trade disputes seem to be getting worse-and have begun to jeopardise the security part of the partnership.
Mr Clinton came to power promising to redouble the commercial bias. Visiting Tokyo for the G7 summit in 1993, he turned his meeting with Kiichi Miyazawa, Japan's prime minister of the time, into a trade negotiation. The defence treaty barely got a mention.
The Clinton team argued that, with the cold war at an end, geo-politics could give way to geo-economics. Communism had collapsed; or, where it had not, communists were too intent on getting rich to threaten anybody. In the absence of this threat, America could withdraw from the costly, tiring business of propping up allies and staring down foes. Instead, it should concentrate on economic goals, chiefly export promotion. If the pursuit of economic gain hurt cold-war ties, then so be it.
This thinking changed American policy. The Commerce Department saw its budget and prestige expand; the State Department grew demoralised. The biggest impact from this shift fell on America's dealings with Japan. Here was a country whose security role now seemed less crucial. And here was a country whose vast markets appeared closed to American products.With his trip to Tokyo in 1993, Mr Clinton inaugurated a policy of aggressive trade demands, untrammelled by concern for the wider partnership.
Three years later, Japan-bashing on trade has damaged relations between the two countries. An opinion poll taken in the middle of last year's acrimonious car talks found that friendly feelings between the two countries had hit a ten-year low. Japans trade minister of the time grew wildly popular by denouncing American demands; so popular, indeed, that he is now prime minister. Meanwhile, thuggish China and North Korea have demonstrated that the security alliance with Japan is as necessary as ever.
In 1995 Joseph Nye, a senior DefenceDepartment official, declared that the military alliance was suffering from neglect.* Wedded to geo-economics, the Clinton team at first failed to gave his concerns their due. What made the difference was last September's rape of the schoolgirl and the wave of anti-American demonstrations that followed. Supported by much of the Japanese press, the demonstrators argued that it was outrageous for Japan to pay 70% of the cost of maintaining American bases on its soil, if American servicemen behaved so badly. Even politicians on whom America had previously relied failed to speak out in defence of the security treaty. In Washington, the Defence Department's vague concern turned into "real panic", in the words of one of Mr Nye's advisers.
Half a hope on trade
That was enough to produce Mr Clinton's sudden switch to worrying about the military alliance. But is the switch anything more than a panic reaction? At first sight, it does not look like it. The prospects for keeping security at the top of the agenda with Japan are dim. Republicans are as reluctant as Democrats to return to the vigilance of the cold war; there are few votes in it. Richard Lugar, the one Republican presidential candidate to stress his knowledge of foreign affairs, got almost no votes in the primaries. At the State Department, old Japan hands marvel at how the tough congressional questions that they used to face have given way to yawning indifference. In sum, neither party seems interested in giving a consistently high priority to the security treaty with Japan.
That said, however, there remains half a hope that America will come back to security in future. It lies in the failure of Japanbashing trade policies.
When he goes to Tokyo, the president will no doubt claim credit for America's shrinking trade deficit with Japan (see chart on next page). But the truth is that this reflects the yen's rise to around Y107 to the dollar, up from Y126 when Mr Clinton took office. It does not reflect the trade talks initiated in 1993, because most of America's important demands have been turned down flat by Japanese officials. Japan-bashing has failed on its own terms.
Nor will it succeed any time soon.Japanese intransigence on trade is likely to prove permanent. During the 1970s and 198os Japan repeatedly yielded to foreigntrade demands, whether for access to its domestic market or for "voluntary" restraints upon its exports. But that was because Japan's firms were making miracle profits during their years of catch-up growth. Now that they are less flush, these firms are far less keen on "generosity".
Besides, the Japanese are now protected by the World Trade Organisation. During last year's car talks, America threatened to use its draconian "Super 301" trade law, which provides for punitive sanctions against countries deemed to be unfair traders. The Japanese said that they would challenge the legality of such a step under WTO rules. The counter-threat worked; the Americans backed down; the Japanese are not going to be cowed by Super 301 in future.
Japanese steadfastness is not the only reason why Japan-bashing has failed. The other is that bashing can backfire on America's own economic interests. Since the 1980s, the fear of a trade war has spread occasional panic through Wall Street. During last year's trade row, investors worried that, by forcing up the yen, American trade pressure might hasten a banking crisis in Japan, with ugly consequences for the American banks that do business with them. Not long afterwards, America's trade negotiators signed a deal on car trade that included little of what they had originally wanted.
None of this means that trade rows are gone. Mr Clinton will not be able to avoid mentioning several disputes next week, concerning photographic film, insurance and semiconductors. Decades of trade rows have produced an interest group of dispute-experts in Washington, who make a fine living by lobbying on behalf of firms trying to penetrate Japan and who know just how to keep trade rows active. But the limited gains from such disputes should at least mean that they are kept in check. No longer will they be pursued without regard to the security relationship.
Half-baked on security
If trade rows can be more-or-less contained, what of the other threats to the alliance? These come down to the idea that the security treaty, born of Japan's defeat in 1945, is now anachronistic. Some Americans argue that Japan has outgrown the need for American defence; as the world's second biggest economy, it should do its own soldiering. For their part, some Japanese feel that reliance on American troops is a slur on the nation's pride; they are fed up with being "a mercantile nation that just writes cheques", in the words of Mr Hashimoto. These are serious objections. General Douglas MacArthur, who ruled Japan from to 1951, likened Japan to a child in need of America's fatherly protection. The military alliance that he helped devise reflects this paternalism. America promises to protect Japan and to quench instability in Asia. In return, Japan merely offers bases for American troops. The Japanese do maintain a "Self-Defence Force" but its usefulness is stunted by Japan's pacifist constitution, which forbids going to war.
For a surprisingly long time, the alliance worked on the basis of America's conqueringSelf-confidence and Japan's corresponding humility. Until the 1970s, Americans continued to see Japan as a backward place where you could afford cheap maids; Japan continued to admire American ways and products. A deep self doubt possessed the Japanese, who were ashamed to sing the national anthem or raise the flag; some left-wingers regarded the Japanese state itself as illegitimate.
All this has been changed by Japan's stunning economic success. Now it is the Japanese who find America cheap, who complain that American workers are lazy and their products unreliable. Japan's flag and national anthem are no longer suppressed; the anti-nationalist left-wing has all but evaporated. The old self-doubt has been replaced by self-confidence, sometimes overblown. In many respects, Japanese reckon they know better than MacArthur's heirs-and plenty of Americans are willing to agree with them.
For at least a decade, therefore, the two countries' military alliance has seemed precariously lop-sided. Some critics, seeing that MacArthur's father-child arrangement has been slow to adapt, are starting to lose patience. Last year Chalmers Johnson, the president of the Japan Policy Research Institute, argued that Japan would never take more responsibility for its own defence while the American security treaty remained in place; he therefore called on his country to close down its Japanese bases.^ On Japan's side, a different version of this argument emerged. The rape, some said, proved that Americans behaved as though they were still members of an occupation force. The only way to cure Americans of their arrogance was to send them packing.
Complacency revisited
It will be easy for next week's summiteers to dismiss these extreme views. Only a small minority wants all American troops to go; a poll taken after last September's rape found that just 14% of Japanese held this opinion. But, having ignored the perils of geo-economics for too long, America had better not ignore this second set of threats. For the truth is that the security treaty is every bit as anachronistic as the critics charge Unless it is brought up to date, nobody should be surprised if the extremists multiply.
Indeed, the same poll demonstrates the dangers of complacency. Even fewer Japanese-just 7%-wanted the bases maintained at their current size; the vast major ity resented their presence, and wanted them scaled back gradually. More polls, assembled in a new book$, suggest that younger Japanese are more hostile to the bases than their elders; and that many doubt whether America would defend Japan in a crisis. In 199o, 62% of Japanese said that America would be a reliable ally; in 1994, only 47% did. At times a majority has said that the bases, by provoking enemy attack, may actually reduce Japan's security.
The alliance needs to be modified before such resentments undermine it. Since last autumn's rape, America has begun to take up this task The armed forces are preparing to hand back unneeded land-not the airbases, which America must keep if it is to deploy troops quickly in Asia and the Middle East, but housing estates and suchlike. Mr Clinton's visit will also bring the announcement of a scheme to involve Japan more in logistical support for American troops taking part in peacetime military exercises or peacekeeping operations. Japan's sense of involvement with the American forces on its soil ought to be promoted further. Japanese defence officials and diplomats seldom visit America's bases in Japan, and one recent exception to this rule suggests how valuable more exceptions could be. A month ago a group of bigwigs from Tokyo was loaded onto a buggy and driven past endless helicopters, tanks and other war materiel. All they could say was sugoi!, which means, roughly, Wow! They had heard Americans talk of their commitment to Japan. Now they had seen the evidence.
Some Japan hands in Washington discuss the sugoi factor and wonder how they can build on it. But the trouble is that a strong unilateralist strain remains in America's military policy, a tendency as marked in Asia as it was in Bosnia. When Bill Clinton sent aircraft carriers to watch over the Taiwan Strait recently, he did not forewarn the Japanese Left out of American plans, they are hardly likely to feel confident in American protection.
This matters, because Japan's leaders will need to feel more confidence in the alliance if they are to play their part in strengthening it. Japanese voters are even less keen than their American counterparts on expanding their military responsibilities abroad. Polls suggest that most Japanese think it wrong to use force to maintain international law; and that most doubt whether their country's military power will ever match its economic stature If the security treaty is to be modernised, a bold politician will have to look his countrymen in the eyes and demand that they rethink some of their most basic attitudes.
Scary as it may sound, the long-term health of the alliance with America may therefore hinge on Japan's chaotic politics Since 1993, a one-party system has given way to a chaos of competing splinter groups and then to something resembling two-party competition. Over the same three years, the country has been ruled by five different prime ministers. But, out of this mess, something promising has emerged Both the two main parties are led by men who want to expand Japan's responsibilities. These leaders need all the support they can get from their American friends. Mr Clinton's visit next week will be a start. But the finishing point remains distant. 
* "The Case for Deep Engagement". By Joseph Nye. Foreign Affairs July/August 1995. ^ "The Pentagon's Ossified Strategy." By Chalmers)Johnson and EB. Keehn. Foreign Affairs. same issue ^^ "Public Opinion in America and Japan". By Everett Carl Ladd and Karlyn Bowman. AEI Press.

For a surprisingly long time, the alliance worked on the basis of America's conqueringSelf-confidence and Japan's corresponding humility. Until the 1970s, Americans continued to see Japan as a backward place where you could afford cheap maids; Japan continued to admire American ways and products. A deep self doubt possessed the Japanese, who were ashamed to sing the national anthem or raise the flag; some left-wingers regarded the Japanese state itself as illegitimate.
All this has been changed by Japan's stunning economic success. Now it is the Japanese who find America cheap, who complain that American workers are lazy and their products unreliable. Japan's flag and national anthem are no longer suppressed; the anti-nationalist left-wing has all but evaporated. The old self-doubt has been replaced by self-confidence, sometimes overblown. In many respects, Japanese reckon they know better than MacArthur's heirs-and plenty of Americans are willing to agree with them.
For at least a decade, therefore, the two countries' military alliance has seemed precariously lop-sided. Some critics, seeing that MacArthur's father-child arrangement has been slow to adapt, are starting to lose patience. Last year Chalmers Johnson, the president of the Japan Policy Research Institute, argued that Japan would never take more responsibility for its own defence while the American security treaty remained in place; he therefore called on his country to close down its Japanese bases.^ On Japan's side, a different version of this argument emerged. The rape, some said, proved that Americans behaved as though they were still members of an occupation force. The only way to cure Americans of their arrogance was to send them packing.
Complacency revisited
It will be easy for next week's summiteers to dismiss these extreme views. Only a small minority wants all American troops to go; a poll taken after last September's rape found that just 14% of Japanese held this opinion. But, having ignored the perils of geo-economics for too long, America had better not ignore this second set of threats. For the truth is that the security treaty is every bit as anachronistic as the critics charge Unless it is brought up to date, nobody should be surprised if the extremists multiply.
Indeed, the same poll demonstrates the dangers of complacency. Even fewer Japanese-just 7%-wanted the bases maintained at their current size; the vast major ity resented their presence, and wanted them scaled back gradually. More polls, assembled in a new book$, suggest that younger Japanese are more hostile to the bases than their elders; and that many doubt whether America would defend Japan in a crisis. In 199o, 62% of Japanese said that America would be a reliable ally; in 1994, only 47% did. At times a majority has said that the bases, by provoking enemy attack, may actually reduce Japan's security.
The alliance needs to be modified before such resentments undermine it. Since last autumn's rape, America has begun to take up this task The armed forces are preparing to hand back unneeded land-not the airbases, which America must keep if it is to deploy troops quickly in Asia and the Middle East, but housing estates and suchlike. Mr Clinton's visit will also bring the announcement of a scheme to involve Japan more in logistical support for American troops taking part in peacetime military exercises or peacekeeping operations. Japan's sense of involvement with the American forces on its soil ought to be promoted further. Japanese defence officials and diplomats seldom visit America's bases in Japan, and one recent exception to this rule suggests how valuable more exceptions could be. A month ago a group of bigwigs from Tokyo was loaded onto a buggy and driven past endless helicopters, tanks and other war materiel. All they could say was sugoi!, which means, roughly, Wow! They had heard Americans talk of their commitment to Japan. Now they had seen the evidence.
Some Japan hands in Washington discuss the sugoi factor and wonder how they can build on it. But the trouble is that a strong unilateralist strain remains in America's military policy, a tendency as marked in Asia as it was in Bosnia. When Bill Clinton sent aircraft carriers to watch over the Taiwan Strait recently, he did not forewarn the Japanese Left out of American plans, they are hardly likely to feel confident in American protection.
This matters, because Japan's leaders will need to feel more confidence in the alliance if they are to play their part in strengthening it. Japanese voters are even less keen than their American counterparts on expanding their military responsibilities abroad. Polls suggest that most Japanese think it wrong to use force to maintain international law; and that most doubt whether their country's military power will ever match its economic stature If the security treaty is to be modernised, a bold politician will have to look his countrymen in the eyes and demand that they rethink some of their most basic attitudes.
Scary as it may sound, the long-term health of the alliance with America may therefore hinge on Japan's chaotic politics Since 1993, a one-party system has given way to a chaos of competing splinter groups and then to something resembling two-party competition. Over the same three years, the country has been ruled by five different prime ministers. But, out of this mess, something promising has emerged Both the two main parties are led by men who want to expand Japan's responsibilities. These leaders need all the support they can get from their American friends. Mr Clinton's visit next week will be a start. But the finishing point remains distant. 
* "The Case for Deep Engagement". By Joseph Nye. Foreign Affairs July/August 1995. ^ "The Pentagon's Ossified Strategy." By Chalmers)Johnson and EB. Keehn. Foreign Affairs. same issue ^^ "Public Opinion in America and Japan". By Everett Carl Ladd and Karlyn Bowman. AEI Press.

text:
WITH no fewer than 22,000 policemen drafted into Tokyo from all over Japan, Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Japanese prime minister, thought he had done everything possible to prevent demonstrators from spoiling his day with Bill Clinton. Mr Clinton and his entourage arrived in Japan for a three-day state visit on April 16th. But despite the tightest of Japanese security, only a stalled engine prevented an armful of Molotov cocktails from being hurled. The would-be terrorist was arrested before the festivities got under way, when his van broke down outside the Diet (parliament) building.
There were few surprises to come out of Mr Clinton's visit to Japan. The two leaders' joint declaration-reaffirming the importance of the bilateral security alliance-had been heavily trailed for weeks. The only new note struck this week was the joint American-South Korean proposal, issued in South Korea on the first leg of Mr Clinton's East Asian trip, for four-party talks aimed at achieving a formal peace on the Korean peninsula. China has already responded positively. If the North Koreans also give their approval, it may yet be a breakthrough. Japan also has a keen interest in a peaceful Korean peninsula. Evidently caught by surprise, and lacking any concrete proposals from his own flustered bureaucrats, Mr Hashimoto was left calling the four-party idea a welcome start.
With elections looming in both America and Japan, both sides were anxious to avoid any hint of discord or disappointment. A few days before leaving Washington, Mr Clinton made a point of hailing last summer's acrimonious trade negotiations as a momentous success. They had, he claimed, boosted sales of American cars and motor parts in Japan by 35%. In Tokyo, the president went on to say that the 2l trade agreements signed with Japan over the past three years have increased American exports to Japan by 85%.
Behind the scenes, America is still haggling hard over access to Japan's markets for insurance, semiconductors and photographic materials. And there may soon be another row over the White House's determination to renew the ten-year-old semiconductor agreement that guarantees American chip makers at least 2o% of the Japanese market. But, on at least the more visible aspects of trade with Japan, the White House has decided to declare victory and go home.
Mr Hashimoto also has a victory to point to. In agreeing to hand back the huge Futenma air station, along with ten other military bases in Okinawa (some 4,700 hectares all told, 20% of the land used by America on the tiny southern island), Mr Clinton has given the Japanese prime minister a potentially election-winning concession. Mr Hashimoto has sometimes cited Eisaku Sato, a former Japanese prime minister, as his political hero. Sato persuaded the Americans to hand Okinawa back to Japanese control in 1972. Now Mr Hashimoto can also claim to have won back some Japanese territory.
But although this concession may seem to risk weakening the security ties between America and Japan, behind the scenes the Clinton administration has secured significant agreements on issues that America has had on its agenda for years. The most important is a bilateral "acquisition and cross-servicing" agreement that America has been pushing for since 1988. This allows Japan to provide fuel and parts for weapons to American forces during joint exercises and UN peacekeeping operations, and is seen in Washington as the first step towards getting Japan to provide much of the logistics in the event of a crisis in Asia. Such an agreement, if it could be applied in wartime, not just peacetime, would make a huge difference if fighting were ever to break out on the Korean peninsula.
Another important concession from Japan that Mr Clinton can rightly claim as a success-though he probably will not trumpet it too loudly at home-is the tacit agreement that the number of American troops stationed in the country (some 47,000 all told) will not be reduced. Japan has also agreed to foot the bill, estimated at $to billion, for moving elsewhere in Japan the various military facilities that America has agreed to close over the next five to seven years. Just building a new runway at an existing American base, so Futenma's functions can be transferred, is expected to cost Japanese taxpayers nearly $4 billion.
Above all, however, the Americans have won the argument that, with the cold war over, the security alliance between the two countries cannot stay as lopsided as it has been till now. The two governments have agreed to strengthen their military ties, with Japan playing an increasing part in helping to defend itself. Moreover, although Japan still rules out "collective" action, shoulder-to-shoulder with its allies, in pursuit of wider security in the region, the debate inside Japan about the proper, responsible role for its armed forces has been given a new push. With luck this could bring about a further strengthening of East Asia's most important alliance.

text:
THE man on the Asakusa omnibus is no more concerned with the legalities of defending his country's interests abroad than are his counterparts in Brooklyn or Bermondsey. But his political masters act as if they would be thrown out of office if they dared even to hint that Japan should play a bigger role in keeping the peace away from its own shores. After President Bill Clinton's recent visit to Tokyo, which produced an agreement to "realign" the American-Japanese security treaty, Japan's government has suddenly had to face up to the political realities of what it means to be a more equal partner in the pact.
Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister, agreed to study the idea of letting Japan's armed forces provide assistance to America's armed forces in military conflicts outside Japanese territory. No one expects-at least not in the foreseeable future-that Japanese soldiers will be fighting shoulder-to-shoulder with Americans in a war on, say, the Korean peninsula. But it is certainly now possible to imagine refugees disembarking from American military transporters at civil airports in Japan, or American warships being refuelled in Japanese ports.
The agreement signed by the two leaders in Tokyo on April 17th also makes provisions for Japanese and American troops to supply one another with spare parts and fuel (though not ammunition) during military exercises, UN peacekeeping operations and humanitarian missions abroad. Anything more than that, the treaty's critics claim, is forbidden by Japan's constitution. In 1981, the Japanese government chose to interpret the constitution as prohibiting it from engaging in "collective defence"-that is, fighting alongside allies abroad. In reality, the relevant article of the constitution is ambiguous.
Nervous about the political repercussions of his agreement with Mr Clinton, Mr Hashimoto has spent the past week assuring the Diet (parliament) that all discussions on the issue will remain within the framework of the constitution. He went to particular pains to scotch suggestions that any realignment of the joint security treaty would expand the area covered by the pact-from what it just calls the Far East to the whole of the Asia-Pacific region. The term Far East used in the treaty is usually interpreted to mean Japan, Korea, Taiwan, the Philippines and the surrounding seas.
But Yukihiko Ikeda, Japan's foreign minister, has indicated that the interpretation of the words Far East could change with the circumstances. Seiroku Kajiyama, the chief cabinet secretary, has gone further, suggesting that the area covered by the pact with the Americans might easily extend to the South Pacific and South-East-Asia.
Many believe that Mr Hashimoto is underestimating the public's willingness to see Japan shoulder a greater share of the region's security. Commentators in the media love to talk about Japan's "staunch antiwar sentiments". And it is true that the atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki left incurable scars on a generation of Japanese. But for younger Japanese, those events are less potent.
There is an undeniable reluctance to discuss security matters publicly in Japan. But that may have little to do with pacifist sentiment. The Japanese have simply been shielded from such considerations by the existence of a joint security pact. With the Americans guaranteeing their defence and providing all the contingency plans for military threats in the region, the Japanese people have simply got on with life.
But ordinary Japanese might welcome a less timid approach to security. When asked about their feelings in a poll after Mr Clinton's visit, 69% said they were satisfied with the new security arrangement-under which America will close ii military bases and consolidate its forces elsewhere in Japan, while keeping its 47,000 troops in the country. And 49% professed themselves satisfied that the joint security agreement was about to be beefed up to give Japan a wider role and a bigger say in helping to maintain stability in the region.
The findings tally with views that have been expressed increasingly in Japan since the Gulf war. The Japanese took justifiable pride in seeing their minesweepers move into the sea-lanes round the Gulf after the fighting had ended-an action permissible because it was done under the auspices of the UN. Since then, government surveys have continued to find strong support for Japan's participation in UN peacekeeping operations-notably in Cambodia and Mozambique. When asked, three out of four Japanese approve of sending the country's troops abroad.
Mr Hashimoto and his colleagues in the Liberal Democratic Party, the largest member of the ruling coalition, have their reasons for tip-toeing around the security issue. And not just because they believe the topic is taboo. They are governing in coalition with the Social Democrats. a party that until recently opposed the very notion of the American-Japanese alliance. If Mr Hashimoto is too enthusiastic about expanding Japan's role, his government might split and fall. For the supremely po litical Mr Hashimoto, that is reason enough to tread carefully.

text:
LIKE it or not, Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Japanese prime minister, has had to accept that he will have to write a letter of apology, on Japan's behalf, to each of the 300 or so women in South Korea, Taiwan and the Philippines who are claiming compensation for being forced into army brothels during the second world war. More claims may be on the way. Historians reckon that up to 200,000 young women and girls around Asia were put into brothels by the occupying Japanese forces. Many are now dead, but their survivors want compensation and an apology. 
Last July, the previous Japanese prime minister, Tomiichi Murayama, set up an Asian Women's Fund to deal with the problem. Although it has government backing, the fund is formally private. On May 20th, the directors of the fund are to decide how much the compensation should be, and to start making payments soon after. The payouts are expected to amount to 2m ($19,000) apiece, down considerably from the Y3m-4m originally mooted. Mr Hashimoto has been told that, without an accompanying apology from the government, the former sex slaves (euphemistically referred to in Japan as comfort women") have threatened to hurl the money back. 
Pressure on Mr Hashimoto to apologise owes much to the awe of the Miki family name in the Liberal Democratic Party(LDP). As poor as a shrine-sweeper, Takeo Miki, a prime minister in the 1970s, was one of the cleanest people in Japanese politics. His widow, Mutsuko Miki, is viewed (slightly uncomfortably) by LDP members as the epitome of the political standards they feel they ought to be embracing these days. The redoubtable Mrs Miki, who works widely on behalf of women's groups around Asia, recently resigned her unpaid job as a promoter of the Asian Women's Fund, releasing a broadside against Mr Hashimoto and the government for trying to avoid dealing with the issue directly. 
The government's line on Japan's wartime victims has been that all outstanding claims were settled with the signing of a peace treaty with America in 1951 and subsequent treaties signed with Japan's various Asian neighbours. But pressure has been mounting lately for Japan to show some form of tangible-and official-remorse for its army's wartime behaviour. In the Geneva-based International Commission of Jurists urged Japan to pay each of the former comfort women $40,000 in compensation as an interim measure. Then, last February, the United Nations Commission on Human Rights suggested that, apart from compensating the women directly, Japan ought to consider prosecuting any surviving officials involved in recruiting for the brothels and to make the official records public. 
The socialist Mr Murayama not only or-- ganised the Asian Women's Fund; he offered to send personal letters of apology to each survivor. But, since taking over as head of the coalition government in February, the LDP'S Mr Hashimoto has sought to distance himself from the whole business. 
So far, the private fund has collected only V330m, mostly from big business. Though refusing to chip in, the government has actually spent more than 600m in publicising the scheme and providing ministerial staff to run it. It may now have to spend much more. 
Insiders reckon there is little hope of raising privately the Vi billion needed to give the fund even the barest of international credibility. Meanwhile, plans for providing compensation (and apologies) to all the former comfort women, including those in China, Myanmar, Indonesia and the Netherlands, have had to be shelved. In the process, all hopes of keeping the compensation plan quietly unofficial are dwindling fast. 
The talk now among the women's supporters is to start a boycott throughout Asia of Japanese goods. Mr Hashimoto continues his frequent breakfast meetings with Japan's captains of industry in the forlorn hope of getting them to give more, but increasingly it looks as though he will have to do what he has feared most-dig deeply into the public purse to prevent the comfort women from becoming yet another government embarrassment.

text:
THERE have been plenty of black days in recent Japanese banking history. May 24th is likely to be another. That is when the country's ten city (or commercial) banks are due to report their 1995 results. On most estimates, their write-offs of bad loans will total some Y6.2 trillion (($64 billion) and their net losses will be around Y1.7 trillion. When all their results have ben announced by the end of the month, the top 20 banks will probably have written off Y10.8 trillion of duff loans and have announced total net losses of about Y3.3 trillion. 
By increasing their reserves against bad loans, the banks will have at least gone some way to putting their problems behind them. But they are not in the clear yet. For one thing, they are under renewed pressure to contribute more to the cost of liquidating Japan's ailing jusen, or mortgage lenders, because a government plan to spend 685 billion of taxpayers' cash on the firms is blocked by public opposition. On May 10th Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister, added his voice to those urging the banks to put up more cash. 
Worse, despite the massive write-offs, banks' reported level of bad loans will probably not fall. Alicia Ogawa, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, an American investment bank, reckons that it may in fact rise by over 9% because the finance ministry is now widening the definition of bad loans that must be reported to include those for which a bank is providing any form of support for a borrower. 
Nor are banks' profits likely to be as fat next year as this one. At around Y4.2 trillion, operating profits for the past financial year will have been higher than ever before. Most of this profit comes from bond and swap portfolios, whose value has been swollen by extremely low interest rates. As the economy picks up, rates will rise and operating profits will fall. 
And lending is still horribly unprofitable. Given the excess capacity within the industry, this is not surprising. Lending to big companies, which accounts for 30% of domestic loans, now earns banks only oneeighth of a percentage point over their cost of funds; taking into account their various administrative costs, they probably lose money. Yet banks have continued to lend to such firms partly because they think that this cements relationships with them, and partly because it helps them to win other, more profitable sorts of business from the firms' subsidiaries.

text:
THE generals at the Bank of Japan and the Ministry of Finance are anxiously surveying the economy to see if the firepower they deployed last year has at last defeated the country's longest recession since the 1930s. The coming few weeks are crucial: by the end of the summer the money the government threw at the economy to get it moving will have been largely spent. By then, it is hoped, public spending will have been replaced by private-sector and foreign demand. The public sector can do little more; its armoury is almost empty. 
Few doubted the need to help the economy. After the collapse in 199o, it limped along thanks only to large dollops of public cash. Then, last year, consumer confidence was devastated by the earthquake in Kobe, the nerve-gas attack in Tokyo, the crisis in the country's banking system and, above all, the rampant yen. A deflationary abyss lay ahead. 
In September, the Bank of Japan pared official interest rates to o.5%. Together with other central banks, it intervened heavily in the foreign-exchange market to push the yen down. Between March 1995 and May this year, Japan's foreign-exchange reserves soared from $141.5 billion to $208 billion. But the biggest single boost to the economy was the Y9.5 trillion ($88 billion) the government poured into public works last year, the largest fiscal stimulus ever. 
This public cash worked at least some Keynesian magic. In the last quarter of last year,Japan's GDP grew by an annual rate of 3.6%; most economists believe that growth in the first quarter of this year was even stronger. The question is what happens now. The macroeconomic weapons have been used up. Short-term interest rates cannot go much lower; intervention will be less effective now that the yen is more fairly valued and, although some people talk of a Y2 trillion supplementary budget before long, that will probably be the last. The country's finances are in a mess and the government cannot continue to print money.Japan's gross public-sector debt has rocketed from 63% of GDP in 1991 to perhaps 95% this year, and the budget deficit will exceed 6% of GDP in 1996. 
The finance ministry is determined to stop the rot. It is likely to insist on a planned increase in the consumption (sales) tax from 3% to 5% next April, and on the abandonment at the end of the year of an income-tax rebate worth Y2 trillion a year to wage-earners. Russell Jones, chief economist at the Tokyo office of Lehman Brothers, an investment bank, says that borrowing much more to throw at the economy would probably be counterproductive: bond investors would start to fret about the increased risk of default and demand higher interest rates. 
Much, therefore, depends on increased demand from companies and consumers. All eyes will be on a Bank of Japan survey of business confidence, due to be released on June 7th. Some signs are already encouraging. Most indicators for companies' capital spending, such as business confidence and capacity utilisation, are up. Retailers are ringing up stronger sales; companies are starting to hire school-leavers again and, taking advantage of low mortgage rates, people are rushing to buy houses. 
Yet there are still worries. In the final quarter of last year, the latest figures available, consumption grew by a meagre 2% and companies' capital spending by less than 5%. Consumer confidence will continue to be dented by falling land prices and record unemployment, and companies' capital spending by worryingly high stocks. And the yen's recent loss of strength has not dented Japanese companies' eagerness to move production overseas. Against economists' expectations, the visible-trade surplus has continued to fall in the face of a weaker yen: in April it dropped by an astonishing 66%, to Y321 billion. 
Even if enough has been done to rescue the Japanese economy from its trough, it will not be the all-conquering version of the late 1980s. In the years of the bubble economy, the real economy piggy-backed on ludicrously inflated financial-asset prices. When they collapsed, so did the real economy. The late 1990s version will be much less showy; Japan's will look much like any other mature economy. 
To get round the effects of the high yen, high domestic labour costs and trade pressures, big companies have shifted production abroad. Overseas production of Japanese goods is rising by o.5% of GDP a year. This is one reason why Japan's current-account surplus has continued to shrink so dramatically. At some stage these firms will start sacking people in Japan. No longer is it true that what is good for Toyota is good for Japan-or at least for all Japanese. Firms such as Toyota operate on a truly global scale; then there are the rest. The difference between them is growing, partly because companies such as the big car makers are shifting costs on to their smaller domestic brethren and partly because the domestic economy is itself opening up. 
Whether domestic firms will be able to respond to such competition depends on how quickly Japan deregulates. The housing, labour and financial markets, for example, are still coddled by bureaucrats. Even the small amount of deregulation in distribution and retailing, reckons the oEcD, will add o.75% to Japanese GDP over the next five years. The deregulated mobiletelephone industry has expanded beyond anyone's dreams. 
Even deregulation would not bring Japan the heady growth rates it had in the 1970s and 1980s; rather, it might bring the 2-3% typical of other mature economies. And it is still questionable whether politicians have the stomach for change. Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister, does not exude deregulatory fervour. At present, however, the economy is still in the hands of bureaucrats, who are even less keen.

text:
FOR a man whose political life has been spent cutting deals in smoke-filled rooms, Ichiro Ozawa has played his hand badly these past few months. In January, the blunt-talking leader of the New Frontier Party,Japan's biggest opposition group, seemed to hold all the trumps. The new government led by Ryutaro Hashimoto was based on an uneasy alliance between dominant conservatives in the shape of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), a lesser number of socialists (who nowadays call themselves Social Democrats) and a much smaller group, the New Party Sakigake. The government faced the unpleasant task of forcing a bill through the Diet (parliament) to liquidate seven virtually bankrupt jusen, or mortgage lenders, with generous help from the public purse. Since few taxpayers wanted their cash spent in this way, Mr Ozawa had a great opportunity to dish the government-perhaps even to force an early election and grab power. 
Things have turned out rather differ ently. Despite the opposition's efforts, the government at last pushed the jusen bills through the all-important lower house of the Diet on June 7th. Yet far from gaining from its opposition, the New Frontier Party's efforts have backfired. The opinion polls put its popularity at a measly 9%, compared with 35% for the LDP. The cabinet's approval ratings, which fell sharply af ter Mr Hashimoto became prime minister, are now back over 5o%. On present trends, the LDP will romp home in the next election. This will be held, most people now think, late this year or early next. 
The New Frontier Party, on the other hand, is in danger of splintering. If it does, the LDP would probably get the overall majority necessary to restore the unchallenged power that it enjoyed for nearly 40 years before losing office in 1993. 
So what did Mr Ozawa do wrong? Despite his reputation abroad as a reformer this week he was in Europe schmoozing with the great and the good-he was a late convert to the politics of ideas. Until he left the LDP in 1993, he had made his career as a thuggish behind-the-scenes fixer. Many Japanese remain unconvinced by his apparent conversion to loftier principles. 
Everything that Mr Ozawa has done to hold up the jusen bills has reinforced this scepticism. Instead of coming up with a persuasive alternative, his party simply tried to block the jusen package by barring all entry to the committee room in which it was to be discussed. Politics rather than principle also seemed to be behind Mr Ozawa's attempt to single out the LDP's secretary-general, Koichi Kato, for investigation. Mr Ozawa wanted to exploit divisions between the LDP's younger generation, led by Mr Kato, and its old guard. 
The first indication that Mr Ozawa's tactics were failing came at the end of March, when the LDP won a by-election with a thumping majority. The opposition promptly ended its three-week blockade. 
Since then matters have got worse. When Mr Kato eventually appeared before the Diet on June 4th, he simply denied allegations that he had received any donations from companies connected to the jusen This week the jusen package was eventually passed with its V685 billion ($6.3 billion) of public cash intact 
Japanese voters are used to shady politicians. After all, the unholy alliance between the LDP and the socialists hardly oozes principle. But voters also expect politicians to be effective. And whereas Mr Hashimoto has been hobnobbing with President Bill Clinton and can claim some credit as a member of the government that has got the economy moving again, Mr Ozawa, in the eyes of the public, has achieved very little. 
This, added to Mr Ozawa's authoritarian manner, has widened divisions among the three main factions in the New Frontier Party: loyal supporters of Mr Ozawa; a liberal faction led by Tsutomu Hata and Morihiro Hosokawa, two former prime ministers; and some Diet-members connected to the Soka Gakkai, a lay Buddhist movement. 
The Soka Gakkai's importance to the New Frontier Party is that it can deliver both money and votes. Its share of the vote has remained at &to% for the past 50 years. But its parliamentary sympathisers have no particular loyalty to the New Frontier Party and the Soka Gakkai has recently been flirting with the LDP. 
For the time being, though, it is the liberal wing of the New Frontier Party that is most disenchanted with Mr Ozawa. It dislikes his authoritarianism, not to mention his desire to let Japanese troops fight abroad under the United Nations' flag. 
Some of the younger members of the party are keen to set up a new party with likeminded liberals from other parties. Chief rebel is Hajime Funada, a party bigwig until he was obliged to step down in late May for "careless" remarks about his desire to set up a new grouping. Mr Funada may make his move this autumn. 
Yet Mr Funada and other possible defectors from the party, even, potentially, Messrs Hosokawa and Hata, are in no rush. The reason-and this is the best hope for the New Frontier Party remaining intact for a while yet-is that the next general election will be conducted under new rules. The present multi-member constituencies will be replaced by 300 single-member constituencies and 200 seats elected from a party list by proportional representation. Under this new system, a divided opposition might be trounced by the LDP. Mr Ozawa, moreover, has a formidable reputation for winning elections and raising the where withal to do so. 
But Mr Ozawa's critics within the New Frontier Party are becoming more vocal. And the longer that Mr Hashimoto puts off the next election, the harder it will become for Mr Ozawa to hold the New Frontier Party together-and the greater the chance that the LDP will come to see the past three years as merely a blip in its post-war dominance of the political landscape.

text:
TO THE evident surprise of both sides, "soccer diplomacy" has scored its first victory. Unable to choose between Japan and South Korea, FIFA, the world authority for association football, decided in frustration to make the two rival contenders hold the World Cup in 2002 jointly. That created an excuse for Kim Young Sam, the president of South Korea, and Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister of Japan, to hold a two-day meeting to start preparations for the football tournament. 
In fact, sport seems hardly to have been mentioned. But the meeting, held on the picturesque Korean island of Cheju on June 22nd and 23rd, ended with hangovers of the worthiest sort. Asked what they talked about while sharing a bottle or two privately after the official banquet, Mr Hashimoto joked: "I forget:' The two leaders clearly enjoyed the informal get-together. And before going their separate ways, both enthusiastically arranged a return match. The carousing next time is to be in the Japanese mountains. 
What President Kim and Mr Hashimoto, both of whom are known to enjoy the occasional drink, recalled of their working sessions was that they cleared the air on a number of issues that have soured relations between South Korea and Japan lately. Both sides concentrated on rebuilding diplomatic relations that have been battered by a recent storm over the sovereignty of a set of islets, as well as compensation for Korean women who were forced during wartime to become "comfort women" (sexual slaves) for the Japanese army. 
The two leaders confirmed the framework hammered out in Bangkok earlier this year for deciding the boundary between their respective zoo-nautical-mile economic zones. A new fisheries agreement that takes the territorial dispute into account is to be negotiated. Above all, both sides agreed to discuss the future, instead of dwelling on the bitterness that has divided them in the past. But first Mr Hashimoto did what was expected of him and apologised for the brutal way Japan ruled Korea after annexing the country in 191o and to the surviving "comfort women". To set the record straight, the two leaders agreed to finance an authoritative study of Japanese and Korean history. 
Such a study is certainly needed. As recently as 1984, the Japanese government commissioned a study of Japan's history and its relations with Korea that drew heavily on nationalistic fabrications invented during the late 19th century. One of the most popular tales of the time was that the southern part of Korea had been a colony of Japan during the fourth and fifth centuries, while the rest of the peninsula had been ruled by China. Despite being the second-oldest kingdom in the world, with 2,ooo years of unbroken rule under the Cilla, Koryeo and Choseon dynasties, Korea was said to have no historical legitimacy-and Japan therefore had an historical right to reclaim it. 
To this day, Japanese schoolchildren are brainwashed into believing that, historically, Koreans are inferior. Little mention is made of the contemporary view by serious Japanese and western scholars that Yamato (ancient Japan) was settled largely in the fourth century by horse-riding tribes from the Korean peninsula. Even in academic circles, it is still taboo to suggest that the Japanese imperial family is descended from a Korean clan. 
As far as recent history is concerned, the Koreans have taken similar liberties with the truth. The Chinese have complained about distortions in South Korean history books which suggest that the country spread across Manchuria in ancient times. Certainly, for the past half century, schoolchildren in Korea, North and South, have been inculcated with an image of the Japanese as being barbaric, warlike and racist. Worse still, they have failed to show proper gratitude for all the civilising gifts they have received from the Korean peninsula. Korean popular culture has kept alive a sense of outrage about the way the country was treated during colonial times, and fostered a self-righteous sense of animosity towards the Japanese. 
The irony is that the Koreans and the Japanese are cousins-far closer than, say, the British and the French. Though both share common features with other East Asian peoples, especially the Chinese and the Mongolians, there is practically nothing to distinguish the Japanese and Koreans from each other. 
Everyone must play 
If soccer diplomacy forces the Koreans and the Japanese to treat each other with more respect, that will be just as well. There is a pressing need for Japan and South Korea to get along better over the next few years. It may be that, well before soccer fans pour through the turnstiles in 2002, a crisis on the Korean peninsula will oblige Japan and South Korea to co-operate more closely. In the event of the internal collapse of North Korea, or of an attack across the border, South Korea would need swift and solid support not only from its main ally, the United States, but also from its cousin across the East Sea. 
Since President Clinton's visit to Tokyo in April to strengthen the security alliance between America and Japan, Mr Hashimoto and his government colleagues have become painfully aware that Japan will be expected to react if hostilities break out on the Korean peninsula. Korea is the Achilles heel of the American-Japanese security pact, says Ralph Cossa, head of the Centre for Strategic and International Studies' office in Honolulu. A Japanese failure to provide adequate support for American troops engaged in the defence of South Korea would shatter the security treatyand might lead to the political and economic ostracism of Japan. It would be diplomatically out of the question for Japan to keep its 200 or so F-15 warplanes sitting on the ground, while American soldiers were dying on the Korean peninsula. 
So far the Japanese have argued that the South Koreans would not allow them to enter the fray. It is true that the joint declaration issued by President Clinton and Mr Hashimoto after their recent summit meeting in Tokyo has been widely denounced in Seoul. The declaration, emphasising the need for Japanese involvement in emergencies throughout the region, is seen as encouraging Japanese militarism. In the next round of soccer diplomacy, South Korea's President Kim has to kick that one straight into the stands.

Asked what Ryutaro Hashimoto talked about while sharing a bottle or two privately after the official banquet , Mr Hashimoto joked : " I forget : ' Ryutaro Hashimoto clearly enjoyed the informal get - together . And before going Ryutaro Hashimoto's separate ways , Ryutaro Hashimoto enthusiastically arranged a return match . The carousing next time is to be in the Japanese mountains . 
 What Ryutaro Hashimoto , recalled of Ryutaro Hashimoto's working sessions was that Ryutaro Hashimoto cleared the air on a number of issues that have soured relations between South Korea and Japan lately . Both sides concentrated on rebuilding diplomatic relations that have been battered by a recent storm over the sovereignty of a set of islets , as well as compensation for Korean women who were forced during wartime to become " comfort women " ( sexual slaves ) for the Japanese army . 
 Ryutaro Hashimoto confirmed the framework hammered out in Bangkok earlier this year for deciding the boundary between their respective zoo - nautical - mile economic zones . A new fisheries agreement that takes the territorial dispute into account is to be negotiated . Above all , both sides agreed to discuss the future , instead of dwelling on the bitterness that has divided them in the past . But first Mr Hashimoto did what was expected of him and apologised for the brutal way Japan ruled Korea after annexing the country in 191o and to the surviving " comfort women " . To set the record straight , Ryutaro Hashimoto agreed to finance an authoritative study of Japanese and Korean history . 
 Such a study is certainly needed . As recently as 1984 , the Japanese government commissioned a study of Japan 's history and its relations with Korea that drew heavily on nationalistic fabrications invented during the late 19th century . One of the most popular tales of the time was that the southern part of Korea had been a colony of Japan during the fourth and fifth centuries , while the rest of the peninsula had been ruled by China . Despite being the second - oldest kingdom in the world , with 2,ooo years of unbroken rule under the Cilla , Koryeo and Choseon dynasties , Korea was said to have no historical legitimacy - and Japan therefore had an historical right to reclaim it .

Little mention is made of the contemporary view by serious Japanese and western scholars that Yamato ( ancient Japan ) was settled largely in the fourth century by horse - riding tribes from the Korean peninsula . Even in academic circles , it is still taboo to suggest that the Japanese imperial family is descended from a Korean clan .

The Chinese have complained about distortions in South Korean history books which suggest that the country spread across Manchuria in ancient times . Certainly , for the past half century , schoolchildren in Korea , North and South , have been inculcated with an image of the Japanese as being barbaric , warlike and racist . Worse still , they have failed to show proper gratitude for all the civilising gifts they have received from the Korean peninsula . Korean popular culture has kept alive a sense of outrage about the way the country was treated during colonial times , and fostered a self - righteous sense of animosity towards the Japanese . 
 The irony is that the Koreans and the Japanese are cousins - far closer than , say , the British and the French . Though both share common features with other East Asian peoples , especially the Chinese and the Mongolians , there is practically nothing to distinguish the Japanese and Koreans from each other . 
 Everyone must play 
 If soccer diplomacy forces the Koreans and the Japanese to treat each other with more respect , that will be just as well . There is a pressing need for Japan and South Korea to get along better over the next few years . It may be that , well before soccer fans pour through the turnstiles in 2002 , a crisis on the Korean peninsula will oblige Japan and South Korea to co - operate more closely . In the event of the internal collapse of North Korea , or of an attack across the border , South Korea would need swift and solid support not only from its main ally , the United States , but also from its cousin across the East Sea . 
 Since President Clinton 's visit to Tokyo in April to strengthen the security alliance between America and Japan , Mr Hashimoto and his government colleagues have become painfully aware that Japan will be expected to react if hostilities break out on the Korean peninsula . Korea is the Achilles heel of the American - Japanese security pact , says Ralph Cossa , head of the Centre for Strategic and International Studies ' office in Honolulu . A Japanese failure to provide adequate support for American troops engaged in the defence of South Korea would shatter the security treatyand might lead to the political and economic ostracism of Japan . It would be diplomatically out of the question for Japan to keep its 200 or so F-15 warplanes sitting on the ground , while American soldiers were dying on the Korean peninsula . 
 So far the Japanese have argued that the South Koreans would not allow them to enter the fray . It is true that the joint declaration issued by Ryutaro Hashimoto after Ryutaro Hashimoto's recent summit meeting in Tokyo has been widely denounced in Seoul . The declaration , emphasising the need for Japanese involvement in emergencies throughout the region , is seen as encouraging Japanese militarism . In the next round of soccer diplomacy , South Korea 's President Kim has to kick that one straight into the stands .
