text:
SHIN KANEMARU, for ten years the Liberal Democratic Party's most influential power broker, once remarked that politicians should be prepared to "overturn" a bureaucrat's desk at the finance ministry. His implication was that the job of a politician is to bring back pork, in the form of new roads, bridges or railways, to his constituents. Kanemaru was disgraced by scandal in 1992 and has since died, but his dictum is still observed: diligent distribution of cash rather than making speeches about national policy is how Japanese politicians get elected. 
The reform of the electoral system for Japan's lower house was supposed to help put a stop to grubby money politics. Under rules passed by the Diet (parliament) in 1994, multi-member constituencies will be abandoned for the next election, due by July 1997. Would-be members of parliament will fight for 300 single-member constituencies plus zoo seats filled by proportional representation. 
Just how these reforms are to reduce the influence of money in politics has always been a bit unclear. Some people have said that the new constituencies, with getting on for half the number of voters of the old ones, will mean that candidates will not have to spend so much money to secure election. Others have claimed that a candidate will find it impossibly expensive to buy the extra number of voters he needs to win a single-seat constituency. So money will play a secondary role. Candidates, runs this optimistic argument, will have to compete on policies. 
It is true that there are a few more political ideas floating around than there were. Ichiro Ozawa, the leader of the New Frontier Party, the largest opposition group, has some good ideas about deregulating the Japanese economy (though they have singularly failed to grab the attention of most Japanese). Ryutaro Hashimoto has something that journalists are supposed to call vision. But, generally, the political debate in Japan has not noticeably moved to a higher plane. 
It is hard to see how it could have done. In parliament both the main opposition group and the government are uneasy coalitions of parties or groups of very different political persuasions. The government itself is a coalition of conservatives and socialists; their only common principles seem to be gleaned from the writings of Machiavelli. 
So it is largely business as usual. In Japan, this means staying in power by distributing goodies to and generally cultivating the local electorate. Politicians send flowers to the bereaved and cards and presents to newly-weds. They try to find jobs for their constituents. Most important, as Kanemaru pointed out, they do their best to distribute largesse from the central government. 
Many in the Diet, especially but not exclusively those in smaller parties, would now rather the reforms had never taken place; among those with second thoughts, it is believed, is Morihiro Hosokawa, who, as prime minister, pushed them through. Tomiichi Murayama, whose Social Democrats face extinction at the next election, and who preceded Mr Hashimoto as prime minister, made an abortive attempt in June to introduce a bill to reverse the electoral reforms. He will probably try again in October, when the Diet reconvenes. Takayoshi Miyagawa, a political pundit, reckons that around four-fifths of the Diet would support a move back to the old electoral system, or a variation of it. 
The problem for many politicians, but especially for newcomers to the Diet, is that money, far from becoming less important, has become more so. Candidates for the new single-member constituencies have some 75% more voters to consider. With three-fifths of the seats elected by simple majority voting, the risks of not having enough of the stuff are higher. Small parties and newcomers are squealing that they do not have the wherewithal. 
Who does? Generally those with inherited seats. Almost a third (163) of the seats in the present Diet are inherited; 20 years ago the proportion was less than lo%. Of today's 163 seats, io8 are held by Liberal Democrats-which, given that the LDP spent 38 years in power, is perhaps unsurprising (many of the rest are ex-LDP as well). The Japanese sum up the advantages of inherited seats in three words:jiban (control of the constituency organisation); kanban (the value of the family name); and kaban (the money bag). 
Diet members who do not belong to the LDP with its legendary grass-roots machinery, and have not inherited their seats, are panicking. Since selection for some singlemember seats means, inevitably, disappointment for the loser, there are thrilling battles in the LDP itself The best known of these is between two heavyweights: Keizo Obuchi, the right-hand man of Noboru Takeshita, who runs the biggest faction in the Liberal Democrats; and Yasuhiro Nakasone, a former prime minister. Both politicians come from Gunma prefecture. Both are desperate to lay their hands on the nomination for the constituency, since neither wants to suffer the indignity of being elected by proportional representation. Serious scraps for Liberal Democratic nominations are going on in zo other singlemember constituencies. 
The electorate should also be worried. Mr Miyagawa points out that Japan has introduced single-member constituencies twice before: for six general elections after the Diet was set up in 189o, and for two in the 192os. Both times single-member constituencies were subsequently abandoned in favour of multiple ones, partly because of an increase in corruption. In an opinion poll published in April, only 4% of people questioned thought that politics would be better as a result of these changes. 
However, the reforms are unlikely to be reversed. The committee in charge of organising the Diet's agenda is controlled by the LDP. More than any other party, it stands to gain if the new system wipes out smaller parties. All of which means that the Japanese will probably have a general election in the autumn, before the reforms can be reversed. And the LDP is likely to walk it.

text:
The house of Japan's democracy is still only half-built 
TO MOST people these days, good government is three-level business. The bottom level is an intelligent, industrious and incorruptible civil service, entitled to send suggestions and criticisms up to the second level but in the end a dutiful executor of instructions. The second level is a political system of two or more parties, which publicly debate their rival ideas about what instructions the bureaucrats should be given. The top level is the voters, to whom the arguing parties submit the final choice between those ideas. Japan is not yet like this. The ground floor is a hive of zealous activity. But the floor above has never housed the sort of multi-party system now accepted from one end of Europe to the other, in almost all of the Americas and in much of southern Asia. As a result, the top floor is not yet in proper use. The edifice of Japanese democracy is still incomplete. 
Of course, Japan is not a one-party dictatorship. Even before the long-ruling Liberal Democrats seemed to come to pieces in 1993, it had various other parties, regular free elections and a voting system only moderately tilted to the rulers. But for practical purposes it remained a one-party state. This was partly because the other parties were never serious contenders for power. The Socialists and the Communists had retired into separate sub-sections of a Marxist dream-world; the other main political group, Komeito, was less a normal party than a kind of self-help club run by the Soka Gakkai, a lay Buddhist organisation. The voters, happy with the way the Liberal Democrats ran the economy until the 198os, dutifully trooped out to vote for them on election day. It was not unlike the Christian Democrats long supremacy in Italy, during the period when that country's Communists had similarly made themselves unelectable. 
The result was that from 1946 until 1993, except fora brief interlude in 1947-48,Japan's government was in the hands of the parties which in 1955 formally united themselves as the Liberal Democrats. The real struggle for power took place among the various factions of the Liberal Democrats, and in that struggle ideas played a much smaller part than clannish loyalty to one's own faction. 
This had two large consequences. Because the contest for power was a private one, inside the bosom of the Liberal Democrats, the big issues of the day seldom got referred to the voters for their decision. Instead, power moved downwards, as many of the issues lost in the dust of the Liberal Democrats' factional rivalries came to be decided by the civil servants. That is why so much of Japan's legislation has its origins within the ministries, and why the bureaucrats write not only the answers to parliamentary questions, as in other countries, but most of the questions too. If anything, the bureaucrats' power has grown even greater in the confusion that followed the crisis of 1993, when yet another scandal led an assortment of ambitious Liberal Democrats to break away from the party. By other countries' standards, Japan's government remains unacceptably bottom-heavy. 
Back to where they were 
Most people thought three years ago that the splintering of the Liberal Democrats would be the start of a real multi-party system, and that japan could now complete the building of a proper structure of government. It has not happened yet 
Only one group of 1993's ex-Liberal Democrat rebels, the New Frontier Party, still counts for much, and New Frontier is split. Its leader, Ichiro Ozawa, wants an ideas-based two-party system, but not all of his followers agree; worse, this indecisive New Frontier now awkwardly embraces the cautious conservatives of the former Komeito movement, who much prefer the old ways. Meanwhile, the Liberal Democrats, now led by Ryutaro Hashimoto, have manoeuvred their way back into power by means of a coalition with the ex-Socialists, who since the end of the cold war have blandly abandoned not only their name (they are now the Social Democrats) but pretty well all of their Marxist clothing too. The Liberal Democrats do not think that Japan needs an alternation-of-government system; they themselves, they explain, contain "all the relevant differences of opinion". In mid-1996, the government-opposition divide in Japan looks no more like a coherent debate between competing ideas than it has done at any time since 1946. 
Nor will the coming election necessarily break the pattern. The electoral reform of 1994-60% of the seats in the lower house of parliament will now be filled from single-member constituencies, instead of multi-member ones-had been expected to hurt the Liberal Democrats, who possessed the wealth and the links with special-interest lobbies to be able to manipulate the old, big constituencies. On the opposition side, New Frontier has been selecting some attractive young candidates who ought to do well in a first-past-the-post system. Yet the predicted transformation has not arrived. 
The opinion polls stubbornly show the Liberal Democrats ahead of everybody else (see table, right). This year's upturn in the economy helps the government, which may also have overcome the original unpopularity of its plan to use taxpayers' money to rescue those home-loans companies. New Frontier remains divided. A cloud of scandal hovers over the ex-Komeito people. The best current guess is that the Liberal Democrats will therefore be the largest party after the election; New Frontier will be second, but with visible cracks around its component parts, especially Komeito; the Social Democrats will lose heavily, being unlikely to win any of the new singleparty constituencies; the Communists may do quite well, as desperate anti-Liberal Democrats turn to them; and the rest will be mere fragments. 
If this does happen, it will generate its own logic. New Frontier will probably start to break up, as some of its members try to make their peace with the Liberal Democrats. The Social Democrats will either hang on as a powerless appendage to a Liberal Democratic government or retire into irrelevant opposition. The Buddhist political movement could become largely an association of local clubs. The Communists might be the small but still beating heart of the real opposition. In short, the Liberal Democrats would again be the dominant party, and much the same sort of party as before-a collection of uneasily coexisting factions which argue more about jobs than about ideas, and which like to work out their differences behind closed doors. 
There are two views of this prospect, and in the gap between them swings the future of Japan. The Liberal Democrats are naturally delighted, and not just because an election like this would be their revenge for 1993. Such a result would also confirm what most of them see as the special nature of Japanese government. 
Now, tomorrow-or never 
It is "an illusion" to think that Japan will move towards a multi-party system, says Kaoru Yosano, the leader of the party's policy council. The Liberal Democrats can manage things perfectly well by themselves. It is also a mistake to expect the Japanese to organise their politics as a contest between ideas: "You in Europe and America are loyal to ideas, we Japanese are loyal to friendship." Decisions about policy, it is explained, can continue to be reached in the usual way, by confabulation within ministries and then between the top bureaucrats and the politicians. That such decisions would seldom be put directly to the voters should not cause surprise: complicated issues "do not really get across to the people". It is all admirably frank. 
New Frontiers Mr Ozawa, on the other hand, though he accepts that it may take years to change the way things work, believes it has got to happen in the end. A political system organised on the basis of clan loyalty will not be able to take the decisions of the 21st century as swiftly and decisively as will be needed. One-party dominance will lead in Japan as anywhere else to over-confidence and thus to gross error; it has already contributed to the economic mismanagement of the past 15 years. Above all, as ordinary people grow familiar with a society based in other respects on the principle of individual choice, it will be hard to explain to them why the big political decisions should go on being taken by a small club of parliamentarians and bureaucrats. 
If Mr Ozawa himself does not manage the breakthrough, a second attempt will have to be made. There are reform-minded people on the Liberal Democrats' benches as well as the opposition's. Let true radicals from both sides, it is being argued this summer, come together to form a new party of single-minded liberalism, a newer and truer New Frontier. It sounds suspiciously like wishful thinking. But sooner or later something has to be done. Politics has to come out from behind the curtain, so that competing parties can debate before the people the rival merits of free markets and communal solidarity, of efficiency and compassion. 
Curiously, the two sides of this Japanese argument seem to have one thing in common. They both believe that the difficult decisions which Japan needs to take in the next few years, at home and abroad, will be more easily taken if "events" push the Japanese into making up their minds. 
The Liberal Democrats' Mr Yosano thinks that a confrontation in Korea, or another Chinese bullying of Taiwan, might help his party reach an internal consensus-which, if it is still the government, will then be Japanese policy-on doing more to help the Americans in the western Pacific. The reformers of the New Frontier Party wonder whether the "shock of a crisis", within Japan or outside, might accelerate the emergence of a more efficient way of running Japan's politics. It is a strangely passive way of looking at things. Of course, politicians everywhere are glad if events put a wind in their sails; but only in Japan is the notion of leadership, of inviting the people to authorise the necessary action before a crisis actually happens, so diffidently approached. How unfortunate if it took a war in Korea to get the Japanese to wake up to the need for a policy that might have helped to prevent the war. 
There is a further uneasy thought. Many Japanese now accept that it is necessary to move on from what you might call basic democracy to a more mature version. They have had, for half a century this year, freely organised parties and honestly conducted elections. Now these Japanese feel that they should progress to the stage at which those elections are the arena in which big issues are decided, and one party hands over office to another on the basis of what the people think. So they should. The uneasy thought is that, just as Japan is wondering whether to move from Democracy A to Democracy B, other people are starting to wonder whether it is time for Democracy C. 
It is coming to be recognised in other parts of the world that even the best specimens of representative democracy, the B sort, have some dangerous weaknesses. It is not hard for rich lobbyists to bribe susceptible members of the political class. The political class does not necessarily produce as prime ministers or presidents people of the highest intelligence and integrity. It is by no means impossible for imperfect political leaders to deceive the voters, at least for a time. This is the case, it is argued, for moving on from representative democracy to direct democracy, in which most big issues are decided directly by the whole of the electorate, not just by a handful of members of parliament. 
That is how democracy is practised in Switzerland, in some American states, sometimes in Australia and recently, on some major issues, in Europe. The trouble for the Japanese is that, if they at last took the leap to Democracy B just when other people were moving on to Democracy c, they would once again start looking like laggards. 
Will the Japanese complete their democratic structure before the architects change the design? The optimists' answer is that Japanese history is a tale of long periods of inactivity followed by sudden bursts of creative zeal-the renaissance of the 15th century, the Meiji Restoration of the 19th century-and the time may have arrived for another outbreak of innovation. The pessimists' answer is: maybe; but, if Japan misses this chance, its politics is going to look pretty archaic compared with that of the rest of the prosperous world. 
Which takes us back to the question we started with, the question whether or not the various parts of mankind all want to live in the same sort of political house. That needs a closing plunge into the turbulent waters where politics, history and religion come swirling together.

In short , Ryutaro Hashimoto would again be the dominant party , and much the same sort of party as before - a collection of uneasily coexisting factions which argue more about jobs than about ideas , and which like to work out their differences behind closed doors . 
 There are two views of this prospect , and in the gap between them swings the future of Japan . Ryutaro Hashimoto are naturally delighted , and not just because an election like this would be Ryutaro Hashimoto's revenge for 1993 . Such a result would also confirm what most of Ryutaro Hashimoto see as the special nature of Japanese government . 
 Now , tomorrow - or never 
 It is " an illusion " to think that Japan will move towards a multi - party system , says Kaoru Yosano , the leader of Ryutaro Hashimoto's policy council . Ryutaro Hashimoto can manage things perfectly well by Ryutaro Hashimoto . It is also a mistake to expect the Japanese to organise their politics as a contest between ideas : " You in Europe and America are loyal to ideas , we Japanese are loyal to friendship . " Decisions about policy , it is explained , can continue to be reached in the usual way , by confabulation within ministries and then between the top bureaucrats and the politicians . That such decisions would seldom be put directly to the voters should not cause surprise : complicated issues " do not really get across to the people " . It is all admirably frank . 
 New Frontiers Mr Ozawa , on the other hand , though he accepts that it may take years to change the way things work , believes it has got to happen in the end . A political system organised on the basis of clan loyalty will not be able to take the decisions of the 21st century as swiftly and decisively as will be needed . One - party dominance will lead in Japan as anywhere else to over - confidence and thus to gross error ; it has already contributed to the economic mismanagement of the past 15 years . Above all , as ordinary people grow familiar with a society based in other respects on the principle of individual choice , it will be hard to explain to them why the big political decisions should go on being taken by a small club of parliamentarians and bureaucrats . 
 If Mr Ozawa himself does not manage the breakthrough , a second attempt will have to be made . There are reform - minded people on Ryutaro Hashimoto's benches as well as the opposition 's . Let true radicals from both sides , it is being argued this summer , come together to form a new party of single - minded liberalism , a newer and truer New Frontier . It sounds suspiciously like wishful thinking . But sooner or later something has to be done . Politics has to come out from behind the curtain , so that competing parties can debate before the people the rival merits of free markets and communal solidarity , of efficiency and compassion . 
 Curiously , the two sides of this Japanese argument seem to have one thing in common . They both believe that the difficult decisions which Japan needs to take in the next few years , at home and abroad , will be more easily taken if " events " push the Japanese into making up their minds . 
 Ryutaro Hashimoto's Mr Yosano thinks that a confrontation in Korea , or another Chinese bullying of Taiwan , might help Ryutaro Hashimoto's reach an internal consensus - which , if Ryutaro Hashimoto is still the government , will then be Japanese policy - on doing more to help the Americans in the western Pacific . The reformers of the New Frontier Party wonder whether the " shock of a crisis " , within Japan or outside , might accelerate the emergence of a more efficient way of running Japan 's politics . It is a strangely passive way of looking at things . Of course , politicians everywhere are glad if events put a wind in their sails ; but only in Japan is the notion of leadership , of inviting the people to authorise the necessary action before a crisis actually happens , so diffidently approached . How unfortunate if it took a war in Korea to get the Japanese to wake up to the need for a policy that might have helped to prevent the war . 
 There is a further uneasy thought . Many Japanese now accept that it is necessary to move on from what you might call basic democracy to a more mature version . They have had , for half a century this year , freely organised parties and honestly conducted elections . Now these Japanese feel that they should progress to the stage at which those elections are the arena in which big issues are decided , and one party hands over office to another on the basis of what the people think . So they should . The uneasy thought is that , just as Japan is wondering whether to move from Democracy A to Democracy B , other people are starting to wonder whether it is time for Democracy C. 
 It is coming to be recognised in other parts of the world that even the best specimens of representative democracy , the B sort , have some dangerous weaknesses . It is not hard for rich lobbyists to bribe susceptible members of the political class . The political class does not necessarily produce as prime ministers or presidents people of the highest intelligence and integrity . It is by no means impossible for imperfect political leaders to deceive the voters , at least for a time . This is the case , it is argued , for moving on from representative democracy to direct democracy , in which most big issues are decided directly by the whole of the electorate , not just by a handful of members of parliament . 
 That is how democracy is practised in Switzerland , in some American states , sometimes in Australia and recently , on some major issues , in Europe . The trouble for the Japanese is that , if they at last took the leap to Democracy B just when other people were moving on to Democracy c , they would once again start looking like laggards . 
 Will the Japanese complete their democratic structure before the architects change the design ? The optimists ' answer is that Japanese history is a tale of long periods of inactivity followed by sudden bursts of creative zeal - the renaissance of the 15th century , the Meiji Restoration of the 19th century - and the time may have arrived for another outbreak of innovation . The pessimists ' answer is : maybe ; but , if Japan misses this chance , its politics is going to look pretty archaic compared with that of the rest of the prosperous world . 
 Which takes us back to the question we started with , the question whether or not the various parts of mankind all want to live in the same sort of political house . That needs a closing plunge into the turbulent waters where politics , history and religion come swirling together .

text:
TOKYO 
IF RECENT trends are anything to go by, voters in Japan's coming general election seem ready to do what many Italians did in April-embrace their local communist as a rebuke to the mainstream political parties for their broken promises and corruption. The mayoral election in Komae City, in suburban Tokyo, on July 7th has rattled Japan's national politicians. With his pledge to rid the city of corruption, Yutaka Yano, a 47-year-old member of the Japan Communist Party, trounced candidates backed by both the governing and the leading opposition groups. The previous mayor, Sanyu Ishii, disappeared suddenly after resigning in mid-June because of mounting gambling debts (see box). 
The Communist comeback in Japan started the day the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) lost power in 1993 after ruling for 38 years. In the unseemly scramble that followed, the former Socialists (who nowadays call themselves Social Democrats) threw their lot in with a motley crew of conservatives to form a coalition government. Now that the LDP has itself taken control of the coalition, the ultra-clean Communists have emerged stronger than ever as the only non-conservative opposition. 
In last year's election for the upper house of the Diet (parliament), the Communists picked up 9.5% of the poll, mainly from uncommitted voters. According to opinion polls, a record 38% of the electorate is unaligned. With other by-election victories, the Communists now have 14 seats in the 252-seat upper house and 15 in the 511-seat lower house. 
Alarm bells started going off in the LDP's headquarters in February when a Communist in Kyoto's mayor's race lost by a whisker to a candidate backed by five mainstream parties. In March, a Communist candidate in an upper-house by-election in Gifu prefecture tripled his previous vote and came close to beating the LDP. 
The Liberal Democrats were forced to beg help in May from the big battalions of the Soka Gakkai (a lay Buddhist group that backs the rival New Frontier Party) when a Communist candidate looked like stealing the Kurashiki mayor's race-in the backyard of Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Liberal Democrats' leader and Japan's current prime minister. Even then, Mr Hashimoto's man barely squeaked home, with the Communist getting 48% of the vote. That was followed by June's municipal elections in Okinawa, where the Communists increased their seats in the 48-seat assembly from two to four. Since then, grassroots groups have been supporting Communist candidates in local elections across the country. 
What will that mean when Mr Hashimoto dissolves the lower house and calls a general election, expected within the next six months or so? Haruo Arima, the Communists' chief campaign strategist, believes his party could do well. With well-drilled local organisations and pots of money from its daily newspaper, Akahata, and other publications, the party will be able to field 300 candidates-one for each of the new single-seat constituencies. By comparison, the LDP has approved 260 candidates and the New Frontier Party no more than 230 candidates. 
Realistically, the Communists expect to win no more than a dozen or so of the single-seat constituencies (mainly in Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, Fukuoka and other big cities), but to come a close second or third in most of the other single-seat races. With a relatively high proportion of the overall vote in the first-past-the-post part of the election, the Communists would then be in a strong position to pick up a good number-perhaps as many as 35-of the zoo seats to be allocated by proportional representation. All told, the Communists could come out of the general election with some 45-50 seats in the revised soo-seat lower house. If that happened, the Communists would overtake the fractured and demoralised Social Democratic Party, which expects to lose half its 63 lower-house seats. 
The Communists are winning supporters by refusing to compromise on such issues as the use of public money to liquidate the bankrupt jusen mortgage companies or to raise the consumption tax from 3% to 5% The party still holds quaintly naive views about defence and Japan's security treaty with America that continue to put many voters off But like Italy's Communistswho built their reputation on running local government cleanly and efficiently-the Japan Communist Party is at least beginning to show that it, too, is ready to trade some of its theoretical idealism for a bit of messy politics.

text:
Thunderous 
Responsibility for the Atlanta bomb, which killed two people and injured hundreds, increasingly seemed to lie at home. Painstaking recovery of the wreckage of TWA flight 800 revealed no hard evidence but a firmer belief that a bomb destroyed the aircraft. Bill Clinton and congressional leaders agreed that more must be done to prevent terrorism; and the Group of Seven countries plus Russia promised to draft by November a treaty to make terrorist bombing an international crime. 
Changing 60 years of political history, Mr Clinton at last signed the Republicans' bill that abolishes automatic welfare entitlements for Americans. Welfare will now be a "second chance", not a "way of life". 
After 5 1/2 years as Argentina's globally respected economics minister, Domingo Cavallo was replaced, as pressure grew for less austerity and more growth. The job went to the-equally orthodox-central-bank president, Roque Fernandez. Policy would not change, he said, to financial markets' relief. But trade unions said a general strike already called for August 8th would go ahead. 
Fly-past 
Turkish MPS voted to let American warplanes continue to fly from bases in Turkey to protect Kurds in northern Iraq after Necmettin Erbakan, the new Islamist prime minister, reversed his earlier opposition to Operation Provide Comfort. 
A 69-day hunger strike by political prisoners in Turkey, in which 12 people died, ended after the government met some of the prisoners' demands. 
An American envoy, John Kornblum, went to Bosnia and won an agreement to strengthen the Muslim-Croat Federation. He also wanted to ensure that Radovan Karadzic has kept his pledge to step down as leader of Bosnia's Serbs. The European Union threatened to pull its mission out of the town of Mostar unless Croats there accept the results of municipal elections, won by Muslims. 
Pravda ("Truth"), founded by Lenin and as hardline as ever, was closed by its Greek owners. They accused the paper's journalists of drinking too much and of partisan reporting. 
Members of the European Union have failed to use 20 billion ecus ($25 billion) of aid available for poor regions, according to a commission report, with Italy the worst performer. Many governments are trying to meet targets for economic and monetary union and have difficulty matching EU contributions. Budget ministers, meanwhile, agreed to cut 2.5 billion ecus ($3.2 billion) from the European Union's budget next year. 
Spain announced increases in taxes on tobacco and alcohol to cover an unexpected shortfall of 721 billion pesetas ($5.7 billion) in last year's public accounts. 
The European Commission proposed the slaughter of up to 2m calves to support beef prices, which collapsed after mad-cow disease was linked to people. Part of the 2 billion ecu ($2.5 billion) cost would come from cutting subsidies to cereal farmers. A British study indicated that BSE could be passed from cows to their calves. 
African action 
East African leaders, meeting in Tanzania, agreed to impose full economic sanctions on Burundi. They called on Pierre Buyoya, Burundi's new military leader, to restore the constitution, parliament and political parties-but stopped short of demanding the reinstatement of President Ntibantunganya, ousted last week. Mr Buyoya, a Tutsi, made a bid to end the ethnic fighting by appointing a Hutu prime minister. 
In northern Uganda, armed members of the Lord's Resistance Army cult were reported to have killed 6o villagers and 40 soldiers. 
Fifteen commuters were killed in a stampede at a railway station near Johannesburg during a crackdown on people travelling without tickets. 
Lebanon's president put an end to speculation that a Lebanese-Israeli peace might precede a Syrian-Israeli one. An Israeli news report said a Syrian envoy had visited Jerusalem. 
The Palestinian Authority, having helped the Israelis find the body of an Israeli soldier murdered by Hamas seven years ago, appealed to Israel's prime minister to free Sheikh Ahmed Yassin, the wheelchair-bound cleric imprisoned for life for ordering the killing. A Palestinian died after apparent torture in a West Bank prison. 
Testing 
China conducted a nuclear test and then said it would call an indefinite halt to all further tests. The announcement coincided with the reopening in Geneva of talks aimed at completing a worldwide ban on future tests. Both India and China continue to express reservations about the proposed draft text. 
Troops killed at least three people in Jakarta, the Indonesian capital, after riots broke out. The cause of the disturbance was a government decision to evict supporters of Megawati Sukarnoputri, an opposition leader, from the headquarters of the political party she had led until recently. 
Benazir Bhutto, the prime minister of Pakistan, said she would appoint her husband to the cabinet, as part of a government reshuffle. 
China protested after Ryutaro Hashimoto, Japan's prime minister, made a visit to a shrine commemorating Japan's war dead.

text:
TOKYO 
JAPANESE people have just about got used to the idea that the "bubble economy" of the late 1980s left them with a mountain of debt. This year the most controversial political issue in Japan has been the government's effort to liquidate seven failed housing loan companies (jusen) using Y685 billion ($6.3 billion) of taxpayers' money. But next year, an even bigger bailout looms. Paying off the debts accumulated by the now defunct Japan National Railways JNR) is going to cost taxpayers more than Y20 trillion-equivalent to Y160,000 for every person in the country. By contrast, the jusen cost the Japanese a mere Y5,soo apiece. 
Yet the most worrying prospect of all is that Japan's debt problems may amount to far more than a short-term crisis, brought about by a speculative bubble. Increasingly, the Japanese are having to recognise that inadequate government finances, combined with a rapidly ageing population (see chart on next page), are leaving them looking into a big black hole of future debts. 
Among all the big rich countries, Japan shares with Italy the dubious distinction of being in the worst financial state. Its public debts now amount to more than Y500 trillionequivalent to a year's gross domestic product. Unfunded pension commitments threaten to push this debt to new and unsustainable levels early in the next century. Last year Japan's budget deficit was equivalent to 3.9% of GDP. However, a recent study by the OECD, the Paris-based economic club for wealthy countries, concluded that rising pension spending could give Japan a budget deficit equal to zo% of GDP by 2030. That made Japan substantially worse off than Italy, which was expected to have a 12% budget deficit by then. Until Japan displaced it, Italy was thought to have the least sustainable pension system among the OECD countries. Now Japan takes that title. 
The problem starts and stops with the speed at which Japan is greying. Although still among the younger of the OECD countries, with only 14% of its population aged 65 or over, some 26% are likely to fit that description by 2025.Japan will then have a higher proportion of elderly people than any other country in the world, including even Germany and Sweden. And although today there are still 5.1 people who are working and contributing to national pension schemes for every person collecting an old-age pension, by 2025 there are likely to be only 2.4 workers per pensioner. 
The implications are clear. Either the pension contributions that working people make will have to rise from today's 16.5% of salary to around 35% by 2025, or pensioners will have to accept far lower benefits. As in most things, the outcome is bound to be a bit of both. 
The government believes it would be political suicide to allow pension contributions to rise above 30%. It has devised a schedule for inching them up gradually over the next three decades to a maximum of 29.6%. The premiums are set to rise to 17.4% in October and will then go up by 2.5 percentage points every five years. 
Surprisingly, the government has managed to sell this idea to employers, who pay half of the pension contributions. Normally, the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), the main force in Japan's coalition government, would do anything to avoid antagonising its paymasters in big business. Although the union-backed socialists (who nowadays call themselves Social Democrats and share power with the LDP) have had no objections to getting employers to stump up more, they have fought hard to prevent benefits from being scaled back or deferred. The deal struck has been to raise the mandatory retirement age from 60 to 65, starting early in the next century. 
The only problem is that this runs counter to trends in the labour market. Rather than keeping their employees on until they are a ripe old age, Japanese firms have started pressuring them to retire earlier. Where once it was only blue-collar workers who were bullied into retiring early, now white-collar staff are finding it increasingly difficult to stay on until the official retirement age. By the time they are 54 or so, managers are expected to leave and make room for younger and cheaper staff. Life becomes increasingly difficult for those who refuse. 
And so expectations and livelihoods are changing fast. Whatever the cherished beliefs of many foreigners, the whole notion of lifetime employment and seniority-based pay has nothing to do with some deeply rooted Japanese traditions. The arrangement was adopted in Japan only after the second world war. 
It is a characteristic of large and steadily expanding firms everywhere-as exemplified by IBM and AT&T in America prior to the 198os. "If the Japanese economy cannot achieve the growth rates necessary, then such systems will probably collapse in the next four or five years," says Akira Esaka, an author and observer of the corporate scene. 
Making matters worse, a large and growing number of Japanese firms are burdened with seriously under-funded private pension schemes themselves. Last year, an electronics giant, NEC, had to invest the equivalent of 109% of its net profit in its pension fund. Four years earlier, it was setting aside less than 3o% of its profits for pensions. 
Actuaries reckon that corporate pension funds in Japan need a 5.5% annual return on their portfolios to keep pace with rising costs. Of late, however, few of them have been breaking even. Meanwhile, they will have to adopt a more accurate form of accounting next year that will send the value of their pension funds plungingand, in turn, put still greater strain on the state-run schemes. 
As the government sweats its way through the summer, public criticism over the country's financial mess is set to worsen. Next April, the government is scheduled to increase the consumption tax from 3% to 5%. Under normal circumstances, that might be regarded as a sensible measure to put the country's finances on a sounder long-term footing. But it is quite likely that it will get confused with the bail-out of the railways, and so be denounced as yet another handout to special interests. 
With the scandal of the railway debt about to hit the headlines and the uproar over the coming devaluation of the corporate pension plans promising to be deafening, it is little wonder that Ryutaro Hashimoto, Japan's prime minister, now wants to dissolve the Diet and call an election sooner rather than later. His efforts this summer to sell the increase in the hugely unpopular consumption tax as a way of easing the country's burgeoning pension crisis, could well be a decisive factor when voters go to the polls this autumn.

By the time they are 54 or so , managers are expected to leave and make room for younger and cheaper staff . Life becomes increasingly difficult for those who refuse . 
 And so expectations and livelihoods are changing fast . Whatever the cherished beliefs of many foreigners , the whole notion of lifetime employment and seniority - based pay has nothing to do with some deeply rooted Japanese traditions . The arrangement was adopted in Japan only after the second world war . 
 It is a characteristic of large and steadily expanding firms everywhere - as exemplified by IBM and AT&T in America prior to the 198os . " If the Japanese economy can not achieve the growth rates necessary , then such systems will probably collapse in the next four or five years , " says Akira Esaka , an author and observer of the corporate scene . 
 Making matters worse , a large and growing number of Japanese firms are burdened with seriously under - funded private pension schemes themselves . Last year , an electronics giant , NEC , had to invest the equivalent of 109 % of its net profit in its pension fund . Four years earlier , it was setting aside less than 3o% of its profits for pensions . 
 Actuaries reckon that corporate pension funds in Japan need a 5.5 % annual return on their portfolios to keep pace with rising costs . Of late , however , few of them have been breaking even . Meanwhile , they will have to adopt a more accurate form of accounting next year that will send the value of their pension funds plungingand , in turn , put still greater strain on the state - run schemes . 
 As the government sweats its way through the summer , public criticism over the country 's financial mess is set to worsen . Next April , the government is scheduled to increase the consumption tax from 3 % to 5 % . Under normal circumstances , that might be regarded as a sensible measure to put the country 's finances on a sounder long - term footing . But it is quite likely that it will get confused with the bail - out of the railways , and so be denounced as yet another handout to special interests . 
 With the scandal of the railway debt about to hit the headlines and the uproar over the coming devaluation of the corporate pension plans promising to be deafening , it is little wonder that Ryutaro Hashimoto's , now wants to dissolve the Diet and call an election sooner rather than later . Ryutaro Hashimoto's efforts this summer to sell the increase in the hugely unpopular consumption tax as a way of easing the country 's burgeoning pension crisis , could well be a decisive factor when voters go to the polls this autumn .

text:
DESPITE government promises of fat subsidies, the good citizens of Maki, a town of 30,ooo people on the coast of the Sea of Japan in Niigata prefecture, decided last week that, no, they did not want a nuclear power station in their backyard. And no, damn it, they were not going to provide the land that the electricity company had been badgering them to sell. 
In Japan's first municipal referendum on nuclear power, residents in Maki voted by three to two on August 4th to do without the much-needed jobs and public works rather than live in fear of an accidental release of radiation. "This town's future direction does not include co-existence with a nuclear power plant," declared Takaaki Sasaguchi, mayor of Maki. Mr Sasaguchi was voted into office in January after promising to hold a plebiscite on the issue. The previous mayor resigned when angry townspeople accused him of pandering to the nuclear industry. 
Five municipalities across Japan have now passed by-laws requiring a referendum to be held on nuclear proposals affecting their towns. Public confidence has been shattered by the engineering blunders that led up to-and the official bungling that followed-last December's leak at Monju, the country's experimental fast-breeder reactor in Fukui prefecture. Though no radiation was released and no one was killed, three tons of liquid sodium burst from Monju's cooling pipes and came perilously close to exploding. So appalled was a safety officer investigating the incident that he committed suicide. 
The central government retains its enthusiasm for nuclear power. It wants to raise the proportion of electricity generated by nuclear means from 31% today to 42% in zo. Central to its plans is the construction of a dozen new reactors along the coast where they can get access to cooling water. Since 1983, the Tohoku Electric Power Company has been seeking to build an 825-megawatt boiling-water reactor on the coast at Maki, the first of four planned for the site. Initially, construction was held up because the town refused to sell the power company a piece of land it needed for building the reactor's core. Since last weekend's referendum, with its decisive turnout of 88%, Mr Sasaguchi has sworn that the land will never change hands-at least, not during the four years that he is mayor. 
For the government in Tokyo, the vote in Maki smacks too much of direct democracy-a worrying challenge to the central authorities. "Building nuclear power plants is a matter of state policy and holding a referendum on it is unsuitable for such policy," huffed the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. 
More shocks await the government. The prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, is embroiled in a legal battle with the governor of Okinawa over the renewal of some 3,ooo leases covering American military bases on the southerly island. As a challenge to the central authorities, the governor has now called a referendum for September 8th so Okinawans can express their feelings about the bases. Outrage at the noise from warplanes and artillery ranges was reinforced by last year's rape of a Japanese schoolgirl by three American soldiers. 
Mr Hashimoto is to devote most of the coming parliamentary session to trying to resolve the bases issue. But if the citizens of Okinawa behave as single-mindedly over American bases as their cousins in Maki have done over nuclear power, a goodly chunk of Mr Hashimoto's foreign policy could go up in smoke. And with it could go his chance of a second term in office.

text:
HIS taste for traditional kendo fencing gear should have given a clue. But it is only in recent weeks that the Japanese prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, has begun to reveal himself as something more than a mere closet militarist. In late July he visited the controversial Yasukuni shrine in Tokyo-the first time in 11 years that a Japanese prime minister had paid homage to the country's military heroes there. There were protests from China, the Koreas and other Asian countries that suffered from the imperial army's atrocities. They were to be expected. What was not was the extent to which the prime minister is willing to pander to the Liberal Democratic Party's militarists. 
During the 1930s and 1940s, the Yasukuni shrine served the state by glorifying and justifying war-offering the chance to be enshrined in sacred soil to those willing to die for the emperor. To the country's nutty fringe of jingoistic nationalists, it still does. Today, as well as being dedicated to the souls of the war dead, it is the resting place of a number of war criminals who were hanged by the Allies after the second world war. As such, the shrine is both a war memorial and a monument to fascism. Any visit by a Japanese leader to Yasukuni is bound to be seen by many people as offensive. 
Such an error was made in 1985 when that old militarist, Yasuhiro Nakasone, was prime minister. Afterwards, he had some painful fence-mending to do with Asian countries. Mr Hashimoto says that his was a private visit-to celebrate his 59th birthday, as well as to commemorate a cousin who was killed during the war. But he went to the shrine in his limo and was accompanied by the usual crew of security guards. He signed the shrine's visitors' book using his title of prime minister. Mr Hashimoto knows well that, outside the home, there is no such thing as a private life for a politician. 
Some Japanese believe that Mr Hashimoto aimed simply to embarrass the Social Democratic Party (SDP). It was the socialists who caused an uproar when Mr Nakasone made his official visit to the shrine. Now that they are in the ruling coalition, the SDr's leaders have been chary about criticising Mr Hashimoto and the Liberal Democratic Party, fearing that he might call an election before they are ready. By flaunting their impotence this time, Mr Hashimoto has been able to settle old scores and leave his party's traditional rivals more splintered than ever. 
There is doubtless some truth in this interpretation. But it is equally true that Mr Hashimoto is keen to bend the rule that has forbidden official visits to Yasukuni by cabinet members. He was chairman of the War Bereaved Families Association of Japan and has led a Diet members' group that visits the shrine. By making his own formal visit in late July, the prime minister has opened the door for the rest of his cabinet colleagues to pay their official respects on August 15th. Apart from being the anniversary of Emperor Hirohito's announcement of the country's unconditional surrender, that is the day that Japan each year quietly mourns its fallen heroes and much more.

text:
TOKYO 
OKINAWANS have the lowest income per person in Japan and more than twice the national rate of unemployment. With a Caribbean-like economy of sugar cane and tourism, they rely on subsidies, tax concessions and other handouts from the central government in Tokyo for almost 80% of the island's revenues. Some 7,800 Okinawans are lucky enough to have wellpaid jobs at the American bases on the island. A few local landowners get paid over the odds for leasing their plots to the Americans. Now the lot of the remaining 1.3m people in Okinawa may improve, providing they act cannily. 
Come August 28th, the Supreme Court in Tokyo is due to rule on a petition brought by the governor of Okinawa, Masahide Ota, on whether the government can force people to lease their land against their wishes. This will be followed on September 8th by a referendum called by the governor to ask Okinawans whether they would prefer to have fewer American bases on the island, which is at present home to more than half the 47,000 GIS in Japan. Though the plebiscite is non-binding, a Yes would send an unwelcome message to the government in Tokyo. 
The bases are a nice source of income for locals, but they are also a noisy nuisance and occupy 20% of the island's land. On balance, most Okinawans would probably prefer to see fewer bases-provided there was something to replace them. They want a new port, a free-trade zone and more subsidies to encourage tourism. 
The rape of an Okinawan schoolgirl by three American soldiers last year, which created outrage across Japan, has given Mr Ota some leverage to demand benefits from the central government. He refused to accept a ruling in March by the local high court, ordering him to sign documents that would allow the central government to take over land used by the bases when their leases expire. The Supreme Court, which tends to follow the government line, is expected next week to order him to do precisely that. 
One quirk the court will have to deal with is that the land leased to the Americans is owned by some 3,000 people, of whom 2,900 are hito tsubo jinushi-owners of plots of 3.3 square metres or less, some no bigger than 90 square centimetres, much less than the size of this page. Many of these "landlords" do not live in Okinawa, and acquired their tiny plots in the hope of forcing the Americans to leave, and thus undermining Japan's security alliance with the United States. 
With a general election approaching, the prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, is keen to avoid trouble. A deal is taking shape designed to buy off the governor and his supporters. But if the Okinawans are too greedy, Mr Hashimoto may decide to call an early general election. Pundits have pencilled October 27th in their diaries. Though Mr Hashimoto's Liberal Democrats might not win an overall majority, they would be certain (under new electoral rules) to gain seats from the Social Democrats (former Socialists), the odd bedfellows in the present coalition government. A tougher, more conservative government in Tokyo-bent on cementing Japan's recently enlarged security deal with America-would have scant time for demanding Okinawans.

text:
Direct investors from Asia are having a big impact in other emerging markets. A look at Latin America first; in the next piece, South Africa 
FOR decades, Latin America's protectionism and stratospheric inflation kept Asian investors away. The only serious Asian money in the region came from the Japanese, who saw it chiefly as a source of raw materials. Now Japanese investment in Latin America is waning-it has fallen to $4 billion a year, from a peak of$6.3 billion in 1988. Happily, as Japanese investment has dwindled, investment from the rest of Asia is on the rise. 
Until recently, such investment has been tiny-under $i billion a year to all Latin America. But it is now growing fast. This year South Korean firms have already announced plans to spend ten times as much during the next three years as they spent in 1991 (when they invested $17om. Taiwan's $8oom stock of investment in the region rose by a tenth last year. 
Leading the charge are South Korea's huge conglomerates, the chaeboL Samsung recently announced that it would spend $i billion over five years to expand its production of television sets and white goods in Brazil and Mexico. Last year, South Korea's Kia opened a $soom car-making plant in Brazil. Daewoo and Hyundai, two other chaebol, are considering investing $soom apiece to set up regional manufacturing centres in Brazil, as well as smaller sums in Colombia and Venezuela. More is on the way: South Korea's president, Kim Young Sam, is bringing the chairmen of the 30 biggest chaebol to Latin America in early September to promote investment. 
Smaller Asian companies are also doing business in the region. In April Bank of Boston, a New England bank, opened a trade-finance centre in Hong Kong to help smaller companies from South-East Asia and China tap into the Latin American market. Bahia, in north-eastern Brazil, is hoping to attract $15om in investment from 80 or so Taiwanese makers of plastics, toys and other cheap goods, for an industrial park improbably called Shangri-La. (Taiwan is also sponsoring a similar $Isom project in Paraguay.) Pusan, South Korea's second city, recently opened its first overseas trade office in Miami-considered the Latin business capital-to help small firms boost trade with Latin America. 
Why this new Asian interest? Some of it reflects assiduous Latin American wooing. In the past year, half a dozen Latin American presidents have visited China, whose $6 billion trade with the region is growing by 30% a year. To some extent, investment is following trade, which grew healthily in the early 199os (see chart). This year, Chile's trade with Asia will overtake its trade with the United States (which has long dominated trade with the region). Chile and Mexico have fought their way into full membership of APEC, the broad Asia-Pacific club; Peru and Colombia are now clamouring to join them. 
Some Asian investment is going, as it has always done, into commodities: China has put some $5oom into Peruvian mining, and Asian timber firms have acquired the right to exploit several million hectares of virgin forest in Guyana and Surinam. But the motives to invest look increasingly diverse. Mexico's devaluation of the peso has lured in several Asian firms. Two big Taiwanese manufacturers-Nien Hsing, a textile firm, and css, which makes batteriesplan to spend $8om between them to build factories in Mexico. 
In through the back door 
Another attraction is the easy access Latin America provides to the giant market of the United States. Once South Korean and Taiwanese textile and toy makers fill the import quotas allotted by the Americans to low-wage countries such as Thailand and Indonesia, they look to assembly plants in Latin America for back-door access. In Tijuana, a quarter of the employment generated by maquiladoras-assembly plants that have preferential tax and tariff treatment-comes from Asian-owned firms. Half of Taiwan's investment in the region is concentrated in maquiladoras in Central America and the Dominican Republicnot coincidentally, among the few countries with which It has formal diplomatic relations. 
But Latin America, which of $i.6 trillion, also combined GDP of $1.6 trillion, a juicy market in its own represents a juicy market in its left consumright Liberalisation has hungry for durable goods, says Seers hun Edwards, a professor at theUniversity of California, Los helped companies such les. That has helped companies computer as Acer, which has grabbed computer Mexican market and has grabbed 30% of the over $3oom across Latin American market and has sales of over $3oom across talk of expanding America. the chaebol's now-paltry sales talk of expanding electronics in the chaebol's now-paltry sales $z billion a year, which would in the region to $2 billion market share, within 5 years. 
If a bevy of trade agreements continues to bring down barriers, firms will have a powerful incentive to set up regional manufacturing bases. For example, Mexico's sweeping free-trade accord with Chile has persuaded both Samsung and Japan's Nissan to ship products from Mexico to serve the distant-but tariff-free-Chilean market. 
On the other hand, residual trade barriers still benefit certain producers. Samsung claims that its Mexican-made television sets sell in Mexico city at a premium of more than lo% over their price north of the border. No wonder the company finds Latin America, which accounts for 11% of its global sales, to be highly profitable. 
Still cause for worry 
Two obstacles could slow the Asian advance. First, Asian managers still worry about Latin languor. Kader, a Hong Kongbased toy maker, complains about the poor work ethic of workers at its Mexican site. Doulton, a Chinese textile firm that has set up shop in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula, is reluctant to use local inputs. To teach its Mexican managers Asian values, Acer flies them to Taiwan. South Korea's Samsung is paying some of its Asian suppliers to set up shop around its Latin American factories. Other Asian firms are training local suppliers to meet quality standards and to organise just-in-time deliveries. 
A greater obstacle is the tendency to appease domestic lobbies by putting hefty tariffs on Asian imports. The most troubling signs of backsliding have come from Brazil. Last year, just hours after its trade minister had promised a Japanese delegation that Brazil would not increase tariffs on imported cars, they were more than doubled, to 7o%. Japan's prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, has lodged a complaint with the World Trade Organisation, and will no doubt take up the matter with Brazilian of ficials during his visit to the region this week. Meanwhile, an angry Toyota put off its planned investment for a year.

Other Asian firms are training local suppliers to meet quality standards and to organise just - in - time deliveries . 
 A greater obstacle is the tendency to appease domestic lobbies by putting hefty tariffs on Asian imports . The most troubling signs of backsliding have come from Brazil . Last year , just hours after its trade minister had promised a Japanese delegation that Brazil would not increase tariffs on imported cars , they were more than doubled , to 7o% . Ryutaro Hashimoto's , has lodged a complaint with the World Trade Organisation , and will no doubt take up the matter with Brazilian of ficials during Ryutaro Hashimoto's visit to the region this week . Meanwhile , an angry Toyota put off its planned investment for a year .

The Bosnian president, Alija Izetbegovic, called for a Muslim boycott of the Bosnian municipal elections which Serbs plan to hold on September 14th. The Organisation for Security and Co-oper ation in Europe, charged witt supervising the Bosnian elections, said it was postponing the official municipal poll be cause of alleged irregularities, though other votes would go ahead that day as scheduled. 
Russia's ailing president, Boris Yeltsin, went on holiday to a resort near Moscow. He refused two requests from Alexander Lebed, his special representative for Chechnya, for a meeting to discuss Mr Lebed's Chechen peace plan. Russian troops continued to withdraw from Chechnya's capital, Grozny, leaving it to separatist rebels. 
Estonia's parliament failed to elect a new state president. Neither the reformist incumbent, Lennart Meri, nor his ex-communist rival, Arnold Ruutel, could muster the twothirds majority needed, despite three rounds of voting. 
A conference opened in Stockholm on the international sexual exploitation of children. The search continued for the bodies of young victims of sex abuse in Belgium. 
The Danish Supreme Court agreed to allow ii citizens to bring a constitutional challenge to Denmark's signature of the Maastricht treaty. The case may take four years. Until it is resolved, Denmark is unlikely to ratify amendments to the treaty being discussed by the EU'S inter-governmental conference. 
After hunger strikes and a two-month protest, 300 illegal immigrants, mostly from Africa, were evicted from a Paris church in an operation involving tear gas, batons and 1,000 police officers. 
The hijacking of a Sudanese airliner on a flight from Khartoum to Amman ended at London's Stansted Airport with the release of all passengers and crew. The Iraqi hijackers and their families were taken into custody. 
Heads will roll 
Two former presidents of South Korea were sentenced for their roles in a military coup and a massacre in Kwangju in 1980. Chun Doo Hwan was sentenced to death and Roh Tae Woo to 22 1/2 years in jail. Government critics said the two men had been put on trial to boost political support for President Kim Young Sam. 
Yakio Hatoyama, a member of New Party Sakigake, part of Japan's ruling coalition, said he was resigning to form a new party that would stand for "real democracy". 
Prosecutors arrested Takeshi Abe, the ex-head of Japan's AIDs-study team, for allegedly administering untreated blood products to haemophiliacs even though he knew that these might lead to AIDS. About 1,800 haemophiliacs have been infected with HIV, the virus that leads to AIDS, of which more than 400 have died. 
Four members of an opposition party in Singapore faced jail after being accused by the government of "contempt of Parliament". They had allegedly lied about the cost of the state's health care. 
More than 200 pilgrims to a shrine at Amarnath in the Himalayas died in bad weather. The shrine has a naturally formed ice phallus of Shiva, a Hindu god. 
Inroads 
Israel's government approved further Jewish settlement-building ("unfreezing a plan accepted by the Rabin government", it said), and allowed the demolition of a Palestinian community centre under construction ("without a permit") in East Jerusalem. "Declaring war" on the Palestinians, cried Yasser Arafat, calling a half-day shutdown in the West Bank and Gaza. 
Turkey and Israel, already linked by an agreement on air-force training, signed one for co-operation between their defence industries. 
The Zimbabwean government offered a 20% pay rise to thousands of civil servants whose strike since August 20th had disrupted the country's essential services. 
A former senior South African security policeman, Eugene de Kock, was convicted on 89 charges, including six of murder, by a court in Pretoria after a trial lasting two vears. 
Making tracks

The Defence Department denied that it had intentionally quashed a 1991 classified report, revealed in the New York Times, suggesting that American troops were exposed to Iraqi chemical weapons during the Gulf war. But it said the full relevance of the report had not been recognised at the time. 
Foreign oil companies in Colombia were rattled by a proposal in the country's Congress for changes whichsaid the foreigners-would make them little more than contractors for the state oil company. Then the interior minister said it was ready to talk about anything, oil nationalisation included, that might bring peace with "leftwing" guerrillas who demand just that and sabotage pipelines to prove it. 
Japan embarked on a love-in with Latin America. After Mexico, Chile and Brazil, its prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, visited Peru to sign a $615m loan deal, before flying to Costa Rica.

text:
IN A twice-weekly ritual, Beijing's corps of intrepid foreign journalists gather for a briefing by a spokesman for China's foreign ministry. Adept at fending off awkward questions and well-versed in China's official line, the spokesman seldom says anything surprising. But now these briefings are to become more challenging for the briefed (and unintelligible for the many who speak little Chinese): the ministry is doing away with English interpretation. This change coincides with a flurry of others designed to encourage the study of Chinese abroad, and a series of shrill commentaries in the official press demanding that the language of a rising China be given its due. 
"Because of poverty and weakness over a long period in contemporary China, people have failed to attach due importance to China's culture, history and language," the People's Daily, mouthpiece of the Communist Party, intoned this month. The state-run China Daily, which publishes in English and will presumably continue to do so, reported that more than 1,000 institutions of higher learning in 60 countries have established Chinese-language programmes, in response to "China's increasing role in the world". This week the foreign ministry's spokesman, Shen Guofang, said the decision to dispense with English translation is "irreversible," but allowed that reporters who experience "insurmountable difficulties" might still ask questions in English. If Mr Shen is feeling generous, he might even answer in English. 
Reporters, and foreign diplomats who also attend the briefings, expect the Chinese to encounter difficulties of their own. Not only has the interpretation afforded the spokesman a few extra moments to contemplate his response, but it has also assured that a uniform translation went out, at least to the world's English-language publications. Western diplomats think the ministry knows that surrendering control of the English version of its statements is likely to increase the risk of serious misunderstandings. They suggest the impetus for the change probably came from elsewhere in the Chinese government. 
As for hastening the day when Chinese will rival English as the world's lingua franca, China is placing its faith in cyberspace and in Chinese proficiency with computers. "I believe", says a professor active in computers, "it is inevitable that in time the majority of Internet users will be Chinese. And when that happens, we will see the Chinese language being widely used in electronic communication." On current trends that may take a while. According to the Xinhua news agency, China has 20,000 people using the Internet, a number predicted to rise to im by 2000. That compares with the som people elsewhere already using the Internet, the vast majority of them in English. home, the New Party Sakigake, one of the small groups in the governing coalition. The Sakigake has been losing popularity of late-and is likely to lose up to half its seats in the general election expected later this year. Indeed its leader, Masayoshi Takemura, and some older members have so little confidence in their own abilities that they wanted to abandon their own party (in effect to dissolve it) and to join Mr Hatoyama's new group en masse. 
No deal, said Mr Hatoyama's reformminded friends, fearing that their nice new party would be tainted. To the reformers, Mr Takemura was a pariah. As finance minister, he condoned a controversial scheme to spend billions of taxpayers' money liquidating bankrupt jusen (mortgage companies). 
Mr Hatoyama is expected to take with him no more than a handful of the Sakigake's 23 lower-house members. His younger brother, Kunio, has already announced that he will shortly be joining him and leaving the New Frontier Party, the leading opposition group within the Diet. The brothers Hatoyama will also pick up a few recruits from the Social Democratic Party, another troubled member of the governing coalition, and will probably absorb another tiny parliamentary group known as the Citizens Action League. All told, Mr Hatoyama expects to start with 12-15 members, though he believes more will join his party after the election. 
More might indeed be persuaded to join Mr Hatoyama's camp if they knew what his nascent party will stand for. He induced outbursts of laughter and derision some months ago when, straightfaced, he claimed it was going to be based on "love and friendship". After publication of a sixpoint agenda, people are only a little better informed. Mr Hatoyama is against bureaucrats and for citizens; and he believes the economy should favour consumers over producers. He represents reformist politics reduced to the blandest of slogans-and little else. The only clear commitment he has made is that if the opposition moves a vote of no confidence in the prime minister-as Ichiro Ozawa's New Frontier Party has promised to do when the Diet reconvenes in October-then his group will back the motion wholeheartedly. 
The departure of Mr Hatoyama and his friends to the opposition benches is hardly going to cause Japan's ruling coalition to collapse. The rebels would need to gather at least 50 seats to rob the ruling block of its overall majority. But the Sakigake's disintegration might bring about enough uncertainty within the coalition's ranks to force Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister and leader of the Liberal Democratic Party, to think about calling an election sooner than he had originally intended.

text:
BEIJING, TOKYO AND TAIPEI 
THERE is no more important-and potentially fateful-relationship in Asia than that between Japan and China. With easily the most advanced economy in East Asia and close ties to the West, Japan has a strong claim to regional leadership. But there are ten times as many Chinese as Jal anese and China's economy is growing fast. The natural tensions between two regional giants are greatly complicated by the bitterness left behind by Japan's invasion and occupation of parts of China in the 1930s. 
Keenly aware of everything that could go wrong between their two countries, the leaders of Japan and China are usually careful to get along with each other. Japan funnels large amounts of aid to China, and China is generally welcoming to Japanese investors. But in the past two weeks there has been a sudden outbreak of heated Japanese-bashing in China. The cause is a flareup in a dispute over who owns eight uninhabited islands that China calls the Diaoyu and Japan knows as the Senkakus. 
Members of the Japan Youth Federation, an extreme nationalist group, are reported to have built a lighthouse and a war memorial on one of the islands. In reaction, the Chinese state press is now at full volume. On August 3oth the People's Daily editorialised: "No Chinese will surrender the country's territory and sovereignty to anyone. If anybody dares do so, he will be cursed for centuries." This kind of language has not been heard since the unpleasantness in the Taiwan Strait earlier this year, and it is the first time in years that Japan has received a full blast. 
China has made it clear that it regards the beacon-building of the young Japanese as part of a broader resurfacing of Japanese expansionism and aggression. They argue that a recent visit by Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Japanese prime minister, to the Yasukuni shrine for Japan's war dead was another sign of this militarism. On August 29th Shen Guofang, China's foreign-ministry spokesman, averred that "the recent actions of some Japanese right-wing groups are not accidental and are directly related to the attitude of the Japanese government". A group of Chinese who have been agitating for war reparations from Japan have also been allowed (or encouraged?) to present a petition to President Jiang Zemin, in his capacity as head of China's Central Military Commission, demanding the dispatch of the Chinese navy to dismantle the offending structures. 
It is not hard to see why China might suspect some sort of collusion between the Japanese government and the youth federation. Ownership of the islands, which are zoo kilometres (125 miles) north-east of Taiwan and 300 kilometres south-west of the Japanese island of Okinawa, is not simply a matter of national pride. They might confer title to over 30,ooo square kilometres of continental shelf beneath the East China Sea-a region sometimes claimed to contain between lo billion and 1oo billion barrels of oils. The latent dispute over the islands began to heat up last December when Yohei Kono, then Japan's foreign minister, protested at China's oil exploration in the region. In JulyJapan ratified the international Convention on the Law of the Sea, so asserting a zone of zoo nautical miles around its territory. And it was just after this that the young Japanese set out for the islands. 
Although the Japanese government has neither endorsed nor repudiated the federation's actions, the whole controversy has allowed Japan publicly to reiterate its claim to the islands, most recently when Yukihiko Ikeda, Japan's foreign minister, visited Hong Kong on August 29th. 
But in fact the Japan Youth Federation is an unlikely vehicle for the Japanese government to use: it has a long record of embarrassing government officials, and even extorting money from them. Though shadowy in some ways, the federation maintains a high profile in Tokyo. It is one of the biggest of the right-wing groups that cruise the city with black "loud-speaker vans" blaring out nationalistic songs and ranting on about territorial issues at deafening volume. Usually they park outside the offices of some offending politician, bureaucrat or businessman to yell abusemostly as a way of extracting hush money. 
This is not the first time that the federation has sought to embarrass the government with extra-territorial claims. In 1990 it built a similar "lighthouse" on a different Senkaku rock-replacing a derelict structure left behind earlier in 1978. An application for the beacon's recognition as an "official sea-route marker" was made to the Maritime Safety Agency in Tokyo, and the agency duly sat on it in the classic Japanese way. 
Nothing more was heard of the federation's claims on Japan's behalf until last July, when seven members of the group once again set sail for the islands. Their latest antics seem to be partly a publicity stunt to aid recruitment among Japanese skinheads, partly an induction rite to keep their young misfits from wandering off. 
One of the odder side-effects of the dispute is that it has provoked an outbreak of pan-Chinese nationalism among liberals in Taiwan and Hong Kong, who have themselves born the brunt of China's sensitivity to issues of "sovereignty". On his recent visit to Hong Kong, Japan's foreign minister was greeted by protests led by some Democrats who, ironically, have long been considered subversives by Beijing. In Taiwan, James Soong, the governor of Taiwan province, appealed to Beijing saying it was high time that it showed the world that it has "the capability and determination to protect China's historical territory"-a phrase with an unhappy similarity to China's justification for its attempted military intimidation of Taiwan earlier this year. 
Both China and Taiwan argue that the islands were indisputably under Chinese jurisdiction from Taiwan province until the Japanese incorporated them into Okinawa prefecture in 1895, during the SinoJapanese war. Taiwan itself and its outlying islands passed into Japanese hands as part of the Treaty of Shimonseki later that year. After Japan's defeat in the second world war, the Potsdam declaration stated that all territories "stolen" from China by Japan would be returned. The rival Chinese governments in Beijing and Taipei assumed that this meant that the Diaoyu islands would now return to China. In fact, they remained under the American jurisdiction of occupied Okinawa and when, in 1972, Okinawa was returned to Japan, the islands went with them. 
China has long said that, for the sake of good relations with Japan, it is prepared to shelve the sovereignty issue-on China's own terms, of course. The People's Daily of August 3oth argued for joint exploration of the region, "on the precondition that China has sovereignty over the islands." This is unlikely to be acceptable to Japan. 
An alternative that is sometimes floated would let China and Japan carve up the area along a line equidistant from their respective undisputed shorelines, treating Taiwan tacitly as an autonomous province of China. This would settle the question of mineral rights, without making a ruling over the status of the islands. Such a deal might suit China; Japan however might still prefer to leave things be, believing that possession is nine-tenths of the law.
