Keenly aware of everything that could go wrong between their two countries, the leaders of Japan and China are usually careful to get along with each other. Japan funnels large amounts of aid to China, and China is generally welcoming to Japanese investors. But in the past two weeks there has been a sudden outbreak of heated Japanese-bashing in China. The cause is a flareup in a dispute over who owns eight uninhabited islands that China calls the Diaoyu and Japan knows as the Senkakus. 
Members of the Japan Youth Federation, an extreme nationalist group, are reported to have built a lighthouse and a war memorial on one of the islands. In reaction, the Chinese state press is now at full volume. On August 3oth the People's Daily editorialised: "No Chinese will surrender the country's territory and sovereignty to anyone. If anybody dares do so, he will be cursed for centuries." This kind of language has not been heard since the unpleasantness in the Taiwan Strait earlier this year, and it is the first time in years that Japan has received a full blast. 
China has made it clear that it regards the beacon-building of the young Japanese as part of a broader resurfacing of Japanese expansionism and aggression. They argue that a recent visit by Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Japanese prime minister, to the Yasukuni shrine for Japan's war dead was another sign of this militarism. On August 29th Shen Guofang, China's foreign-ministry spokesman, averred that "the recent actions of some Japanese right-wing groups are not accidental and are directly related to the attitude of the Japanese government". A group of Chinese who have been agitating for war reparations from Japan have also been allowed (or encouraged?) to present a petition to President Jiang Zemin, in his capacity as head of China's Central Military Commission, demanding the dispatch of the Chinese navy to dismantle the offending structures. 
It is not hard to see why China might suspect some sort of collusion between the Japanese government and the youth federation. Ownership of the islands, which are zoo kilometres (125 miles) north-east of Taiwan and 300 kilometres south-west of the Japanese island of Okinawa, is not simply a matter of national pride. They might confer title to over 30,ooo square kilometres of continental shelf beneath the East China Sea-a region sometimes claimed to contain between lo billion and 1oo billion barrels of oils. The latent dispute over the islands began to heat up last December when Yohei Kono, then Japan's foreign minister, protested at China's oil exploration in the region. In JulyJapan ratified the international Convention on the Law of the Sea, so asserting a zone of zoo nautical miles around its territory. And it was just after this that the young Japanese set out for the islands. 
Although the Japanese government has neither endorsed nor repudiated the federation's actions, the whole controversy has allowed Japan publicly to reiterate its claim to the islands, most recently when Yukihiko Ikeda, Japan's foreign minister, visited Hong Kong on August 29th. 
But in fact the Japan Youth Federation is an unlikely vehicle for the Japanese government to use: it has a long record of embarrassing government officials, and even extorting money from them. Though shadowy in some ways, the federation maintains a high profile in Tokyo. It is one of the biggest of the right-wing groups that cruise the city with black "loud-speaker vans" blaring out nationalistic songs and ranting on about territorial issues at deafening volume. Usually they park outside the offices of some offending politician, bureaucrat or businessman to yell abusemostly as a way of extracting hush money. 
This is not the first time that the federation has sought to embarrass the government with extra-territorial claims. In 1990 it built a similar "lighthouse" on a different Senkaku rock-replacing a derelict structure left behind earlier in 1978. An application for the beacon's recognition as an "official sea-route marker" was made to the Maritime Safety Agency in Tokyo, and the agency duly sat on it in the classic Japanese way. 
Nothing more was heard of the federation's claims on Japan's behalf until last July, when seven members of the group once again set sail for the islands. Their latest antics seem to be partly a publicity stunt to aid recruitment among Japanese skinheads, partly an induction rite to keep their young misfits from wandering off. 
One of the odder side-effects of the dispute is that it has provoked an outbreak of pan-Chinese nationalism among liberals in Taiwan and Hong Kong, who have themselves born the brunt of China's sensitivity to issues of "sovereignty". On his recent visit to Hong Kong, Japan's foreign minister was greeted by protests led by some Democrats who, ironically, have long been considered subversives by Beijing. In Taiwan, James Soong, the governor of Taiwan province, appealed to Beijing saying it was high time that it showed the world that it has "the capability and determination to protect China's historical territory"-a phrase with an unhappy similarity to China's justification for its attempted military intimidation of Taiwan earlier this year. 
Both China and Taiwan argue that the islands were indisputably under Chinese jurisdiction from Taiwan province until the Japanese incorporated them into Okinawa prefecture in 1895, during the SinoJapanese war. Taiwan itself and its outlying islands passed into Japanese hands as part of the Treaty of Shimonseki later that year. After Japan's defeat in the second world war, the Potsdam declaration stated that all territories "stolen" from China by Japan would be returned. The rival Chinese governments in Beijing and Taipei assumed that this meant that the Diaoyu islands would now return to China. In fact, they remained under the American jurisdiction of occupied Okinawa and when, in 1972, Okinawa was returned to Japan, the islands went with them. 
China has long said that, for the sake of good relations with Japan, it is prepared to shelve the sovereignty issue-on China's own terms, of course. The People's Daily of August 3oth argued for joint exploration of the region, "on the precondition that China has sovereignty over the islands." This is unlikely to be acceptable to Japan. 
An alternative that is sometimes floated would let China and Japan carve up the area along a line equidistant from their respective undisputed shorelines, treating Taiwan tacitly as an autonomous province of China. This would settle the question of mineral rights, without making a ruling over the status of the islands. Such a deal might suit China; Japan however might still prefer to leave things be, believing that possession is nine-tenths of the law.

text:
WITH the Japanese in Okinawa voting decisively for a cut in America's military facilities on the island, some political observers are wondering whether Japan could go the same way as the Philippines. In the early 1990s, a similar grassroots movement led quickly to the closure of America's military bases at Clark Field and Subic Bay, along with four smaller installations elsewhere in the Philippines. 
Though the turnout in Okinawa on September 8th-the first prefectural referendum to be held in Japan-was only 59% instead of an expected 70%, the central government in Tokyo got the message loud and clear. Of those who voted, about go% supported the demand for an American cutback. Although the referendum is nonbinding, the burden born by the Okinawans, who play host to 29,000 of the 47,000 GIS in Japan, will remain a key issue in Japanese politics. Unlike his predecessors, the prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, will be unable to ignore it. 
While the islanders are not especially anti-American, the noise of low-flying warplanes and artillery practice has taken its toll. Okinawans have been incensed by the accidents and crimes of GIS who, until recently, have tended to be whisked away from Japan before the local courts could mete out punishment. 
That practice has started to change since September last year, when a 12-yearold girl was raped by three American soldiers, who are now serving long sentences in a Japanese jail. Last October, 85,000 Okinawans joined a protest demanding a reduction in the American presence on the island. More than 500,000 Okinawans, half the island's adult population, have also signed a petition calling for changes in Japan's security treaty with America. 
During President Clinton's visit to Tokyo in April, when Japan and America reaffirmed the treaty, worries about Okinawa were addressed by an agreement that America would give up its sprawling air base at Futenma in central Okinawa, together with ten other facilities, and move their functions and personnel to other bases in Japan. But little progress has been made since. Hence the frustration vented by Okinawans in this week's referendum. 
At a meeting with the governor of Okinawa, Masahide Ota, two days after the referendum, Mr Hashimoto discussed plans to help the islanders, who have lowest income per person in Japan and an unemployment rate that is twice the national average. Many Okinawans have benefited from American spending locally, so any withdrawal would leave the islanders even poorer. Mr Ota wants government money to develop the tropical island, for tourism and industry. Mr Hashimoto offered him Y5 billion ($45m) to start at least the planning phase of the prefecture's wistful development schemes. With the Okinawa issue on the way to being resolved-at least in the short term-Mr Hashimoto has started dropping hints about a snap election. 
As for Mr Ota, he has won a huge following-and not only in Okinawa. He has vowed to have all American troops off the island by 2015. His tactics are spreading to the mainland. Other prefectural governors, under pressure to accept American troops being relocated from Okinawa, are beginning to rebel as well. In any case, it would be highly inconvenient for the Americans to redeploy. Based in Okinawa they are much closer to potential trouble spots, including Korea and the Taiwan Strait. The Americans are prepared to make concessions to preserve this foothold. But if rumblings in Japan continue, how soon will it be before America decides it would be far better served by moving its soldiers on Okinawa, not to some other place within Japan, but to Hawaii? Mr Ota may get his wishes sooner than he ever dreamed-or, indeed, really wanted.

text:
THREE years, four prime ministers and five cabinets since the previous general election, the Japanese electorate is at last to have a say again in who runs the country. Although the prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, does not have to call an election until July, it is now as certain as anything in politics that he will go for October. An extraordinary session of the Diet (parliament) was called for September 27th. Mr Hashimoto said it would be dissolved the same day. The date of the election is expected ("99.9% sure," according to Seiroku Kajiyama, the cabinet's chief secretary) to be October 2oth. 
This will be the first election of the all-important lower house since rebel members of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP)joined a vote of no confidence in the government in June 1993. Led by Ichiro Ozawa, the rebels then splintered from the LDP after the party's failure to embrace political reform. In the ensuing general election, the LDP lost the absolute majority it had enjoyed for almost four decades. 
A series of coalition governments followed. Excluded from the first two, the LDP managed to get a hand back on the reins by doing a deal with the Social Democrats and the much smaller New Party Sakigake. The deal was that the LDP had to put up with a Social Democratic prime minister, Tomiichi Murayama, until he resigned in January this year, to be replaced by Mr Hashimoto. 
The question in the coming election is simple: will the LDP regain its previously rigid grip on Japanese politics? The party's top brass clearly believes that this is as good a chance as it will get. Opinion polls seem to bear out their optimism. Almost half the electorate thinks that Mr Hashimoto's government is doing a decent job. In an opinion poll for the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a leading daily, 22.4% of those sampled said they would vote for the LDP--nearly three times as many as those supporting any other party. 
Mr Hashimoto has been trying to build on this by boosting his credentials as a statesman. This past week he popped off to America to address the United Nations and hobnob with Bill Clinton. Among the things they discussed was Mr Hashimoto's recent success in overcoming local objections to the presence of so many American bases on Okinawa, largely by offering V5 billion ($45m) to help develop tourism. 
For the time being, the opposition's hand is weak. Of those polled, only 6.5% said they would vote for New Frontier, the main opposition party. Mr Ozawa, its leader, has struggled to hold his group together. Members have been irked by his overbearing leadership and tactical failures, such as the party's inability to exploit an unpopular plan to liquidate a clutch of mortgage companies with public money. Frightened by the party's low popularity, five of its members have left this month, at least three to rejoin the LDP. 
But the timing of the election has also been prompted by fears in the LDP that its fortunes could soon deteriorate. The government is committed to a plan to raise consumption tax from 3% to 5% next April. The LDP'S secretary-general and second-incommand, Koichi Kato, faces a flaying by the opposition for dubious donations he is said to have received. And hanging over everything is an economic recovery that shows signs of faltering. 
Will Mr Hashimoto's gamble work? Two things will be decisive. One is that, under new rules, 300 of the 500 seats are in first-past-the-post constituencies, the other zoo being decided by proportional representation. The second is that the successful parties will be those that get the support of floating voters: nearly half the voters are said to support no party. Both these factors favour the LDP. 
The floaters, for instance, are unlikely to make their choice based on the parties' differences in policy: they have none, at least on paper. All the parties (bar the Communists) mouth the same platitudes about deregulating the economy and taking power out of the hands of the bureaucrats. So voting will be heavily influenced, as usual, on the strength ofthe local (and, to a lesser extent, national) party machines. Building such machinery takes time, so wellestablished incumbents have a huge advantage. The LDP has by far the most members with the necessary long service in the Diet. 
Without the wherewithal, the small parties and a divided opposition will have a hard time fighting the first-past-the-post seats. The LDP's planners must be delighted by the surge in support for a new group, the Democratic Party. According to Seizaburo Sato, a political pundit and LDP guru, this fledgling party (to be formally set up on September 28th) is more likely to take votes in the single-seat constituencies from Mr Ozawa's New Frontier Party than from the LDP. 
The new party is the creation of Yukio Hatoyama, a defector from Sakigake, and Naoto Kan, the present health and welfare minister and one of Japan's most popular politicians. Already 46 members of the lower house (all but one from Sakigake and the Social Democrats) have announced that they will join the Democratic Party. 
Mr Ozawa's party is likely to do better than the Democrats in contests for the 200 seats elected by proportional representation. Although these are distributed according to the parties' share of the national vote, the more candidates a party has campaigning in first-past-the-post seats, the greater the likelihood of voters giving it their support for the national ones. New Frontier has approved 255 candidates for first-pastthe-post seats; so far, the Democrats have nominated far fewer. 
Of Japan's other political parties, the best placed are the Communists, who have the money, the organisation and the candidates as well as an unusually clean reputation. The Communists are fielding candidates for all 300 first-past-the post seats. But the party does not command mass support and, realistically, it expects to pick up no more than 30 to 35 seats. Neither it nor any of the other parties in Japan will be much of a roadblock to the Liberal Democrats' march back to political dominance.

text:
IN RECENT years, there has been much speculation over whether politics in Japan would become more like politics in the West. In one respect, the answer seems to be a definite Yes. Faced with the prospect of crushing defeat in the election on October 20th, Ichiro Ozawa, the leader of the opposition New Frontier Party, has done a Bob Dole and promised a huge tax cut. On October 2nd, Mr Ozawa unveiled plans to cut taxes by Y18 trillion ($161 billion), by halving rates for income and local taxes and cutting the corporate-tax rate from 50% to 40%. On the face of it, Mr Ozawa's proposals would create a huge hole in the budget. But, like Mr Dole, Mr Ozawa claims that his proposals would pay for themselves through the growth and higher revenues they would generate. 
Whether the Japanese public believes him remains to be seen. In opinion polls taken before Mr Ozawa unwrapped his package, the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), led by Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister, was the clear front-runner, with 39% support. Mr Ozawa's party had 13% support, just a point ahead of the newly formed Democratic Party. 
Presumably, Kenichi Sixpack is reassured by the fact that the economy, after five years of stagnation, grew by 4.4% in the first half of this year. This growth was the result of a plunging yen and the cutting of interest rates to almost nothing. Even more significantly,Y14 trillion (the rough equivalent of the annual GDP of Finland) was thrown at the economy in a single government gesture authorised in September 1995. If nothing else, Japanese voters may be inclined to give the government of Mr Hashimoto high marks for effort. 
Yet there is much in the government's record to criticise. It could have used its macroeconomic tools sooner and more wisely. Much of the recent spending splurge has been wasted, partly because the sector at which the government was trying to push money-building-is so corrupt, but also because so much money cannot be spent efficiently in such a short time. Worse, the government has failed to use the opportunity of lax monetary and fiscal policies to push deregulation. This year, indeed, it has sat on just about every large deregulatory proposal: to split up NTr, the domestic telecoms giant; to allow the creation of holding companies to make the management of sprawling Japanese companies more efficient; and to divide the finance ministry. 
Without deregulation, stimulative monetary policies have been rendered less potent. And, since government finances are now in a mess, deregulation, if and when it does come, will have to coincide with a period of fiscal austerity. To put the Midget back into shape, the LDP has already promised to rescind a temporary cut in income tax and raise consumption taxes. Combining that with deregulation could be awkward since it will, initially, entail job losses. Mr Ozawa's New Frontier Party has now attempted to differentiate itself clearly from the LDP by promising to cut taxes rather than raise them. This is something of a reversal, since six months ago it was saying that it wanted to increase consumption taxes to lo%, from their present 3%. 
All parties, meanwhile, claim to be in favour of deregulation, though on this subject vagueness rules. One reason for the lack of detailed discussion is that politicians have traditionally been the distributors, not the formulators, of policy. That has been left to bureaucrats.As a result there are few independent think-tanks, let alone think-tanks attached to parties, dedicated to the task of coming up with new policy ideas. But if politicians of whatever hue want to be taken seriously about deregulation and reform of the bureaucracy, they will have to do better than expect bureaucrats to fill in the details.

text:
THE main uncertainty of the Japanese general election on October 20thwhether the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) will win big or win small-is probably being settled right now thousands of kilometres away, in central China. With the typhoons from the south petering out, this is where Japan's weather pattern is formed in early autumn-and with it the prospects for a drenching on polling day. 
That would be enough to keep many voters at home. In 1993, at the last election of the lower house of the Diet (parliament), some 67% of the electorate cast their vote. But expectations were high then. With broken promises and few reforms to show for all the political upheaval, the Japanese are now vastly more cynical. The supporters of small parties tend to be more committed, so the LDP badly needs to persuade the apolitical rump to turn out and vote. Good weather would help. And the LDP is hoping that its superior resources will also contribute to a swelling of support. 
It would be ironic if money does indeed prove crucial. This, after all, is Japan's first general election under a new system that is meant to make campaigning less expensive, and so reduce the money-grubbing corruption that has underpinned Japanese politics and so infuriated the public. In reality, the new system, which combines 300 single-seat constituencies with 2oo proportional-representation (PR) seats contested in it regional blocks, has done the reverse. Smaller parties and independents lack the money to build local machines and to buy television advertising. And though individual candidates are restricted in their campaign spending, the parties can splurge as they like on national advertising.

text:
THINK back 20 years, and the southern part of South America was both an economic backwater and an armed camp. Its countries were ruled by military dictatorships, eyeing each other with suspicion and hostility, even threats of war, across borders sealed against all but a trickle of trade. Think back just seven years, and the dictatorships had given way to civilian democracies, but (Chile apart) the region's economies remained wedded to beggar-thy-neighbour protectionism, and were prostrated by inflation, instability and debt. 
And now look five years ahead. Barring accidents, by 200 an integrated, growing and relatively open market of at least 24om people, with an output of well over $i trillion, will stretch from the Brazilian north-east to Chile's Pacific coast, over what can be called (taking some geographical liberty with Brazil) South America's southern cone. 
At its heart, Brazil and Argentina, which between them account for more than half of Latin America's GDP, should have a common foreigntrade policy and, for all but a handful of products, a common external tariff, with increasingly convergent, and market-friendly, macroeconomic policies. United with them in a customs union will be their small neighbours Paraguay and Uruguay. And most, maybe all, of the rest of South America will be linked to this core by free-trade agreements. 
As investors, both local and foreign, exploit the potential for growth, scale and specialisation offered by this new market, this southern cone will be emerging as an agribusiness and mining superpower, with a diversified and modernised manufacturing industry fuelled by cheap and abundant energy. It will have forced its way back on to the world economic and business map, after an absence of two generations, and be preparing, led by a once self-doubting but already confident Brazil, to take its place, with the rest of Latin America, the Caribbean, Canada and the United States, in a freetrade area, starting around zoos, that will embrace the entire western hemisphere. 
That, at least, is the prospect. Some of it has happened already. The big push came from the formation of the southern common market, Mercosur (in Spanish; Mercosul in Portuguese), by Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay in 1991. True, some of the change began, and would have gone on, anyway. Latin American economies could not stay stuck for ever in the age of state industry, state inter vention and isolated markets. And Mercosur is only one in a web of international agreements-31 of them, by the count of ECLAc, the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean-signed since 199o to liberalise trade within the region. Meanwhile, older but moribund sub-regional groups, such as the Andean Group soon to be "Community"-are reviving. Yet Manuel Marin, the European commissioner who handles relations with the region, is right to call Mercosur the "hard kernel" of its integration. 
This is the world's fourth-largest integrated market, after NAFTA (the North American free-trade area), the European Union and Japan. It is a dynamic one. Intra-Mercosur trade has soared; combined GDP, despite ups and downs, has grown by an annual average of 3.5% since 199o; and at $5,ooo its income per head is 3o% above that of Latin America as a whole. Above all, Mercosur is seen throughout the region as the leader in the field. 
It is still not yet a full free-trade area, let alone a customs union, applying a common external tariff; its "common market" tag expresses only an aspiration-toward free movement not just of goods but of services, capital and labour-not fact. Even so, this is the world's most ambitious scheme of regional integration since the birth of the European Economic Community in 1957. Mercosur offers a framework and a timetable (and a snappy brandname that has become an attractive visiting-card in the rest of the world). And it has won political commitment: despite some backsliding and a few tense moments, its members, by and large, have stuck to their undertakings and kept the process moving. 
It is too early to say with confidence that Mercosur is irreversible. Much can yet go wrong: Latin America's history has seen many visionary schemes for integration that foundered on local rivalries, economic turbulence, outside meddling or their own flawed economic assumptions. But there are two basic grounds for optimism. The first is that Mercosur is the creation of democratic governments; it can fairly be seen not as a short-term expedient but as a long-term project for integration between the peoples they represent. Second, it is based on a commitment to trade liberalisation, and is being taken forward by governments pledged to broadly sound macroeconomic policies that have tamed inflation. Earlier integration schemes, such as the Latin American free-trade association of 196o, did increase trade among members, especially in manufactures, through the granting of selective bilateral preferences. But their intention was only to widen protected markets, in an ultimately doomed effort to make import-substitution work better. In contrast, Mercosur's integration is predicated on market opening and export-based growth; "open regionalism", as it is known. 
The clearest single measure of Mercosur's progress is the growth in trade that it has prompted. From $4 billion in 199o, trade among its four members more than tripled to $14.5 billion by 1995. There is plenty of room for more: in 1995, intra-group trade amounted to only 1.6% of Mercosur's GDP, compared with 4.5% for the nrA countries and 14% for the Eu. Trade has flowered partly because the end of inflation, followed by economic growth, produced consumer booms, first in Argentina and then in Brazil. But another reason is that Mercosur has lifted artificial barriers that had long restrained commerce between those two countries. Between them, they account for 97% of Mercosur's GDP, and they have at last recognised that they are natural trading partners. 
The assumptions changed in Asuncion 
When in 1494 Queen Isabel of Castile and King Joao II of Portugal made the Treaty of Tordesillas, fixing a boundary between their respective empires at a point 370 leagues west of the Cape Verde islands, they created what turned out to be one of history's less porous frontiers. Though groups of marauders, and then settlers, pushed Brazil's frontier further west into the Amazon, the Mato Grosso and to the river Uruguay, there it came to rest. While exSpanish South America fractured into separate countries after achieving independence in the early i9th century, Brazil remained united. In the south, there were two bits of unfinished business. A struggle between Brazil and Argentina for control of the territory north of the river Plate was settled when Uruguay emerged as a buffer state, after British mediation. And Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay ganged up in the 186os in a terrible war which humbled an expansionist Paraguay. 
Thereafter, the two big neighbours paid remarkably little attention to each other (except on the football field). Argentina rose as an agricultural power, and then declined; Brazil got on with the business of filling its huge territory with people and industry. Until 1985, apart from a couple of border encounters, only three Brazilian presidents had ever visited Argentina, and only two Argentine rulers had made the trip the other way. Sporadic attempts to increase bilateral trade bore only modest fruit, in the face of military and political mistrust. 
That changed when civilian governments took charge again-in Argentina in 1983, in Brazil in 1985-after long periods of military rule. The two new presidents, Raul Alfonsin and Jose Sarney respectively, signed agreements aimed first at strengthening democracy and reducing military tensions; by allowing mutual inspection of nuclear facilities, for example. But they also tried to revive sick and still-protectionist economies through selective bilateral trade preferences, in the form of sectoral agreements, while maintaining restrictions on imports from other countries. 
The process then underwent a vital change: the election of Carlos Menem in Argentina in 1989, and of Fernando Collor in Brazil in 199o, brought to power governments intent on trade opening and economic reform. They scrapped import bans and quotas. In place of notions of managed trade and industrial policy, when Mercosur was born in 1991, under the Treaty of Asuncion (capital of Paraguay), it was as an instrument to achieve free trade among members and to seek the efficiencies needed for competition in the world economy. The earlier agreements had involved negotiating exceptions to general tariff protection. The Mercosur treaty turned this process inside-out, requiring automatic and progressive tariff cuts, and allowing protection only that was both selective and temporary. 
The decision in 1994 to proceed to a customs union involved a second debate as to how open Mercosur should be. Argentina, like Uruguay and Paraguay, had low tariffs on capital goods; one of its aims in opening its economy was to allow its firms cheap access to imported technology. Brazil, in contrast, wanted to protect its own capital-goods industry. In the event, the agreed common external tariff (CET) was a compromise: Argentina and the others agreed to raise tariffs, Brazil to bring them down. Today, Mercosur's average trade-weighted external tariff is 14%-well below that of any of its members (except Paraguay) in 199o, and broadly comparable to current Latin American norms. 
A customs union should help to deepen Mercosur's internal free-trade area: it obviates the need to determine the national origin of goods traded between members. But, as free-traders object, Mercosur's external tariffs vary widely from low to high, so distorting relative prices. ChileLatin America's fastest-growing economy, and one that liberalised trade earlier and more thoroughly than did others-offers a contrast. Though Chile's external tariff of ii% is only slightly lower than Mercosur's, it is applied uniformly to almost all imports (bar the rising number that come in tariff-free, under bilateral trade deals). This has prevented Chile from becoming a full Mercosur member. Still, the free-trade agreement that Mercosur reached with Chile last June, though highly complex, underlines its relative openness. Mercosur is close to a similar deal with Bolivia, and talks are due with the Andean Group as such this month, to start setting a framework for individual deals with its other members (Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Venezuela). 
Trade, politics and diplomacy 
Some of the rise in trade within Mercosur represents a diversion of trade from outside sources: fo instance, the sale of cars between Brazil and Argentina; or, more deliberately, Brazil's decision to buy oil from Argentina rather than Iraq. But the rise in intra-group trade has gone hand-in-hand with an accelerating rise in Mercosur's trade with the rest oi the world. Economists agree that, overall, Mercosur has been more trade-creating than trade-diverting, the test of whether regionalism is open or closed. It has had other benefits too: without the growth in its exports to Brazil, Argentina would have suffered even worse than it did from the knock-on impact of Mexico's 1994-95 currency collapse. 
While Mercosur's exports to much of the rest of the world are dominated by primary products, trade liberalisation has helped to create local markets for manufactures. These (especially cars and car parts, chemicals and machinery) make up a sizeable part of intra-group trade: almost half of Argentina's $5.6 billion of exports to Brazil last year, and almost 85% of the $4 billion of goods that Brazil sent in return. Much of this is intra-industry trade, as similar firms, or branches of the same firm, swap products or components, taking advantage of the specialisation made possible by a bigger market. 
This process is helped along by the hefty foreign investment that Mercosur countries are attracting, some from each other, but more from outside. Outside direct investment within Mercosur has risen sharply. It totalled around $6 billion in both 1994 and 1995, and is likely to go higher this year, as multinationals, especially in the car, chemical and food industries, upgrade existing plants, build new ones or enter a region that they used to ignore. 
Mercosur has also brought political gains. Democracy and military detente were a precondition of success in the project, but have also benefited from it. Brazil and Argentina have moved from renouncing their incipient nuclear-weapons programmes to conducting joint military exercises. 
Brazil's elderly aircraft-carrier (which lacks planes) has exercised with the airmen of Argentina's navy (whose aircraft-carrier has been mothballed for several years). For the first time, small units from the two armies are due shortly to conduct a joint training exercise in peacekeeping. 
But for Mercosur, Paraguay would this year almost certainly have gone back to military rule, setting a dangerous precedent for Latin America. When in April a rebellious general moved against President Juan Carlos Wasmosy, Mercosur foreign ministers descended on Asuncion and demonstrated to the upstart that he would face diplomatic and economic isolation. Mercosur's presidents promptly agreed that, as in the Eu, democracy should be a formal condition of membership. Revealingly, elements of Chile's right-wing opposition, close to General Pinochet and the armed forces, cited this as a reason to oppose their country's deal with Mercosur. 
Another indicator of Mercosur's effectiveness is its diplomatic pulling power in the wider world. Last December, it signed a framework agreement with the EU, its largest single source of external trade and investment. The deal is not all that some enthusiasts in Mercosur hoped for, but it sets a tentative target of free trade by 2005. It now looks increasingly likely that the planned western-hemisphere free-trade area will involve an agreement between NAFrA and Mercosur. And the Japanese, during a visit to the region by their prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, in August, expressed interest in starting a dialogue with Mercosur. 
In sum, Mercosur has got off to a surprisingly good start. Yet this survey will argue that if it is to continue to prosper, it faces tougher challenges than those it has surmounted so far. The first is the maintenance of macroeconomic stability, open trading regimes and economic growth in Brazil and in Argentina; for while Mercosur can contribute to all of these, it cannot flourish without them. The second is to make an integrated market a reality by improving transport links and customs procedures, standardising or demolishing a mountain of rules and regulations, and striking the right balance between the nation state and common-market institutions. All of these issues are likely to test its members' commitment to their common project.

The first is the maintenance of macroeconomic stability, open trading regimes and economic growth in Brazil and in Argentina; for while Mercosur can contribute to all of these, it cannot flourish without them. The second is to make an integrated market a reality by improving transport links and customs procedures, standardising or demolishing a mountain of rules and regulations, and striking the right balance between the nation state and common-market institutions. All of these issues are likely to test its members' commitment to their common project.

Both countries denied sending troops across the border or supplying local Tutsi militias. France's President Jacques Chirac paid an effusive visit to Syria and a cross one to Israel, where he objected to security he considered overzealous. In Ramallah he addressed the Palestinian parliament, the first head of state to do so, urging Palestinians to shun violence as they sought a state of their own. 
After mediation by an American envoy, the rival Kurdish factions in northern Iraq agreed in principle, though not yet in fact, to a ceasefire. 
Qatar's ruling family ended its feud, after the government dropped legal action against the deposed emir. The ruler's third son was named heirapparent. 
After Lebed 
Boris Yeltsin, Russia's unwell president, appointed as security chief Ivan Rybkin, a former speaker of parliament, replacing Alexander Lebed. Mr Rybkin will also be in charge of peace negotiations with Chechen rebels. Mr Lebed strengthened his alliance with Alexander Korzhakov, the president's former bodyguard. 
Alexander Rutskoi, who tried to overthrow President Yeltsin in 1993, was elected governor of Kursk in western Russia. 
Russia and Ukraine said they were ready to sign a bilateral treaty, despite a vote by the Duma, the lower house of Russia's parliament, to halt a share-out of the former Soviet Black Sea Fleet between the two countries. Ukraine has also been smarting over claims from some Russian politicians for a reassertion of Russian sovereignty over Sebastopol, the fleet's home port in the Crimea. 
The conservative Homeland Union, a party led by Lithuania's ex-president Vytautas Landsbergis, won parliamentary elections, avenging Mr Landsbergis's 1992 defeat by former communists. 
Bosnia's local elections were again postponed be cause of worries of fraud, mainly by Bosnian Serbs. President Clinton promised to open NATO to East European members in 1999. Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic are thought likeliest to be in the first wave. 
The Vatican at last admitted that evolution is "more than just a hypothesis". But, the pope added, it still does not apply to the soul. About 300,000 Belgians marched in Brussels to support the families of four girls murdered by members of a paedophile ring and to protest against the authorities' handling of the case. 
Gro Harlem Brundtland, Norway's prime minister for ten of the past 15 years, resigned to give her Labour Party time to prepare for a general election next year. Her successor is expected to be the party leader, Thorbjoern Jagland. 
Finland's opposition Centre Party won the country's first elections to the European Parliament. The vote was interpreted as a rebuff to the government's policy of bringing the Finnish currency swiftly into Europe's planned economic and monetary union. 
German workers took to the streets after talks between IG Metall, the engineering union, and employers broke down. The protests, against cuts in sick pay, may presage a long hot autumn. 
Japanese mist 
The Japanese election produced no clear victory. The Liberal Democratic Party led by Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister, won 239 seats, 12 short of an overall majority. But its old coalition partners lost seats and the shape of a new government remained unclear. 
The Taliban Islamic militia held on to Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan, amid reports that its harsh rule was alienating the city's people. AntiTaliban forces gained ground in battles outside the capital. Pakistan devalued its currency by 8% against the dollar and announced a budgetary package, aimed at closing the government's fiscal deficit, in an attempt to win the support of the International Monetary Fund. 
Starr gazing 
Kenneth Starr, the Whitewater special prosecutor, delayed the release of a report on the apparent suicide of Vince Foster, a White House aide. Mr Starr had promised not to make any statements or take any actions that might look politically motivated in the run-up to the presidential election. In Nicaragua's presidential election, the main right-wing candidate, Arnoldo Aleman, scored an unexpected firstround victory with about 49% of the vote, well over the 45% hurdle. The left-winger, Daniel Ortega, president in Sandinist days but now trying to look like a social democrat, took about 38% and claimed fraud. 
Some 30 inmates died in a fire, locked in without escape, in one of Venezuela's famously awful prisons.

text:
Something really has changed in Japanese politics. But not enough, as the general election showed 
INCONCLUSIVE as it was, the vote in Japan's general elec. tion on October 20th was a vote for reform. In a country so uniformly well-educated and well-informed, the record low turnout of 59% was an indictment of the many missed opportunities and broken promises during the past three years of coalition governments of varying stripe. Expectations of economic and political change-to toss aside corruption, and the suffocating blanket of bureaucratic controls that have cosseted particular manufacturers, farmers and other producer groups at the consumer's and the country's expense-ran rampant when the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) broke up in 1993 after 38 years of uninterrupted rule. But many of these hopes have been disappointed. No wonder so many voters stayed at home, or went to the baseball. 
Now the Liberal Democrats are back with more of a mandate to govern, having boosted their strength in the soo-member lower house of the Diet (parliament) from 211 to 239 seats. Perversely, however, their victory at the ballot box has left Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister and the leader of the LDP, with less room to manoeuvre-and, quite possibly, a foreshortened term in office (see page 39). The LDP-led coalition that he will head after being reappointed as prime minister on November 7th will have its work cut out just trying to hang on to power. 
A real change, but not yet a sufficient one 
Disappointing though this is, it does not mean that the Japan of 1996 is the same as the Japan of 1993 or of 1983. There has been at least one, fundamental, change. In the 198os, certainly, and in the early 199os, widely, government was seen in Japan as the solution of most economic and social problems. Now, bureaucrats are no longer seen as the solution: they are seen as the problem. That is why all the political parties in this general-election campaign declared themselves in favour of "administrative reform". Alas, none of them offered convincing or clear plans; none but the LDP looked likely to form a credible governing team. 
That does not, however, mean that this issue is dead. In so far as it is organised at all, Japanese politics is likely to continue to organise itself around the question of the role and power of government. If the LDP-led coalition fails to deliver any deregulation and any reform, that will provide its opponents with their chance. Which is a strong reason to expect at least some progress from Mr Hashimoto. 
It is unlikely to come quickly. The new government's most pressing task will be financial. Including obligations incurred by local government, Japan's national debt now stands at a staggering Y440 trillion ($3.9 trillion), almost equivalent to the country's annual GDP. Meanwhile, the biggest ofthe immediate liabilities-settling theY20 trillion debt remaining from the defunct Japan National Railways-is about to arise. The bill will cost every man, woman and child in Japan V16o,ooo apiece. Using public money to liquidate the seven failed jusen (mortgage companies) earlier this year all but brought down the government, and that cost taxpayers a paltry V685 billion, a mere Y5,500 per person. For Mr Hashimoto, the gathering clouds threaten a drenching. 
All the more reason to press on, at speed, with reforms aimed at freeing the economy. In the short term, this means deregulation rather than the broad, administrative reforms that were so often touted during the campaign. Japanese government would be healthier if its bureaucrats had less discretion and were more accountable to their political and electoral masters (indeed, if bureaucrats were to be made to act like servants rather than masters, as they have for decades). Changing laws to achieve this, and restructuring ministries, is worth doing. But what Japan most needs now is straightforward deregulation. 
As if on cue, the government's Economic Planning Agency has just published a study showing that even the modest steps taken so far to loosen up the economy have paid off handsomely. A handful of measures-such as easing the restrictions that prevented department stores from expanding into local neighbourhoods, approving the construction of threestorey instead of only two-storey wooden houses, and allowing agencies for temporary workers to be set up-are said to have added an average of V7.9 trillion a year to the economy over the past six years. Modest they may be, but without them the country's abysmal growth since the early 199os would have been o.6 percentage points lower each year. 
Such evidence ought to strengthen the chances of a new batch of deregulatory proposals that are to be published in late November by the Economic Council, an advisory panel within the prime minister's office. These cover six troubled aspects of the economy-finance, telecommunications, employment, distribution, land and housing, and health and welfare. So far, officials within other ministries have not been allowed to tinker with the proposals for fear that they would neuter them. Which, given a chance, they would. 
It is not that the Economic Council's suggestions are so outrageous. One simply proposes raising the plot-ratio (ie, height to floor-space) of buildings to provide better land use in Japan's crowded cities. Another would liberalise commissions on securities transactions so that brokers could offer discount services. A third would remove the restrictions on firms (such as cable Tv operators) wishing to go into the telephone business. But the Economic Council's reforms are radical in at least one respect: as a matter of principle, they are designed to provide the consumer with greater choice-by giving freer rein to market forces. 
As he struggles to keep his fragile coalition together, Mr Hashimoto could win rounds of public applause by defending and implementing such reforms. A fine way to do so would be to turn the advisory Economic Council into a fullblooded Economic Reform Agency, with statutory powers. If Mr Hashimoto were to act, the Japanese economy could really roll. And his government might even survive.

text:
THE one clear result of Japan's general election on October 20th is that it has solved nothing. Although the dominant Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) headed by Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister, fell short of winning an absolute majority in the soo-seat lower house of the Diet, it nevertheless increased its strength from 211 to 239 members. Meanwhile, the challenge mounted by Ichiro Ozawa and his New Frontier Party (NFP) flopped miserably. Far from threatening the LDP's dominance, the main opposition party wound up with 156 seats, four fewer than it had before the election. 
The irony is that, in clinching a bigger lead, Mr Hashimoto has found that forming a new administration has suddenly become more difficult. The question this past week has been not just what political complexion Japan's new government will have, but how long it will last. Some are already beginning to suggest that another election could be needed within a year or so. 
Mr Hashimoto has two immediate problems. The first is the collapse of the LDP'S two former coalition partners: the Social Democratic Party (SDP) and the smaller New Party Sakigake. Both were devastated in last Sunday's election; their combined strength plummeted to only 17 seats (see chart). The result is that, whereas Mr Hashimoto could rely on a comfortable 40-seat majority over the opposition's combined strength before the election, the best he can muster now is a slender majority of five or six, even though his own party's strength rose. 
The prime minister's other problem is that he cannot even bank on that slender majority. After flip-flopping a few times, the two surviving Sakigake members have now decided not to join his new government. They say they will co-operate with the LDP on administrative reforms, but from outside the cabinet. 
Meanwhile, Takako Doi-the popular speaker of the house who was persuaded to rejoin the crumbling SDP on the eve of the election and lead its fight for survival-has threatened not to throw her party's lot in with the government. As with the pair of Sakigake survivors, Miss Doi has offered to support an LDP-led coalition on a case-by-case basis, but to keep her troops out of the cabinet. 
There is no question that the SDP'S fall from grace started when it compromised its socialist principles by joining forces with the conservative LDP to form a coalition government in 1994. Unlike the former SDP leader, Tomiichi Murayama, the redoubtable Miss Doi is not so easily seduced by the promise of power-and is determined not to let her party make such a near-fatal mistake twice. The SDP needs time, she says, to heal its wounds. 
Others have learned much the same lesson about consorting with the LDP, and have been seeking likewise to distance themselves from the ruling party and its venal antics. The new Democratic Party of Japan, formed just weeks before the election by two Sakigake renegades, Yukio Hatoyama and Naoto Kan, has been even more reluctant to help Mr Hashimoto in his quest to form a government. 
The fledgling Democratic Party did nowhere near as well last Sunday as expected, barely managing to keep its pre-election strength of 52 members. Pundits had predicted giddily that it would win at least 80 seats, making it a new focal point for liberal-minded forces within the Diet. But the Democrats confused the public by providing two figureheads, and by refusing to say whether they were standing unequivocally as an opposition party or as one that was prepared to work for reform from within a coalition government. 
To his credit, Mr Hatoyama has insisted all along that his new party-with its membership of young reformist politicians drawn largely from the ranks of the SDP and the Sakigake-should promote its legislative agenda from the opposition benches. But his colleague and co-founder, Mr Kan, has continued to hint otherwise. Not surprisingly, it has been Mr Kan whom the LDP leadership has been wooing assiduously this past week. 
As health and welfare minister in the previous coalition government, Mr Kan has made himself the most popular politician in Japan. He it was who rooted out the bureaucratic corruption within the health service that had allowed some 2,000 haemophiliacs to contract AIDS though the use of unheated blood products. The populist Mr Kan let it be known that he would not be averse to another prominent cabinet post. But as Mr Hashimoto's new coalition has begun to look increasingly wobbly, joining the cabinet seems to have lost some of its appeal. 
In desperation, the LDP bigwigs have started courting their bitter rivals (and former colleagues before the bust-up of 1993) in Mr Ozawa's New Frontier Party. Dissidents within the NFP who have remained loyal to Morihiro Hosokawa and Tsutomu Hata, both former prime ministers, have been seething under Mr Ozawa's dictatorial rule and have threatened to walk out of the party on several occasions. Mr Hata's group, in particular, was on the verge of forming a party of its own several months ago but cancelled its plans when a general election appeared to be imminent. 
Many of the NFP'S younger members have also become distressed with the way the Soka Gakkai-a lay Buddhist organisation with deep pockets and an agenda of its own-has tightened its grip on their party. With roots in 8m households in Tokyo, Osaka and other big cities across Japan, the Soka Gakkai is by far the biggest vote-generator in the country. It is reckoned to be able to deliver an additional 20,000 votes (more than to% of the total cast in a typical urban constituency) to any candidate it chooses to back. In Sunday's election, the Soka Gakkai backed more than zoo of the 235 candidates that the NFP fielded in single-seat constituencies. Those unhappy with religion's incursion into politics have been urging Mr Hata and Mr Hosokawa to wash their hands of the NFP and its Buddhist friends. 
The LDP would be delighted if they did: between them, Mr Hata and Mr Hosokawa could be expected to bring anything up to 30 supporters with them if they defected and joined an LDr-led coalition. Such a move would provide Mr Hashimoto with the majority he is seeking in the upper as well as the lower house. 
But the two senior NFP leaders are involved in a power struggle with Mr Ozawa, who half-heartedly offered to stand down after the party's poor showing. During the campaign, Mr Ozawa promised to slash taxes, instigate drastic administrative reforms and prop up the economy-and vowed to leave politics if he was prevented from honouring his pledges. But now the truculent Mr Ozawa, backed by the majority of his older colleagues in the NFP and their Soka Gakkai supporters, has decided not to go without a fight. No love is lost between Mr Hashimoto and Mr Ozawa, but this is the one battle that the prime minister is praying his erstwhile rival in the LDP will win outright The more disgruntled opposition Mps, the better for Mr Hashimoto.

With roots in 8 m households in Tokyo , Osaka and other big cities across Japan , the Soka Gakkai is by far the biggest vote - generator in the country . It is reckoned to be able to deliver an additional 20,000 votes ( more than to% of the total cast in a typical urban constituency ) to any candidate it chooses to back . In Sunday 's election , the Soka Gakkai backed more than zoo of the 235 candidates that the NFP fielded in single - seat constituencies . Those unhappy with religion 's incursion into politics have been urging Mr Hata and Mr Hosokawa to wash their hands of the NFP and its Buddhist friends . Ryutaro Hashimoto would be delighted if they did : between them , Mr Hata and Mr Hosokawa could be expected to bring anything up to 30 supporters with them if they defected and joined an Ryutaro Hashimoto - led coalition . Such a move would provide Mr Hashimoto with the majority he is seeking in the upper as well as the lower house . 
 But the two senior NFP leaders are involved in a power struggle with Mr Ozawa , who half - heartedly offered to stand down after the party 's poor showing . During the campaign , Mr Ozawa promised to slash taxes , instigate drastic administrative reforms and prop up the economy - and vowed to leave politics if he was prevented from honouring his pledges . But now the truculent Mr Ozawa , backed by the majority of his older colleagues in the NFP and their Soka Gakkai supporters , has decided not to go without a fight . No love is lost between Mr Hashimoto and Mr Ozawa , but this is the one battle that the prime minister is praying his erstwhile rival in Ryutaro Hashimoto will win outright The more disgruntled opposition Mps , the better for Mr Hashimoto .

Yes, he won Bill Clinton won the American presidential election with 49% of the popular vote against Bob Dole's 41%, and 31 states against his 19. He becomes the first Democrat to be elected twice since Franklin Roosevelt. But the Republicans held on to both the Senate and the House of Rep resentatives. Ross Perot won 8% of the vote. Less than half of the eligible voters cast their ballots, a record low. 
Warren Christopher resigned as secretary of state, but will stay on until Mr Clinton's inauguration in January. Several other team members, including William Perry, the defence secretary, Mickey Kantor, the commerce secretary, and Leon Panetta, the White House chief of staff are also to go. 
Voters in California approved by a large margin a proposition to end racial quotas in state contracting and employment. 
In Nicaragua, expecting official (but still provisional) results of its October 2oth elections on November 7th, the Sandinists accused the seemingly victorious Liberal Alliance of fraud. They demanded a fresh vote in two big provinces, and called a day of "civic protest"-peaceful, apparently-on November 8th. 
Hell in Zaire 
All parties in the war in eastern Zaire have agreed to accept a multinational force to save refugees, but few countries have offered troops. France wants military intervention; European Union aid ministers met to discuss proposals. More than a million people, mostly Hutu refugees, have been left without food or shelter after aid agencies were driven out of the region by fighting. Having seized part of eastern Zaire, rebels offered a three-week ceasefire. 
Leaders of big third-world countries, meeting in Zimbabwe, accused rich countries of trying to dictate rules of world trade. One big gripe: rules on labour conditions, seen by the poor as a way of negating their lower wages. But Bangladesh, which supplies half of Europe's T-shirts, said it no longer used child labour in its textile factories. 
Israel's infrastructure minister, Ariel Sharon, unveiled a plan to settle lOO,ooo more colonists in the occupied West Bank Not a government plan, said a spokesman. 
In Algeria, Islamist guerrillas seized ten women and three children at a village and slit their throats. Later, in another village, 31 more people were murdered the same way. 
Interregnum 
Russia's president, Boris Yeltsin, took back presidential powers less than 24 hours after handing them over to his prime minister, Viktor Chernomyrdin, to undergo a heart operation. Doctors said the seven-hour quintuple bypass went well. 
Robert Tatum, an American businessman, was murdered in Moscow. He had been seeking control of the city's Radisson-Slavyanskaya hotel. In Ukraine Evheny Sherban, a prominent businessman and member of parliament, was also murdered. Russia's trade unions said that up to 2m workers went on strike to demand payment of $7 billion in unpaid wages by federal and local governments. Some parts of Russia are running short of food and fuel as winter approaches. 
The European Commission said 12 of the 15 EU countries would meet the Maastricht treaty's requirement for budget deficits of no more than 3% of GDP in 1997 if they are to join EMU. Britain, Italy and Greece were the exceptions. But the European Monetary Institute, precursor to a central bank, felt that progress towards deficit reduction has been too slow. 
Voters in Romania and Bulgaria rebuffed ex-communists and supported reformists. Romanians made the Democratic Convention the largest party, and in his race for re-election President Ion Iliescu holds a slim lead over Emil Constantinescu, the Democratic Convention candidate, before a run-off on November 17th. In Bulgaria's presidential election, Petar Stoyanov, a pro-reform lawyer, defeated the Socialist candidate, Ivan Marazov. 
Allies of Serbia's president, Slobodan Milosevic, easily won elections for the federal Yugoslav parliament and the parliament of Montenegro, the second republic in the Yugoslav federation. 
The European Bank of Reconstruction and Development predicted that growth in former communist economies would accelerate next year from a projected 4% rate in 1996. But all of them, it said, must do more to reform their financial systems and improve infrastructure. 
Bhutto out 
Benazir Bhutto was dismissed as prime minister of Pakistan by the country's president. The president said her government was incompetent and corrupt; it, and parliament, were also dismissed. Miss Bhutto was put under house arrest, but later freed. A general election is to be held in February. Japan's Liberal Democratic Party won over enough defectors to form a government. Ryutaro Hashimoto was formally reappointed prime minister. 
A Khmer Rouge commander and 300 fighters became the latest rebel group to defect to the Cambodian government. But Pol Pot, the rebel leader, was reported to be preparing to renew his attacks on government forces. A senior official in Washington said America had revised its view, and saw no prospect of Afghanistan's civil war coming to an early end.

text:
THE days of coalition government in Japan are over. After its victory in the recent general election, the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) has managed to cobble together enough ofa majority to enable it to rule the country without having to pay anything more than lip service to the opposition. So, with Japan's return to single-party government-for the first time since the LDP lost office in 1993 after 38 years of uninterrupted rule-are the Liberal Democrats about to revert to their business-asusual brand of politics? It looks like it. This week's in-fighting, leading to a cabinet reshuffle, suggests that Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister, will be hard pressed to prevent his party from slipping back into many of its old ways. 
The LDP won 239 of the 500 seats in the lower chamber of the Diet (parliament) on October 2oth. Since then, the party chieftains have extracted pledges of allegiance from more than a dozen independents and other conservatives keen to rejoin the LDP once the dust settles. 
Having seen their pre-election strength plunge from a combined 86 seats to just 17, the LDP's two former coalition partners, the Social Democrats and the New Party Sakigake, are glad these days of any scrap of influence over the ruling party. They will side with the government on most issues, giving Mr Hashimoto a comfortable 270 votes in the lower chamber. 
Reverting to form, the Liberal Democrats have spent the past week carving up the spoils of victory along traditional factional lines. The LDP'S old factions-the source of much of its internal strife and venal behaviour-were supposedly abolished when it limped from power three years ago to do penance in opposition. Yet, in formally announcing his new zi-member cabinet shortly after his own reappointment as prime minister on November 7th, Mr Hashimoto handed out portfolios according to the old LDP formula. Four posts apiece went to each of the party's four big battalions (the Obuchi, Miyazawa, Mitsuzuka and Nakasone factions), one to a minor LDP group (the Komoto faction), and four more to senior Liberal Democrats from the rubber-stamping upper house. 
All the main cabinet appointments have gone to, or remained with, party heavyweights. The former LDP secretarygeneral, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, has taken over the finance ministry. He has had cabinet experience twice before (trade and foreign affairs) and was involved in privatising Japan National Railways. His clout and experience are expected to make him a central figure in the LDP's proposals for streamlining the bureaucracy, especially the finance ministry. 
Yukihiko Ikeda, who was well thought of as foreign minister during the previous government, has kept his job. The foreign ministry has traditionally gone to a member of the Miyazawa faction, to which Mr Ikeda belongs. Seiroku Kajiyama, a senior member of the Obuchi faction, has been kept on as the chief cabinet secretary and government spokesman. 
Likewise, the main posts within the party itself have remained largely unchanged. Koichi Kato stays on as the LDP'S secretary-general and number two after Mr Hashimoto. Mr Kato went through the ritual of offering to stand down-because of allegations about receiving an illicit Y10m ($go,ooo) political donation-but was easily persuaded to remain at his post. 
With factional in-fighting dominating the scene like old times, Mr Hashimoto is going to have his work cut out trying to honour his election promises. Apart from streamlining the bureaucracy, the prime minister has promised to tackle several pressing issues, among them the need to find new places to put Americans removed from their bases in Okinawa, legislation to provide insurance for public nursing of the elderly, and reform of the financial system. 
To secure the Social Democrats' and the New Party Sakigake's support, the LDP agreed to submit bills before the end of january that would strip the finance ministry of some of its power and provide a measure of independence for the Bank of Japan. In all it agreed to tackle some 14 issues, including legislation to make it easier to set up non-profit organisations and the appointment of a Diet committee to review the tax system, especially the scheduled increase in consumption tax from 3% to 5% next April. Many of these reforms risk being forgotten, if the LDP reverts to form.

text:
The Japanese government has announced its intention to reform the financial system. Should its proposals be taken seriously? 
WHEN Japan's voters returned the Lil eral Democratic Party to power in October after a three-year interregnum, most people assumed that the victors would quickly forget their election promises of "administrative reform"-shorthand for taking power over the economy out of the hands of Japanese bureaucrats. For once, the sceptics may be wrong. On November lith Ryutaro Hashimoto, Japan's prime minister, promised that his government would undertake a sweeping deregulation of the country's financial system by 2001. Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, the new finance minister, called the proposals "the equivalent of London's Big Bang". 
In search of a good, if hackneyed image (earlier this year South Korea used the same phrase to describe its own financial-reform package), Mr Mitsuzuka may have been overstating his case. Few of these proposals are new; many were proposed by a government committee in August. Detail is lacking. Some important areas for reform have been ignored. And there will be opposition from vested interests, especially Japan's big securities firms, to those reforms that the government has proposed. But for all that, the prime minister has set a deadline and given his pledge. This time, at least, there seems to be the political will for serious reform. 
About time too. Bureaucrats and politicians alike appear to have realised at last that the glacial pace of Japan's previous financial reforms has strangled the country's economic recovery and thwarted Tokyo's pretensions to be an international financial centre. While it has been mired in red tape, the world's two other big financial centres, London and New York, have roared ahead. 
Tokyo also faces a growing challenge from Hong Kong and Singapore, which would both like to become Asia's main financial hub. Fed up with Japanese bureaucracy, some financial folk are already moving to Singapore and other centres with a lighter regulatory touch. They are not the only ones leaving town: over the past three years, 54 companies have delisted from the Tokyo Stock Exchange. "Shock therapy is necessary.The alternative is for Tokyo to become a local market," a senior bureaucrat at the finance ministry told foreign journalists this week. 
Japan's over-regulated and compartmentalised financial system is a product of both accident and design. After the second world war, the Americans imposed a version of their own Glass-Steagall act, which separates commercial and investment banking, in the shape of Article 65 of the Securities and Exchange Law. But bureaucrats also designed the financial system to make it easier to channel savings into favoured industries: the more segregated the various parts of the financial sector were, the easier it was to control the institutions through which savings were channelled. For example, long-term credit banks made long-term loans to industry. In addition, they were given a monopoly on issuing fixed-rate debt. Commercial banks took deposits and lent at floating rates. All interest rates were set by the finance ministry. 
Much of this apparatus is still intact. Banks face fierce competition for corporate business, especially now that big companies can tap the capital markets themselves. But the regulations prevent bankers from meeting this challenge by underwriting equities. They are also barred from selling insurance. Other sorts of financial firms also have their hands tied: securities firms cannot offer banking or insurance services, and insurance firms cannot go into banking or securities. Still too tight 
The sharp divisions between businesses have been relaxed a bit, but only gradually. Interest rates began to be liberalised in 1984. At the end of 1993, banks were finally allowed to underwrite corporate bonds (though not equities) through subsidiaries. And from the beginning of October, life and non-life insurers have been free to enter each other's business, again via subsidiaries. In spite of all this, the boundaries that remain between businesses are still substantial. 
Such tight control has become not just redundant, but positively harmful. To enable financial firms to earn a crust, bureaucrats have allowed the cost of many financial products and services to remain high by approving cartels and discouraging aggressive competition. Insurance premiums are fixed by bureaucratic fiat. Two decades after they were scrapped in America, and a decade after they disappeared in Britain, fixed commissions on all but the biggest share trades still raise the cost of buying equities in Japan. 
Mr Hashimoto now says that he wants to do away with this rigid financial system. Insurers, banks and securities firms, he promises, will be allowed to enter one another's business. Legal barriers separating the different sorts of banks are to be scrapped. Stock commissions and insurance premiums will be deregulated. The asset-management business will be opened up and the detailed rules that govern how pension funds allocate their money will be abandoned for a more general prudential requirement. 
Light the fuse. . . 
That is not all. The quality of financial information disclosed by companies will be improved by the adoption of accounts "consistent" with those of other developed countries. In short, assets will be valued at their proper market price, not the price at which they were bought. Pension funds will have to do this from next April. text:
PROMISES are one thing, action quite another. The reformist mettle of Ryutaro Hashimoto, Japan's prime minister, is about to get its first test. On November 12th, the day after Mr Hashimoto promised to deregulate the financial system, an advisory committee to the prime minister came out with the final version of a report into whether the Bank of Japan should be given more independence from the Ministry of Finance. Yes, said the report, it should, but only in return for greater accountability. 
Yet although the bank's governor, Yasuo Matsushita, supported the proposed reforms in public, in private its officials were disappointed at how little independence the measures would actually bring. Officials from the finance ministry would still be able to attend discussions of the bank's policy board; the government would be able to postpone centralbank decisions (it did not say for how long); and the report did not address the question of whether the ministry would still have control over the bank's budget. 
Since the report proposed to take little power away from them, finance ministry officials were understandably silent on the subject. Whether the meekness of the committee's recommendations was the result of strong-arming by the finance ministry is another matter. Six of the eight members were academics over whom the ministry presumably held little sway. The panel's less-than-revolutionary proposals may have had more to do with the fact that it was headed by Yasuhiko Torii, the dean of Keio University, who specialises in development economics rather than monetary matters. 
Does it matter if the bank does not get more independence? It may not. Countries who have given their central banks a greater measure of independence have done so because of their politicians' temptation to inflate the economy to get re-elected. In Japan, to get re-elected, politicians generally distribute pork, not growth. The country's inflation record has been second-to-none. 
Still, with Japan's stock of debt escalating as fast as it is-this year gross debt will almost equal the country's GDP-the temptation to inflate is presumably rising. An independent central bank might prevent that happening. The prime minister himself has said that reforming the 54-year-old law governing the bank is his government's most important task. 
All is not lost for the central bankers. The revision of the law is now to be discussed by yet another committee, the Financial System Research Council, which will draft a new law defining the Bank of Japan's status. Mr Hashimoto is then due to present this bill to the next full session of parliament. The prime minister could lean on this committee to propose far bolder recommendations than those contained in this week's report. If he is serious about reform, he will have to.

text:
RYUTARO HASHIMOTO, Japan's prime minister, looks pretty impregnable. With the solid backing of his own Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and at least a third of the parliamentary opposition, he can expect to muster an overwhelming majority on practically any issue that concerns him. In many ways, Mr Hashimoto's government is as robust as the one led by his former mentor, Noboru Takeshita, almost a decade ago. The only thing that could lay it low is a scandal-such as the Recruit "shares-for-favours" case that overwhelmed the Takeshita government. Over the past few weeks, a scandal that may prove as serious has begun to swirl around the Hashimoto government's feet. 
The problem is centred around Japan's Ministry of Health and Welfare (MHW). In the old days, this would have been an unlikely school for scandal. It was the big spending ministries, like construction, where the money-and the bribes-sloshed around. But with the ageing of the Japanese population, there is now big money in health care. In an effort to encourage the construction of old-people's homes, the central government has been offering subsidies of up to 50% of the cost of construction, with a further 25% to be paid by local governments. All that needs to be done is to convince local welfare authorities that a government-subsidised institution is needed. Altogether, some Y9 trillion ($8 billion) in subsidies are available. 
One man tempted by the scale of the largesse on offer was Hiroshi Koyama, the owner of a company that operates old-people's homes. Angling for subsidies of over billion to build four nursing homes, Mr Koyama has been accused of greasing the palms of bureaucrats who could help with the approval process. He was arrested on November 18th along with Shigeru Chatani, a 39-year-old former ministry official. All told, some seven health and welfare officials are currently under investigation-and the pool continues to widen. There is much speculation that thorough investigation will lead inexorably to the ranks of senior politicians. 
The biggest fish caught so far is Nobuharu Okamitsu, who resigned from his post as administrative vice-minister (senior civil servant) at MHW on November 19th, following allegations that he had been bought membership in a golf club worth Y16m by Mr Koyama and handed Y60m to help buy an apartment. In a melodramatic pre-dawn press conference, Junichiro Koizumi, the new health and welfare minister, who has a reputation for bureaucratbashing, announced that he may well take punitive action against Mr Okamitsu. 
The irony is that Mr Okamitsu was appointed to the ministry's top job in order to clear up the mess left by the last scandal there, when civil servants allowed the continued sale of HIV-tainted blood, with fatal results. He was also the author of a book on welfare in which he wrote: "Public expenditure is not rain from heaven, but sweat from the taxpayers' brow." Quite.
