FOR the past ten years, Japan's giant domestic telecoms carrier, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone (NTT), has been trying to avoid being broken up. Although a decision was postponed earlier this year, both the prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, and his new telecommunications minister, Hisao Horinouchi, want NTT's fate decided as soon as possible, preferably before the year is out. But the proposed merger of Britain's BT with America's MCI has thrown the debate into confusion. 
One option, championed by the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, is to copy what happened to ATa,T in America in 84. Under this proposal, the world's largest telephone company would be split into two regional domestic carriers and a longdistance one, which would then be free to enter the international market from which the giant is presently barred. The strategy would eliminate cross-subsidies between NTT's local and long-distance operations. It might also-although America's experience is not encouraging here-bring some transparency into the charges NTr makes for access to the local telephone network, which most complain are too high. 
But there are several drawbacks to a split. NIT claims that the administrative costs would be high, at V450 billion ($4 billion). More compelling is the fact that, as America found, replacing a national monopoly with several local ones achieves only half the benefits of competition: longdistance charges remain inflated by the fees firms must pay local carriers to deliver their calls. For Japanese politicians and bureaucrats, a third argument has the greatest force. In the wake of the deal between BT and MCI, which created the first of what are expected to be several global "supercarriers", it seems perverse to make Japan's telecoms giant smaller. 
For all these reasons an alternative method of dealing with nr's dominance has been gaining ground. It is championed by a telecoms sub-committee of the Economic Council, an advisory body to the prime minister. Tsuruhiko Nambu, an economics professor at Gakushuin University, and the sub-committee's chairman, argues that NTT should remain intact and that it should be allowed into the international market; that Japan's entire telecoms market should be flung open; and that a tough, independent regulator should decide how much NTT could charge other companies for access to its local customers. 
The committee's report is due to be presented to the prime minister on December 3rd. Its recipe is closer to Britain's model, which left BT intact and exposed it to growing competition. For this solution to work, though, everything depends on the ferocity of the regulator. Britain's Don Cruickshank, who has recently visited Tokyo, has had a weary battle to force competition on BT. After 12 years of this, the giant still has 9o% of the British domestic market. 
In Japan's case, NTT's domestic competition comes from other long-distance firms and from mobile telephone companies (the largest of which it owns). The mobile market is booming-and with it NT-r'S operating profits. The access charges mobile-telephone firms pay NTT to connect their calls help explain its 38% leap in earnings, to V245.4 billion, from the first halves of the previous and current financial years. 
But the brunt of the decision about nrz-r's future will be felt by Japan's three existing international carriers, particularly the biggest, Kokusai Denshin Denwa (KDD) which once had a monopoly. One way or another, Nfl will be allowed to enter the international market. 
The three are already struggling: in contrast to NTT's huge rise in profits, KDD'S Operating profits fell by 20% in the first six months of this year. KDD'S problem is its high costs. The price of international calls from Japan is twice the Asian average and fully three times that of international calls from America. Their business is therefore an easy target for the attentions of "callback" companies, which enable people in Japan to call abroad at the lower international rates charged in other countries. There are now more than 40 call-back firms in Japan. Their tariffs for calls to the United States are, on average, half the price charged by KDD, according to Eric Gan of Goldman Sachs, an investment bank (see chart). 
Call-back competition is still smallprobably not more than 5% of the market. But it is having an impact: on November 14th KDD announced that it wanted to cut rates by an average of 5.1%. NTI, with its familiar brand name and 6om customers, poses a much greater threat. The news that the Economic Council thought NTT should be allowed into the international market unfettered sent KDD'S shares skidding by 5.6% on November z7th alone; since the middle of August they have fallen by 40%.

text:
CYNICS who say Ryutaro Hashimoto's new cabinet is merely going through the motions of shrinking the Ministry of Finance may yet have to eat their words. Under Mr Hashimoto's leadership, Japan's Liberal Democratic Party(LDP) increased its strength in parliament in the election on October 20th thanks largely to promises about curbing the size and influence of the country's meddlesome bureaucracy. Even so, Mr Hashimoto has been harsher on the ministry than many expected. 
In the past, there was little to be gained from irritating such a powerful ministry. But voters are furious about the government's bungling of the banking sector's bad loan mess, the multi-billion dollar trading scandal at Daiwa Bank, and the use of public money to liquidate the jusen mortgage companies. All of these matters fall within the finance ministry's purview. Mr Hashimoto knows a lot of political capital is to be had from hitting the ministry. 
On December 2nd, Mr Hashimoto defied his party barons and declared that the ministry would be stripped of all its powers to oversee financial institutions. That responsibility would be handed instead to a new independent body-provisionally called the Financial Inspection and Supervisory Agency-which would report directly to the prime minister's office. A cabinet minister, it was suggested, would be in charge, not a bureaucrat. Gasps of disbelief and outrage have been reverberating around the finance ministry ever since. 
Well they might. Mr Hashimoto's cabinet is packed with bigwigs from the LDP'S various factions. Ever since the election these people have been quietly arguing that he should go slow on financial reform. Most senior members of Japan's ruling party owe their reputations for bringing home the bacon partly to their cosy relations with finance-ministry officials. Over the past month, the ministry has gone out of its way to court LDP members from rural constituencies, offering additional subsidies for local farmers and construction projects. Rumours are rife about tax audits being threatened for any LDP members rash enough to advocate breaking up the ministry. 
If push comes to shove, the finance ministry would probably surrender the nitty-gritty task of examining financial institutions' loan portfolios. But it is loth to give up its far more important power of administrative guidance, which it uses daily to whisper advice into the ears of banking, securities and insurance executives. This power is viewed as essential, not least because it allows the ministry's officials to line up their well-paid jobs for retirement. 
The prime minister may yet succumb to resistance from nervous colleagues. But pressure is mounting for the government to do something. In addition, the finance ministry, normally dedicated to budget balancing, is being blamed for the continuing dismal performance of the economy. The two small opposition parties that support Mr Hashimoto's minority government, the Social Democrats and Sakigake, are insisting that the ministry be defanged. They are backing Mr Hashimoto's bid to have the enabling legislation drawn up quickly so a bill can be presented to parliament early in the new year. 
Although the finance ministry may bear the brunt of Mr Hashimoto's reforms, another institution, the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications' post office savings system, seems to have escaped unscathed. Politicians of every hue are reluctant to see control of the world's biggest bank, with deposits of f220 trillion ($2 trillion), pass to an independent body well away from their own sticky fingers. When times are hard, parliamentarians can be relied upon to lobby hard for supplementary budgets-which invariably means using postal savings to funnel money into boondoggles back home. That is the one perk that reformers are not going to be allowed to spoil.

text:
LIKE many of his generation, Koji Kobayashi did not know when to quit. He was one of a handful of men of towering talent who created the industrial powerhouse of modern Japan. He took Nippon Electric Company (today known solely by its initials, NEC) through Japan's period of austerity and long back-breaking hours of reconstruction, to make it one of the world's electronics giants. A story is told that, in the early hard-up days after the second world war, the determined Mr Kobayashi carried around the firm's cash in a bag to prevent it being seized by creditors. Employees would be paid in secret outside the NEC factory. 
He deserves his encomium as "father of reconstruction". Long before MITI,Japan's famed Ministry of International Trade and Industry, came up in 1979 with its slogan "Information is the Future" Mr Kobayashi had been steadily turning an equipment maker into an information-technology firm. NEC was the first Japanese firm to acquire, under licence, American semiconductor expertise. In 1963, it was the first firm in Japan to make semiconductors. 
In 1964 the lad who had started in NEC straight from university was made president of the company. He was then 57, an age when people in corporate Japan might be expected to think of retiring. But Mr Kobayashi continued to dominate NEC-and the rest of the Japanese electronics industry-well into his eighties. Even in his dotage, as chairman emeritus, showing up at his office twice a week, he continued to hold enormous sway over the business, retaining the right to vote on crucial issues. As such, he was all that is good and bad about Japanese management. 
The perils of fatherhood 
What had been good for Japan in the 1960s and 1970s had become dubious by the 198os-and positively detrimental by the 199os.A particular problem has been the way former captains of industry, Mr Kobayashi especially, cast a shadow across swathes of the economy. In some cases, the protective measures they sought while their battered industries were struggling for survival persist when they are no longer needed, imposing a costly burden on Japanese consumers. In others it is the companies that suffer, not necessarily from protection but from the inflexibility of their own ideas. 
None more so, ironically, than NEC. Two generations of managers struggled to wrestle the company free from Mr Kobayashi's version of the future. Undoubtedly, "C&C", the slogan he coined in 1977 to denote the convergence of computing and communications, was a nifty idea at the time. But what ought to have been little more than a fleeting observation became elevated into a corporate philosophy-a mantra masquerading as a strategy. Mr Kobayashi had a forceful manner. During the war, any colleague regarded as troublesome had been challenged by him to a sword fight. Employees of Mr Kobayashi said he promoted his ideas with the determination of a kyoso, a word usually used to describe the founder of a religion. He wrote a handful of books on cac and travelled the world preaching his gospel. NEC became a prisoner of a catchphrase, causing it to miss out on opportunities that Fujitsu, Toshiba and even stolid Hitachi quickly pounced upon. It was only two years ago that NEC began belatedly to enter the multimedia business. And, despite NEc's lauded strength in C&C, it had to buy its way in. 
Mr Kobayashi's headstrong views left the company ill-prepared for other changes. More than Fujitsu or Toshiba, NEC is still reeling from the body-blows that Japanese computer makers received at the hands of an American upstart in 1992. A decade earlier, NEC had come up with the first personal-computer design suitable for Japan, and had gone on to grab half the domestic Pc market. Even when cheap IBM-clones became the rage abroad during the 198os, Mr Kobayashi insisted that his company's rcs should use its own proprietary design. It says much for his powers of persuasion that many Japanese software firms committed themselves to producing computer programs strictly for the NEC design, and not compatible with IBM'S. In so doing, Mr Kobayashi made NEC's design the dominant standard for Japan-and thereby kept the foreign competition at bay. 
With no cheap clones from abroad to worry about and hogging 50% of the domestic market, NEC earned huge profits from selling PCs in Japan during the 198os. Then Compaq spoilt everything. In a brilliant assault on the Japanese market, the clonemaker from Texas offered PCs that sold for half the price of those of NEC. American firms such as IBM and Dell followed with lowpriced machines. Financially, NEC has suffered ever since. 
Thanks to a new generation of managers, NEC will doubtless make the painful adjustments and recover. But the company's fall from grace is a reminder of the perils of pride at the top. The vitality-sapping influence of Mr Kobayashi's outmoded view is a parable for modern Japan. That, more than anything, is what Ryutaro Hashimoto's government is now trying to change.

text:
NO SOONER does Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Japanese prime minister, seek to douse the flames of one bureaucratic scandal than he has to send the fire brigade racing to another. A bribery case involving the Ministry of Health and Welfare is getting all the media coverage. But it is a corruption case smouldering away at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) that looks the more incendiary. 
The health and welfare row has forced the prime minister to admit to receiving a total of *7m ($62,ooo) in political donations from organisations linked to the bribery scandal. Mr Hashimoto, who had at first denied the allegations, has now apologised for being so "careless" and has offered to return the money. It is in fact small compared with other sums illegally changing hands at the health ministry. A former senior civil servant there, now under arrest, has admitted to receiving more than V65m from a favour-seeking businessman. 
But when it comes to putting the squeeze on business, the health bureaucrats are amateurs compared with the MITI officials who lord it over the oil industry. The scandal that is causing real anxiety throughout Nagatacho (the Capitol Hill of Tokyo) concerns an oil wholesaleing company called Izui Sekiyu Shokai. Its founder, Junichi Izui, was arrested in early November on suspicion of evading taxes on V66om out of the V4.2 billion he earned on deals with Mitsubishi Oil during 1992-94. 
Where, asked the prosecutor's office, was the undeclared money going? Aided by files they hauled off, they have established a trail leading to MITI, as well as back to Mitsubishi Oil. Mitsubishi was one of several oil companies bidding for prospecting rights in Vietnam in the early 199os. Though something of an outsider, Mitsubishi won the rights to a sector that has subsequently proved to be rich in oil. Mitsubishi received substantial assistance in pushing its bid from MITI. Oiling the wheels, so to speak, were a number of officials within MITI, who had been lavishly entertained by none other than Mr Izui. 
Shinji Sato, the new trade minister, was so concerned about corruption at MITI that he cancelled his trip to the World Trade Organisation meeting in Singapore this week. Instead he spent his time interrogating 130 senior officials. No fewer than 42 of the officials were found to have been on the take. Six of MITI'S senior career bureaucrats have been reprimanded, and the top civil servant has received a pay cut for doing a lousyjob. 
But not all of Mr Izui's Y66om slush fund was used to lubricate officials at MITI. Indeed, the authorities now suspect that much of it, and other money, was handed back to Mitsubishi and used to pay for political favours higher up. For instance, the person who put in a good word for Mitsubishi during the bidding process in Hanoi in 199o was the late Michio Watanabe, a senior Liberal Democrat politician with a wealth of useful contacts in Vietnam. Mr Watanabe was the deputy prime minister and foreign minister at the time. 
To date, nine LDP members of the Diet-including Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, the finance minister, and Taku Yamasaki, the party's policy boss-are known to have accepted political contributions from Mr Izui. Bloodhounds in the prosecutor's office are now sniffing the money trail up the hill to the Diet. Having high-ranking bureaucrats on the take is bad enough. But a scandal that rocked the cabinet could end Mr Hashimoto's spell in office.

text:
THERE are few things so pleasing to the ear as the wail of a dying cartel. "It is truly regrettable that the agreement will surely damage consumers' interests," fumed Takeo Inokuchi, the chairman of the Marine & Life Insurance Association of Japan, on December 15th. "We question the agreement because it is . . . at the expense of the business interests of Japanese non-life insurers." 
The agreement that has infuriated Mr Inokuchi was an insurance deal between America and Japan on December 14th, the day before an American-imposed deadline. This would, in the words of a gushing American press release, "dramatically deregulate the Japanese insurance market." For once this was not hyberbole: business will become much tougher for Japanese non-life insurers. But for consumers, the price of insurance will come down. 
The Americans have been trying to batter down the door into the Japanese market since 1993, so far with limited success. Of the Y6.32 trillion ($66.8 billion) paid in non-life premiums last year, foreigners collected just Y134 billion. Why have their efforts borne fruit now? Many deadlines have, after all, come and gone. This time, though, the deal bears the stamp of Ryutaro Hashimoto, Japan's prime minister. In early November, Mr Hashimoto promised a financial "Big Bang" to resuscitate the country's ailing financial markets. Many Americans did not believe him. They were wrong. The agreement was probably as surprising to American negotiators as it was unwelcome to the big Japanese insurance companies. 
The foreigners are already in Japan, but have been unable to compete by offering cheaper insurance. Premiums are set by a supposedly independent body, overseen by the finance ministry. Its aim is not to give consumers a good deal but to keep even the duffest Japanese insurance firms in business. Although premiums may be set 10% above or below the rate established by this body, in practice the cartel is so strong-five firms control more than half the market-that rates do not vary. Uniquely among insurance firms in rich countries, Japanese insurers actually make money writing policies. (Elsewhere firms typically lose money on policies but make it up from investing premium payments until they have to pay claims.) 
For how much longer? Car insurance accounts for half of the revenues in the nonlife sector. From next September insurers will be able to set premiums on car insurance freely. Those with the lowest costs and most accurate way of assessing risk will win out. Japanese insurers not only have high overheads-the big five have 270,ooo salespeople-but heavy regulation means that they also lack the skills for pricing risk. Foreign firms such as AIG and Cigna, both from America, have neither handicap. AIG'S Japanese subsidiary, for example, has sold policies by telephone since early December, with prices to% below the official rate. The price is expected to fall further once other government restrictions are removed. 
The effects on Japan's insurance market will be dramatic. At the moment, points out Paul Heaton of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, an investment bank, an 18-year-old boy racer would pay about the same insurance as his dad, who keeps his car in a garage all week and takes it out for an occasional spin at weekends. With more accurate pricing of risk, boy racers will pay more but overall premiums will fall sharply. Unless they get their act together, Mr Heaton reckons, the biggest insurers may see their profits fall by anything up to 60%. 
Japanese insurance firms think that differentiating insurance premiums according to risk is wrong. They say that some youngsters might not be able to pay more for their car insurance. Perhaps; but the truth is that teenagers are riskier than their parents. And accurate pricing of financial risk in Japan is crucial to a healthier financial system-whatever the country's insurance companies say.

text:
Ryutaro Hashimoto could well surprise his critics by proving to be a radical deregulator. It is in Japan's, and his own, interest that he does 
IT HAS not been an easy start to the year for Ryutaro Hashimoto, Japan's prime minister. Since December 17th his government has been embroiled in a terrorist siege, thousands of miles away at the Japanese ambassador's residence in Peru; more than 7o hostages are still being held, some of them Japanese. Back home Japan's 125m people are far more worried about economic matters, and with good reason: the world's second-largest economy appears to be heading downhill again after an upward spurt at the start of 1996. Mr Hashimoto's government is being blamed for being too slow to deregulate and too fast, in its budget for 1997-98, to raise taxes. The Tokyo stockmarket has been tumbling, and so has the yen. And this is hardly surprising, say most pundits-Mr Hashimoto's Liberal Democratic Party, which has ruled Japan for most of the post-war period, was never likely to make the sort of radical changes the country really needs. 
Yet that judgment would be both unfair and premature. Unfair, because since October 20th when Japan's election returned Mr Hashimoto and his party to government the prime minister has in fact been a surprisingly bold and enthusiastic reformer. Many of his proposals have yet to become law, but the signs are that Mr Hashimoto is going to shake up the bureaucracy and deregulate the economy far more than most people expected (see pages 19-21). The judgment would be premature not only for that reason but also because this process of deregulation and governmental change is directed at the long term, not the short. And that process is of international importance: it could make the difference between a Japan that is vibrant, confident and outward-looking, and one that is sluggish,jittery and parochial. 
A matter of self-interest 
Why should Japan make radical reforms? And why should Mr Hashimoto be the man to make them? The second question is the simpler to answer: because public opinion is pressing for reforms, and Mr Hashimoto knows that if he fails to deliver he will hand the fragmented opposition an ideal flag around which to rally. His party fell just short of an overall majority in parliament in October, so he needs the support of some tiny parties and knows that a fresh election may not be far away. He and his party have a selfish interest in change. There is nothing wrong in that. So does Japan. 
There is a basic difference between this bout of reform and the many waves of "market-opening" that Japanese governments have announced over the past decade or more. It is that those waves occurred chiefly because of foreign pressure. Today's clamour for reform has nothing to do with American trade negotiators or other foreigners. It is entirely a domestic affair. And it is arising for two quite different reasons. 
The first is purely pragmatic. Most areas of Japan's economy are intensely competitive, with Toyota slugging it out against Nissan, say, or Matsushita against Sony. Some, however, remain tightly regulated, with monopolies or oligopolies protected against new entrants, whether Japanese or foreign. This keeps prices high and discourages innovation. While the rest of the economy was booming, few people worried about this. Now, however, Japan has had four lean years; the next four look modest at best; and over the horizon can be seen the heavy burden on taxes and pensions likely to be imposed by the rapid ageing of Japan's population. 
This has focused minds on the fact that many of the most protected, highly regulated sectors produce inputs for other companies and so their high prices make everyone suffer. This is particularly true of areas such as telecommunications, air transport, road freight, and wholesale and retail distribution, but it also applies to agriculture and construction. Opening these areas to competition and innovation would lower prices and generate new jobs and activity, just as it did in the 1980s in America and Britain. Those who would lose from deregulation are bound to oppose it, fiercely. Now, however, there is a wider interest in overcoming that opposition. Mr Hashimoto has made a good start in exploiting that interest, but he has a long way to go. 
The second reason is philosophical. For years, decades even, most Japanese have believed that although politicians may be corrupt or incompetent, bureaucrats could be relied upon to save the day. Bureaucrats were hardly thought of as civil servants; more like civil masters, really. That is changing. The combination of a long-drawn-out recession and of frequent revelations of bureaucratic dishonesty and corruption mean that today's favourite sport, in politics, the media and among the public at large, is bureaucrat-bashing. The state apparatus is no longer seen as the solution to problems; it is seen as part of the problem. 
In this lie both opportunities and threats. Opportunities, because recalcitrant officials will be less able to obstruct the deregulation that Japan needs. Many bureaucrats now support economic deregulation. But threats, too, because it is important in any democracy that there is a basic confidence in the institutions of government, and that is what Japan has lost. To restore it, Japan needs laws to enforce more openness on its ministries and to put checks on bureaucrats' power to make up rules as they go along. Such reforms, like those for economic deregulation, look easier in theory than they are in practice. It will take a bold prime minister to achieve them.

Since December 17th Ryutaro Hashimoto's government has been embroiled in a terrorist siege , thousands of miles away at the Japanese ambassador 's residence in Peru ; more than 7o hostages are still being held , some of them Japanese . Ryutaro Hashimoto's government is being blamed for being too slow to deregulate and too fast , in its budget for 1997 - 98 , to raise taxes . The Tokyo stockmarket has been tumbling , and so has the yen . And this is hardly surprising , say most pundits - Ryutaro Hashimoto's Liberal Democratic Party , which has ruled Japan for most of the post - war period , was never likely to make the sort of radical changes the country really needs .

Unfair , because since October 20th when Japan 's election returned Ryutaro Hashimoto and Ryutaro Hashimoto's party to government Ryutaro Hashimoto has in fact been a surprisingly bold and enthusiastic reformer . text:
Against all expectations, it looks as if Japan really is reforming its economy 
"NOBODY bashes Japan any more; Japan is nothing to anyone," laments Isao Nakauchi, the boss of Daiei, Japan's biggest retailer. An exaggeration perhaps, but not much of one. Gone are the heady 198os, when Japanese companies seemed unstoppable; when, briefly, backof-the-envelope calculations suggested Tokyo's land was worth more than the whole of America; when some Japanese and western commentators opined that Japan had developed a form of capitalism newer and better than that practised elsewhere. 
All this now smacks of hubris. Seven years after the bursting of the stockmarket and property bubbles, Japan's economy is still struggling. GDP fell in the second half of 1996, a period of strong world growth. So did Tokyo's stockmarket. Since 1992, America's GDP has expanded by a cumulative 22%,Japan's by 6%. 
Can Japan bounce back? It has tried everything. Throwing public money at the economy succeeded, in 199296, in moderating the slump but it is now incapable of generating sustained growth. Nor, any longer, can Japan export its way out of trouble. In desperation, politicians and some bureaucrats seem to be embracing an idea they have paid lip service to for years: that the only way to get the economy moving is to cut bureaucratic control and deregulate. 
In his first speech to parliament after retaining the prime ministership in October 1996, Ryutaro Hashimoto promised sweeping reforms and big reductions in the number and power of ministries. "It is clear," says the new trade and industry minister, Shinji Sato, "that the current Japanese economic system, which supported the half-century of economic development following world war two, has reached its limit." 
Well, politicians have been saying this sort of thing for years. What is different now? The short answer is that this time there is more than waffle. In mid-November, for example, Mr Hashimoto said that Japan's financial markets, like Britain's ten years earlier, would get a "Big Bang"; by zoot broking commissions are to be liberalised, and the walls separating Japan's compartmentalised financial industry torn down. The aim is to reverse the longterm decline in the share of GDP contributed by the financial sector. 
Barely three weeks later, the prime minister declared that the finance ministry, Japan's most powerful bureaucracy, would be stripped of its powers to supervise financial institutions. The ministry has been shamed by its bungling of Japan's banking crisis. Supervisory powers are to be transferred to a new independent body reporting to the prime minister. In mid-December, Japan said it would deregulate insurance, one of the most closely controlled bits of the economy and the subject of a protracted trade row with America. Insurance premiums, which are presently fixed will, except in life insurance, be deregulated; insurers will be able to determine their own rates. 
The financial sector is not alone. At the moment, in the domestic airline business, would-be carriers have to get permission for every route from the Ministry of Transport, which sets fares and the number of seats available. The ministry has refused to allow newcomers into the business. Now, it seems willing to countenance some competition. The day after Mr Hashimoto announced his financial Big Bang, Skymark, a discount airline, set up shop-the first new airline allowed for more than 40 years. 
As with airlines, so with telecoms. In December, the government decided to restructure nTT, the world's biggest telephone company. For the first time NTT will be allowed to offer international calls; in return KDD, Japan's erstwhile state-owned overseas telephone company, and the two other private international telephone firms will be allowed into the domestic market. 
A Japan that can say "Help" 
It is a long list and shows that something is genuinely going on: reform is not just talk. Still, the fact of reform is one thing, its real significance another. Japan's economy, after all, though competitive in most areas, remains extensively regulated in parts. There is a lot to do. Are the reforms undertaken or promised so far just piecemeal change, confined to areas where movement can no longer be avoided? Or are Japanese politicians to be taken seriously when they claim the reforms are an attempt to overhaul the entire system of economic management in modern Japan? 
A conclusive answer is not yet possible but there are reasons for thinking that, with a couple of qualifications, the process is more likely to prove a bold overhaul than a modest tinkering. The first qualification is that the government has made life more difficult for itself by its fiscal stance. In the budget for 1997 (unveiled on December 25th) government spending is to fall only slightly in real terms and rise in nominal terms. True, government borrowing will be cut, but only because taxes will rise. The government is still not resisting all old-style porkbarrel temptations: it will allocate V34 billion ($295m) to new bullet-train lines likely to lose money. 
A second qualification is that anti-competitive measures could slip through and blunt the deregulatory edge of reform. Consider NTT. The company will not be broken up. Rather, it will become two local firms and one long-distance one, with shares in all three being held by a holding company. Unless the regulator is tough, there is no obvious competitive advance there-and in one respect it is a backward step. In order to push NTS restructuring through, a ban on holding companies, in force since 1947, will have to be overturned. The ban was originally imposed to promote competition by breaking up the monopoly powers of the zaibatsu, conglomerates which once dominated Japanese industry (zaibatsu were controlled by holding companies). Permitting the return of the old ownership pattern, some people fear, could allow back an excessive concentration of power-though the danger is smaller now that Japan's economy is huge and sophisticated than it was when the economy was small and immature. 
Why reform could bite 
That said, there are three reasons for thinking reform could end up changing the economy for the better. The first is that it will be hard to restrict the scope of reform now it has started. Change one thing in Japan and you start changing many others. 
At the moment, companies may fire people only if there are "reasonable grounds"-a provision usually interpreted to mean "if the company as a whole is losing money". If a firm is in profit overall, it cannot fire workers from loss-making divisions. The introduction of holding companies would enable bosses to redefine lossmaking divisions as separate firms from which redundancies would be possible. 
That is not all: holding companies would also require a change to Japan's tax system. At the moment, profits in one company may not be offset by losses in another. Holding companies need to be able to do this, so Japan will have to introduce consolidated taxes, which it plans to do by 1998. In short, the restructuring of NTT could lead, through holding companies and consolidated taxes, to a wider restructuring of corporate Japan, largely, though not entirely, for the better. 
The second reason for thinking reform could be swift and thorough is that there appears to be nearconsensual support for it among the great and good. At the end of November, in the space of a week, three committees came out with deregulatory proposals. One set up by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) submitted 133 proposals. The Economic Council, which advises the prime minister, produced a list of six areas for reform. And the Administrative Reform Committee, set up at the end of 1994 in the prime minister's office, argued for accelerated reform in 13 areas. 
Of these, the Economic Council was the most radical. It demanded the easing, then scrapping of building restrictions to loosen up the property market. It wanted to throw open telecoms to all entrants. It called for an end to many of the rules that make shipping and road haulage two of the country's most regulated and corrupt businesses. It recommended the abolition of restrictive laws affecting employment agencies. Behind such proposals lies an intellectual revolution: almost all decision makers agree that change must come. 
The third reason for taking seriously Japanese politicians' professions of radicalism is that-to be blunt-they have little choice. Reform looks like their only chance to reinvigorate the economy. Apart from the bubble years of the late i98os, Japan's economic growth has been slowing since the early 1970s (see chart). In the past five years such meagre growth as it has achieved has derived mostly from the V33.6 trillion ($3oo billion) of reflationary public-spending packages. The biggest of these, in 1995, pumped a massive Y9 trillion into the economy, equivalent to almost 2% of GDP. 
The economy duly surged by 8.4% in the first quarter of 1996 but, in confirmation that such a stimulus can now be nothing more than the shortest of short-term fixes, GDP shrank in the second quarter. Most economists think the economy will grow by only 1.5% in 1997. Some think even less. 
What to do? Exports are not a solution. Even if a massive export drive were possible (which, given the shifting of manufacturing abroad, it may not be), such a drive would be politically unthinkable: no one in Japan wants more trade rows with the United States. 
Interest rates are at rock bottom (the discount rate is just o.5%); they cannot be reduced further. The government's finances are in a dreadful mess. Public debt has been soaring for the past five years and the government is desperate to tighten fiscal policy to restrain it. That will do nothing to boost economic growth. 
So what is left? If fiscal and monetary tools are not available, if exports will not soar, if the cost of capital cannot be cut, then the case for deregulation grows ever stronger. True, it is an odd instrument to use to jump-start a stalled economy. It changes an economy's structure and takes years to make its full impact.japan's immediate problem is at least partly a cyclical short-term matter, with consumer confidence, banks and companies still suffering the after-effects of the bust of 1991-92. Nevertheless, even if deregulation will not dramatically increase next year's growth, there. is little doubt that it is needed-and will benefit the economy considerably in the long term. 
The price is wrong 
Contrary to rumour,Japan is not a planned economy. But over-regulation is a big problem, as Japan's high costs show. The cost of living in Tokyo is almost 60% higher than in New York, according to Japan's Economic Planning Agency (EPA) Sharp, an electronics company, compares operating costs in Japan with other countries. Apart from the cost of money, everything is pricier in Japan, often dramatically so (see table on next page). 
High costs have many causes, regulation foremost amongst them. For example: 
Housing. Rules limit the amount of floor space that can be built on a plot of land to (normally) zoo-3oo% of the size of the plot Originally imposed because of the dangers of earthquakes, these "plot ratios" have become outdated: technological advances mean that tall buildings can be as safe as short ones. Yet Japanese cities sprawl outwards, two-storied, bidding up the cost of land. 
Distribution. Coastal shipping is a cartel; new ships cannot be built unless old ones are scrapped. It costs more to ship something from Yokohama to Hokkaido than to Los Angeles. Ports are almost entirely regulated; entry to any port businesses, such as running warehouses, is virtually closed to newcomers. It is three times as expensive to move a container in the port of Kobe as in Hong Kong. Trucking firms are controlled by a bewildering system of permits. 
Retailing. The Large-Scale Retail Store Law still makes it difficult to set up large shops. Until 1992, any firm that wanted to set up a big shop had to ask permission from existing small ones. They rarely voted to commit commercial suicide. So Japan is dominated by shops employing two people or fewer; they account for 14% of total retail sales, double the figure for America. In 1992 the law was relaxed. Anyone who wanted to open a big shop merely had to seek permission from local-government committees. The number of shops of over soo square metres has risen fast as a result. But permission for supermarkets is far from automatic: the committees that consider applications include many owners of small shops. 
How much could the ending of such rules help businesses? In some sectors, enormously. The mobile-telephone market provides an extreme example. In 1994 the Japanese were, for the first time, allowed to own, notjust rent, hand sets. In April ofthat year, there were 2.13m subscribers; twoand-a-half years later there were zom. In 1996, DoCoMo, the mobile-telephone arm of NTr, spent the equivalent of almost 0.2% of GDP on investment on mobile telephones alone. 
Not every business will do so well: there will be losers (such as some small shops) as well as winners. On balance, though, more jobs stand to be won in unshackled industries than lost in mollycoddled ones. 
The EPA, which is the main official champion of deregulation, recently estimated that the government's limited deregulatory efforts so far had contributed 1.69 extra percentage points to GDP growth each year between 1990 and 1995. This somewhat rosy analysis (which looked at the benefits of growth in the big shops, but not at the effects of deregulation on small ones) is confirmed by a more thorough study of deregulation being undertaken by the OECD. The organisation is looking at five sectors: electricity, airlines, trucking, telecoms and retail distribution. These account for between 15% and 20% of GDP in the countries in the study (America, Germany, France, Britain and Japan) The preliminary results suggest that in Japan, deregulating these sectors alone could cut prices in those areas by between to% and 2o% and boost GDP by over 6% more than it would otherwise have grown over the next ten years. Why? 
The answer is not just that these sectors are heavily regulated, but also that they provide inputs for other sectors of the economy. Deregulating them therefore has a big knock-on effect. The OECD, which is to publish the full study later in 1997, may well be underestimating how much of one. Even halving the productivity gap with the rest of the OECD would, on the OECD'Sown calculations, boost GDP by 2%-and increase real incomes by $120 billion a year. 
The case against 
The economics of reform might be unimpeachable. The reasons for adopting it might be compelling. The commitment to it of many politicians and officials might well be strong. Nevertheless, a measure of scepticism is always required when dealing with japanese politics. How large a dose is needed now? 
Mr Hashimoto is not, by nature, a radical reformer. His record after becoming prime minister in January 1996 hardly inspires confidence: big deregulatory decisions were postponed, raising suspicions about his commitment to change. Even if his reformist zeal were genuine, his ability to push through change is limited by the weakness of his office. He needs to keep the backing of party barons, some of whom, now that the LDP seems entrenched in power again, may hanker after a return to the pork-barrel politics of old. 
Moreover, the LDP relies upon the vested interests that reform would cut down to size. Some of these interests will be immensely hard to tackle, in agriculture, for example, and construction. Reformers must also cope with what critics see as an "iron triangle", in which politicians get bureaucrats to distribute lucrative contracts to local companies; the companies provide money to politicians, and the bureaucrats eventually land plum jobs in the companies which have distributed largesse. 
Yet these practices are increasingly getting the scrutiny and censure they deserve. Two examples have been gripping Japan of late. One involves the Ministry of Health and Welfare, whose top bureaucrat was arrested in December for allegedly taking bribes from a nursing-homes constructor. The other involves MITI, which investigated I30 of its bureaucrats for taking "favours" from an oil distributor; some have even been reprimanded. It is a start. 
If the past five miserable years have had a silver lining, it is the soul-searching about why Japan's economy has performed so miserably of late. "Nobody", says Peter Tasker, an analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, an investment bank, "thinks that the way that Japan does things is better." The soul-searching has produced that intellectual revolution and near-consensus for reform which made the 1996 general election so dull; everyone was singing from the same hymnbook. But dull as it seems, it is this widespread agreement that could presage change. 
Japan sometimes seems to be unalterable. Certainly, it eschews change through confrontation. But often, behind the facade, a consensus can coalesce for a new way of doing things. When that happens, change can be profound. It may be happening already. By the turn of the century the Japanese economy could well look very different-and more dynamic than it looks now.

In 1994 the Japanese were , for the first time , allowed to own , notjust rent , hand sets . In April ofthat year , there were 2.13 m subscribers ; twoand - a - half years later there were zom . In 1996 , DoCoMo , the mobile - telephone arm of NTr , spent the equivalent of almost 0.2 % of GDP on investment on mobile telephones alone . 
 Not every business will do so well : there will be losers ( such as some small shops ) as well as winners . On balance , though , more jobs stand to be won in unshackled industries than lost in mollycoddled ones . 
 The EPA , which is the main official champion of deregulation , recently estimated that the government 's limited deregulatory efforts so far had contributed 1.69 extra percentage points to GDP growth each year between 1990 and 1995 . This somewhat rosy analysis ( which looked at the benefits of growth in the big shops , but not at the effects of deregulation on small ones ) is confirmed by a more thorough study of deregulation being undertaken by the OECD . The organisation is looking at five sectors : electricity , airlines , trucking , telecoms and retail distribution . These account for between 15 % and 20 % of GDP in the countries in the study ( America , Germany , France , Britain and Japan ) The preliminary results suggest that in Japan , deregulating these sectors alone could cut prices in those areas by between to% and 2o% and boost GDP by over 6 % more than it would otherwise have grown over the next ten years . Why ? 
 The answer is not just that these sectors are heavily regulated , but also that they provide inputs for other sectors of the economy . Deregulating them therefore has a big knock - on effect . The OECD , which is to publish the full study later in 1997 , may well be underestimating how much of one . Even halving the productivity gap with the rest of the OECD would , on the OECD'Sown calculations , boost GDP by 2%-and increase real incomes by $ 120 billion a year . 
 The case against 
 The economics of reform might be unimpeachable . The reasons for adopting it might be compelling . The commitment to it of many politicians and officials might well be strong . Nevertheless , a measure of scepticism is always required when dealing with japanese politics . How large a dose is needed now ? 
 Ryutaro Hashimoto is not , by nature , a radical reformer . Ryutaro Hashimoto's record after becoming prime minister in January 1996 hardly inspires confidence : big deregulatory decisions were postponed , raising suspicions about Ryutaro Hashimoto's commitment to change . Even if Ryutaro Hashimoto's reformist zeal were genuine , Ryutaro Hashimoto's ability to push through change is limited by the weakness of Ryutaro Hashimoto's office . Ryutaro Hashimoto needs to keep the backing of party barons , some of whom , now that the LDP seems entrenched in power again , may hanker after a return to the pork - barrel politics of old . 
 Moreover , the LDP relies upon the vested interests that reform would cut down to size . Some of these interests will be immensely hard to tackle , in agriculture , for example , and construction . Reformers must also cope with what critics see as an " iron triangle " , in which politicians get bureaucrats to distribute lucrative contracts to local companies ; the companies provide money to politicians , and the bureaucrats eventually land plum jobs in the companies which have distributed largesse . 
 Yet these practices are increasingly getting the scrutiny and censure they deserve . Two examples have been gripping Japan of late . One involves the Ministry of Health and Welfare , whose top bureaucrat was arrested in December for allegedly taking bribes from a nursing - homes constructor . The other involves MITI , which investigated I30 of its bureaucrats for taking " favours " from an oil distributor ; some have even been reprimanded . It is a start . 
 If the past five miserable years have had a silver lining , it is the soul - searching about why Japan 's economy has performed so miserably of late . " Nobody " , says Peter Tasker , an analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson , an investment bank , " thinks that the way that Japan does things is better . " The soul - searching has produced that intellectual revolution and near - consensus for reform which made the 1996 general election so dull ; everyone was singing from the same hymnbook . But dull as it seems , it is this widespread agreement that could presage change . 
 Japan sometimes seems to be unalterable . Certainly , it eschews change through confrontation . But often , behind the facade , a consensus can coalesce for a new way of doing things . When that happens , change can be profound . It may be happening already . By the turn of the century the Japanese economy could well look very different - and more dynamic than it looks now .

text:
Investors are realising that deregulation and slow growth do not make for a buoyant stockmarket 
ANYONE hoping that a new year would breathe new life into Japan's stockmarket has been sorely disappointed. On December 24th the Nikkei 225 average fell by 529 points. A half-hearted rally followed. This proved short-lived. This week, in the first four trading days of 1997, the Nikkei dropped by 1,37z points to close on January 9th at 18,074. Since mid-December, it has shed nearly11.5%. 
The most cursory of glances at the fortunes of Japanese shares should make investors in the vertiginous stockmarkets of America and Europe pause for thought The Nikkei peaked fully seven years ago. Since then it has made repeated attempts at recovering, only to fall back. Its post-bubble nadir was in July 1995, when it slipped below 14,500. From then it rallied to pass 22,000 in June last year. Then it started to drift down. The drift has now turned into a slump. 
Three factors are behind the latest falls. The first is all too familiar: economists are revising down their expectations about how much the economy will grow next year. In the first half of last year, many economists (especially foreign ones) thought that Japan was at last on the road to a sustainable recovery. Yet even before the recovery moves into high gear, the government is about to tighten fiscal policy. In April the sales tax will be pushed up from 3% to 5%, an income-tax rebate will be stopped and social-security contributions will go up. With consumer spending thus choked off, the economy, which grew by around 3.5% last year (albeit mostly in the first quarter), is likely to slow to a crawl. Expectations of how fast companies' earnings will grow have been scaled back as a result, particularly in materials businesses such as steel, textiles and paper. 
Some industries also face a less familiar problem: deregulation. As competition hots up in previously protected sectors, so investors fear that profits will drop. Shares in KDD, Japan's erstwhile state-owned international telecoms company, have fallen by more than a third since August because of the prospect of competition from NT, which was previously restricted to domestic services. 
Deregulation, or at least the prospect of it, has hit shares in financial services companies the hardest. The stockmarket has responded swiftly to the announcement last November by Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister, of a "Big Bang" to shake up Japan's financial system. Shares in banks, securities firms and insurance companies have been pummelled. Excluding Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, shares in Japan's big city banks as a group are lower now than at the peak of the bad-loan crisis in summer 1992, according to David Atkinson of Goldman Sachs, an investment bank. 
The only solid performers on the Tokyo market are shares in companies which are internationally competitive, such as Toyota or Honda, Japan's two biggest carmakers, or in companies whose earnings are largely immune to slower economic growth, such as railway and cigarette companies. "People will have to get to work and they will still smoke lots of cigarettes," says Pelham Smithers, an analyst at ING Barings, an investment bank. 
The third reason why investors are shying away from Japanese shares is that they look expensive. Stocks in the Nikkei are trading at about 65 times the companies' expected earnings for the coming fiscal year, estimates Darrel Whitten, an analyst at Lehman Brothers, an investment bank. Such a multiple is justified only if earnings are likely to leap. Yet Japan is now a mature economy, and a sluggish one at that; growth in most companies' earnings will be modest. Mr Whitten thinks that, in consequence, investors are in a drawn-out process of adjusting their expectations. 
It matters for Japan's beleaguered banks how this adjustment takes place. Japanese banks count unrealised gains on their share portfolios towards the capital that they must maintain to meet international standards. With the Nikkei at i8,ooo, the capital of six of the biggest 20 banks falls below the 8% demanded by regulators. At 17,000, half of the top 20 will be undercapitalised. And if the Nikkei reaches 15,ooo, 13 of the 20 biggest banks will have no unrealised profits at all, estimates Goldman's Mr Atkinson. Further problems for the banks, in turn, will only prolong Japan's economic travails.

text:
A deal is done 
The Israelis and Palestinians, with a lot of help from America and, at the last minute, a little from Jordan, signed a deal on Israel's withdrawal from a large part of Hebron. They also agreed on three (still to be defined) stages of further redeployment in rural areas of the West Bank. World leaders praised them. One Israeli minister resigned. Some 270 Palestinians, stranded on the LibyanEgyptian border since September 1995 when Muammar Qaddafi ordered Palestinians out of his country, were allowed to return to Libya. 
A letter-bomb exploded at the London head offices of a Saudi-owned pan-Arab newspaper, al-Hayat, injuring a security guard. Another dozen letter-bombs were delivered to the paper in New York and Riyadh. Nobody claimed responsibility. 
South Africa responded sharply to an American threat to cut aid if it went ahead with the sale of arms to Syria. President Mandela said South Africa would sell where it chose and not be dictated to by anyone. 
After a brief visit home, President Mobuto Sese Seko of Zaire returned to France. 
Rebels in southern Sudan captured several towns on the Ethiopian border. The Sudanese government blamed Ethiopia for the attack. 
Above the law 
The Supreme Court considered arguments that President Bill Clinton should be immune while in office from a private lawsuit brought by Paula Jones, a former Arkansas state employee who alleges that the president sexually harassed her in a Little Rock hotel in 1991. 
The top Democrat on the House Ethics Committee resigned over his handling of a taped telephone call involving Newt Gingrich, the speaker, who is under investigation on ethics charges. 
Two women cadets left the Citadel, a military college in South Carolina that was forced by court order to admit women, complaining of harassment by male colleagues. Two women remain. 
Mr Clinton made Roy Romer, the governor of Colorado, chairman of the Democratic National Committee. 
A step ahead in Peru's hostage affair. The Tupac Amaru guerrillas accepted a government idea for a committee to oversee negotiations. 
Japan's overtures On a visit to South-East Asia, the Japanese prime minister, 
Ryutaro Hashimoto (right), sought new ties that would cover security as well as trade and investment. The proposal was received warily in the Association of South-East Asian Nations, partly for fear of upsetting China Widespread strikes against South Korea's new labour laws moved into their fourth week. Though the government expressed regret for the way it passed the laws, it refused to scrap them, as unions demanded. Three union leaders were arrested. 
Datta Samant, an Indian trade-union leader well known for his militancy, was shot dead in Mumbai. 
Mother Teresa resigned the leadership of the mission she founded in India 47 years ago. The 86-year-old Roman Catholic nun is in poor health. 
In Singapore, a veteran opposition politician, J.B. Jeyaretnam, who failed to win a seat in a general election held earlier this month, accepted a seat as a nominated member of parliament. 
Hong Kong newspapers claimed that the former director of immigration, Lawrence Leung, gave China information about the British colony's residents. Mr Leung, who has denied the reports, resigned last year. 
By the people Bulgaria's Socialists agreed to hold elections by the end of 1997, a year early. Opposition parties, which have been staging large demonstrations outside parliament for several weeks, are still demanding an immediate poll. 
Electoral officials ruled that opposition parties had won municipal elections in Belgrade and Nis, Serbia's two biggest cities. But the Belgrade chief of the ruling Socialist Party said it would challenge the ruling. 
President Yeltsin, in hospital with pneumonia, suggested that Russia and Belarus should unite. 
After raising tensions with Turkey by ordering a Russian missile-defence system, Gla&os Clerides, president of Cyprus, lowered them by saying it would not be delivered for 16 months. 
A former president of Switzerland, Jean-Pascal Delamuraz, now its economics minister, apologised for accusing Jewish groups of "ransom and blackmail" in demanding that Swiss banks compensate victims of the Holocaust for losses. 
A Spanish conservative, JoseMaria Gil-Robles, was elected president of the European Parliament. 
Germany's federal budget deficit in 1996 was DM18.4 billion ($11.6 billion) higher than projected. The publicsector deficit as a whole was 3.9% of GDP, well above the target of 3% for countries wanting to join Europe's planned single currency.

text:
Gender gap 
SIR-An analysis of divinity and gender has the potential to be thought-provoking. It is a pity that Karen Armstrong's article (December 21st) is not. If Ms Armstrong's point is that God transcends gender, then there is no reason to emphasise the "feminine" aspects of God. But if her point is to illustrate the kinder, gentler elements of monotheism, she should not muddle it with simplistic notions of gender. 
Some of the most potent deities of destruction, be they, esoteric Buddhist deities, such as Rokujison, or Hindu deities like Shiva, are "feminine". Ms Armstrong passes over them because they belong to polytheistic pantheons. More insight would be gained if, in fact, gender and divinity were analysed without relying upon cliches regarding so-called feminine ("redolent of peace and healing") and masculine ("warlike", "full of hatred", "cruel") qualities. Kyoto THOMAS CONLAN 
SIR-Ms Armstrong's article was welcome enlightenment for those of us who have struggled with and abandoned the standard western monotheist religions. Here in America, abandonment of monotheism is seen as trendy and "new age". But our pre-Christian and early postChristian ancestors seemed to have a better understanding of what constitutes the divine. 
I sometimes wonder if Samuel Huntington, in his "Clash of Civilisations", left out one of the coming clashes that may well occur here in the West: the battle of the neo-pagans (allied with the Buddhists, Hindus and others) versus the triumvirate of monotheism. Most neo-pagans that I know do not seek a battle, only acceptance. Your intellectual inquiry into the subject gives me hope that we will be successful. Arlington, JOHN GORDON Virginia SENNETT 
SIR-The capacity of Ms Armstrong to outline a universal history of religion in three pages of The Economist is remarkable. But she adorns her panorama with mistakes and misrepresentations informed by two obsessions: feminism and a resentment of Judaism. 
Ms Armstrong is preoccupied with the pronoun "He" in reference to God in all three monotheistic religions. Curiously, she finds consolation in the post-biblical Hebrew term Shekhinah, the presence of God, which happens to be a feminine noun. That Allah, or "God" in Arabic, though a masculine noun, is called alRahman and al-Rahim, or "compassionate" or "merciful" saves Islam from her criticism, for these attributes are etymologically related to the word "womb". Yet in the Hebrew Bible, in a central passage describing God's encounter with Moses, he is presented as follows: "The Lord, the Lord God merciful and gracious, longsuffering and abundant in goodness and truth." The word "merciful" here is a translation of rahum, which, like its Arabic equivalent, is related to rehem, or "womb". 
Ms Armstrong speaks of Israel's jealous God who demanded that the people bind themselves by a covenant to him alone. Here she fails to understand two things. The common notion of the jealous God is due to an error in translation. In biblical Hebrew, hana means "wholly committed" to some worthy principle, cause or objective, and not "jealous". As for the covenant-a central idea in the Judaic perception of the relationship between God and Israel-it is by its nature, as in English law, an agreement entered into by two parties-in this case, Israel and God. Once concluded, the agreement is binding on both. Perhaps Ms Armstrong will be more comfortable with such a democratically accepted God. Silver Spring, Maryland M. ROSHWALD 
SIR-God is, as decreed by nature and echoed in the Bible (despite some gender introduced into biblical text), female. Genesis 1: 27, which Ms Armstrong cites, says that both male and female were created in God's image. 
Life is created upon conception, a notion that both Catholics and fundamentalist Christians would accept. Now, as science tells us, all embryos begin life as females, until a genetic trick turns about half into males (hence the decorative but generally useless nipples on the male). As all humans are created female and in God's image, God must be female. 
London ROBERT PILLER 
Anglo files 
SIR-Your article on language and electronics (December 21st) was off the mark in two respects. It is not "extraordinary" for English, as a lingua franca, to be spoken as a second language by more people than speak it as a first. That is the very nature of a lingua franca-take Latin, Swahili, Urdu or Mandarin. Latin came to a point where it no longer had any native speakers, yet was the undisputed international language of Europe during the Middle Ages. 
Many people grow up with more than one language: a common one, and one or more specific to their region or ethnic, religious or social group. Adding English to the mix does not cause any dislocation. 
The other fallacy is that the internationalisation of English will benefit those speaking English as a first language. Anecdotal evidence already suggests that it does not, since it leads to the misconception that just because someone speaks "your" language, he or she thinks like you. George Bernard Shaw understood this perfectly when he referred to Britain and America as two great peoples separated by a common language. 
Hong Kong JUERG GASSMANN 
SIR-As an English-speaker, I have no prejudice against the language. But I found your article to be a mixture of self-worship and wishful thinking. If English were not such a decrepit, illogical language, your dreams might come true. But its flaws are too great: it is undisciplined and lacks an academy; its 26 letters cannot cover its 44 sounds, which it spells in more than 250 ways; it has no regular method of pluralising; and its multiple meanings for words are overwhelming. 
 KENT JONES Esperanto League Chicago for North America 
SiR-Your article on language and electronics is most enlightening, especially the part on the plural of"mongoose". I always thought the plural was "mesgooses". 
Tokyo JEAN-LOUIS CLAUDON 
Uncharitable 
SIR-Your haphazard leader on America's tax-exempt organisations ("Tax-exempt and loving it", January 4th) misses several crucial points. Although it is true that the tax code could use some revision to tighten restrictions on the use of charitable organisations to promote partisan politics, America's non-profit sector is generally healthy and effective. It is built on a compact between government and citizenry. In 1938 Congress noted that "the exemption from taxation of money or property devoted to charitable. . . purposes is based on the theory that the government is compensated for the loss of revenue by its relief from financial burden . . . and by the benefits [of promoting] the general welfare." 
As for the percentage of American contributions that actually go to "unambiguously good causes", ask the nation's hospitals, universities, museums, libraries, research laboratories, homeless shelters, neighbourhood clinics and art organisations if they use the bulk of their receipts to pay fund-raisers. 
The contention that abolishing the tax deduction would not hurt charities is wrong. Preliminary results from a study commissioned by the Council on Foundations indicate that elimination of the charitable deduction under certain flat-tax proposals would not end giving, but would reduce it by a substantial amount. 
The strength of America's nonprofit sector lies in people's freedom to choose the cause they want to support. Few would agree that the government is a better steward of their generosity than the charities they sustain. 
DOROTHY RIDINGS President Council on 
Washington, DC Foundations 
Australia's identity 
SIR-Your article on Australia ("A national identity crisis", December 14) is an interesting and largely erudite exposition of one of this country's current debates, but it requires some further examination of the migration and racism issues it raises. 
You write that: "most internationally minded Australians would like to play down the significance of Ms [Pauline] Hanson", the independent MP from Queensland whose maiden speech you cite. Quite. But you then go on to perpetuate the myth that most beneficial Australian thought-processes take place in the Sydney-Melbourne Canberra triangle "where the richer and better educated" live. 
Your article might have more accurately pointed out that, on the conservative side of Australian national politics, most of the early rebuttals of Ms Hanson's views came from Queensland. Indeed, as state premier, I have made it clear in a series of speeches and public comments that her stance on migration and racism is thoroughly unacceptable to the state government, the overwhelming bulk of Queenslanders and most Australians. 
It is a shame that a leading opinion-former such as The Economist should, through its own ignorance of the facts, seek to tar all Queenslanders with the same brush as Ms Hanson. ROB BORBIDGE Premier of Brisbane Queensland 
SIR-Your article on Australia's cultural and economic future rightly identifies a division in Australian opinion. The push to integrate economically with Asia has been led by intellectuals and politicians in the "paternalistic" way you suggest. This has left public opinion lagging: at best ambivalent and at worst violentlyxenophobic. 
In 1994, as a student in Australia, I was surprised in my final year to hear my history professor tell our class that he still thought a student would find more use for French or German than any East Asian language. In the ensuing debate I voiced my feelings of cultural affinity with various groups of Asian immigrants. Having a pony tail at the time, I was told by the learned professor "Well, you would do, with a pigtail like that." Australia's intellectual circles still harbour oldworld loyalties. London ROB BURGESS 
A matter of taste 
SIR-Sake aficionados everywhere salute the excellent article in your December 21st issue ("Brewed for the gods"). But in singing the praises of jizake and the exquisite ginjos, you are a little harsh on the seishu plonk of the salaryman. 
His sake, too, is free of flavouring agents and preservatives; the major breweries got rid of them years ago. He drinks his sake hot from personal choice, not because heating destroys unde-- sirable flavours. Problems associated with fusel oil, a natural byproduct of the brewing process, were solved by Japanese chemists decades ago. 
One need not wait until October to enjoy new jizake. The year's best brews are honoured every April by the National Institute of Fermentology, and go on sale soon thereafter. Not everyone is so taken with the elite winners, however. Takeo Nihei, the founder of sake-brewing in America, was once heard to remark, "There's no such thing as a bad sake." 
CHRIS PEARCE International Sake Honolulu Association 
SIR-I read your article on sake with interest, as I am a sake-brewer by trade and, apparently, the only non-Japanese member of the profession in Japan. When articles such as yours appear, I am reminded of the complicated nature of sake brewing. One or two points in your otherwise competent article caught my nitpicking professional eye. 
Special sake rices are credited with lending apple, banana, orange and nut nuances. Orange is not a flavour that occurs, even in ginjo sake, but the aroma particular to such high-grade brews does contain superb fruity elements-banana, apple and melon in particular. These aromas are not derived from the sake rice variety, as your article suggests; they are produced by the metabolic action of the yeast. 
You disparage the practice of serving sake hot, observing that foul sake can be made more palatable by heating. Many fine sakes are sublime warm, but not hot. The "ginjo boom" of recent years is, in part, a backlash against the chemical additives which became common in the post-war years of scarcity, and it spawned as an unfortunate sideeffect the belief that good sake should only be drunk cold. This over-simplistic view is coming under scrutiny as more sake lovers rediscover the joys of okan, warmed sake. Yamatotaldashi,, 
Japan PHILIP HARPER Heaven sense 
SIR-I am a grandchild of Koji Kobayashi, or "Ji-Ji", as we children called him. In your obituary (December 7th) you say, "the vitality-sapping influence of Mr Kobayashi's outmoded view is a parable for modern Japan." 
I don't know much about his ability as president of NEc, but I received good advice from him. He always asked his grandchildren, "Are you studying well? To study hard is very important" This is not outmoded advice. The new generation will change Japan, not the prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto. Ji-Ji may be saying to young Japanese from heaven, "Are you studying hard?" Tokyo JUN HATORI

SIR-Your article about corporate downsizing (December 21st) leads me to believe that I am not reading The Economist as often as necessary: the article refers to Hughes Electronics as a subsidiary of General Electric Had my extensive business travels caused me to miss one of the biggest corporate sales of 1996?

Gender gap 
SIR-An analysis of divinity and gender has the potential to be thought-provoking. It is a pity that Karen Armstrong's article (December 21st) is not. If Ms Armstrong's point is that God transcends gender, then there is no reason to emphasise the "feminine" aspects of God. But if her point is to illustrate the kinder, gentler elements of monotheism, she should not muddle it with simplistic notions of gender. 
Some of the most potent deities of destruction, be they, esoteric Buddhist deities, such as Rokujison, or Hindu deities like Shiva, are "feminine". Ms Armstrong passes over them because they belong to polytheistic pantheons. More insight would be gained if, in fact, gender and divinity were analysed without relying upon cliches regarding so-called feminine ("redolent of peace and healing") and masculine ("warlike", "full of hatred", "cruel") qualities. Kyoto THOMAS CONLAN 
SIR-Ms Armstrong's article was welcome enlightenment for those of us who have struggled with and abandoned the standard western monotheist religions. Here in America, abandonment of monotheism is seen as trendy and "new age". But our pre-Christian and early postChristian ancestors seemed to have a better understanding of what constitutes the divine. 
I sometimes wonder if Samuel Huntington, in his "Clash of Civilisations", left out one of the coming clashes that may well occur here in the West: the battle of the neo-pagans (allied with the Buddhists, Hindus and others) versus the triumvirate of monotheism. Most neo-pagans that I know do not seek a battle, only acceptance. Your intellectual inquiry into the subject gives me hope that we will be successful. Arlington, JOHN GORDON Virginia SENNETT 
SIR-The capacity of Ms Armstrong to outline a universal history of religion in three pages of The Economist is remarkable. But she adorns her panorama with mistakes and misrepresentations informed by two obsessions: feminism and a resentment of Judaism. 
Ms Armstrong is preoccupied with the pronoun "He" in reference to God in all three monotheistic religions. Curiously, she finds consolation in the post-biblical Hebrew term Shekhinah, the presence of God, which happens to be a feminine noun. That Allah, or "God" in Arabic, though a masculine noun, is called alRahman and al-Rahim, or "compassionate" or "merciful" saves Islam from her criticism, for these attributes are etymologically related to the word "womb". Yet in the Hebrew Bible, in a central passage describing God's encounter with Moses, he is presented as follows: "The Lord, the Lord God merciful and gracious, longsuffering and abundant in goodness and truth." The word "merciful" here is a translation of rahum, which, like its Arabic equivalent, is related to rehem, or "womb". 
Ms Armstrong speaks of Israel's jealous God who demanded that the people bind themselves by a covenant to him alone. Here she fails to understand two things. The common notion of the jealous God is due to an error in translation. In biblical Hebrew, hana means "wholly committed" to some worthy principle, cause or objective, and not "jealous". As for the covenant-a central idea in the Judaic perception of the relationship between God and Israel-it is by its nature, as in English law, an agreement entered into by two parties-in this case, Israel and God. Once concluded, the agreement is binding on both. Perhaps Ms Armstrong will be more comfortable with such a democratically accepted God. Silver Spring, Maryland M. ROSHWALD 
SIR-God is, as decreed by nature and echoed in the Bible (despite some gender introduced into biblical text), female. Genesis 1: 27, which Ms Armstrong cites, says that both male and female were created in God's image. 
Life is created upon conception, a notion that both Catholics and fundamentalist Christians would accept. Now, as science tells us, all embryos begin life as females, until a genetic trick turns about half into males (hence the decorative but generally useless nipples on the male). As all humans are created female and in God's image, God must be female. 
London ROBERT PILLER 
Anglo files 
SIR-Your article on language and electronics (December 21st) was off the mark in two respects. It is not "extraordinary" for English, as a lingua franca, to be spoken as a second language by more people than speak it as a first. That is the very nature of a lingua franca-take Latin, Swahili, Urdu or Mandarin. Latin came to a point where it no longer had any native speakers, yet was the undisputed international language of Europe during the Middle Ages. 
Many people grow up with more than one language: a common one, and one or more specific to their region or ethnic, religious or social group. Adding English to the mix does not cause any dislocation. 
The other fallacy is that the internationalisation of English will benefit those speaking English as a first language. Anecdotal evidence already suggests that it does not, since it leads to the misconception that just because someone speaks "your" language, he or she thinks like you. George Bernard Shaw understood this perfectly when he referred to Britain and America as two great peoples separated by a common language. 
Hong Kong JUERG GASSMANN 
SIR-As an English-speaker, I have no prejudice against the language. But I found your article to be a mixture of self-worship and wishful thinking. If English were not such a decrepit, illogical language, your dreams might come true. But its flaws are too great: it is undisciplined and lacks an academy; its 26 letters cannot cover its 44 sounds, which it spells in more than 250 ways; it has no regular method of pluralising; and its multiple meanings for words are overwhelming.
