Uncharitable 
SIR-Your haphazard leader on America's tax-exempt organisations ("Tax-exempt and loving it", January 4th) misses several crucial points. Although it is true that the tax code could use some revision to tighten restrictions on the use of charitable organisations to promote partisan politics, America's non-profit sector is generally healthy and effective. It is built on a compact between government and citizenry. In 1938 Congress noted that "the exemption from taxation of money or property devoted to charitable. . . purposes is based on the theory that the government is compensated for the loss of revenue by its relief from financial burden . . . and by the benefits [of promoting] the general welfare." 
As for the percentage of American contributions that actually go to "unambiguously good causes", ask the nation's hospitals, universities, museums, libraries, research laboratories, homeless shelters, neighbourhood clinics and art organisations if they use the bulk of their receipts to pay fund-raisers. 
The contention that abolishing the tax deduction would not hurt charities is wrong. Preliminary results from a study commissioned by the Council on Foundations indicate that elimination of the charitable deduction under certain flat-tax proposals would not end giving, but would reduce it by a substantial amount. 
The strength of America's nonprofit sector lies in people's freedom to choose the cause they want to support. Few would agree that the government is a better steward of their generosity than the charities they sustain. 
DOROTHY RIDINGS President Council on 
Washington, DC Foundations 
Australia's identity 
SIR-Your article on Australia ("A national identity crisis", December 14) is an interesting and largely erudite exposition of one of this country's current debates, but it requires some further examination of the migration and racism issues it raises. 
You write that: "most internationally minded Australians would like to play down the significance of Ms [Pauline] Hanson", the independent MP from Queensland whose maiden speech you cite. Quite. But you then go on to perpetuate the myth that most beneficial Australian thought-processes take place in the Sydney-Melbourne Canberra triangle "where the richer and better educated" live. 
Your article might have more accurately pointed out that, on the conservative side of Australian national politics, most of the early rebuttals of Ms Hanson's views came from Queensland. Indeed, as state premier, I have made it clear in a series of speeches and public comments that her stance on migration and racism is thoroughly unacceptable to the state government, the overwhelming bulk of Queenslanders and most Australians. 
It is a shame that a leading opinion-former such as The Economist should, through its own ignorance of the facts, seek to tar all Queenslanders with the same brush as Ms Hanson. ROB BORBIDGE Premier of Brisbane Queensland 
SIR-Your article on Australia's cultural and economic future rightly identifies a division in Australian opinion. The push to integrate economically with Asia has been led by intellectuals and politicians in the "paternalistic" way you suggest. This has left public opinion lagging: at best ambivalent and at worst violentlyxenophobic. 
In 1994, as a student in Australia, I was surprised in my final year to hear my history professor tell our class that he still thought a student would find more use for French or German than any East Asian language. In the ensuing debate I voiced my feelings of cultural affinity with various groups of Asian immigrants. Having a pony tail at the time, I was told by the learned professor "Well, you would do, with a pigtail like that." Australia's intellectual circles still harbour oldworld loyalties. London ROB BURGESS

SIR-Sake aficionados everywhere salute the excellent article in your December 21st issue ("Brewed for the gods"). But in singing the praises of jizake and the exquisite ginjos, you are a little harsh on the seishu plonk of the salaryman. 
His sake, too, is free of flavouring agents and preservatives; the major breweries got rid of them years ago. He drinks his sake hot from personal choice, not because heating destroys unde-- sirable flavours. Problems associated with fusel oil, a natural byproduct of the brewing process, were solved by Japanese chemists decades ago. 
One need not wait until October to enjoy new jizake. The year's best brews are honoured every April by the National Institute of Fermentology, and go on sale soon thereafter. Not everyone is so taken with the elite winners, however. Takeo Nihei, the founder of sake-brewing in America, was once heard to remark, "There's no such thing as a bad sake." 
CHRIS PEARCE International Sake Honolulu Association 
SIR-I read your article on sake with interest, as I am a sake-brewer by trade and, apparently, the only non-Japanese member of the profession in Japan. When articles such as yours appear, I am reminded of the complicated nature of sake brewing. One or two points in your otherwise competent article caught my nitpicking professional eye. 
Special sake rices are credited with lending apple, banana, orange and nut nuances. Orange is not a flavour that occurs, even in ginjo sake, but the aroma particular to such high-grade brews does contain superb fruity elements-banana, apple and melon in particular. These aromas are not derived from the sake rice variety, as your article suggests; they are produced by the metabolic action of the yeast. 
You disparage the practice of serving sake hot, observing that foul sake can be made more palatable by heating. Many fine sakes are sublime warm, but not hot. The "ginjo boom" of recent years is, in part, a backlash against the chemical additives which became common in the post-war years of scarcity, and it spawned as an unfortunate sideeffect the belief that good sake should only be drunk cold. This over-simplistic view is coming under scrutiny as more sake lovers rediscover the joys of okan, warmed sake. Yamatotaldashi,,

text:
IT WAS billed in Tokyo as a landmark initiative by Ryutaro Hashimoto to take Japan's relations with South-East Asia beyond mere economics. The prime minister would explain the "Hashimoto principle" to the leaders of South-East Asia during an eight-day tour, ending with a big speech in Singapore on January 14th. With the bulk of Japan's $14.5 billion of official development assistance being poured into the region, Mr Hashimoto was assured of a friendly and polite reception. But his main proposal-to elevate relations between Japan and the Association of South-East Asian Nations (As EAN) to a summit-level forum that would regularly discuss security as well as trade and investment-met with a cool reception. 
Why? In part, because South-East Asians retain suspicions of Japan that date back to the wars of the 194os. But the real difficulty is South-East Asian apprehensions about the future, rather than the past. The ASEAN countries are reluctant to have special relations with Japan, for fear of antagonising China. Although Mr Hashimoto went out of his way to talk of the need to be on good terms with China, the SouthEast Asians fear that regular security discussions with Japan would feed Chinese fears of encirclement. So, although the ASEAN leaders spoke warmly of Mr Hashimoto's speech, the betting in both Tokyo and Singapore is that regular Japanese-ASEAN summits will not be held. 
Even the Malaysian prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, who has long been pushing a "look east" policy of more links with North-East Asia, stopped short of endorsing Mr Hashimoto's idea. He did promise, however, to discuss the question of more contacts with Japan when he meets his South-East Asian counterparts next December. 
Dr Mahathir has his own schemes. His pet project is for regular summits involving ASEAN, China, South Korea and Japan-an East Asian Economic Caucus. The Japanese, who do not want to exclude America from such a group, remain cool on the idea. So the likelihood is that the main forum for discussing security in Asia will remain one set up by ASEAN itself-the ASEAN Regional Forum, which includes Japan, America and China, as well as the European Union. The problem with the forum is that its very inclusiveness means its discussions usually seem vague or empty. 
Still, its primacy does highlight a peculiarity of Asian diplomacy. Japan's historical baggage and diplomatic uncertainty mean that it has been unable to match its economic strength with the prowess to play a leading role in shaping the region's international institutions. That role instead has fallen increasingly to the seven ASEAN countries, which are economic pygmies compared with Japan. Partly because they are seen as small and unthreatening, the ASEAN countries have been able to take initiatives that would have been much more controversial had they come from a big power-such as Japan, or indeed China. 
So, though the Asia-Pacific Economic Co-operation forum includes Japan, China, America, Australia and Canada, it has become accepted practice that every second of its summits is held in an ASEAN country. It was also ASEAN that proposed the Asia-Europe Meeting and played host to the body's inaugural meeting in Bangkok last March. The World Trade Organisation's first ministerial meeting was also held in an ASEAN country (Singapore). Ja-, pan has been largely passive in all this. Mr Hashimoto's speech marked an attempt to find a bigger role for his country. If, as seems likely, it is gently rebuffed, it will be back to the drawing-board in Tokyo.

text:
TO JUDGE by the warnings of its prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, Japan faces financial disaster. In his speech at the opening of the new parliamentary session on January 20th, Mr Hashimoto called for drastic economic reform and vowed that, in pursuit of it, he would brush aside the pleas of interest-groups. Look at the budget his government is presenting, however, and you begin to doubt his seriousness. 
No sooner were the words about fiscal rectitude out of his mouth than Mr Hashimoto was outlining the government's porkladen spending plans for the year from April ist. The Y77.4 trillion ($651 billion) budget represents a 3% increase on the current year's spending. 
Does that mean the prime minister is insincere? Not necessarily. The trouble is that, now that the government is no longer in a formal coalition, many of the rankand-file within his ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) believe they are rid of the need to appease their partners. Accordingly, they want to go on a politics-as-usual binge and, to preserve party unity, Mr Hashimoto has caved in to them. Hence the restoration of allocations for rice subsidies. Hence the new public-works programmes. Hence a whole network of new bullet-train routes which, by any measure, will be hopelessly uneconomic. 
Where is all the money to come from? The government will raise an additional Y7 trillion by increasing the consumption tax from 3% to 5% in April and ending Y2 trillion-worth of tax cuts introduced as emergency measures during the recession. As a result, the central government's budget deficit is projected to fall to around 3.2% of GDP next year, compared with an estimate of over 4% of GDP for the current year. Still, the gap between Japan's revenue and spending will remain Y16.7 trillion. Other figures-for instance, for the growth in national debt, and for the total public-sector deficit, which includes the liabilities of local governments and state corporationsare even more alarming. 
The deficit incurred by central and local government is now put at 7.4% of GDP by the OECD. Mr Hashimoto has sworn to cut this to no more than 3% by 2005. To cover the current shortfall, more money is to be borrowed. Including local government's liabilities, Japan will be in debt to the tune of V460 trillion by the end of next year-almost equal to the country's GDP. That will make Japan the biggest debtor nation in the world. (America's gross public debt is around 64% of GDP.)Just servicing Japan's public debt is now gobbling up 22% of the budget. That is more than the government allocates to education, science and defence combined. 
To find a solution, Mr Hashimoto has appointed a council for fiscal reform. The 3o-member group is headed by the prime minister himself and includes six cabinet ministers, four former prime ministers, and numerous members of the LDP and the two smaller parties with which it used to rule in coalition and on which it still depends in the Diet. They have to come up with ideas for laws to balance the books by June, so they can be enacted in the autumn. 
The central question is whether the prime minister's professed concern about the problem, coupled with his undoubted political wiles, will be enough to overcome the pressures from within the LDP to keep on spending as usual. The glee and ease with which politicians with vested interests have hijacked the budget are not encouraging. The current mood of bureaucrat-bashing-although important to the much-needed drive to deregulate the economy-has hobbled the finance ministry, which used to restrain the worst excesses of politicians. Faced with relentless lobbying by politicians demanding handouts for their sponsors, the finance ministry has simply capitulated. 
Its most egregious cavein has been to defer the settlement of Y28 trillionworth of liabilities left by the defunct Japanese National Railways, while giving its approval for work to start on unprofitable bullet-train lines in remote parts of the country. It was the building of "political" railway lines that got the railways into such a financial pickle in the first place. 
To make matters worse, the LDP is determined to introduce a Y5.2 trillion supplementary budget in the weeks ahead-"to sustain the economic recovery and prevent the stockmarket from falling further." The rationale for this extra spending is extremely dubious, since the stockmarket's fall is largely to do with the effect of deregulation on company profits, rather than economic weakness. But LDP politicians have debts to repay to friends in the building industry, who helped finance the party's return to power. 
Meanwhile, the prime minister has to get his budget through the Diet. The opposition is firmly against both the new budget and the supplementary one. With only 240 out of the 500 seats in the lower house, Mr Hashimoto needs the support of the Social Democrats (i5 seats) and the Sakigake (two). And they are beginning to waver. In other words, by shoring up his internal support he may have undermined his external support. Realising this, the prime minister has spent the past week trying to patch over the cracks between the LDP and the parties that support it from outside the government. 
If he is skilful, however, Mr Hashimoto's political problems-in particular, the need to keep the LDP's allies within the fold-could provide him with the cover he needs to rein in spending. New warnings have just been issued to the LDP's lobby groups to show some restraint. Meanwhile, heavy hints are being dropped that extensive "profitability studies" of the new bullet-train proposals will be needed. It is still possible that some at least of the wilder spending plans in the budget will go, and Mr Hashimoto's reputation for good housekeeping will be restored.

text:
The stockmarket has delivered a damning verdict on Japanese banks. But there is probably worse to come 
THIS is a dreadful time to be a banker in Japan. Since the beginning of this year, the share prices of the country's banks have fallen by nearly 15%; since early November, by almost a quarter. Plummeting bank shares have brought down the overall market: banks account for around one-fifth of the broad, capitalisation-weighted Topix share index. This week share prices have been bouncing up and down, but so far this year Topix has fallen by 6%. 
As ever, averages hide a multitude of sins. Shares in Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, by far Japan's (and the world's) biggest, have fallen by "only" about one-fifth since November nth. But shares in 15 of the top 20 banks have fallen by more than a quarter, and five of these by 30% or more. 
Prices are barely higher than in 1992, when fears about banks' bad debts were at their peak. Indeed, the plunge has raised anew fears about the frailty of Japan's financial system-not least because Japan boasts seven of the world's ten biggest banks by assets. Such worries should be put in perspective: a meltdown of the banking system is hardly likely, given that the government has guaranteed the safety of the 20 biggest banks. Nevertheless, the Japan premium-the premium that Japanese banks are forced to pay to borrow abroad-is again on the rise. 
Why have bank shares fallen so much? And will they continue to do so? At first glance, the causes of the rout may look obscure. After all, investors have known for many years that the banks' balance sheets are chock-a-block with bad loans, and that there are many more bad loans than the banks admit to. Moreover, most banks seem to have been making reserves against their bad loans faster than they have been acquiring new ones. So why are investors dumping bank shares now? 
One reason is a fear that the pace of reserving against bad loans is about to slow down. This fear is partly the product of a vicious circle, because it stems from the rap idly shrinking value of the banks' own equity portfolios. 
In effect, profits on these shareholdings are a cushion against bad debts, because they can be turned into cash. Lately, banks have indeed been selling shares to help write off their bad debts. However, to maintain close relations with the companies concerned, they have also been buying some back at higher prices. As worries about banks have brought down the stockmarket, this practice makes the cushion thinner. Alicia Ogawa, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, an investment bank, says that three banks-Nippon Credit Bank, Yasuda Trust and Hokkaido Takushokuhave already run out of shares they can sell at a profit. 
Another trend has also convinced investors that banks will take longer than it was previously thought to earn their way out of trouble. In the past couple of years they have made much of their money from lending to the government. Buying government bonds, with money borrowed at interest rates of almost nil, enabled the city (commercial) banks to make record operating profits in the year to March 1996 (thanks to writing off bad loans, they also made record net losses). But in the six months to September, they played this game much less skilfully: although longand short-term interest rates barely budged, city banks' bond-trading profits dropped by 96%. 
Nor is lending to companies likely to help much. Razor-thin margins show no sign of increasing. Having grown anaemically in the first half of 1996, lending shrank in the last quarter and is likely to shrink more when the government increases taxes in April. Betsy Daniels, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, an investment bank, expects banks' operating profits to fall by a quarter this fiscal year. 
Bad as all this is, it is not enough to explain the severity of the collapse in bank shares. Two other factors have been crucial: the announcement last November by the prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, of a "Big Bang" to deregulate Japan's financial markets, and the banks' recent efforts to bolster their capital. 
Tearing down the walls between Japan's compartmentalised financial-services industry will increase competition and further reduce already meagre profits. It may seem odd to worry about the effects of this on the big banks. In principle, it should be easier for banks this size to muscle their way into businesses from which they are currently excluded, such as underwriting and trading equities, than for others to move onto their own turf. 
The trouble, says David Atkinson, an analyst at Goldman Sachs, an American investment bank, is that their very size is their weakness. City banks already account for almost two-thirds of the profits of the entire financial system. Non-banking businesses are thus too small to bring in much money. If, as is probable, the banks respond to deregulation by squandering huge amounts of resources on these businesses, the result will be even greater oversupply-and precious little profit. This is just what hap pened in the corporate-bond market, which banks piled into as soon as they were allowed to in early 1994. 
The second extra reason for the steep collapse in banking shares lies in a technicality: the manner in which the banks have tried to augment their core (tier one) capital by issuing equity. Because few investors want to buy bank shares while the banks are in their present miserable condition, many banks have chosen not to issue conventional equity but to sell "convertible preference shares" instead. These are more like bonds than shares, in that investors recover principal and (if the bank pays a dividend) a fixed rate of interest. But these shares do not count as core capital since they convert into common stock only after a few years. To try to keep investors sweet, the price at which they do so is ratcheted down if the price of the stock falls, so that investors get more shares. 
There lies the rub, Many investors, particularly American hedge funds, have no interest in the shares at all: they want only the juicy fixed returns offered by the preference shares. To lock in these returns, they have therefore sold short any shares they are likely to receive. And the lower a bank's shares fall, the more such investors are forced to sell, thus causing a vicious downward spiral. 
Now that banks' shares have fallen so far, are they cheap enough to reflect investors' fears? Thanks to the fall in the rest of the stockmarket, and thus in the value of banks' equity portfolios, probably not. Since the start of the year, the average ratio of banks' share prices to the value of their net assets (their so-called price-to-adjustedbook ratio, or PBR) has fallen only from 1.95 to 1.75, calculates Miss Daniels. 
This suggests that bank shares probably have further to fall. Many American and British banks trade at higher PBRS. For example, Citicorp, an American bank, trades at a PBR of about 3. But then it makes operating profits more than four times those of, say, Fuji Bank. Yet in the early 1990s, when Citicorp was in a similar pickle to the one in which Japanese banks now find themselves, its shares traded at a PBR of 0.5. Japanese bank shares are probably headed in the same direction, if not as far. Investors have at last realised that there is no point in paying so much for Japanese banks' assets when they generate such meagre returns. All at once, everyone wants to be rid of them, to pass them on to a greater fool. The problem, says Miss Daniels, is simply that "there is no greater fool out there".

text:
AS THE campaign to build a new capital away from the hustle and high cost of Tokyo gathers pace, the rivalry among provincial governments offering suitable sites has become intense. But Tokyo itself is not going to relinquish its status as the seat of government without a struggle. 
With Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister, seeing the move as a central part of his plan to halve the number of ministries and reform the country's creaking bureaucracy, the Tokyo metropolitan government has suddenly allocated Y320m ($2.6m) for an advertising campaign aimed at stopping the new-capital movement dead in its tracks. This will not be easy. Last summer, Mr Hashimoto's own Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), along with the two minor parties it shared power with at the time, and backed by the leading opposition party, altered the law governing any decision to move the capital. Instead of merely explaining what an alternative city must offer, the government now has to select an actual site for a new Diet (parliament) building, Supreme Court and main ministries no later than 1998. 
A new advisory body headed by Gaishi Hiraiwa, a former captain of industry, received its instructions from the prime minister on December i9th. The council's 20 members are now tramping the country to see which of the nine prefectures offering sites is to be the lucky one. The plan calls for a start to be made on clearing the ground by 2000 so that the first Diet session can be held in the new capital by 2010. 
To find the winner, the council will use criteria laid down by a previous advisory body. This suggested that the new capital should be 60 to 300 kilometres (38 to 19o miles) from Tokyo and have enough space for a city of 600,ooo people. Using figures released by the National Land Agency in 1992, the cost of the move was put at V14 trillion, excluding money for a new airport and various road and rail links. 
Much of the previous council's thinking was formulated two years ago when Kobe had just been devastated by an earthquake that did Y14 trillion-worth of damage, killing more than 6,ooo people and making 310,ooo people homeless. Understandably, high on the panel's list was the need to move the seat of government to a place safer than Tokyo, which lies at the intersection of three seismically active zones. In 1923 an earthquake killed 142,ooo people. 
The front-runners for the new capital are up in the hills. Kobe's fatal quality was the reclaimed land and soft coastal soils that underpinned most of the city's buildings. Such foundations-to be found below much of Tokyo, too-tend to amplify an earthquake's vibrations. By contrast, buildings that stand on mountain bedrock are safer. If seismic safety is to be the prime requirement, the new capital looks like being on the hills of northern Japan. Abukuma in Fukushima prefecture is a possibility. Locals there are pushing an area that is twice the size of Tokyo, on a bullet-train route and already home to some 26o,ooo people. The betting, however, is on the hilly sites of Aichi, Gifu and Mie prefectures. All three are judged to be more convenient for people in the country as a whole. 
The thought of losing so much revenue from property taxes-not to mention many of Tokyo's freest spenders-has concentrated the minds of officials in the metropolitan government As well as starting an advertising campaign, officials have been putting the word around that moving the capital would cost every JapaneseY31o,ooo apiece. Their calculation assumes that the removal cost would be Y14 trillion and would be financed by bonds paying 5.1% annually for 60 years. In reality, land prices as well as interest rates are now half what they were in 1992 when the Y14 trillion figure was first computed. 
The critics are right about one thing, though. Moving 6oo,ooo people out of the city will not make life much easier for the 3om who will stay in the greater Tokyo area. The crowding, pollution and property prices will stay about the same. So will all the best non-government jobs. Local officials aside, few residents care one way or the other whether the Nagatacho and Kasumigaseki districts-Tokyo's Capitol Hill and Foggy Bottom-are packed off to the mountains of central Japan. Tokyo will continue to be the mecca for the best and the brightest. It will remain the country's centre for culture, media, education, design, entertainment, finance, technology and everything else. Imagine New York, Los Angeles, Seattle, Palo Alto and Cambridge, Massachusetts, all rolled into one-but without Washington. Who would ever notice the difference?

text:
An acrimonious dispute between America and Japan over international airlines looks set to get worse 
AS DOGFIGHTS go, the latest trade spat between the United States and Japan could prove a bloody one. Past disputes have largely arisen when the Americans have tried to prise the lid off what they regard as Japan's hermetically sealed markets. The latest one, involving international flights, is different, not least because, for a change, it is largely the Japanese who feel aggrieved. Both sides think that they have a strong case and both say the issue must be thrashed out. On February 4th the two sides agreed to another round of talks (their last was in January) in Washington at the beginning of March. Fresh from a victorious round of trade talks on insurance late last year, the Americans are in no mood to back down. Nor are the Japanese. 
International aviation has been a bone of contention between the two countries for years. At root is an agreement foisted on the Japanese in 1952, at the end of the American occupation. This gives two American carriers (United Airlines and Northwest Airlines) broad rights not only to fly to various airports in Japan but to pick up passengers there and fly them anywhere else: what the industry calls "beyond rights". A third airline, Federal Express, has similar rights for cargo. 
Only one Japanese airline,Japan Airlines (Ini.), was given similar freedom to fly to American destinations (largely because it was the only Japanese airline licensed to offer international flights). And it was allowed beyond rights only from New York, with a mandatory stop in San Francisco. "Japan has the worst bilateral accord of any country in the world," says Paul Smith, an analyst at HSBC James Capel, a firm of stockbrokers. 
Why has this rumbling now suddenly got worse? The Japanese have become increasingly irked by the fact that American airlines have rights so much broader than their own. This has enabled American carriers to pick up increasing amounts of the traffic between the two countries (see chart on next page). The Japanese are cross, too, about the way American carriers have used their beyond rights. Some American aircraft have been arriving in Japan almost empty, picking up passengers and whisking them to other destinations in Asia. Japanese officials think that no more than half the seats of these aircraft should be filled by people boarding in Japan. 
To "equalise" the relationship, Japanese officials want not only JAL but another airline, All Nippon Airways (ANA), to be able to fly to and from the same places as American carriers. They also want)apanese airlines to have the same beyond rights in the United States as American airlines have in Japan. "We want Japanese airlines to be able to do what American airlines can do," says a Japanese negotiator. 
That is not, on the face of it, an unreasonable request. But the Americans have steadfastly refused to budge. Two years ago, the Japanese transport ministry therefore stopped American airlines from opening any new onward routes from Japan. The Americans cried foul. Last year the row became ugly. The Ministry of Transport refused to approve some new freight services that Federal Express wanted to offer; and America's Department of Transportation retaliated with a threat to restrict JAL's cargo services. Suddenly it even seemed possible that Japan would tear up the 1952 accord. This is the last thing anyone wants, least of all the Americans. Carrying people between Japan and the United States is a big, profitable business for America's airlines and is growing by about 8% a year. 
But what the Americans fear most is being shut out of Asia's lucrative market. The International Air Transport Association reckons that Asia's share of all air traffic will rise from a quarter in 1993 to over half by 2ooo. For the past two years Japanese travel to the rest of Asia has been rising by more than lO% a year. In the latest fiscal year, JAL took almost 20% more passengers to South-East Asia than during the year before. 
In late September, as away out of the impasse, President Clinton suggested to Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Japanese prime minister, that the two countries reach an open-skies agreement. Under such agreements, which America has signed with a host of countries in recent years, airlines from one country can fly to anywhere in the other country, pick up passengers and take them to whichever country they choose (provided it, in turn, agrees). 
The Japanese are not exactly salivating at the prospect. Such an agreement, they think, would continue to give American airlines an unfair advantage.The Japanese claim that opening international markets without first opening the American domestic market would allow American airlines to use profits earned on internal flights (which account for more than 40% of world air travel) to subsidise their expansion beyond American shores. 
By contrast, Japan's domestic market is not only much smaller than America's, but is about to become a lot less profitable. The transport ministry is beginning to deregulate. Last November it announced that HIS, a discount travel operator, would be allowed to open a domestic airline, the first company to do so in more than 40 years. Two smaller operators have also been given the nod. On January 3oth, the transport ministry said that it would start deregulating fares and capacity in transport in the 1997 fiscal year, which begins in April. Competition will drive down the three carriers' already meagre profits. Small wonder that airlines have been the worst performers in the Japanese stockmarket over the past six months. 
Given the high price of flying in Japan (it costs as much to fly from Tokyo to Sapporo as from Tokyo to Los Angeles), the transport ministry has little choice but to start breaking up the cartel. Yet bureaucrats hesitate to expose the airlines to more foreign competition at the same time. 
Hence the two other arguments that Japanese trade negotiators wield against open skies. American airlines have managed to accrue three times as many slots as Japanese carriers to fly between Japan and the United States at Narita, Tokyo's international airport, they say, because of unfair competition. Without a redistribution of these slots to Japanese carriers, open skies would merely entrench that unfairness. A second fear is that, as a result,American carriers will capture so much travel between the two countries that they will eventually force up prices. 
For a ministry which presides over the most heavily regulated sector of the Japanese economy, that second argument sounds odd. The first has more merit. Slots are limited; both the big international airports, at Narita and Kansai, are operating at full capacity. That said, the problem is largely of the transport ministry's own making. It could have encouraged regional airports to be used as hubs. It could have decided that the extension to Haneda, Tokyo's domestic airport, which opens in April, be used for international flights. And it could increase the number of flights going into Narita which takes only 25 flights an hour, compared with, say, 40 at Britain's similarly sized Gatwick. 
Its own fault 
Above all, it could have deregulated much earlier. The fact that an American airline can fly less than half full across the Pacific and still offer cheaper flights from Japan than Japanese carriers says a lot about the effects of the present domestic cartel on the competitiveness of Japanese airlines. JAL's costs per passenger mile are 70% higher than those of American airlines coming into Japan, according to Naoko Matsumoto, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, an investment bank (see box). 
The result of all this is that, per head of population, Japan has fewer international flights and fewer available seat-miles (total seats multiplied by the number of miles flown) than any other OECD country. It also has fewer international flights than many of its Asian neighbours. Whatever the iniquities of the original deal between the United States and Japan, that has been the cost to would-be Japanese travellers of the transport ministry's attempts to cosset the country's airlines. The victims have been Japanese travellers and Japanese companies. They have most to gain from opening Japan's skies.

Such an agreement, they think, would continue to give American airlines an unfair advantage.The Japanese claim that opening international markets without first opening the American domestic market would allow American airlines to use profits earned on internal flights (which account for more than 40% of world air travel) to subsidise their expansion beyond American shores. 
By contrast, Japan's domestic market is not only much smaller than America's, but is about to become a lot less profitable. The transport ministry is beginning to deregulate. Last November it announced that HIS, a discount travel operator, would be allowed to open a domestic airline, the first company to do so in more than 40 years. Two smaller operators have also been given the nod. On January 3oth, the transport ministry said that it would start deregulating fares and capacity in transport in the 1997 fiscal year, which begins in April. Competition will drive down the three carriers' already meagre profits. Small wonder that airlines have been the worst performers in the Japanese stockmarket over the past six months. 
Given the high price of flying in Japan (it costs as much to fly from Tokyo to Sapporo as from Tokyo to Los Angeles), the transport ministry has little choice but to start breaking up the cartel. Yet bureaucrats hesitate to expose the airlines to more foreign competition at the same time. 
Hence the two other arguments that Japanese trade negotiators wield against open skies. American airlines have managed to accrue three times as many slots as Japanese carriers to fly between Japan and the United States at Narita, Tokyo's international airport, they say, because of unfair competition. Without a redistribution of these slots to Japanese carriers, open skies would merely entrench that unfairness. A second fear is that, as a result,American carriers will capture so much travel between the two countries that they will eventually force up prices. 
For a ministry which presides over the most heavily regulated sector of the Japanese economy, that second argument sounds odd. The first has more merit. Slots are limited; both the big international airports, at Narita and Kansai, are operating at full capacity. That said, the problem is largely of the transport ministry's own making. It could have encouraged regional airports to be used as hubs. It could have decided that the extension to Haneda, Tokyo's domestic airport, which opens in April, be used for international flights. And it could increase the number of flights going into Narita which takes only 25 flights an hour, compared with, say, 40 at Britain's similarly sized Gatwick. 
Its own fault 
Above all, it could have deregulated much earlier. The fact that an American airline can fly less than half full across the Pacific and still offer cheaper flights from Japan than Japanese carriers says a lot about the effects of the present domestic cartel on the competitiveness of Japanese airlines. JAL's costs per passenger mile are 70% higher than those of American airlines coming into Japan, according to Naoko Matsumoto, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, an investment bank (see box). 
The result of all this is that, per head of population, Japan has fewer international flights and fewer available seat-miles (total seats multiplied by the number of miles flown) than any other OECD country. It also has fewer international flights than many of its Asian neighbours. Whatever the iniquities of the original deal between the United States and Japan, that has been the cost to would-be Japanese travellers of the transport ministry's attempts to cosset the country's airlines. The victims have been Japanese travellers and Japanese companies. They have most to gain from opening Japan's skies.

THE Japanese call it gaiatsu-using foreign pressure as an excuse for doing something that everyone agrees is necessary but no one wants to take the flak for. This time the problem is Japan's ports. These have long been nests of restrictive practices that hobble importers and shipping lines alike. The transport ministry is keen to do something about the problem, but the bureaucrats are scared of special interests such as the dockers and the cargohandling cartel. Hence the convenience of leaving the dredging work to America's Federal Maritime Commission (FMC) in Washington, DC. 
The American overseer of sea-trade has spent several weary years urging the transport ministry to use its authority to sort out the ports. Now it has finally understood how gaiatsu works. From April 14th, it will levy a $100,000 surcharge on Japan's three largest shipping firms-Nippon Yusen Kaisha, Mitsui OSK Lines and Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha-every time one of their container vessels docks in an American harbour. With the three Japanese lines visiting American ports over 400 times a year between them, this could cost them $40m annually. And if the authorities in Tokyo decide to retaliate-as the Japan Harbour Transportation Association has threatened to do-the FMC says it will hike the surcharge to as much as $1m a visit. 
The FMC expects Japan's flagship lines to squeal to the government-and be heard. The three shipping firms lost a combined 14 billion ($128m) last year on their North American routes. Competition from other Asian lines has cut transpacific shipping rates by 30% over the past 18 months, so the Japanese firms know that they will not be able to pass any cost increases on to customers. 
The FMC's aim, of course, is to provide the gaiatsu excuse that the Japanese authorities need to concede-after an appropriate amount of sucking their breath regretfully through clenched teeth. Already the prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, has called the FMC'S decision "very regrettable". The transport minister, Makoto Koga, has asked the FMC to withdraw its planned sanctions, promising to make "adjustments" to Japanese harbour practices within three to five years. 
All good, clean, ritual stuff The only real outrage has come from Shiro Takashima, the 83-year-old autocrat who has dominated the nation's ports for the past two decades. As boss of his own stevedore company and chairman of the Japan Harbour Transportation Association, the formidable Mr Takashima has threatened to ban all American ships from Japan. 
In theory he could do it. Virtually all the vessels that carried Japan's $689 billion of two-way trade last year were given their berths on his say-so. When a shipping company-foreign or domestic-needs to change a route, a vessel or a port of call, it has to ask the harbour association six weeks in advance. If the paperwork is not perfect, approval is delayed for a month. 
Ever since the war, Japanese boat owners have learned to live with the yakuza, gangsters who infest the country's waterfronts and often dictate which firms win which contracts. But the harbour association's "prior consultation" wheeze is barely a decade old. It was introduced in 1986ostensibly to avert a strike by dock workers over the shift to containerisation. Masquerading as a shield for dockers' wages, the procedure is really a mechanism for reserving contracts for association members and extracting "concessions" from shipping firms. So far, fear of the harbour association has stopped newcomers from setting up their own cargo-handling facilities. 
The FMC thinks Tokyo's transport mandarins should do something about this. The ministry spends no billion a year upgrading harbour walls and loading bays, but seems reluctant to take on the stonefaced men who stop them working properly. Perhaps a bit of gaiatsu will give the bureaucrats the necessary spine.

text:
PUT yourself into the polyester suit and behind the thick-rimmed spectacles of a Communist Party cadre, and take a look at the world as seen from Beijing. 
China is a huge land, roughly the size of the United States, and vulnerable. It cannot be defended by brute military force alone, and not just because internal threats tie up so much of that force. China's People's Liberation Army (peA) may be the world's largest, yet it is outnumbered by two to one when the armies of its seven biggest neighbours are added together, to say nothing of America's huge Pacific presence. And China's military technology is put in the shade by most of its neighbours'. 
Four-fifths of China is rugged and inhospitable, yet it is through these western frontierlands that five invasions of nomads have arrived to conquer part or all of the Chinese state, most recently until 1911. Even now only a third of China's people live in this western region, but it contains the bulk of China's mineral resources, notably oil-one reason for maintaining a large military garrison. 
Of the hinterland's sparse population, a fractious minority subsumed under earlier imperial expansion now chafes at Chinese rule. In Xinjiang, China's westernmost province, Kazakhs, Tajiks, Kyrgyz and Uighurs seek to rebuild ethnic and nationalist ties with the new central Asian republics, sometimes under a pan-Islamic banner. Recently the province has seen a spate of terrorist bombings. The risk of fresh rebellion is another reason for keeping a powerful military presence there. 
Separatist tendencies are strongest in Tibet. The government in Beijing has tried to counter them with a blend of economic development and suppression of support for the Dalai Lama. That support grew stronger as it was forced underground. Over the past decade, large numbers of ethnic (Han) Chinese have moved in to seek a new living in Tibet's larger towns, but this has failed to quell Tibetan longing for independence. Even in Inner Mongolia, where Hans now outnumber Mongols sixfold, Mongolian nationalism still has to be kept down by tough government measures. 
The least fractious two-thirds of China's population, about 8oom, live on the eastern one-fifth of its land. This is an area roughly the size of America's eastern seaboard-plus Alabama, West Virginia and Pennsylvania-but with nearly six times the population. Sheer numbers do not necessarily bring security: for a start, the region's economy remains predominantly rural, and so harder to defend. A rural campaign against the cities was, after all, how the Communists got to power. 
Nor is the coastal plain easy to defend. In the 19th century western imperial powers had no trouble invading it. Earlier this century Japan managed to wreak breathtaking brutality on this region. Today the region remains vulnerable to attack. It would be devastated by the air superiority alone of Taiwan, with which China is technically still at war. America's military strategists can allow themselves the luxury of discounting any future conflict with another power on continental American soil; China's equivalents have to assume that any such conflict would take place on their home ground. 
What of China's neighbours, of which it has no fewer than 14 with shared land borders? At least four ofthose borders-with Russia, North Korea, Tajikistan and India-are disputed. In addition, China has sea claims overlapping with Vietnam, the Philippines, Brunei, Malaysia, Indonesia, South Korea and Japan. China also lays claim to three ter- ritories not yet under its jurisdiction: Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan. And then there is its "sphereof-influence boundary" across the Pacific with America, outlined by two American political scientists, Andrew Nathan and Robert Ross, in a new book* on Chinese security concerns, which this section draws on. By the authors' count, therefore, "China's territorial interests overlap with those of 24 other governments." China has this century been in military conflict with no fewer than seven: Russia, India, Japan, Vietnam, South Korea, Taiwan and America. 
The strategists in Beijing will admit that China is probably as strong as it has ever been, and its borders as secure. Relations with India are improving after past bloody conflicts. Sino-Russian relations have gone from strength to strength since the collapse of the Soviet Union; until then, the 4,000mile border had been the world's most heavily armed, with 1.5m troops massed along it, backed by nuclear weapons. Last year China even signed a border agreement with Vietnam, a communist vassal-turned-foe. 
What if 
Yet, in Chinese eyes, the keenest vigilance is still called for. A nuclear-arms race might develop on the Korean peninsula, pushing Japan, China's old aggressor, to acquire its own nuclear weapons. North Korea's despot regime might yet try to divert its sullen masses with a full-scale invasion of the south, with frightening consequences for China. Trade and investment between China and South Korea would certainly be hit; and North Korean refugees would probably flood into Manchuria. In the end, though, a Korean unification is likely to be led by South Korea. Then Japan might tempt South Korea under its security umbrella. 
Further south, China has little influence over the maritime states of South-East Asia, whose economies look towards America and Japan rather than China. What if they entertain a superpower that is hostile to China? This happened quite recently when tiny Vietnam entertained two powers at once, the United States and the Soviet Union. China dreads the risk of superpower encirclement. 
In the 1950s America contained China from what Douglas MacArthur called America's "unsinkable aircraft carrier", Taiwan. It was this containment, along with Maoist ideology, that helped push China into its quarter-century of economic isolation. Next, China's Soviet ally turned enemy, tilting for influence in North Korea on one side of China and Vietnam on the other. This helps to explain China's invasion of Vietnam in 1979 and its support for Cambodia's genocidal Pol Pot regime: the Soviet Union was threatening to squeeze China from both her northern and southern flanks. China's warming to America was a cold-war necessity. 
For the moment, the cadre notes, Russia lies quiet in Asia, wracked by domestic troubles. Russia and Japan are in dispute over the Kurile Islands, and relations between the two countries are coolish, which suits China just fine. China also welcomes America's defence presence in the Asia-Pacific region to guard against Russian military resurgence. And America's defence pact with Japan is a useful way of preventing a new rise in Japanese militarism. If America were to withdraw from the region, it would be a disaster in China's eyes. 
On the other hand, China must keep a sharp watch for signs that America and Japan might be combining to contain or divide it. Both countries have parliamentarians who loudly deny the Chinese government's legitimacy. In this light the strengthened security agreement signed a year ago between Bill Clinton and Ryutaro Hashimoto, Japan's prime minister, looks disturbing to the Chinese. Separately, America has talked about helping Japan build a theatre missile-defence system. Why, asks the cadre, should it do that unless it wants to encircle China? 
China's greatest concern is for territorial integrity. Hong Kong and Macau, separated from China since 1841 and 1557 respectively, are at least to return soon. Yet both Britain and America are trying to undermine the future exercise of Chinese sovereignty in Hong Kong by playing the human-rights card. After Hong Kong's return, attention will soon be turned to wooing back Taiwan by peaceful means. Yet that very attention will increase the risk that such a policy might continue to fail, as it has done so far. And if America really believes in "one China", as it says it does, why is it constantly intervening in Taiwan's favour? China cannot afford to give an inch on territorial issues, or else Tibetan separatists, Hong Kong liberals, Taiwanese independents and (who knows?) the man on the Beijing omnibus would take a mile. 
Satisfaction not guaranteed 
Remove the glasses, and it is clear that China's foreign policy is frantically reactive, dedicated to stopping Taiwan moving towards independence, averting fresh challenges to its territorial claims and preventing new power balances from shaping the region. China lives in dread that new power arrangements amongst China's near-neighbours will threaten its external security. Yet it palpably lacks the power to impose its views on others. So its diplomacy comes in two distinct styles: high principle and pragmatism. Under the first heading, the emphasis is on sovereignty, not open to discussion. Many visitors to Beijing have been treated to the lecture that begins: "The whole world admits there is but one China. . . ", and ends: "Five thousand years of history have proven that anybody who tries to divide China will be cursed for generations." 
The second style involves cool calculations of national interest and balance of power. Thomas Christensen of Cornell University calls China the "high church of realpolitik". This, ironically, would have served it very well in dealing with the western imperial powers that knocked down its doors in the 19th century. Today it sets China dangerously at odds with the American-led concept that foreign policy can have legitimate concerns-human rights, self-determination-that transcend national boundaries. For now, the danger remains that China will be, as Messrs Nathan and Ross put it, "not a satisfied power". 
*"The Great Wall and the Empty Fortress, by Andrew Nathan and Roben Ross. W.W. Norton, 1997

text:
In this article, Eisuke Sakakibara argues that pessimism about the Japanese economy is overdone 
IN FISCAL 1996 (which ends on March 31st), Japan will probably have achieved GDP growth of 2.5% or more, as forecast by the government. That will be among the highest of the G7 countries. The short-term pessimism over the economy that has recently been pervasive in Tokyo and elsewhere is based primarily on two assumptions. The first is that the 77 trillion ($57 billion) tax increase in April 1997 will be a major drag on consumption and may result in a "double dip" recovery. The second is that the non-performing loan problems, which are worsening, may result in bankruptcy for some large financial institutions. 
Neither speculation can be supported by the facts. First, the tax increase has been anticipated for the past few years, and to the extent that consumers are rational, has already been incorporated into their consumption behaviour. Indeed, housing starts jumped substantially last September in anticipation of the consumption tax rise and have plateaued since. Additionally, there has been a small increase in automobile purchases during the past few months. True, there may be some small reactions to these purchases during the April-June quarter but those reactions will be temporary. 
What is more important is that business sentiment has been improving, reflecting continuing favourable prospects for profits. In all industries, it is now expected that profit levels will increase on average at slightly less than lO% in fiscal 1996 and 1997. Investment in plant and equipment is expected to grow substantially in fiscal 1997, reflecting the outlook for profits. I do not intend to make any macroeconomic forecast here, but I will say that achieving the 1.9% growth predicted by the government for fiscal 1997 should not prove hard. 
The writing off of non-performing loans by banks, on the other hand, is proceeding steadily and their total amount is now 29 trillion, as against 1,346 trillion of total assets. There has been some downgrading of several top banks by rating agencies as well as market rumours about financial distress at some banks during the last few weeks. But the finance minister, Hitoshi Mitsuzuka, has said that both the Ministry of Finance and the Bank of Japan would stand firmly behind those institutions, and the market has swiftly regained its stability. Large-scale streamlining and restructuring are being undertaken by these banks, and the authorities fully back the efforts they are making to overcome their present difficulties. Indeed, the socalled "Tokyo Big Bang" will be implemented in the coming years to deregulate Tokyo's financial markets, and these deregulatory efforts have been carefully scheduled, with full consideration given to the process of recovery of the industry's shattered health. 
Both domestic and foreign observers have expressed some scepticism about the possibility of implementing the six broad reforms announced by the Hashimoto government. It is true that neither the prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, nor his party, the Liberal Democrats, has ever been perceived as the ultimate "reformer". In fact, both have been seen as somewhat nationalistic and often conservative. 
But the history of reform is surprising: it has often been tough conservatives who have implemented genuine reforms. Edmund Burke spoke of radical reform to preserve nationhood, and it is exactly that type of reform that the Hashimoto government has set about implementing. I, for one, have long defended the Japanese-style market economy, and my position remains unchanged. Job security, harmony within society, and co-habitation with nature should still be the cornerstone of the Japanese economy and society. However, we must adapt to the ever-increasing trend toward globalisation and quickly adjust our system in order to survive in this new environment. As we have done for the 130 years since the Meiji Restoration, we will quickly absorb what needs to be absorbed and become fully competitive with the AngloSaxon and other systems. 
In sectors such as automobiles, semiconductors, and machine tools we are still fully competitive. It is in areas such as finance and information that we need to concentrate our efforts to catch up. 
The Tokyo Big Bang is a series of reforms to restructure our financial system and institutions to achieve such goals in the area of finance. During the current session of the Diet (parliament), a bill will be enacted to deregulate cross-border and cross-currency financial transactions completely. That act would transform the international financial field in Tokyo. Following foreign-exchange deregulation, blueprints to deregulate or internationalise areas such as securities, banking, insurance, business accounting standards, and taxation should be announced by the end of 1997. Most of the changes should be enacted, where legal action is necessary, in the normal session of the Diet between January and June 1998. Mr Hashimoto has said the Tokyo Big Bang will be completed by 2001, but the process is likely to be quicker than that, with most of the necessary measures in place by the end of the century. 
The lessons of Asian history 
Some of the irrational pessimism currently pervading Japan seems to be the result of an identity crisis to which many Japanese have fallen victim since the end of the cold war and the achievement of Japan's goal of catching up with the West. Until quite recently, Japan could easily identify itself with the free non-socialist world, despite historical and cultural differences, and could concentrate on economic activities. 
However, with the end of what Samuel Huntington, a professor at Harvard, calls the civil wars among the western powers, a new perspective on the world scene that places greater emphasis on differences between civilisations has emerged-and many Japanese who have had a few qualms about Americanising their way of life in the search for economic prosperity have suddenly lost their confidence now that they have achieved what they thought was their goal. Some confusion has naturally been generated and a serious search for national identity has ensued. 
In order to understand the nature of this search-and to grasp its implications for modern Japan-it is necessary to look at some recent trends in Japanese historiography. Serious soul searching has been going on for some time now, particularly among philosophers, anthropologists, economic historians, and among Asian regional specialists. Many have taken a long, hard look at Japanese history before the Meiji modernisation in the 19th century and Asian history before westernisation. 
Influenced by the writings of Fernand Braudel and Immanuel Wallerstein (historians who helped establish a tradition of global comparative history), large numbers of Japanese intellectuals are beginning to realise that a global economic system existed in the areas around the Indian Ocean, the Arabic Sea, the South China Sea, and the East China Sea long before the westernisation of the world. The Mediterranean world sketched by Braudel and the world system across the Atlantic Ocean described by Wallerstein were nothing other than subsystems of the global system that encompassed Africa, the Mediterranean, the Islamic Middle East, India, China, and Southeast Asia. 
The centre of world economic and commercial activity from about the eighth and ninth centuries until around the dawn of the i8th century was the area encompassed by the Islamic empires, India, Southeast Asia and the coastal areas of China. In the 15th and i6th centuries, Europe entered this global commercial network. Europeans imported enormous amounts of consumer goods, ranging from cotton products, tea, and ceramics, to lacquerware and seasonings such as pepper and cloves. They exchanged those goods for silver and gold which they obtained from North and South America. 
The key to this global economic system was the importance placed on commercial activities by Islamic merchants. Around the time of the Abbasid dynasty, cross-border trade became extremely active in the Islamic world with merchants acting as mediators for the movement of goods among western and African countries, India, and (later) China. Joint business operations resembling modern corporations thrived. Islamic, Jewish, and other merchants travelling on dhows-wooden ships with triangular sails-had reached as far as the southern coast of China as early as the 11th or 12th century. Chinese merchants sailing on junks reached Calcutta and other Indian ports on the Bay of Bengal sometime between the 12th and 14th centuries. 
It is true that Venetian, Spanish, Portuguese, Dutch, and English merchants participated in this global trading network. But compared with their Islamic, Indian, and Chinese counterparts they were latecomers, originally interested in importing luxury Asian goods for the European nobility and bourgeoisie in exchange for wool and woollen products or silver and gold.

However, according to the new view emerging among Japanese intellectuals, Asia has a long tradition of global trade among countries with diverse cultures and religions. What we are witnessing now is the "Asian Renaissance", born of the fusion of Asian commercial globalism and western capitalism. 
Owing to geography, Japan found itself at the periphery of the Asian global trading network, and precisely because of this peripheral location it has been able to retain its independence throughout its history. In this sense, Japanese history resembles that of western Europe, particularly England, in that the nation was never trampled under by the military aggression of the Chinese, Mongolian, or Islamic empires. Japan was late in developing its economic system compared with other Asian and Islamic countries. 
Unlike economic historians of the past, Japanese Braudelians and Wallersteinians claim that Japan's modernisation had proceeded fairly steadily before the Meiji Restoration of 1868. They claim that levels of productivity, education, and culture during the 17th and i8th centuries in Japan were comparable to those in Europe. In explaining the rapid increase in agricultural productivity during the Edo period (1605i868), they introduced the concept of an "Industrious Revolution" (increase in labour productivity by independent and relatively entrepreneurial farmers); this was conceived as a counterpart to the Industrial Revolution of the West. 
Of course, some catching up was necessary in order to revolutionise production "industrially" and to equip a modern army. But the infrastructure of modernity, according to the new view in vogue among Japanese intellectuals, was already there. 
Japan as model 
The implication of all this historical work is as follows: the pivotal question facing Asia and Japan today is not an all-or-nothing choice between globalisation western-style or receding into a pre-modern and backward tradition. Rather, the question is how Asian countries can help create a new global system along with the West. 
Many aspects of western market capitalism need to be incorporated into the new system, and in this context reform-perhaps even revolutionneeds to be implemented quickly. However, this does not imply that the traditional elements of the Asian economic structure-family and regional ties, or what Francis Fukuyama, of George Mason University, called the "trust" network-need to be changed. Rather, the "Asian Renaissance" may well create a new paradigm, one that is different from western individualism or laissez-faire capitalism. In such a paradigm, it is likely that there will be an important role for Japan, because it is both part of Asia and a nation that has succeeded in modernising its system without fundamentally losing its culture and religion. In other words, the sun may well rise again in the 21st century, with Japan not emulating the West but instead playing a leadership role in the effort to fuse modern western capitalism with pre-modern but nonetheless well-developed Asian global commercialism.

In this article , Eisuke Sakakibara argues that pessimism about the Japanese economy is overdone 
 IN FISCAL 1996 ( which ends on March 31st ) , Japan will probably have achieved GDP growth of 2.5 % or more , as forecast by the government . That will be among the highest of the G7 countries . The short - term pessimism over the economy that has recently been pervasive in Tokyo and elsewhere is based primarily on two assumptions . The first is that the 77 trillion ( $ 57 billion ) tax increase in April 1997 will be a major drag on consumption and may result in a " double dip " recovery . The second is that the non - performing loan problems , which are worsening , may result in bankruptcy for some large financial institutions . 
 Neither speculation can be supported by the facts . First , the tax increase has been anticipated for the past few years , and to the extent that consumers are rational , has already been incorporated into their consumption behaviour . Indeed , housing starts jumped substantially last September in anticipation of the consumption tax rise and have plateaued since . Additionally , there has been a small increase in automobile purchases during the past few months . True , there may be some small reactions to these purchases during the April - June quarter but those reactions will be temporary . 
 What is more important is that business sentiment has been improving , reflecting continuing favourable prospects for profits . In all industries , it is now expected that profit levels will increase on average at slightly less than lO% in fiscal 1996 and 1997 . Investment in plant and equipment is expected to grow substantially in fiscal 1997 , reflecting the outlook for profits . I do not intend to make any macroeconomic forecast here , but I will say that achieving the 1.9 % growth predicted by the government for fiscal 1997 should not prove hard .

There has been some downgrading of several top banks by rating agencies as well as market rumours about financial distress at some banks during the last few weeks . But the finance minister , Hitoshi Mitsuzuka , has said that both the Ministry of Finance and the Bank of Japan would stand firmly behind those institutions , and the market has swiftly regained its stability . Large - scale streamlining and restructuring are being undertaken by these banks , and the authorities fully back the efforts they are making to overcome their present difficulties . Indeed , the socalled " Tokyo Big Bang " will be implemented in the coming years to deregulate Tokyo 's financial markets , and these deregulatory efforts have been carefully scheduled , with full consideration given to the process of recovery of the industry 's shattered health .

text:
Israel continued to prepare the land for a new settlement in East Jerusalem. Three Palestinians were killed by Israeli soldiers during mass protests; two others blew themselves up near Israeli settlements in Gaza. Arab foreign ministers, meeting in Cairo, called on member states to halt all dealings with Israel: Egypt, Jordan and the Palestinians were excused because of their peace treaties; Morocco, Tunisia, Oman and Qatar could be affected. 
Jordan's King Hussein visited Bill Clinton; Binyamin Netanyahu was due to follow him on April 7th. Israel's prime minister said publicly that he was considering forming a national unity government with Labour. 
The National Council of Resistance, an Iranian opposition group based in Paris, claimed that Ibrahim Zalzadeh, an Iranian writer and publisher, had been abducted by the authorities in February and later murdered. 
Rebels in Zaire claimed to have captured Kamina, on the rail route between the capital and the country's second-largest town, Lubumbashi. Peace talks between government and rebels were due to open in South Africa. President Mobutu accepted parliament's nomination of a veteran opponent of his, Etienne Tshisekedi, as prime minister. 
Newt backs Taiwan 
Newt Gingrich, speaker of the United States House of Representatives, said in Shanghai that America would defend Taiwan if the island was attacked. A spokesman for President Clinton said the comment did not necessarily represent the official view. Meanwhile, Taiwan's government said that it would soon permit direct shipping links with mainland China. 
Japan's prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, introduced a bill into parliament to extend the leases of American military bases in Japan. But there were also reports that an American soldier had sexually assaulted a Japanese woman--the rape of a schoolgirl by American servicemen had earlier led to protests against the bases. 
India's Congress party was expected to make a bid for power after withdrawing its support for the minority government. 
Pakistan curbed its president's power to dismiss a government summarily. The power was granted to the president during a period of military rule. 
Sam Rainsy, a Cambodian opposition politician, escaped when grenades were thrown at a demonstration, killing at least 16 people. 
Sitting tight 
Illegal immigrants rushed to regularise their status, to marry, even to get arrested before a new law came into force in the United States on April 1st. Anyone caught since then has little chance of winning the right to stay, and faces speedy deportation and a ban of three to ten years on re-entry. In Mexico, the law was denounced as "racist". 
Thousands of schoolchildren in 16 states of the United States were inoculated after hepatitis was discovered in strawberries from Mexico. 
Thirty-nine members of a cult called Heaven's Gate, based at Rancho Santa Fe in the suburbs of San Diego, committed suicide. They believed that they were about to be taken to a higher level by a spacecraft travelling in the wake of the Hale-Bopp comet 
The trial of Timothy McVeigh, accused of the Oklahoma City bombing in April 995, opened in Denver with jury selection. 
Refugees flooded into towns in Colombia's north-western Uraba region. Driven from their homes by FARC guerrillas, the army said; by paramilitaries and air-force bombs, said FARC. By the lot of them, said the victims. 
Brazil's new rules on import finance angered its Mercosur trade partners. Its aim is to slim a swelling trade deficit; "protectionist", they said. 
Six Central American countries proposed a free-trade treaty to the United States. 
The fat man sings 
Germany's chancellor, Helmut Kohl, ended speculation by saying he wants to run for re-election in 1998. He hopes to shepherd in Europe's single currency and the expansion of NATO. 
An Italian patrol boat collided with a boat full of Albanian refugees, drowning at least 80 of them. Italy still plans to lead a force of 5,ooo soldiers to protect humanitarian aid missions to Albania. 
Russia and Belarus signed a treaty aimed at unifying their countries, but only after liberals in the Russian government removed much of its substance. 
Viktor Pynzenyk, Ukraine's leading economicreformer, offered his resignation as deputy prime minister. He was angry that parliament had delayed passing the state budget, thereby blocking $3 billion of aid from the IMF. 
Italy's prime minister, Romano Prodi, announced a mini-budget designed to ready the country for the introduction of a European single currency in 1999. 
The Serb-dominated part of Bosnia signed an agreement on joint customs with Serbia, an arrangement it does not have with Bosnia's MuslimCroat federation. 
France's xenophobic National Front held its congress in Strasbourg, amid protests by 50,000 demonstrators. 
Guy Spitaels, a former leader of Belgium's French-speaking Socialists, was charged with accepting bribes in the late 1980s from a French aircraft maker to finance his party.

When the Japenese army retreated from China at the end of the second world war, it left behind thousands of century on, Japan faces the huge cost of disposing of these rusting relics of its military past. Starting on April 29th, the countries that have ratified the Chemical Weapons Convention have ten years in which to get rid of their stocks of chemicals used in warfare, to dismantle the plants for making them, and to remove any chemical weapons left behind in other countries. Japan's sole obligation is to deal with the shells left in China in 1945. That is more than enough to keep the Japanese busy. 
China has not yet ratified the convention it signed with 129 other countries in Paris in 1993, but since 1991 it has been negotiating with Japan on the best way to clear up the old chemical dumps. Most of the dumps are in Jilin province, in northeast China. This is part of Manchuria, which Japan invaded in 1931, creating a puppet state. Surveys by China in the 1950s put the number of chemical shells left by Japan at 2m, mostly in the Harbin district. Smaller caches of chemical weapons have been found elsewhere in China. 
They are a continual danger. Claims for damages are working their way through the Tokyo courts on behalf of Chinese injured or killed by accidentally coming into contact with the chemicals. Officials in Beijing say that more than 2,000 people have been hurt or killed in this way. 
Japan has sent seven teams to various parts of China to examine the chemical dumps. The Japanese government puts the number of its chemical shells in China at 700,000, rather than the 2m estimated by the Chinese. The Japanese researchers say they have found no evidence that they contaminated the land or affected the health of local people. 
The Chinese have reluctantly agreed to let the Japanese deal with the crumbling shells in China rather than cart them back to Japan. But it will cost the Japanese government dearly. In March last year, Japan's prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, promised his Chinese counterpart, Li Peng, that Japan would respond to the Chemical Weapons Convention "with sincerity"-in other words, foot the bill. 
Japan had hoped to get away with simply building a factory ship that would process the poisonous gases and toxic chemicals in a Chinese port and float away when thejob was done. But in December it agreed instead to build a special processing plant in Jilin province. The site and the technology to be used are expected to be decided soon. The cost of the plant is put at up to 500 billion ($4. billion). 
Neither China nor Japan has any experience of disposing of old chemical weapons. Japanese technicians have been sent to Germany, Britain and America to study various ways of handling the shells. The Germans have become particularly adept at clearing stocks of chemical weapons left over from the first and second world wars. But, at most, they have had to dispose of no more than 3o shells a day. To meet the chemical convention's ten-year plan, the Japanese plant in China will have to process upwards of 200 a day.

Scepticism there may be, but the Japanese economy is being deregulated. Which industries will benefit and which will lose? 
THIS week the yen fell to almost ei 127 to the dollar, its lowest level in more than four years. Japan's big exporters are cock-ahoop. Many of its car makers, electronics firms and electrical producers have probably made record profits in the financial year that ended in March. According to Toyo Keizai, a financial-information group, 93 of Japan's top 500 companiesnearly all manufacturers-will have made more money than ever before. 
Now they no longer face a strong yen, will Japanese manufacturers grumble less about the rules that make it costly to do business in Japan? According to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI), electricity prices are about a third above those in America, road transport costs about 4o% higher, and coastal shipping and international telephone charges three times as expensive. If big manufacturers stop pressing Ryutaro Hashimoto's government to deregulate, many expect reform to slow down. Hence the scepticism that greeted a package of 2,823 reforms announced in March. 
In fact, the government realises that manufacturing, which accounts for only 26% of GDP, is not big enough to revive the economy. It is therefore promoting change in telecoms, energy, transport, land and retailing. What does that mean for the industries involved? 
In energy the government abolished in April last year a rule that allowed Japan's small and inefficient oil refiners to monopolise imports of oil products. That meant refining costs were three times those in Singapore, and petrol prices the OECD'S highest. Deregulation has caused petrol prices to fall sharply. Transport companies are purring; the oil companies squealing. Showa Shell and Mitsubishi Oil, Japan's fifth and sixth biggest refiners, announced in February that they are to merge. More will follow them. 
In electricity, MITI has ordered generators to reduce prices by a fifth by 2001 and opened the market to new entrants. From next year companies such as Kobe Steel and Hitachi Zosen, a shipbuilder, will start to sell surplus electricity to the generators, and MITI is considering allowing them to sell their electricity directly by separating generation and distribution. On April 9th Toyota, Japan's largest car marker, announced that it plans to go into electricity generation. Japan's electricity generators, such as Tokyo Electric Power, will find their margins squeezed; retail and wholesale users will gain. 
In transport, the famously antediluvian Ministry of Transport announced in late January that it would abolish its rigid capacity and price controls by2001at the latest. It has already allowed more taxis and more flexible fare structures. Late last year, the ministry approved four new airlines, the biggest run by HIS, a discount-travel firm. These are the first new domestic carriers in 40 years and in March they received six slots at Tokyo's Haneda airport. The newcomers will hurt the three incumbent domestic airlines, and especially All Nippon Airways, which has the largest share of the domestic market. 
In telecoms, deregulation will initially strengthen the biggest firm. Restrictions which have long separated domestic and international calls have gone. That will allow NTT, Japan's domestic monopoly, to offer international calls (although it will be split into three parts, all held by a holding company).
