text:
FOR Japan's disturbingly complacent nuclear industry, the most dangerous explosion in recent weeks has come not from a blast in a plutonium plant or a burst in reactor plumbing, but from the prime ministers bad temper. "I am disgusted", thundered Ryutaro Hashimoto, when told on April 15th that yet another radiation leak had occurred in a plant run by the govemment's Power Reactor and Nuclear Fuel Development Corporation (PNC) What especially angered him was that, once again, the announcement had been delayed in an attempt to cover up mistakes made by the agency. Some 30 hours passed before the PNC told local authorities that radioactive tritium had leaked from its Fugen reactor in Fukui prefecture. "It's completely hopeless," Mr Hashimoto declared as he ordered the Fugen advanced thermal-reactor to be shut down. Two days later the PNC compounded its sins, by belatedly admitting that there had been ii previous minor leaks at Fugen over the past three years. 
The most recent Fugen leak is the PNC'S third major accident in less than 18 months. More by luck than swift action or good judgment, none has been worse than level three on the international scale (with Chernobyl scoring seven, the maximum, and Three Mile Island five) A failure to extinguish a fire properly at the PNC's nuclear fuel plant at Tokaimura in Ibaraki prefecture on March lth set off an explosion that exposed 37 workers to radiation-making it Japan's worst nuclear accident. 
The Tokaimura plant is expected to remain closed until 2001, and the accident may have to be upgraded to level four if more people in the area are found to have been affected. Air samples taken from the plants ventilator shafts indicate an eightfold increase in particles capable of emitting alpha and gamma radiation. The PNC has found traces of radioactive caesium-137 up to 60km (38 miles) from the site. The fear is that other long-lasting isotopes, including plutonium-239, may have been released during the explosion as well. Apart from being radioactive, plutonium is 30,000 times more poisonous than cyanide. A single particle, if ingested, can lead to lung cancer. 
Ordinary Japanese, as well as the prime minister, are alarmed that the PNC has suppressed evidence and delayed warnings when accidents have occurred. The agency has been accused of a cover-up after a bungled attempt to put out the fire at Tokaimura. Had it been extinguished, there would have been no explosion, and far fewer people would have been exposed to radiation. Five officials at the plant have been fired, and criminal charges are being prepared. 
In December 1995, the Monju fast-breeder reactor at Tsuruga sprang a leak in its sodium-cooling circuitry. Though no radiation was released and no one died, three tons of liquid sodium burst from Monju's cooling circuits. This came close to exploding and blowing the plutonium-fuelled reactor to smithereens. So close did Monju come to being a disaster on the scale of Chernobyl that a PNC safety officer committed suicide. 
The safety officer revealed that the PNC had waited a whole hour before reporting the catastrophic leak to the authorities, and that a videotape of the damage caused by the spill had been heavily edited before being released to the press. Worse, despite fire alarms going off all over the place, operators had shut down the reactor slowly by hand instead of hitting the panic-button to close the reactor immediately. The Monju fast-breeder has remained shut - and may well be scrapped. 
The expanding nuclear industry in Japan is keen to prevent citizens' groups from gaining influence, as they have done in America. A growing number of towns now require referendums to be held before a nuclear power station can be built nearby. Despite promises of government riches, the residents of Maki, a small seaside town, voted last summer against having a nuclear power station on their doorstep. Japan gets a third of its electricity from nuclear power. Some 50 reactors have been built over the past 30 years. Another half a dozen or so are being built or planned. 
Mr Hashimoto has no argument with nuclear power. But the PNC's incompetence, which has put the public's health at risk, has stirred the wrath of the prime minister's office. Mr Hashimoto is determined to be remembered as the leader who brought Japan's overbearing civil service to heel. Bureaucrat-bashing is in season.

text:
LIMA AND TOKYO 
CRASH went the explosives. Out of tunnels beneath the Japanese ambassador's residence, in through its blown-in main entrance and by ladders on to the roof sprang 140 specially trained Peruvian government troops. Within 4o minutes, all 72 hostages were free, mostly unharmed. Every one of the 14 Tupac Amaru guerrillas who had been holding them was dead. President Alberto Fujimori had taken a calculated gamble and won hands down. 
Behind his smiling inscrutability, Mr Fujimori has always been both tough and ready for a calculated gamble. In 1992, he sent tanks to shut down Peru's Congress, which was hesitating to grant him the wide powers he sought to put down rampant guerrilla violence. On that occasion his bet was that domestic support would outweigh mild international disapproval. 
This week, after more than four months of on-off-on haggling for a peaceful end to the affair, he lost patience with the hostagetakers-and with the ever-timid Japanese government. Throughout the four months he had kept the Japanese constantly informed, but they were not told of the coming assault until it was under way. 
The hostage-takers-only 14 of them, fewer than had been thought at first, and many of them teenagers-were caught offguard. Several, including their leader, Nestor Cerpa, were reportedly playing indoor football in a room at ground level-until the floor exploded beneath them. They were swiftly killed, as soon were all the others. Some attempted to surrender, in vain. The troops had been ordered to take no prisoners; not, it seems, to make an example, or for the sake of later convenience, but for the speed and safety of the operation, in which it had been widely feared that many of the hostages would die. Only one did so, a Supreme Court judge, hit by a bullet (and, said some reports, a subsequent heart attack). Two soldiers were killed. 
Of the surviving hostages, only twoone was Francisco Tudela, Peru's foreign minister-were even wounded. All 24 Japanese escaped unhurt. That was as well for Mr Fujimori. In February,when it looked as if the Peruvians were preparing to use force, Japan's prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, hastily arranged to meet him in Toronto, and got what he thought was a promise to seek a peaceful solution-unless the guerrillas threatened to start killing their hostages-no matter how long it took. 
The affair has embarrassed the Japanese government from start to finish. The flamboyance of the embassy party which the Tupac Amaru guerrillas broke into was maybe unwise; the lax security certainly was. Worse, though it put all its embassies on high alert this week, Japan's manifest unreadiness for risky but decisive action against terrorists has been signalled to the world, not least by the Peruvians' failure to give it notice of the assault: Mr Hashimoto was woken from his sleep to be told it had happened. He wished he had been told in advance, he admitted publicly later, while conceding uncomfortably that "President Fujimori used the best timing and that brought about the result." 
Support for Mr Fujimori at home has soared. Peruvians were growing critical of the government's inability to end the affair. The assault followed weeks of seeming hesitation. In return for the hostages, Mr Fujimori had been prepared to fly their captors to Cuba, and won Cuban acceptance. But Nestor Cerpa overplayed his hand, stubbornly insisting not indeed-as in December-that all, but that at least some of the 4oo-odd people from his group held in Peru's jails be freed. Neither public opinion, nor Mr Fujimori's generals would contemplate that. Attempts at mediation by the Canadian ambassador and Juan Luis Cipriani, a Catholic bishop, had broken down on this point. Hours before the troops went in, Monsignor Cipriani announced that he was giving up. 
Now the president has restored his reputation as one ready for decisive action to maintain order. And in case anyone had missed the point, he greeted the freed hostages in person, dressed in a bullet-proof jacket. But he is not the only winner. Hard men in the armed forces had argued for the use of force right from the start; at the weekend two had replaced the then interior minister and police chief. Mr Cerpa's folly has done Peru's less-than-robust democratic institutions no good at all.

text:
THE Japanese have long had a high regard for their bureaucrats. They were considered the brightest and best in the land. That view is waning. The bureaucrats allowed the economy to get out of hand, and failed to clear up the mess after the bubble burst. A spate of bureaucratic mishaps has further eroded public trust. Worse, it seems that, like politicians, bureaucrats can be venal. 
The country's so-called "iron triangle" of interlocking interests-business, the bureaucracy and politics-has never really been anything more than an iron dumbbell: companies on one side, government regulators at the other. Politicians have had few pickings. Political donations from the corporate sector never added up to more than a tenth of what businessmen spent softening up ministry officials and finding cushy jobs for them after retirement. 
Glad, for once, to see others accused of being on the take, Japan's politicians have been quick to blame civil servants for many of their own sins. During last October's general election, all the major political parties pounced on the bureaucracy's misfortunes, making "administrative reform" their rallying cry. Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister, swore that his ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) would halve the number of ministries and agencies. Reelected, Mr Hashimoto is now trying to deliver on his promise. In the next few weeks, his Administrative Reform Council will reveal its plans for cutting the bureaucracy down to size. 
But while a bureaucracy on the run has handed the politicians a chance to have more than a passing say in formulating policy, it is unclear what they will do with it. Do they, for example, have the intellectual resources to come up with solutions to Japan's national debt-now Y45o trillion ($3.6 trillion) and widening-or the rapidly ageing population that threatens to bankrupt the health and welfare services? 
At the moment they do not. The source of legislation in Japan has long been the bureaucracy. A cabinet minister's job is simply to shepherd a bill from his bureaucrats through parliament. The cabinet's task is to co-ordinate the legislative agenda and to seek a consensus with other political parties.That is how the legislative process has worked since the LDP came together in 1955. But is there a better way of creating policy in Japan? The Administrative Reform Council will recommend setting up British-style independent agencies to do a number of administrative jobs (such as vehicle licensing and managing teachers' pensions) currently performed by bureaucrats. But, though the ministries may be smaller, the remaining bureaucrats will still expect to formulate policy. 
If politicians are to gain control over policy, the quality of cabinet ministers will have to be improved. They need to be selected for their competence rather than their seniority, and then kept in their jobs long enough for them to master the intricacies of their ministries. They should answer their own questions in parliament rather than rely on officials from the ministries. The prime minister needs to be given power to take charge of a ministry if there is an emergency. The inability to do that is what lies behind the government's sorry record on crisis management during the Kobe earthquake two years ago, the costly oil spill in the Sea of Japan this year and the hostage crisis in Peru. 
Such measures would improve government and increase the ruling party's influence. The opposition parties need to be given more power, too. They should be allowed to call witnesses to give evidence in parliament, a right at present denied to the opposition. There might be public hearings (as in the American Congress) or select committees (as in the British parliament) to monitor the administration. 
Another idea to give more authority to government would be to introduce an American-style General Accounting Office (GAO)-as the fledgling Democratic Party, founded last September by Yukio Hatoyama and Naoto Kan, wants to do. A Japanese GAo would help members of parliament "to be better informed and debate issues such as government waste," says Yoshito Sengoku, head of the party's Policy Research Council. Mr Sengoku has made a study of waste in public corporations. 
Because such reforms would help government and opposition alike, their chances of being introduced are slim. With the LDP in charge-and likely to tighten its grip on parliament-the bureaucrats can probably relax again. But discontent with officialdom will not go away. Sooner or later, the LDP will have to decide whether it seriously wants to govern, or is content to tag along with the bureaucracy.

TOKYO Its new defence guidelines are a cautious step in the right direction WITH several of the world's most dangerous places on its doorstep, Japan is coming painfully and reluctantly to terms with the insecurities of Asia after the cold war. An unsettled dispute over the Senkaku islands (called Diaoyu in China), which both China and Taiwan also lay claim to, has given the Japanese an early glimpse of the kind of territorial skirmishes that might crop up. And with every new revelation from the starving and increasingly paranoid regime in Pyongyang, the Japanese have become more aware that North Korea has pointed its missiles as much at them as at the South Koreans. The cold war may be over, but the security climate around the region is still chilly. In Japanese political circles, the basis of cold-war strategy-to defend the homeland in the event of attack by Soviet forces-is now recognised as largely irrelevant. But finding the political will to confront a more diffuse, but no less alarming, set of threats is becoming one of the government's biggest worries. The publication of new defence guidelines on June 7th represents an overdue attempt to start redefining Japan's role. The way Japan has chosen to interpret its post-1945 constitution bars it from engaging in the collective use of force to settle international disputes. The Japanese like it that way. Japan's armed forces stay strictly at home-keeping defence costs down and soldiers out of harm's way. The constitution has also helped to reassure neighbours who suffered at the hands of the old imperial army that Japanese militarism is dead and buried. 
Unfortunately, such a stay-at-home approach to national security cannot help Japan defend itself from newer threats to its well-being. A suicidal thrust by a collapsing North Korean dictatorship, for instance, would require Japanese forces to venture farther afield. No matter how crude, missiles bearing nuclear or biological warheads would have to be hunted down and destroyed in their launching sites. This is what Bill Clinton was hinting at in April 1996, when he broached the idea of expanding the security pact between Japan and America. The two countries promised then to review their agreement on defence co-operation and give Japan a greater role. The result of the past 15 months' deliberations has now been made public. 
The joint security treaty that Japan signed with the United States in 196o remains the cornerstone of the country's defence policy. Guidelines put in place in 1978 spell out precisely how the two sides should co-operate to defend Japan from attack It is these guidelines that are now being updated. The draft recommendations cover some 4o-odd things that Japan would be expected to do during an emergency-from offering logistical support to American troops, to evacuating civilians. The report calls for Japan to support American forces in two main ways: by providing various facilities and by giving support at the rear. The first would allow American forces to use civilian airports and harbours in Japan and to rely on Japanese minesweeping and search-and-rescue operations at sea. The second would involve providing American ships and aircraft with supplies, including fuel and oil from Japanese stocks. Weapons and ammunition have been left off the supply list, though Japanese units will be allowed to transport ammunition and weapons for American forces, provided the stocks come from American depots. 
The interim report goes further, much further, than simply giving Japan a bigger part to play in its own defence. It shifts the whole emphasis of the security treaty between the two countries away from defending the Japanese archipelago towards dealing with conflicts in the region surrounding Japan. Two of the three sets of circumstances considered by the report cover much the same ground as the existing guidelines: how to prepare for an invasion of Japan and how to repulse an invader. It is the third set of circumstances-how to work together during emergencies in surrounding areas-which represents the main thrust of the revised guidelines. 
America has been making it clear for several years that the biggest stick it has in coping with conflicts in and around the Pacific is its security treaty with Japan. As the Americans see it, the bigger the stick, the better. But the drafting has not been entirely a matter of America thrusting its demands on a reluctant Japan. The Japanese have their own agenda. They want, above all, a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council. Doing more to help to keep the peace in Asia could bolster Japan's case. 
The government believes that the report itself will not have to be debated in the Diet (parliament). But various laws will have to be amended if Japanese forces are to play a wider role. Ryutaro Hashimoto's ruling Liberal Democratic Party aims to introduce a package of bills in the next session. The trickiest part for the government now will be putting the public's mind at rest about the "grey areas" in the report. Some parts have been deliberately left ambiguous. One such concerns minesweeping, a non-combat activity that Japan might be expected to undertake for American troops making a landing on, say, a Korean peninsula at war. But an enemy would hardly view Japanese mine-sweeping, even by non-combatants, as peaceful-and could well respond with direct attacks on Japanese forces. There are also legitimate concerns within the Diet that Japan could be dragged into conflicts-breaking up a Chinese blockade of Taiwan, for instancethat were of greater concern to the United States than to Japan itself. 
So far, the main political parties in Japan have been careful not to over-react to the new guidelines. But eventually the issue is expected to make the Social Democratic Party abandon its shaky alliance with the Liberal Democrats. Though the party is nowadays a shadow of its former self, its support-especially in the upper househas helped Mr Hashimoto's minority government remain in power. Without it, he would have to cut a deal elsewhere. 
Most expect him, reluctantly, to accept the overtures from conservatives within Ichiro Ozawa's New Frontier Party, the lar est of the opposition groups and the most enthusiastic about a bigger security role for Japan. China has already expressed its vehement opposition to Japan's beefed up security pact with America (see box). It is going to like it even less when the revised guidelines are enthusiastically embraced by a new hardline Japanese government.

text:
THE ink was barely dry on the new draft military guidelines setting out the way in which America and Japan should co-operate in a future crisis in East Asia when Japanese officials fanned out to apply the first gloss. Since the draft will not be completed until the autumn, that leaves time to reassure the neighbours. The two most prickly ones are South Korea and China. 
South Korea knows that, if war were to break out with North Korea, American troops and planes passing through American bases in japan would be critical to its survival. But South Korea is still hypersensitive about its former colonial master. It does not want the Japanese to join in any fighting, nor Japanese warships to patrol in South Korean waters. Though Japan's emissaries got a polite hearing in Seoul, the South Koreans will be ultrawary of anything that might give Japan a military toehold in their affairs. 
The Chinese have been less polite. Senior military officials have let it be known that they are unhappy with the new guidelines, which they claim are based on "cold-war thinking". By that they do not mean the alliance's old job of containing Russia, but what they fear is its new one: containing China. Ever since Bill Clinton and Ryutaro Hashimoto reaffirmed their security alliance last year, both Japan and America have been at pains to tell China that the alliance is not directed at anyone, only at coping with instability. But, perhaps because many countries in the region see an increasingly powerful China as a rising source of tension, the Chinese are not so easily fobbed off. 
Back in April, China's foreign-ministry spokesman said publicly for the first time that China opposed the stationing of foreign-read American-forces in the region. The locals could sort out their own problems, thank you. The remarks caused alarm, especially in ASEAN, the Association of South-East Asian Nations, whose members were already smarting from China's land-grabs for disputed rocks and reefs in the South China Sea. Reports have since filtered out of a bad-tempered meeting in March in Beijing under the umbrella of the ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF) A discussion of confidence-building measures degenerated into a stand-up row between the Chinese and the Americans over America's forces in the region. 
Yet China's increasingly public opposition to America's military presence has achieved little, except to push those who want the Americans to stay to speak up too. Perhaps for that reason, another ARF meeting held in Malaysia in May passed off more smoothly. The big test of regional tempers will come when foreign ministers gather for an ARF summit in July.China's mood will not be improved by the new America-Japan guidelines.

text:
Japan is sometimes tempted to sell some of its $zoo billion-worth of American Treasury bonds, said Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Japanese prime minister, prompting a big fall in the Dow Jones industrial average, quickly reversed by official backpedalling. Mr Hashimoto, more reforming than some, is annoyed by what he sees as American whingeing over the slow pace of deregulation in Japan and over its current-account surplus. 
That surplus seems likely to keep growing in the next few months: the Bank of Japan's quarterly tankan survey shows optimism is stronger among Japan's manufacturers, helped by rising exports, than among nonmanufacturers. 
American consumer confidence, meanwhile, continued to rise, reaching a 28-year high in June, according to the Conference Board. 
Marketing ploy 
After failing to buy Gateway 2ooo, a mail-order Pc firm, Compaq, has taken a different tack. It is to pay $3 billion for Tandem Computers, in large part to get the mainframe maker's 4,ooo-strong sales force and high-margin corporate customers. 
Oracle, the world's secondlargest software company, finally delivered the product at the heart of its network-computer strategy. It hopes that its new database software, Oracle8, tying together a web of cheap desktop machines built to its design, will topple Microsoft's Pc-software empire. 
A licence for digital terrestrial TV was awarded to British Digital Broadcasting after it complied with a request from regulators to dump BSkYB from its ranks on competition grounds, leaving a consortium of two big TV stations, Carlton and Granada. But BSkyB will supply BDB with the bulk of its content. After a long battle for control of Germany's digital pay-Tv market, Kirch and a Bertelsmann unit, cLT-ufa, agreed to build a digital Tv service jointly around Premiere, Germany's main pay-Tv channel. They will use one decoder Kirch's, and also Kirch's film archive. cLT-ufa will not now proceed with plans for its own digital network 
Pipe of peace 
In a deal reached with states' attorneys-general, American cigarette makers agreed to pay $370 billion over the next 25 years to protect the tobacco industry from antismoking lawsuits. The industry also agreed to big curbs on advertising and to accept regulation by the Food and Drug Administration. 
Boeing looked likely to drop its "sole provider" provisions in its contracts with three American airlines, in order to placate the European Commission which has threatened to block the Seattle-based giant's $15 billion acquisition of McDonnell Douglas. 
Union Pacific Resources, tiring of the friendly approach, launched a hostile $6.4 billion bid for Pennzoil, a rival oil company, and filed lawsuits against Pennzoil's poison-pill tactics. 
The feuding accountants and consultants in Andersen Worldwide rejected for the second time their board's nominee for chief executive: George Shaheen, the boss of Andersen Consulting. 
Rhone-Poulenc plans to spend FFr25 billion ($43 billion) to take full control of its American drug firm, RhonePoulenc Rorer, in which it has a 68% stake. The French firm may now spin off its chemicals business in 1998. 
Christie's sale of the Princess of Wales's dresses in New York raised $3.2m-a record for a charity auction of clothes. In London a Van Gogh, "Harvest in Provence", fetched 8.8m ($14.4m) at Sotheby's, a record for a work on paper by the artist, and the highest price for a modern work in Europe since 1990. 
LVMH, still trying to prevent the L23.8 billion ($39 billion) merger of Guinness and Grand metropolitan, increased its stake in GrandMet to 6.3%, though the two British drinks groups reiterated their intention to merge. Bernard Arnault, the boss of the French luxury-goods group, which is the biggest shareholder in both drinks firms, seems set on calling an extraordinary general meeting of GrandMet shareholders. 
Nike apologised to Muslims and recalled from Islamic countries more than 38,ooo pairs of basketball shoes carrying a logo that resembles "Allah" in Arabic script. 
More light needed 
The British government told Eurotunnel bosses it might consider extending the company's concession beyond 2052 if it gets more freight traffic off the roads and on to rail. Eurotunnel's shareholder meeting to approve its rescue plan was adjourned until July loth. The company wants an extension before then to persuade 730,ooo unhappy French shareholders to back the plan, which hands most of the company equity to its bankers. 
Volkswagen and IG Metall, Germany's powerful engineering union, reached a deal which allows the car maker to cut its workforce through an early-retirement plan. 
British Airways seems set for a spate of trouble after the union representing most of the airline's cabin staff voted to strike over pay.

text:
Proposed reforms of Japan's hugely wasteful financial system are long overdue. But they will hurt much more than advertised, says Richard Cookson 
JAPAN is about to set out on the economic equivalent of a radical slimming cure. It needs to do something drastic to downsize its bloated, rigid and inert financial system and make it fit, flexible and fleet of foot. Last November the country's prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, announced that his country's financial system would soon have its own "Big Bang" to free it from heavy regulation and segmentation. The term was invented for Britain's reforms a decade earlier, when the London Stock Exchange was thrown open to all comers and commissions deregulated; but Japan's Big Bang is much more ambitious. In particular, it is intended to shrink the banking system and its ability to lend recklessly. This should increase competition, and thus returns for savers. 
In the recent past, Japan's financial system has proved better at destroying wealth than at creating it. Whereas other stockmarkets have soared, the Nikkei zzs average is still trading at half its peak, seven-and-a-half years after Japan's stockmarket bubble burst. At the same time land values have plummeted. These two factors together, says Jesper Koll, an economist at J.P. Morgan, have destroyed a decade's wealth-creation (see chart 1, next page). 
Then there is the rockiness of the banks. Ignore the finance ministry's assurances that they have nearly solved their bad-debt problems: many of Japan's banks are still chock-a-block with bad loans. By the end of the financial year this March, banks had written off, written down or reserved against some 254 trillion of bad loans, with about 15 trillion still to go, according to Betsy Daniels, an analyst at Morgan Stanley-and at a time when interest rates are at a record low. As and when interest rates go up, so will the banks' bad debts. 
None of the top zo banks has actually gone bust, and none, claims the government, will be allowed to. But in a financially more sophisticated country, at least two, Hokkaido Takushoku and Nippon Credit Bank, would have been shut down; and all 2o are probably still in worse shape than they own up to. This year they will be able to make reserves against "self-assessments", filed with the finance ministry, that do not have to tally with what they say in public. Banking rumour has it that at least one city bank's self-assessment of its bad loans is double the figure it officially admits to. 
Unloved yen 
Next, there are concerns about the yen's status as an international currency. The introduction due in 1999 of the euro, Europe's single currency, will further reduce the already modest number of international transactions denominated in yen. Although Japan is the world's biggest creditor nation, the yen has never been a truly international currency: the country's capital markets are so undeveloped that nobody really wants to hold yen. This matters because it leaves Japanese companies particularly exposed to foreign-exchange risks. The government, too, suffers from the yen's lack of international stature. Its gross debt-to-;DP ratio has been rising alarmingly, and is likely to reach too% this year. The extra liquidity would make it easier for the government to finance its deficit. 
There are worries, too, that Tokyo as a financial centre is lagging behind London and New York. Lots of Japanese financial products are traded elsewhere. For example, fully one-third of the business in Nikkei 225 stock futures is conducted on the Singapore Monetary Exchange (Simex); and 15% of the trading in Japanese shares is booked in London. Nor does Tokyo attract foreign business in the way that New York and London do. Many foreign companies have delisted their shares from the Tokyo Stock Exchange.A telling set of statistics from the Nomura Research Institute puts the value of foreign-equity trades in 1995 at $1.2 trillion in London, $261 billion in New York, and $1 billion in Tokyo. This survey will argue that the common factor behind all these failings, and the most compelling reason for deregulation, is a fundamental flaw in Japan's financial system: its crass inefficiency at allocating money, any economy's lifeblood. Despite some recent tinkering, the system remains hugely biased against savers and in favour of borrowers and intermediaries such as banks and securities firms. 
Savers have little choice over where to invest their money; for reasons that will be explained later, most of them put it on deposit at the bank or, increasingly, the post office. Deposit-takers, on the other hand, until recently had little reason to worry about the relative riskiness of their borrowers. Rapid growth eventually lifted all boats off the rocks. Besides, lending was backed by collateral, and if that was not enough, a firm's main bank would bail it out. Ultimately the banks were guaranteed by the government. And the keiretsu system of cross-shareholdings among "families" of firms with common interests made it hard for outside shareholders to apply pressure on banks to lend more profitably. 
This system worked reasonably well while the economy was immature and money was scarce; but now that the economy has grown older and money more plentiful, the system has become counterproductive. It squanders savers' money on a breathtaking scale. Returns on household financial assets are puny, as chart 2 shows. Banks, with their huge captive deposit base, are lending to anyone with collateral who wants to borrow, good risk or bad. 
Because of the way the system has developed, money has, in one sense, no value. Rare is the Japanese company which pauses to think that the cost of money has anything to do with the risks the firm is exposed to. Companies with a credit rating little better than junk can borrow money at a rate only slightly higher than that paid by rock-solid firms. As a result, few Japanese companies bother to work out "hurdle rates" (the risk-adjusted minimum rate of return they need to earn on an investment). Some admit that if they did, they would probably never make any investments. 
None of this does savers and private investors any good at all. Alex Kinmont, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, has had a stab at working out just how unprofitable Japanese companies are. He reckons that the big companies listed on the blue-chip section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange are earning only about half the 8% return that equity investors should expect on reasonable assumptions about risk premiums and bond yields. Of the ao biggest banks, only five would make that return. 
The Japanese financial system's most urgent need is for greater flexibility. As things stand, certain products and services can be offered only by specific institutions. Banks cannot underwrite or deal in shares, but only they can offer foreign-exchange services; securities firms cannot offer banking services, but only they can directly sell investment trusts, the Japanese version of mutual funds. Neither is allowed to sell or underwrite insurance. Commissions on all but the largest equity trades are still fixed. 
Nurse knows best 
The main obstacle in the way of more flexibility has been the Japanese finance ministry. The trouble with the ministry is that it thinks it knows best; certainly better than markets, which it deems dangerous. New products, for example, must be approved by the ministry to protect investors from their own ignorance (the word "confusion" is often bandied around).Yet with a few notable exceptions, the ministry's employees, shunted from section to section, are themselves ignorant about modern finance. Though many have been to Tokyo University, Japan's best, most graduated in law. They take their time to think about new-fangled ideas, so the wait to launch a new financial product can be interminable. Only this July will the Tokyo Stock Exchange and the Osaka Securities Exchange at long last be allowed to list options on individual stocks. 
The ministry's strong control on new products also makes for some odd inconsistencies. Over-thecounter (OTC) equity derivatives such as swaps and options are still considered gambling instruments, so they remain banned in Japan, even though they are permitted in every other big developed country. But oTc bond options do not, apparently, fall foul of Japan's gambling laws, and are therefore allowed. Moreover, the ministry's rules governing financial firms are notoriously opaque, and subject to bureaucratic whim; often they seem calculated not so much to regulate firms but to protect them. 
Japan's Big Bang is supposed to change all this. Proposed reforms of Japan 's hugely wasteful financial system are long overdue . But they will hurt much more than advertised , says Richard Cookson 
 JAPAN is about to set out on the economic equivalent of a radical slimming cure . It needs to do something drastic to downsize its bloated , rigid and inert financial system and make it fit , flexible and fleet of foot . Last November Ryutaro Hashimoto's announced that Ryutaro Hashimoto's country 's financial system would soon have its own " Big Bang " to free it from heavy regulation and segmentation . The term was invented for Britain 's reforms a decade earlier , when the London Stock Exchange was thrown open to all comers and commissions deregulated ; but Japan 's Big Bang is much more ambitious . In particular , it is intended to shrink the banking system and its ability to lend recklessly . This should increase competition , and thus returns for savers . 
 In the recent past , Japan 's financial system has proved better at destroying wealth than at creating it . Whereas other stockmarkets have soared , the Nikkei zzs average is still trading at half its peak , seven - and - a - half years after Japan 's stockmarket bubble burst . At the same time land values have plummeted . These two factors together , says Jesper Koll , an economist at J.P. Morgan , have destroyed a decade 's wealth - creation ( see chart 1 , next page ) . 
 Then there is the rockiness of the banks . Ignore the finance ministry 's assurances that they have nearly solved their bad - debt problems : many of Japan 's banks are still chock - a - block with bad loans . By the end of the financial year this March , banks had written off , written down or reserved against some 254 trillion of bad loans , with about 15 trillion still to go , according to Betsy Daniels , an analyst at Morgan Stanley - and at a time when interest rates are at a record low . As and when interest rates go up , so will the banks ' bad debts . 
 None of the top zo banks has actually gone bust , and none , claims the government , will be allowed to . But in a financially more sophisticated country , at least two , Hokkaido Takushoku and Nippon Credit Bank , would have been shut down ; and all 2o are probably still in worse shape than they own up to . This year they will be able to make reserves against " self - assessments " , filed with the finance ministry , that do not have to tally with what they say in public . Banking rumour has it that at least one city bank 's self - assessment of its bad loans is double the figure it officially admits to . 
 Unloved yen 
 Next , there are concerns about the yen 's status as an international currency . The introduction due in 1999 of the euro , Europe 's single currency , will further reduce the already modest number of international transactions denominated in yen . Although Japan is the world 's biggest creditor nation , the yen has never been a truly international currency : the country 's capital markets are so undeveloped that nobody really wants to hold yen . This matters because it leaves Japanese companies particularly exposed to foreign - exchange risks . The government , too , suffers from the yen 's lack of international stature . Its gross debt - to-;DP ratio has been rising alarmingly , and is likely to reach too% this year . The extra liquidity would make it easier for the government to finance its deficit . 
 There are worries , too , that Tokyo as a financial centre is lagging behind London and New York . Lots of Japanese financial products are traded elsewhere . For example , fully one - third of the business in Nikkei 225 stock futures is conducted on the Singapore Monetary Exchange ( Simex ) ; and 15 % of the trading in Japanese shares is booked in London . Nor does Tokyo attract foreign business in the way that New York and London do . Many foreign companies have delisted their shares from the Tokyo Stock Exchange . A telling set of statistics from the Nomura Research Institute puts the value of foreign - equity trades in 1995 at $ 1.2 trillion in London , $ 261 billion in New York , and $ 1 billion in Tokyo . This survey will argue that the common factor behind all these failings , and the most compelling reason for deregulation , is a fundamental flaw in Japan 's financial system : its crass inefficiency at allocating money , any economy 's lifeblood . Despite some recent tinkering , the system remains hugely biased against savers and in favour of borrowers and intermediaries such as banks and securities firms . 
 Savers have little choice over where to invest their money ; for reasons that will be explained later , most of them put it on deposit at the bank or , increasingly , the post office . Deposit - takers , on the other hand , until recently had little reason to worry about the relative riskiness of their borrowers . Rapid growth eventually lifted all boats off the rocks . Besides , lending was backed by collateral , and if that was not enough , a firm 's main bank would bail it out . Ultimately the banks were guaranteed by the government . And the keiretsu system of cross - shareholdings among " families " of firms with common interests made it hard for outside shareholders to apply pressure on banks to lend more profitably . 
 This system worked reasonably well while the economy was immature and money was scarce ; but now that the economy has grown older and money more plentiful , the system has become counterproductive . It squanders savers ' money on a breathtaking scale . Returns on household financial assets are puny , as chart 2 shows . Banks , with their huge captive deposit base , are lending to anyone with collateral who wants to borrow , good risk or bad .

text:
IN LATE May, the severed head of an 11year-old boy, Jun Hase, who had been missing for three days, was found outside the gates of a school in Kobe. The rest of his body was discovered the same afternoon. A note in the boy's mouth predicted more murders; in a letter to a local newspaper the murderer threatened to kill three people a week. On June 28th, police arrested a boy of 14 who, they say, confessed not just to killing Jun Hase, but also to attacking two schoolgirls in March, one of whom died. 
The murder and the age of the suspect have provoked a bout of soul-searching in Japan. "The killing comes amid an increase in the frequency and savagery of crimes committed by young people," thundered the Yomiuri, a right-leaning newspaper. "The investigation of the Kobe killing . . . must offer new insights into how our faulty society can be repaired." Some observers blame Japan's high-pressure education system. Even Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister, fretted that this might be the cause. 
Yet murder is still astonishingly rare in Japan. In 1995, the latest year for which figures are available, there were nine murders per 100,000 population in America, 4.7 in Germany, 2.7 in Britainand just one in Japan. Murders by youngsters are actually declining, as is juvenile crime in general. In 1985, police arrested over 300,ooo youngsters; ten years later the figure was under 200,000. 
For that thank, in part,Japan's police. There were arrests in 96% of the murder cases investigated in 1995. This success rate has much to do with the respect and trust that the police have from local communities, where the ubiquitous police boxes, known as koban, provide a range of services from helping the lost to lending the bus fare home. People tell the police what they know. In the Kobe murder, the police received over 3,000 pieces of information from the public. Much was misleading, but what apparently led the police to their suspect were reports that he cut off the heads of cats and carried their tongues around in his pocket. Sick, certainly; but indicative of wider problems in Japan, probably not.

text:
WITH 9.4m eligible voters, Tokyo is by virtue of its sheer size and diversity an ideal political weathervane. Despite a record low turnout (40.8%), caused as much by the scorching heat as by the shortage of good scandals and controversies, the election for the city's assembly on July 6th prompts three political predictions. 
The first is that the resurgent Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) will continue to build on the remarkable recovery it made at last October's general election. Already poised to gain an overall majority in the powerful lower house of the Diet (parliament), the LDP looks certain to strengthen its position still further in the upper-house election a year hence. By then, the ruling party could be back with the majority in both houses that it has enjoyed throughout most of its history. 
The second forecast is that political parties that have failed to differentiate themselves from the Liberal Democrats-either because they joined the LDP-led coalition or because they have split from the LDr but remained virtually indistinguishable-will become increasingly irrelevant. It is now only a matter of time, months probably, before the imploding Social Democratic Party vanishes and Ichiro Ozawa's fractious New Frontier Party (NFP) falls apart altogether. 
The third prophesy is that, lacking any discernible opposition, Japanese voters who wish to make a protest will in future either abstain or throw their weight behind the Communist Party. Watch for the Communists to start winning more mayoralties and governorships in the months aheadand to increase their strength in the upper house next year. 
The clear winners in the Tokyo municipal election were the LDP, which increased its presence in the 127-seat assembly from 38 to 54; the Communists, who doubled their number of seats from 13 to 26; and the Buddhist-affiliated Komei, which saw all 24 of its candidates elected. The Social Democrats, by contrast, saw their seats fall from four to one. None of the NFa'S ii candidates was elected. 
The Democratic Party of Japanformed less than a year ago-fizzled badly, too. Aiming for a minimum of 25 seats, the Democrats wound up with only 12. Pulled in opposite directions by its two joint leaders, the party's days are numbered. 
At present, however, it is Mr Ozawa who has the biggest problems. At the national level, the Komei threw its lot in with his followers when the NFP was formed in 1994. The two groups have functioned as a single party in the lower house of the Diet ever since. As the political wing of the Soka Gakkai, a lay Buddhist organisation with more than 8m supporters in Japan, the Komei has enormous wealth and a reputation for getting out the vote. It was all set to merge the rest of its political apparatus with the NFP's later this summer. But after getting ten times as many votes as the NFP in the Tokyo election, the Komei's leaders are now having second thoughts. 
Meanwhile, Mr Ozawa is facing further desertions from his party. This past week it was the turn of Kazuo Aichi, a former defence minister, to leave the NFP, fed up with Mr Ozawa's bullying tactics and highhanded manner. Three more NFP Diet members are expected to leave before the end of July, bringing the total number of NFP defections to 53-almost a third of the party's parliamentary membership. Most defectors have headed back to the LDP. 
Mr Ozawa would like to do the same, and take the rest of his former LDP colleagues with him. He has been having long discussions with the barons on the more conservative wing of the LDP. But the Liberal Democrats' success in last weekend's election was yet another triumph for Mr Ozawa's sworn enemy, Koichi Kato, the secretary-general of the LDP, who also engineered the party's comeback last October. Mr Kato expects to be made prime minister after Ryutaro Hashimoto completes the further two-year term that the party will approve this coming September. He is likely to ensure that Mr Ozawa's chances of being welcomed back into the fold are small.

text:
IN OCTOBER 1995, tens of thousands of Okinawans turned out to demonstrate against the American military presence on their island. That demonstration, combined with the determination of Masahide Ota, Okinawa's governor, to see all American bases closed by 2015, convinced many outsiders that the American bases on Okinawa faced overwhelming local opposition. Not so. As tempers have cooled in Japan's southernmost outpost, so more and more locals have become convinced that the bases are still important to the island's economic future. Local newspaper polls have recently found that only 14-23% of residents actually want to see them closed. 
Instead of focusing on the outright closure of the bases, many Okinawans seem to have adopted a more subtle strategy. This involves continuing to make life difficult for America's military bases on their doorstep, so as to extract a higher price for their continued presence. At the same time, officials in both Okinawa and Tokyo are working hard on new schemes that are designed to diversify the island's economy. 
The problem is that, while America's military presence on Okinawa nowadays contributes only 7% to the prefecture's economy (down from 41% at the time Japan took back Okinawa in 1972), it counts for vastly more in the towns and villages surrounding the bases-especially in the poorer northern half of the island. Some communities in rural Okinawa have even started hinting that they would not mind having bases that are being relocated from elsewhere moved to their neighbourhood. 
At 6%, unemployment on Okinawa is nearly twice the national average. After the prefectural government, America is one of Okinawa's biggest employers, providing good livelihoods for some 8,ooo local inhabitants. The bases are also a major source of income for 28,ooo landowners. While a small but vocal group of anti-war protesters, who have acquired tiny plots of one tsubo (3.3 square metres) or less, have been demanding that America vacate the land they own, that is the last thing that most local landlords want. Nearly half of them are retired, relying on the rent from the bases as their only source of income. If handed their land back, few could expect to receive anything like the average Y11m ($95,000) per hectare they get annually from leasing their plots to the bases. Nor could they get the annual 5% increase in income that is guaranteed by the arrangement. 
Landowners aside, the biggest fear for Okinawans generally is that, were the bases to go, so would the generous handouts that the government in Tokyo doles out as compensation for playing host to three out of four American bases in all of Japan. With little local manufacturing, a backward farming sector that still relies heavily on sugar cane and a tourist industry hobbled by sky-high air fares from the mainland and restricted flights elsewhere, the prefecture relies on subsidies from Tokyo for twothirds of its income-some Y430 billion a year. To that has to be added Y4.7 trillionworth of development aid that the central government has provided over the 25 years since reversion. 
How to wean Okinawa's 1.3m residents-the most heavily subsidised people in Japan-off handouts? Not easy given the island's singular disinterest in entrepreneurial activity. But the prefectural government has not given up hope. Its latest wheeze, "Cosmopolitan City Okinawa", aims to make the island self-sufficient, while taking advantage of its cultural heritage and natural beauty. 
Most of this is pie in the sky. But a few things make eminent sense. One plan involves lobbying the central government to deregulate airfares so that the local tourist industry can take off. (ust see what Hawaii has done since American air fares were deregulated.) Another proposal is to provide tax breaks for manufacturers who import components and then re-export the finished goods. Given such breaks, Taiwanese entrepreneurs say they would invest heavily in Okinawa, just so they could export "Made in Japan" products to the rest of the world. 
Back in Tokyo, Mr Hashimoto's party and its coalition partners have roughed out an eight-point plan for Okinawa. The key element is to turn the prefecture into a freetrade zone under a "one country, two systems" formula that would offer Okinawa a more flexible tax and regulatory regime than mainland Japan. So far, however, the prime minister and his colleagues have failed to sway the finance ministry, which frowns on such panderings to the provinces. As Okinawans see it, Mr Hashimoto had better start banging some bureaucratic heads together and bring something more than the Y5 billion offered so far. No one forgets that the first, and last, time the present emperor visited Okinawa, someone lobbed a Molotov cocktail at him-an act unimaginable elsewhere in Japan. Given their mounting frustrations, the normally easy-going natives of Okinawa could turn a good deal nastier than anyone thinks.

As Okinawans see it , Mr Hashimoto had better start banging some bureaucratic heads together and bring something more than the Y5 billion offered so far . No one forgets that the first , and last , time the present emperor visited Okinawa , someone lobbed a Molotov cocktail at him - an act unimaginable elsewhere in Japan . Given their mounting frustrations , the normally easy - going natives of Okinawa could turn a good deal nastier than anyone thinks .

text:
SOMEONE bright in Japanese diplomatic circles has been rewriting the manual for dealing with Russia. The u-turn made by the prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, in a policy speech given to businessmen in Tokyo recently, has at last raised the prospect of a substantial improvement in relations. 
Like a cracked record, Japan has in recent years infuriated its friends by mindlessly repeating that there can be no question of economic aid for Russia until progress is made on the return of the Northern Territories-the four islands off the northern tip of Japan lost to the Soviet Union at the end of the second world war. Though this "indivisibility" between economic and political relations is presented as the cornerstone of Japanese diplomacy towards Russia, many inside as well as outside Japan have begun to view it more as a stumbling-block. 
The Soviet Union almost agreed to return at least two of the four disputed islands in 1973, with hints that the other two islands could follow. But after bellicose demands from Kakuei Tanaka, Japan's prime minister at the time, for the return of all four islands-otherwise known as the southern Kuriles-an angry Leonid Brezhnev put the offer back into cold storage. All subsequent attempts to conclude a peace treaty, putting an official end to hostilities between the two countries, have been thwarted by the territorial dispute. 
Boris Yeltsin broke some of the ice during his visit to Japan in 1993. He recognised the validity of a 1956 joint declaration that promised to return two of the islands to Japan. The Tokyo Declaration that emerged after the 1993 summit agreed to seek a solution to the territorial dispute "on the basis of historical and legal facts", though the Russians then backed off sharply on a promise of talks because of nationalist pressure at home. Mr Hashimoto has now decided to put the fruitless territorial bickering aside for the moment, and instead stress the need for Japan to strengthen its economic relations with Russia first. 
Over the past two years, the two countries have shown that they can get along if they try. Russian gunboats had been firing shots across the bows of Japanese trawlers which ventured too close to the disputed islands. But Japanese officials and their Russian counterparts put their heads together, without recriminations, and defined safe fishing zones and ways of arbitrating disputes that did not compromise either side's claim to the islands. Mr Hashimoto wants to build on the "positive attitude" fostered by the fishing accord. 
Within days of Mr Hashimoto's initiative came concrete proof that a lot of preparation had been done beforehand. Approval was announced for a joint $10 billion project to develop a natural-gas field in Irkutsk in Russia and build a pipe line to Japan via Mongolia, China and South Korea. The foreign ministry in Tokyo hinted that talks between the four countries involved may start as early as this month. Mr Hashimoto will then join President Yeltsin at an unofficial summit in the Russian Far East in early November to discuss this and other projects. 
Mr Hashimoto has promised to take a long-term view ofthe relationship. But how long-term? He probably wants to see serious signs of progress on the return of the islands by no later than the summer of 1999. That is when his second two-year term as prime minister will be drawing to a close. In recent times, no Japanese prime minister-other than Yasuhiro Nakasone, who was prime minister from 1982 to 1987-has hung on to the job for more than two terms. As he enters his second term this September, Mr Hashimoto may see co-operation with Russia as a way to secure a favourable write-up in the history books.

text:
THE prime minister of Japan, Ryutaro Hashimoto, can expect to be elected unopposed as president of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) on September 8th. As such, he can look forward to being prime minister for another two years after his current term as party leader expires on September 30th. But that is the extent of certainty in Japanese politics at the moment. A debilitating power struggle has broken out over the future direction of the LDP. It is even spilling into the ranks of the opposition, threatening to create new groupings among the minor parties. 
In simple terms, it is a struggle between the young-or the relatively young, this being politicsand the old. The leading "youngster" is Koichi Kato, aged 58, the party's secretary-general. He is widely credited with engineering the LDP's remarkable comeback in last September's general election and its humbling of the opposition in the Tokyo municipal election in July. 
The government has managed to get its legislative programme through the Diet (parliament) thanks largely to Mr Kato's success in keeping two minor parties within the coalition, the small Social Democratic Party and the even smaller New Party Sakigake, and by wooing disaffected members from the opposition New Frontier Party. He has built the Liberal Democrats' strength in the all-important 500seat lower house of the Diet from 231 after September's election to 25o today. 
The most wobbly member of the coalition is the Social Democratic Party. It is unhappy about the coming review of the defence guidelines that seeks to give Japan an enlarged role under its security treaty with America. The Social Democrats want to see the security pact torn up rather than beefed up. With an upper-house election due in July next year, they fear losses worse than those they have already suffered if they remain in the government. Many of their leftwing supporters have given up and thrown their weight behind the resurgent Communist Party. Mr Kato will be hard pressed to keep the coalition together when the defence debate hots up this autumn. 
That is where the oldies in the LDP see an opening. These right-wingers want to bring back their old conservative pals who bolted from the LDP with Ichiro Ozawa in 1992.A grand alliance between the LDP and Mr Ozawa's dwindling New Frontier Party would provide more than enough support to bulldoze any legislation through the Diet that was needed for Japan to play a greater military role around the region. A hawkish former prime minister, Yasuhiro Nakasone (aged So), has been influential in trying to bring about such a deal. 
Mr Ozawa was once a power in Japanese politics. With desertions mounting within his ranks, his hope of regaining power is to get himself and his more loyal troops back within the LDP as soon as possible. If he does not do something before his party's annual meeting in December, his group is likely to split. 
Before any grand alliance among conservatives can take place, Mr Ozawa and some of the LDP's more geriatric right-wingers must first dislodge Mr Kato from his powerful position. As a first step, Seiroku Kajiyama, the LDP's chief cabinet secretary, a highly influential post, has threatened to resign, saying that, having done the job for 8 months, it is time for him to step down. His aim is to embarrass Mr Kato into having to resign as well. Mr Kajiyama has also been stirring up trouble by announcing that the new defence guidelines would allow Japan to support any American actions in the Taiwan Strait. That was intended as a further embarrassment for Mr Kato, who had just returned from explaining to the Chinese that the defence guidelines were for dealing with emergencies solely on the Korean peninsula. Mr Hashimoto himself is due to go to Beijing next week, and will presumably have to do some explaining. 
In normal circumstances, Mr Hashimoto would be expected to shuffle the members of the LDP's executive office as well as the cabinet after his reappointment A lot of cabinet posts will doubtless change hands in September. But getting rid of Mr Kato would upset the party's mainstream supporters. To avoid being outmanoeuvred, Mr Kato has asked the prime minister "to use his own judgment" when he shuffles the party's top posts. That is a Japanese ploy for cooling a bit of strife while simultaneously strengthening one's own position-by showing a willingness to accept the boss's decision no matter how unpalatable. 
The betting is that Mr Kato will keep his job-which will put him on the fast track to becoming prime minister after Mr Hashimoto. The betting also is that Mr Kajiyama will be arm-twisted to stay on as well. Mr Hashimoto wants to go down in history as the leader whose reforms turned Japan, scratching and screaming, into a more liberal, deregulated country. He is going to need both men hard at work to get even half his programme through.

text:
Diana, Princess of Wales, died in a car crash in Paris along with her companion, Dodi Al Fayed, and the car's driver, who had drunk three times the legal amount of alcohol. Six photographers and a motorcycle courier accused of chasing the car are under investigation for manslaughter. In London, hundreds of thousands of people came to lay flowers outside Buckingham Palace and Kensington Palace, and to sign books of condolence. 
NATO peacekeeping troops returned control of a television transmitter in Bosnia's Serb Republic to hardliners competing with the president, Biljana Plavsic, for control of the Bosnian Serb statelet. The hardliners, led by Radovan Karadzic, had threatened to disrupt Bosnian local elections on September 13th-14th. Boris Yeltsin, Russia's president, said he would definitely retire at the end of his current term of office, in 2000. 
Italy's foreign minister, Lamberto Dini, suggested delaying Europe's single currency if too many countries fail to meet the criteria, but the European Commission dismissed the idea. Germany appeared likelier to meet the targets after officials said that adopting Eu accounting standards would take a sliver off the government deficit. 
The state rolls on: taxes and social-security contributions consumed a record 42.4% of the European Union's GDP last year, said the Eu's statistical agency, Eurostat Three Nordic countries imposed the heaviest burdens on their economies, with Sweden taking 55.2%. Ireland, Spain and Britain taxed less than 36%. 
Arkady Gukasyan was elected president of Nagomo-Karabakh, the disputed territory held by Armenia against the wishes of Azerbaijan. He rejects international proposals for returning the area to Azerbaijan's sovereignty while giving its ethnic Armenian population autonomy. 
Bombs exploded in BenYehuda, the main pedestrian shopping street in central Jerusalem. Early reports said that six people were killed, including the suicide-bombers, and more than 100 were wounded. 
An Egyptian court sentenced an Israeli Druze to 15 years in prison after convicting him of spying for Israel. 
Abassi Madani, leader of Algeria's banned Islamic party who was recently freed from six years' imprisonment, was put under house arrest for calling, in a letter to the UN, for an end to bloodshed and the opening of dialogue. 
Plans for a UN rapid-deployment force took a step forward when Kofi Annan, the secretary-general, officially inaugurated the brigade staff. Seven countries have so far committed troops to the force, which is expected to be operational by 1999. 
The loo or so countries that have committed themselves to a total ban on anti-personnel landmines began a three-week meeting in Oslo to complete the text of a treaty to be signed in Ottawa in December. 
Despite promises that he would tackle corruption in Kenya, President Daniel arap Moi failed to persuade the IMF to resume lending. But the Kenyan shilling, which fell by nearly 20% when the IMF suspended a $z20m loan last month, steadied. 
The Comoros government said it had invaded the island of Anjouan, which last month set up its own administration. It was seeking independence-or a return to French rule. 
Trading Clinton 
Congress returned to Washington, with President Clinton promising that his main priority would be to obtain "fast-track" authority for trade deals, including the admission of Chile to NAFTA. Left-wing Democrats reiterated their demands that Congress should keep its authority to amend such deals. 
The governor of Arizona, Fyfe Symington, was convicted of fraud and resigned. 
Joseph Kennedy, the son of Robert Kennedy, gave up his campaign to be governor of Massachusetts. 
Inter-party arguments almost prevented the first meeting of Mexico's newly elected Congress, where the mighty PRI no longer-after 68 years-has an overall majority. In the end it did meet, to hear President Ernesto Zedillo both welcome the jubilant parties of opposition and warn them not to put Mexico's economic rehabilitation at risk. 
In Colombia's guerrilla-ridden province of Antioquia, the governor appointed army and police officers to replace four mayors kidnapped to sabotage next month's elections. Many Colombians had more commonplace worries: the continuing recession, which led to a nationwide day of strikes and protests. 
On a visit to Beijing, the Japanese prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, sought to allay Chinese fears about a strengthened security pact with the United States. 
In the latest of a number of signs of social unrest in China, about soo retired civil servants demonstrated in Dujiangyan, in Sichuan province. They demanded higher pensions. 
For the first time, President Fidel Ramos of the Philippines did not rule out running for a second term next year, if the constitution were amended to allow this. The Roman Catholic church, which is strong in the Philippines, said it was opposed to a constitutional change.

text:
HALF a century is clearly far too short a time for the Chinese to forget all the misery and degradation they suffered at the hands of the Japanese from 1931 to 1945. While others quietly commemorate August 15th as the anniversary of the end of the second world war, the Chinese celebrate it for their "victory over Japan". It is a day to remember the Nanjing Massacre of 1937 and other atrocities committed by the imperial army during its occupation of China, when some 13m Chinese are said to have been killed. Not surprisingly, the image of Japan as the enemy remains etched indelibly in the Chinese collective consciousness. 
And it will continue to do so while Japanese politicians persist in claiming that the atrocities never happened, or make annual pilgrimages to Yasukuni shrine to pray for the souls of Japan's war dead and war criminals alike, or deliberately say provocative things just to stir up trouble. Japan's determination to glide over past crimes also makes it harder for Japan to play the responsible security role in Asia that its government wishes. Overshadowing the fourday visit by Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Japanese prime minister, to China starting on September 4th-officially to commemorate the 25th anniversary of normalisation of diplomatic ties-is the "Kajiyama statement". This has allowed the Chinese to claim that Japan is up to its old militaristic tricks again. 
As chief cabinet secretary, Seiroku Kajiyama knew perfectly well what he was doing. By announcing that the current revision of Japan's defence guidelines would allow it to send ships to support American military operations in the Taiwan Strait, Mr Kajiyama was out to embarrass Koichi Kato, a political rival within the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and the number-two man in the government. Mr Kato, a Mandarin-speaker and former diplomat, had just returned from explaining to officials in Beijing that the guidelines were being beefed up in large part to allow Japan to provide some logistical support should American troops have to deal with an emergency on the Korean peninsula. Japanese officials are reluctant to draw a clear geographical line separating areas where they will help America out and areas where they won't, for fear of causing new instabilities or tying their own hands too closely in a future crisis that affects Japan's interests in the region. 
To Mr Hashimoto's dismay, China reacted predictably. On a recent tour through Asia, the Chinese prime minister, Li Peng, described attempts by Japan to expand the scope of its security pact with America to cover the area around Taiwan as "utterly unacceptable". Were they to succeed, thundered Mr Li, Japan could expect relations with China to suffer irreparably. 
Of course, Mr Li's words were uttered more for consumption at home than for sending shudders through diplomatic saIons in Tokyo. With China's National People's Congress planned to start on September 12th, a bit of ritual Japanbashing was to be expected. Even so, Mr Hashimoto could be sure of a tough time this week explaining that Japan's revised defence policy is in no way intended to "contain" China. He was due to spend the first evening making this clear to Mr Li and to have a similar session with President Jiang Zemin on Friday. 
The Japanese side have decided that the best approach is to be frank. Mr Hashimoto outlined what he intends to say during a recent speech in Tokyo. The review of the America-Japan defence co-operation guidelines was to be described in detail. But, in exchange, China would be asked to be as open about its own military build-up. Mr Hashimoto intended stressing, once again, that Japan sees Taiwan as an integral part of Chinese territory, and endorses China's stated desire to see the Taiwan issue settled peacefully. 
Reassurances about Japan's joint security treaty with America aside, Mr Hashimoto's hosts want convincing on several other matters. They are keen to know what the government intends doing about the neo-nationalists within the LDP who not only insist on making regular visits to Yasukuni shrine, but also want to rewrite the history books again-purging them of any reference whatsoever to Japan's wartime atrocities. A Supreme Court ruling to let the Ministry of Education carry on censoring Japan's school textbooks has handed critics in Beijing yet another stick for prodding Mr Hashimoto (see box on next page). 
With preparations in hand to turn the forthcoming party congress into a curtainraiser for the new Jiang-Li era, nothing would give the Chinese leaders greater satisfaction than a full and abject official apology from Mr Hashimoto for Japan's militaristic past. Two recent Japanese prime ministers, Morihiro Hosokawa and Tomiichi Murayama, conveyed their remorse for the pain caused to the Chinese people and acknowledged that Japan had waged a war of aggression against China. And in an unprecedented statement during a royal visit to China in 1992, Emperor Akihito expressed his sorrow for Japan's wartime abuses. But none of these apologies has impressed the Chinese. 
Perhaps nothing ever will. "Even if Mr Hashimoto read an apology written for him by President Jiang himself, it would still likely be deemed 'insufficient' by the Chinese," says Ralph Cossa, of the Centre for Strategic and International Studies in Hawaii. Mr Hashimoto will probably limit himself to the kind of regret his predecessors offered-and then agree to get down to the real business of coughing up cash. 
Both sides know that China's professed fear of rising Japanese militarism is something of a predictable charade, designed to put the government in Tokyo on the defensive. It is part of the softening-up process that intensifies whenever China is seeking fresh yen loans from the Japanese government.Japan's current 58o billion ($4.8 billion) five-year loan programme for China has only a few more years to run. While in Beijing Mr Hashimoto will present his hosts with the latest Y200billion instalment. He will also announce plans for a fresh round of soft loans to help clean up China's filthy coal-burning power stations. 
The bill paid, and back in Tokyo, Mr Hashimoto will then be free to get on with the biggest task confronting his administration this year. That is to build a consensus at home so the revised defence guidelines for co-operating with American forces can be implemented without further ado. Mr Hashimoto has no trouble convincing the Chinese who, as firm believers in the "corkin-the-bottle" theory, much prefer to see Japan locked into a co-operative defence arrangement with America than left to go it militarily alone. A far bigger problem is similarly to convince the anti-defence-pact members of the governing coalition.

Mr Kato , a Mandarin - speaker and former diplomat , had just returned from explaining to officials in Beijing that the guidelines were being beefed up in large part to allow Japan to provide some logistical support should American troops have to deal with an emergency on the Korean peninsula . Japanese officials are reluctant to draw a clear geographical line separating areas where they will help America out and areas where they wo n't , for fear of causing new instabilities or tying their own hands too closely in a future crisis that affects Japan 's interests in the region . 
 To Ryutaro Hashimoto's dismay , China reacted predictably . On a recent tour through Asia , the Chinese prime minister , Li Peng , described attempts by Japan to expand the scope of its security pact with America to cover the area around Taiwan as " utterly unacceptable " . Were they to succeed , thundered Mr Li , Japan could expect relations with China to suffer irreparably . 
 Of course , Mr Li 's words were uttered more for consumption at home than for sending shudders through diplomatic saIons in Tokyo . With China 's National People 's Congress planned to start on September 12th , a bit of ritual Japanbashing was to be expected . Even so , Ryutaro Hashimoto could be sure of a tough time this week explaining that Japan 's revised defence policy is in no way intended to " contain " China . Ryutaro Hashimoto was due to spend the first evening making this clear to Mr Li and to have a similar session with President Jiang Zemin on Friday . 
 The Japanese side have decided that the best approach is to be frank . Ryutaro Hashimoto outlined what Ryutaro Hashimoto intends to say during a recent speech in Tokyo . The review of the America - Japan defence co - operation guidelines was to be described in detail . But , in exchange , China would be asked to be as open about its own military build - up . Ryutaro Hashimoto intended stressing , once again , that Japan sees Taiwan as an integral part of Chinese territory , and endorses China 's stated desire to see the Taiwan issue settled peacefully . 
 Reassurances about Japan 's joint security treaty with America aside , Ryutaro Hashimoto's hosts want convincing on several other matters . They are keen to know what the government intends doing about the neo - nationalists within the LDP who not only insist on making regular visits to Yasukuni shrine , but also want to rewrite the history books again - purging them of any reference whatsoever to Japan 's wartime atrocities . A Supreme Court ruling to let the Ministry of Education carry on censoring Japan 's school textbooks has handed critics in Beijing yet another stick for prodding Ryutaro Hashimoto ( see box on next page ) . 
 With preparations in hand to turn the forthcoming party congress into a curtainraiser for the new Jiang - Li era , nothing would give the Chinese leaders greater satisfaction than a full and abject official apology from Ryutaro Hashimoto for Japan 's militaristic past . Two recent Japanese prime ministers , Morihiro Hosokawa and Tomiichi Murayama , conveyed their remorse for the pain caused to the Chinese people and acknowledged that Japan had waged a war of aggression against China . And in an unprecedented statement during a royal visit to China in 1992 , Emperor Akihito expressed his sorrow for Japan 's wartime abuses . But none of these apologies has impressed the Chinese . 
 Perhaps nothing ever will . " Even if Ryutaro Hashimoto read an apology written for Ryutaro Hashimoto by President Jiang himself , it would still likely be deemed ' insufficient ' by the Chinese , " says Ralph Cossa , of the Centre for Strategic and International Studies in Hawaii . Ryutaro Hashimoto will probably limit Ryutaro Hashimoto to the kind of regret Ryutaro Hashimoto's predecessors offered - and then agree to get down to the real business of coughing up cash .

It is part of the softening - up process that intensifies whenever China is seeking fresh yen loans from the Japanese government . Japan 's current 58o billion ( $ 4.8 billion ) five - year loan programme for China has only a few more years to run . While in Beijing Ryutaro Hashimoto will present Ryutaro Hashimoto's hosts with the latest Y200billion instalment . Ryutaro Hashimoto will also announce plans for a fresh round of soft loans to help clean up China 's filthy coal - burning power stations . 
 The bill paid , and back in Tokyo , Ryutaro Hashimoto will then be free to get on with the biggest task confronting Ryutaro Hashimoto's administration this year . That is to build a consensus at home so the revised defence guidelines for co - operating with American forces can be implemented without further ado . Ryutaro Hashimoto has no trouble convincing the Chinese who , as firm believers in the " corkin - the - bottle " theory , much prefer to see Japan locked into a co - operative defence arrangement with America than left to go it militarily alone . A far bigger problem is similarly to convince the anti - defence - pact members of the governing coalition .
