text:
CONTINUITY at all costs was the guiding principle as Japan's prime minister selected his new cabinet and top party aides on September lth. The costs may yet be high. Earlier this week, as Mr Hashimoto was being reappointed as president of the ruling Liberal Democrats (and hence prime minister), allegations were made that three key members of his new line-up had received illicit funds from Junichi Izui, an Osaka oil trader who is standing trial for alleged fraud, bribery and tax evasion. All three politicians have denied any wrong-doing. But that has not stopped the opposition gleefully demanding that Mr Izui testify under oath before the Diet (parliament) when it reconvenes later this month. 
To ensure that his precious reform package stays on course, Mr Hashimoto has been adamant about keeping a number of key ministers and officials in place. So far, the prime minister's plans for streamlining the troubled finance ministry, not to mention deregulating Japan's hide-bound financial markets, have depended critically on having a strong man like Hiroshi Mitsuzuka as finance minister. So it was no surprise that Mr Mitsuzuka, a powerful factional boss and wily politician, has kept his cabinet seat. 
The prime minister has also insisted that all three of his party's top executives stay. They are needed to keep a wary eye out for sneaky attempts by party rightwingers to destroy the LDP'S fragile coalition with two smaller reform-minded parties, in order to tie up with conservatives in the opposition's New Frontier Party instead. Koichi Kato has therefore retained his post as secretary-general. So have Taku Yamasaki, boss of the party's policy research council, and Yoshiro Mori, chairman of its executive council. The trouble is that Mr Yamasaki and Mr Mori were alleged to have received large gifts of cash from the Osaka oil trader. 
So was Keizo Obuchi, a former chief cabinet secretary and boss of the biggest factional grouping within the LDP. Mr Obuchi has been brought on board as foreign minister to oversee the delicate negotiations on defence co-operation with America. But as one of Mr Hashimoto's closest allies, Mr Obuchi's presence in the cabinet is expected to give the prime minister's reform programme a much-needed shove in the right direction. Now all Mr Hashimoto has to do is keep his fingers crossed that the opposition's plan to grill Mr Izui comes to naught.

text:
TOKYO 
WITH the opinion polls giving him high marks for his first term as prime minister and no rivals daring to challenge him, Ryutaro Hashimoto secured a second term as president of Japan's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) on September 8th. As head of the largest political party in the Diet (parliament), Mr Hashimoto now gets another two years as prime minister. That ritual out of the way, he has got down to the real work of cutting the deals on who is to be in his new cabinet-and, more importantly, who should hold the three top posts in the party executive (see box). 
The new line-up is going to be crucial to the prime minister's efforts to get his proposed legislation through the Diet. Mr Hashimoto wants to be remembered as the national leader whose vision and determination changed the social, financial and political course of the country; on a par with the dramatic reforms introduced by the Meiji leaders in 1868 and General Douglas MacArthur in 1947. 
The prime minister has six big reforms in view: of the administrative, fiscal, financial, welfare, economic and education systems. Each is formidable. In addition, he has to quell fighting within his own party, and keep together his rag-tag coalition with smaller parties that is necessary to shore up support in the upper house (where the LDP is 14 seats short of a majority). 
Overhauling the administrative system, in particular making the bureaucracy smaller and more responsive to public needs, is proving the most difficult nut to crack. Mr Hashimoto has been chairing the Administrative Reform Council himself to keep in line the panel of the good and the great. During the general election last year, he promised to halve the size of the government, reducing the number of ministries and agencies from zz to ten or so. 
In its preliminary report published on September 3rd, the council proposed squeezing the administrative machinery into 12 ministries and agencies, plus a more powerful cabinet office. This would absorb the old prime minister's office plus the cabinet secretariat and the Economic Planning Agency. The council also recommends hiving off the ministries' routine work to quasi-government organisations modelled on Britain's executive agencies. This leaner government, it is argued, would be better able to get on with the job of forming policy and drafting legislation. 
But where would all the unneeded bureaucrats go? Trade unions are insisting that civil servants transferred to the new quasi-government organisations be given the same pay, pensions and status as colleagues who remain behind. So the net result could well be no change in the overall size of the bureaucracy. Instead, there would simply be fewer, larger ministries with a plethora of administrative appendages. Meanwhile, opposition from bureaucrats themselves and their zoko gn (lobby groups of MPS) within the Diet is threatening to thwart the two most crucial aspects of Mr Hashimoto's administrative reforms-restructuring the finance ministry and privatising the key functions of the posts and telecommunications ministry. 
The council has stopped short of recommending that mail delivery be privatised. But it wants to see the post office's huge 0oo trillion ($830 billion) life insurance scheme (more than twice the size ofthe largest life insurance company) privatised by 2oo1, with the post office's even vaster savings bank (four times bigger than Japan's largest commercial bank) turned over to the private sector at some future date. 
This is not privatisation merely for the sake of it. There are good administrative reasons why the post office's funds should be kept well away from the government's grubby fingers. At present, the funds are recycled through the finance ministry's "offbudget budgef' known as FILP(fiscal investment and loan programme). Among other things, one of the finance ministry's leading uses of FILP funds is to maintain a welter of redundant public corporations, whose main purpose these days is to provide cushy jobs for civil servants in their later years. 
Unfortunately for Mr Hashimoto, he is unlikely to be granted an open season for agency shooting. Many of his party colleagues are heavily indebted to the grassroots organisation run by regional post-office chiefs, which can be relied upon to get out the vote come election time. Fearing they will lose the postal workers' support in next summer's upper-house election, a vociferous group within the LDP is determined to kill any attempt to break up the posts and telecommunications ministry. 
For reformers, however, an even bigger disappointment is the council's failure to strip the finance ministry of its financial policy-making prerogatives. The ministry managed to bamboozle the council into believing that it needed to retain its authority over financial as well as fiscal policy, despite the wishes of Mr Hashimoto and his party's coalition partners. It was because of conflict between the ministry's financial and fiscal responsibilities (which led to the asset-inflated bubble economy a decade ago and the subsequent banking mess) that administrative reform became popular in the first place. 
Piqued, Mr Hashimoto is now suggesting that the finance ministry be stripped of its tax-collecting powers instead. A merger between the ministry's tax agency and the prefectural governments' 140,ooo taxmen is being talked about. However, being such a patent non-starter, the proposal can only mean that the prime minister is losing patience. It does rather seem as though the cornerstone of Mr Hashimoto's precious reform package is slowly but surely turning into something as wobbly as jelly.

text:
TOKYO 
JAPAN'S prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, worries about confusion. 
After his re-election as president of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) earlier this month, Mr Hashimoto said his decision to make Koko Sato a member of his new cabinet had caused "a lot of confusion" among the public, and for that he apologised. Mr Hashimoto apologised for creating even more confusion when Mr Sato resigned on September 22nd after only la days in the job. 
The Japanese public, however, are less confused than amazed that Mr Sato was ever appointed in the first place. Mr Sato was convicted of taking bribes in a scandal involving Lockheed in the early 1970s, and given a two-year suspended prison sentence. To add to their amazement, Mr Sato, every inch a politician of the old school, was put in charge of administrative reform (short-hand for slimming down the bureaucracy). 
The kerfuffle has weakened both the prime minister and the party. The LDP'S two coalition allies objected to Mr Sato's appointment; newspaper editorials thundered their disapproval, and the cabinet's popularity ratings fell from 53% to 35%, according to a poll by the Asahi Shimbun newspaper. 
What now? Although Mr Sato has been replaced by Sadatoshi Ozato, an uncontroversial but uninspired choice, the aftershocks will rumble on. On September 25th, in a further blow to Mr Hashimoto, Ihei Ochi, the agriculture minister, resigned for reasons of ill health. Mr Sato was foisted on the prime minister by Yasuhiro Nakasone, the de facto leader of a faction within the LDP. That Mr Hashimoto was unable to refuse shows that the factions wield as much power as they ever did. 
As a result, Mr Hashimoto's image as a strong man has taken something of a battering. His clout within the LDP rested in part on his popular appeal-and the lack of an obvious alternative. Yet Mr Sato's appointment to such a sensitive job suggests both the prime minister and his party were prepared blithely to ignore public opinion. 
Perhaps no more. The opposition parties smell blood and, emboldened by Mr Sato's resignation, may well step up attacks on other ministers. Three of them, including the new foreign minister, Keizo Obuchi, are accused of taking bribes from an Osaka-based oil trader. They deny the charges. Mr Hashimoto may yet have to apologise for more confusion.

text:
South-East Asia's foundering economies need help. Their biggest investor has plenty of reasons to offer it 
THERE was an audience with the emperor. There was a big dinner. There were talks with Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Japanese prime minister. Hobnobbing with the great and good is always a treat, of course; but although this week's three-day visit by the Thai prime minister, Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, was presented as merely cementing relations between the two countries, there was much more to it than that. It is exaggerating only a bit to say that Japanese investment drove South-East Asia's economies to prosperity. The Japanese are thus acutely concerned about the rumbling crisis on their doorstep, while their Asian friends, Thailand in particular, are desperate that Japanese banks and manufacturers do not react to the region's present turmoil by investing and lending less. 
In principle, Japan should hardly be bothered about what happens to the four countries-Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia and Malaysia-whose currencies have recently been ravaged. Their combined output is but a tenth of Japan's and they take only 12% of Japanese exports. Even if they buy less, say most economists, Japan's GDP would slow by only o.3-.4% as a result. But for an economy that shrank by 2.9% in the second quarter, and may be lucky to grow 1% over the entire year, such a potential drag on growth is anything but insignificant. Out of pure self-interest, the Japanese are doing all they can to help South-East Asia overcome its crisis. 
Tokyo's concern can be gauged from the fact that the Export-Import (EXIM) Bank contributed $4 billion of the $17.2 billion bail-out for Thailand co-ordinated by the IMF at the beginning of August. This is the largest sum EXIM Bank has ever lent. The government has also encouraged private banks to roll over many of their loans to Thai companies that have fallen due (which, some say, may be 8o% of their Thai loan books). All of this, according to a Thai central banker, may not be enough to steady Thailand's precarious financial sector. That will require another $io billion or so. The Thais consider Japan the obvious place to find the extra cash. This may explain why top Thai officials found it worthwhile to meet with three big private Japanese banks-Sakura, Sumitomo and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi-as well as to drop in on EXIM Bank. 
Investors in Japanese shares are also concerned. Although Asia accounts for only about 4% of the overall earnings of Japanese companies, car makers and manufacturers of electrical machinery have a particularly big exposure in South-East Asia. Goldman Sachs, an American investment bank, reckons that these sectors account for more than a third of . this year's expected growth in Japanese corporate profits. If demand in these countries falls further, so, almost certainly, will such companies' earnings. 
It is not just Japan's manufacturers that are exposed. Japanese banks competed against each other to finance growth in Asia, especially in Thailand. Of that country's $70 billion of external private debts, $37.5 billion are to Japanese banks, according to the Bank for International Settlements. In Indonesia, which this week saw its currency plunge (see box on next page), around $22 billion of the officially reported $55 billion of foreign debt is owed to Japanese banks, and some analysts think that the country's true foreign indebtedness is much greater. 
These numbers need some context. Although they probably underestimate Japanese banks' true exposures, they are small compared with the banks' domestic lending. And perhaps a third of loans are to Japanese companies operating in the region. Still, the further their currencies fall, the greater the South-East Asian countries' foreign debt burdens become and the greater the risk of default. In Thailand alone, some $40 billion of private foreign-currency debts fall due in the next 12 months. And rumours circulate in Bangkok of a moratorium on debt payments. This would sting Japanese banks, still struggling to cope with their domestic bad loans. In all, such worries could give an already shaky Japanese stockmarket the vapours. 
Sending jobs abroad 
So it matters a lot to Japan what happens in South-East Asia. Equally, Japanese companies' reaction to the turmoil is crucial to the economic health of South-East Asia. Last year, Japanese companies invested about $5.7 billion in factories or property developments in Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines. This represents just over a third of all foreign direct investment in the region last year, and far more in Thailand (see charts on next pages One in seven manufacturing workers in Thailand is employed by a Japanese firm. Matsushita, a consumer-electronics firm, alone accounts for 4% of Malaysia's GDP; a fifth of Malaysia's new manufacturing jobs in the 199os are at Japanese companies. 
In the past, says Chihung Kwan, an economist at Nomura Research Institute, Japanese investment in Asia has been driven mainly by the level of the yen against the American dollar. Since many Asian countries more or less pegged their currencies to the dollar, Japanese companies could use them as a cheap proxy for an American manufacturing base. The yen's fall against the dollar since April 1995, however, has diminished the incentive to use South-East Asia as an export base. 
This year's sharp devaluations against both the dollar and (to a lesser extent) the yen, should make such investments look more attractive. But, argues Mr Kwan, it is not just the level of their currencies that matters, but how volatile they are against the dollar. "The myth of the dollar peg has been broken," he says. Given the instability that pegging has caused, these countries are unlikely to fix their currencies again soon, so volatility will be a continuing fact of life. 
Yet Japanese manufacturers have not been using South-East Asia only, or even mainly, as a cheap base for exports to elsewhere in the world. Many have invested in the region because economies there have been growing fast and trade barriers between them are coming down. More than 70% of the products that Japanese companies produce in Asia are now sold within the region. So Japanese manufacturing companies are very exposed to any slowing of local demand. This was, for some products, happening anyway. Car sales in Thailand between January and June fell 14.5% at an annual rate, and car makers say they expect worse to come. Consumer electronics will presumably go the same way. 
Demand would fall further were there a credit crunch. This is already under way in Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines. And that is where Japan's banks again come into the picture. Unless they are prepared to lend, investment, and with it growth, will slump. That would create a vicious downward spiral, in which lower growth led to even less new investment. Japan and the South-East Asian countries are all desperate to avoid that. They will be hard-pressed to do so.

This may explain why top Thai officials found it worthwhile to meet with three big private Japanese banks-Sakura, Sumitomo and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi-as well as to drop in on EXIM Bank. 
Investors in Japanese shares are also concerned. Although Asia accounts for only about 4% of the overall earnings of Japanese companies, car makers and manufacturers of electrical machinery have a particularly big exposure in South-East Asia. Goldman Sachs, an American investment bank, reckons that these sectors account for more than a third of . this year's expected growth in Japanese corporate profits. If demand in these countries falls further, so, almost certainly, will such companies' earnings. 
It is not just Japan's manufacturers that are exposed. Japanese banks competed against each other to finance growth in Asia, especially in Thailand. Of that country's $70 billion of external private debts, $37.5 billion are to Japanese banks, according to the Bank for International Settlements. In Indonesia, which this week saw its currency plunge (see box on next page), around $22 billion of the officially reported $55 billion of foreign debt is owed to Japanese banks, and some analysts think that the country's true foreign indebtedness is much greater. 
These numbers need some context. Although they probably underestimate Japanese banks' true exposures, they are small compared with the banks' domestic lending. And perhaps a third of loans are to Japanese companies operating in the region. Still, the further their currencies fall, the greater the South-East Asian countries' foreign debt burdens become and the greater the risk of default. In Thailand alone, some $40 billion of private foreign-currency debts fall due in the next 12 months. And rumours circulate in Bangkok of a moratorium on debt payments. This would sting Japanese banks, still struggling to cope with their domestic bad loans. In all, such worries could give an already shaky Japanese stockmarket the vapours. 
Sending jobs abroad 
So it matters a lot to Japan what happens in South-East Asia. Equally, Japanese companies' reaction to the turmoil is crucial to the economic health of South-East Asia. Last year, Japanese companies invested about $5.7 billion in factories or property developments in Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines. This represents just over a third of all foreign direct investment in the region last year, and far more in Thailand (see charts on next pages One in seven manufacturing workers in Thailand is employed by a Japanese firm. Matsushita, a consumer-electronics firm, alone accounts for 4% of Malaysia's GDP; a fifth of Malaysia's new manufacturing jobs in the 199os are at Japanese companies. 
In the past, says Chihung Kwan, an economist at Nomura Research Institute, Japanese investment in Asia has been driven mainly by the level of the yen against the American dollar. Since many Asian countries more or less pegged their currencies to the dollar, Japanese companies could use them as a cheap proxy for an American manufacturing base. The yen's fall against the dollar since April 1995, however, has diminished the incentive to use South-East Asia as an export base. 
This year's sharp devaluations against both the dollar and (to a lesser extent) the yen, should make such investments look more attractive. But, argues Mr Kwan, it is not just the level of their currencies that matters, but how volatile they are against the dollar. "The myth of the dollar peg has been broken," he says. Given the instability that pegging has caused, these countries are unlikely to fix their currencies again soon, so volatility will be a continuing fact of life. 
Yet Japanese manufacturers have not been using South-East Asia only, or even mainly, as a cheap base for exports to elsewhere in the world. Many have invested in the region because economies there have been growing fast and trade barriers between them are coming down. More than 70% of the products that Japanese companies produce in Asia are now sold within the region. So Japanese manufacturing companies are very exposed to any slowing of local demand. This was, for some products, happening anyway. Car sales in Thailand between January and June fell 14.5% at an annual rate, and car makers say they expect worse to come. Consumer electronics will presumably go the same way. 
Demand would fall further were there a credit crunch. This is already under way in Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines. And that is where Japan's banks again come into the picture. Unless they are prepared to lend, investment, and with it growth, will slump. That would create a vicious downward spiral, in which lower growth led to even less new investment. Japan and the South-East Asian countries are all desperate to avoid that. They will be hard-pressed to do so.

PRIVATISING the post office would seem an obvious step in Ryutaro Hashimoto's plans for reform. For one thing, it would get up to a third of Japan's 855,000 bureaucrats off the government payroll. But the prime minister is facing strong opposition to the idea within the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP). With a tough upper-house election looming next summer, politicians do not want to be seen threatening the existence of the post office's 24,600 branches, conjuring up visions of little old ladies having to travel farther to pay insurance contributions or withdraw cash. Worse, LDP backbenchers fear losing the handouts and support they receive at election time from the postmasters' association and the postal unions. Postmasters carry tremendous prestige in Japan. Most are descendants of the rich and influential individuals who bought the title when the service was established in 1871. 
The rebellion within the LDP would have been unthinkable a month ago, when Mr Hashimoto was riding high in the public's esteem thanks to his plans for reform, including bringing the wayward bureaucracy to heel. But his popularity plunged overnight-from 53% to 35% in the Asahi Shimbun's opinion poll-after he allowed Koko Sato into his cabinet on September lith. Mr Sato, who was convicted of taking bribes during the Lockheed scandal of 1976, has since resigned from the cabinet. But the public has yet to forgive Mr Hashimoto for capitulating to nefarious forces within the LDP hierarchy. Lacking a power base of his own, Mr Hashimoto has only the power of his office to silence the party plotters who would do him down. With his public support diminished, the prime minister now faces a sizeable insurrection in the party over post-office privatisation. 
With Y230 trillion ($1.9 trillion) in deposits, Japan's postal-savings business (yucho) is the largest bank in the world. Its life-insurance scheme (kampo) has some y100 trillion worth of assets, making it more than twice the size of Nippon Lifeitself the world's largest conventional insurance company. The bulk of the money collected by the post office is deposited with the Ministry of Finance's trust-fund office, where it is used to finance Japan's "off-budget" expenditures, known as FILP (fiscal investment and loan programme). Among other things, FILP funnels money to the building industry (paving Japan's river beds is the latest wheeze) as well as to dozens of state-owned companies that have long ceased to serve any useful purpose other than to provide lucrative retirement jobs for ageing bureaucrats. 
As Mr Hashimoto sees it, the main purpose of privatising the post office is to divert to the private sector a Niagara of public cash in a bid to impose some much-needed financial discipline on the ministries and their zoku giin (tribe members) within the LDP. Cutting the number of bureaucrats by a third would save the country Y1.4 trillion a year in wage costs alone. In an interim report, the Administrative Reform Councila 15-member panel of the great and the good chaired by the prime minister himself-recommended that the task of mail delivery be left untouched but that the post office's life-insurance business be privatised by 2001, with savings to be privatised later. 
The political tribe within the LDP that does the postal ministry's bidding has now had its instructions. All three parts of the post office-mail, savings and insurancemust be kept in the governments hands. Even Koichi Kato, the party's influential secretary-general and the main force behind the Hashimoto cabinet's existence, has come out strongly against post-office privatisation. Mr Kato is adamant about keeping the small but important Social Democratic Party within the governing coalition. The socialists want nothing to do with privatising any part of the post office. 
Mr Hashimoto knows that, if he is to maintain the core of the reform programme he has staked his career on, then all those savings and insurance premiums cannot be left sloshing around the public sector. As a compromise, political insiders expect that the post office will be allowed to remain intact. But it will probably have to accept some reduction-20% is talked about-in manning levels as part of the price of being let offthe hook. Moreover, interest rates on savings could well be pegged below those offered by commercial banks. And the bonuses paid to postal workers for selling insurance may be abolished. 
The tricky part is what to do with all the postal funds accumulating in the Ministry of Finance's trust-fund office. Mr Hashimoto is expected to insist that they should at least be managed by a professional outside firm instead of a bunch of amateurs at the ministry. The point of privatising the post office in the first place was to get those funds out of the government's grubby fingers-and, in the process, give the people a better return on their savings. The prime minister could yet salvage a bit of public kudos from a political disaster.

text:
AN ADVISER to President Clinton once remarked that, if reincarnated, he would like to come back as the bond market because "you can intimidate everybody". Because of pessimism about the economy, yields on Japanese-government bonds are only a whisker above the lowest in history (in Genoa in 1619). So Ryutaro Hashimoto has probably been feeling rather intimidated of late. 
The reception given to the economic reforms proposed by the ruling Liberal Democratic Party on October 21st is unlikely to make the prime minister feel better. Businessmen groaned, commentators griped, the stockmarket swooned (though temporarily; it jumped sharply the next day) and bond yields are still poised to beat that Genoan record. There were no big proposals in the package, scarcely any small ones (save one to have more public holidays on a Monday so that people can have more long weekends to spend money), and little, in the short term at least, to coax people to raid their savings. Mr Hashimoto's main proposals were a bit more deregulation in telecommunications; a few less taxes on holding, buying and selling land; some help for medium-sized and small companies; and an intention (no more) to reduce Japan's extravagant corporate taxes. No income-tax cuts, no more public-works spending. Two other packages are due this year, but the government does not appear to have the stomach for deregulation. 
Yet Mr Hashimoto is in no hurry. Although almost every commentator says that Japan's economy will grow little this financial year, most think that it will grow at 2% or more next year. Mr Hashimoto may reason that big changes now would have implied that the government was panicking; that it has proposed none may simply mean that it, too, thinks the economy will improve. 
Deregulation is the key in the medium term; and the reason why there were few deregulatory proposals this week may be because there have already been moves in this direction. Low and falling land prices have had a big impact on confidence. This explains why Mr Hashimoto made a few extra proposals to try to deregulate the property market. Yet in truth land prices seem to be finding a floor: prices of prime commercial land in big cities are already rising, thanks, in part, to the relaxation of rules on how much property can be built on a site.

text:
SUMMIT meetings, say cynics, usually offer more stagecraft than statecraft. If so, the big players in North-East Asia have been putting on quite a show. Shortly after China's president, Jiang Zemin, met Bill Clinton late last month, Russia's president, Boris Yeltsin, played host to Japan's prime minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, for less formal talks in Siberia. This week, Mr Yeltsin was in Beijing for a friendly chat (and ardent bearhugs) with Mr Jiang. He also held meetings with hina's prime minister, Li Peng, who later flew to Tokyo to meet Mr Hashimoto and to have an audience with Japan's Emperor Akihito. 
All these summits generated their fair share of froth-witness the spectacle of Mr Jiang strumming a guitar in Hawaii, or Mr Yeltsin and Mr Hashimoto going fishing in the Siberian forests. But they produced some genuine achievements too, not least for China. Indeed, it is China's growing power and purpose in the region that provide much of the impetus behind the recent flurry of high-level diplomacy. 
China and Russia may still find it hard to boost their anaemic trade, but they managed to put an end of sorts to a pesky dispute over border demarcation (despite continuing to disagree on two intractable border prob lems). In the 196os, China and the Soviet Union were involved in fighting at their borders. So China at least will be glad of one less problem to worry about in the north as it looks south in its search for greater regional influence. Russia and Japan had less success with their territorial dispute, over four small islands occupied by Russia since the end of the second world war. But at least they declared their intention to try to settle the disagreement within three years. 
While in the United States, Mr Jiang agreed to suspend China's nuclear co-operation with Iran. In return, Mr Clinton moved to lift a ban on the sale of American nuclear-energy technology to China. While China gets better technology, American companies could win contracts worth billions of dollars in coming years. 
Beyond all the agreements and statements, the spate of meetings also offer a sketch of how relations between these four countries are beginning to take shape. As a Kremlin spokesman, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, put it shortly before leaving for Beijing: "The timing of all these visits is a coincidence, but a very symbolic one" Russia, still uneasy about NATO'S ex ansion to its west, is making clear that it has other eastern strings to its foreign-policy bow. But the symbolism of all these visits is not lost on China's leaders either. In the new web being woven from the dignitaries' criss-crossing flight paths, there is a clearly discernible hub: Beijing. 
Big-power relations in East Asia are shifting in dramatic if indeterminate ways. Few would deny that America remains the predominant power to be reckoned with in the region, but no one is sure either how soon China's rising influence will be felt, or how it will be managed. Judging by its dip lomatic performance this month, China has decided that winning friends and influencing people requires a lighter touch. 
That contrasts sharply with the bluster that blew from Beijing last year. Most dramatic was the plunge in relations with the United States after China drew American warships to the Taiwan Strait with a series of intimidating missile tests in the shipping lanes off Taiwan. 
Relations between China and Japan, meanwhile, soured sharply last year after Japan and America reaffirmed their security alliance and then went to work on new military guidelines, published earlier this year, that give Japan a greater supporting role (though not a fighting one) in the event of future crises in the region. As tensions rose, Japan and China also traded words over disputed islands in the East China Sea (called the Diaoyus by China, the Senkakus by Japan). 
Staying cool 
Both countries have since sought to cool tempers. The United States and Japan have insisted that their guidelines are aimed neither at China nor at any other country. Indeed,Japan especially has gone to great lengths to convince China of this. But it will not give China the one assurance it wants: an explicit promise to exclude Taiwan from the scope of the security agreement. Both Japan and America have offered to include China in three-sided discussions, hoping by doing so to demonstrate openness; but China still says, officially anyway, thatjapan's explanations on the security pact are "obscure and unconvincing". Nonetheless, there has been an important softening in China's attitude. Issues that last year were treated as trouble spots are, say diplomats, this year being swept aside. 
China also appears eager to minimise its differences with the United States, although Congress, with its steady drip of anti-China motions, makes this difficult. But even in America, playing statesman has been lucrative for Mr Jiang, since he enjoys nearly total control over the press coverage at home of his exploits abroad, all of which add to his stature. 
To have Mr Clinton come calling, as is due to happen next year, will add to Mr Jiang's political triumphs. These include not only his American visit, but also his smooth handling of Deng Xiaoping's death, the handover of Hong Kong and the 15th congress of China's Communist Party. Successes such as these at home, say Chinese diplomats, have given Mr Jiang the confidence to run foreign policy according to his own pragmatic instincts and to resist hardline pressure. 
But where might Mr Jiang's pragmatic instincts lead? China's stated aim is a more multipolar region. Implicit in that phrase is a challenge to America's role as the world's only superpower. Rather than challenge American power head-on, China is putting on a friendly regional face. China's offer of money to help sort out South-East Asia's financial problems was a first-and one that people in the region have begun to contrast, however mistakenly, with what they see as America's aloofness from their problems. 
Meanwhile, China places great emphasis on the "strategic perspective" of its ties with the region's bigger powers, America, Russia and Japan. And the Chinese insist that no one partnership is directed at any other country. Given the long-standing rivalries in the region, however, and China's desire to play a bigger regional role, that does not sound very convincing.

text:
Japan's currency has fallen by a third against the dollar since April 1995. It may tumble even further 
HIS silence has been deafening. In April, a few words from Eisuke Sakakibara of Japan's finance ministry arguing that the markets were too pessimistic about the Japanese economy were sufficient to reverse a sharp fall in the currency. Then, slowly, the yen began falling again. The retreat is now in danger of becoming a rout. This week a dollar fetched Y26, compared with Y115 at the end of June. Some Tokyo economists think that the yen is about to plunge. Yet from "Mr Yen" there has been not a peep. 
The implication is clear: both the finance ministry and the Bank of Japan would not mind if the yen fell further. Mr Sakakibara's optimism was, it transpires, premature. Japan's economy shrank at an annual rate of 11.2% in the second quarter of this year. Although it is likely to bounce back in the third quarter, the economy is undeniably in poor shape, principally because of weak domestic demand. In April the government raised taxes and cut public spending. Consumers have been keener to save than to spend. As for companies, they have preferred to pay off debts rather than invest in new buildings and equipment. 
Until recently, the only prop for Japan's economy, thanks to a cheapening yen, has been its companies ability to export cars, electronic gadgets and so forth overseas. Even that prop has been crumbling as other Asian countries have had their currencies mauled. Almost half of Japanese exports go to the rest of Asia. As long as Asia's financial crisis remained confined to the small South-East Asian countries that account for a bit more than 12% of Japan's exports, the drag on its economy was minor; now that South Korea, which accounts for about 7% of Japanese exports, has been sucked into the crisis, the prospects for Japan's exporters have become grimmer. 
Small wonder, then, that pessimism reigns in Japan. The stockmarket has fallen by a quarter since June; on November 13th, the Nikkei 225 average reached 15,427, its lowest level for over two years. Long-term interest rates are the lowest anywhere in recorded history. Economists have been scrambling to reduce their growth forecasts: having thought in June that the economy would grow by 3.1% next year, Jesper Koll of J.P. Morgan trimmed his prediction to 2.5% in September. Now he thinks that it will grow by a mere 1.2%. 
Japan's options are limited. Consumers and companies seem unwilling to spend much more. The government wants to spend less. Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister, has staked his reputation on getting Japan's finances, which are in a horrible mess, into better shape. A bill to reduce the government deficit from 7% to 3% of GDP by 2003 is working its way through the Diet, Japan's parliament. The American government wants Japan to backtrack on these spending cuts, but even if it does, noone thinks that the Japanese government will start spending much more again. 
Which leaves exports. The catch, points out Peter Tasker, a strategist at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, is that, thanks to the collapse of currencies elsewhere in Asia, the yen has actually appreciated by 9% in trade-weighted terms over the past year. An increase in exports to America and Asia therefore requires an even weaker yen. 
America seems willing to put up with this. It does not want to tip Japan, whose GDP is much larger than the rest of Asia put together, into recession. Because America's economy is still growing at a brisk rate, its officials are content with a stronger dollar, which should help slow growth and reduce the threat of higher inflation. text:
This week it seemed that Japan was at last facing up to its banking crisis. Then it seemed not 
THE Japanese finance ministry has long and vehemently insisted that the country's 20 biggest banks are too big to fail. Oops. As of November 17th, with the collapse of Hokkaido Takushoku Bank-the country's tenth-largest city (ie, big commercial) bank-there are only 19 on that list The Tokyo stockmarket decided that this was a jolly good thing, for it showed that the financial authorities finally had a template and, possibly, public money to deal with the festering banking crisis. Having fallen by a quarter since the beginning of the year, the Nikkei 225 average promptly rebounded by 8% or 1,200 points-the fourthlargest rise in its history. 
So much for wishful thinking. Most of the surge in the Nikkei, it seems, came from short-sellers who needed to replace the borrowed shares that they had sold the week before in the (temporarily wrong) expectation that the market would slide further. The finance ministry appeared to be operating less from a new template than from old habit, and the promised flow of money dried up when Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister, asserted: "I have never said that public funds would be used." So on November 19th the Nikkei sobered up and dropped by 5.3%. And after a few days in which it seemed that Japan was finally ready to confront its long-running banking crisis head on, reality returned: Japan's banks are still in trouble, and the government is still unsure what to do about it. 
Certainly, there is little evidence of new thinking from the finance ministry. Until the 11th hour, it had been trying to armtwist healthier institutions into taking over Hokkaido Takushoku, known in Sapporo, its home, as "Takugin". Plans to merge the troubled bank with Hokkaido Bank came to naught in September. So did attempts to get life-insurance companies to inject a further Y150 billion ($1.2 billion) into the bank's capital base. In the end, as depositors fled and other banks grew reluctant to lend to Hokkaido Takushoku, the authorities had to accept the inevitable. 
Takugin's is the biggest financial collapse in Japanese history. No one yet knows how big; the finance ministry's inspectors are only half way through the audit they started a month ago. Takugin had Y6.8 trillion worth of deposits on its books last March and, officially, its non-performing loans amounted to Y934 billion. That makes its failure nearly three times larger than Japan's previous record-holder. The full story maybe much worse. Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's top financial daily, reckoned recently that 22% of the bank's loans were dodgy. This would bring the amount of non-performers to Y1.5 trillion. 
Takugin's profitable business is likely to end up with Hokuyo Bank, a healthy midsized institution in Sapporo, while most of the non-performing loans will be inherited by the Deposit Insurance Corporation, an emergency pool funded mainly by other banks. The Bank of Japan, the central bank, has smoothed the process by lending Takugin a staggering Y1.12 trillion, with more likely to follow. The central bank can lend any amount if a bankruptcy threatens the stability of the country's financial system. "A clear case of systemic risk existed," insists a senior Bank of Japan official. 
The hitch in all this is that the Deposit Insurance Corporation itself is not rolling in money. It is thought to be in the red by as much as Y21O billion, although it is empowered to borrow up to Y2 trillion from the Bank of Japan. Banks may also face higher premiums for deposit insurance. But, one way or another, the public will have to foot the bill. 
Therein lies the problem. Having been savaged by an outraged electorate over the liquidation of seven jusen, or mortgage companies, last year, and with a crucial up per-house election due next summer, Japanese politicians have been understandably nervous about even hinting that public money is needed to sort out Japan's banking mess. Behind closed doors that is, however, precisely what the government has been talking about for months. One rumour is that it will set up a Securities Holding Fund to buy preferred stock issued by the banks. The Y8 trillion being mooted would come from savings at the post office, which is owned by the government. 
Whatever the outcome,James Fiorillo, a banking analyst at ING Barings in Tokyo, reckons that it will take Y8 trillion of public money just to solve bad-loan problems among Japan's 19 remaining big banks. That is nearly 12 times greater than the amount of public money (Y685 billion) involved in the jusen fiasco-and it still leaves the messes at dozens of smaller banks unresolved. 
The good news in all this is that the finance ministry has accepted the demise of its cherished "convoy system", which has forced stronger financial institutions to help their weaker brethren. With financial deregulation looming, winners are no longer willing to support losers. Two implications follow. One is that the gap between good and bad banks will widen further as funds are pulled away from weaker institutions. The second is that investors in failed banks can expect to lose their shirts. A suspicious public is unlikely to accept a government bail-out for the banks unless it is clear that, unlike in the jusen affair, shareholders are bearing the pain.

text:
Japan's financial system is melting down. It is unclear whether the government can act quickly enough to stop it 
NO, SAID both the governor of the Bank of Japan and the finance minister, with straight faces, Yamaichi Securities was not insolvent. Why, then, did Japan's fourth-largest securities firm announce on November 24th that it would be closing? Yamaichi is done for, and everybody knows it. Plenty of other financial firms should be considered insolvent too. Six years after Japan's once-powerful banks began drowning in losses, the government at last seems prepared to let bad banks, insurers and stockbrokers fail. 
Earlier this month, Sanyo Securities, a middling securities firm, went under. On November 17th, Hokkaido Takushoku, a big commercial bank, followed suit. This week brought the collapse of Tokuyo, a tiddler, while Ashikaga, a big regional bank, begged its biggest shareholder, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, for assistance. No one thinks that these will be the last. Queues are forming outside weaker banks as worried depositors pull out their savings. Confidence in the financial system is collapsing. 
So serious has the crisis become that, at last, politicians and the finance ministry are discussing a subject long forbidden: injecting public money into the system. On November 27th, after much dithering, Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister, said that public funds would be used to solve the banking system's woes. But although that principle is now accepted, Mr Hashimoto has yet to put forth details. Whether the government can deliver a package that is both big enough and of the right sort to fix the financial system's problems remains an open question. 
Yamaichi's demise has been the immediate catalyst in this crisis. Once the biggest securities firm in Japan, the company's straits have been no secret: it has lost money in four of the past six years. But even as Yamaichi's problems mounted, it was widely assumed that the finance ministry would quietly arrange for a bank to take it over. The decision to allow a firm of Yamaichi's size and stature to fail came as a shock. More shocking still was the news that it had hidden huge losses from regulators by setting up dummy companies in the Cayman Islands. According to preliminary investigations, these amounted to 264 billion ($2 billion). There is more: according to a senior official at the finance ministry, "Yamaichi may have used investors' money for its own purposes." The amount involved is not known. 
Financial authorities feel the need to maintain the fiction that Yamaichi is solvent for three reasons. First, the Bank of Japan is not supposed to lend to insolvent institutions; insolvency would have made it hard for the central bank to lend Yamaichi the money to settle outstanding trades and to return investors' assets. 
Second, if it was insolvent, the authorities would have to dip into the Compensation Fund for Deposited Securities to repay investors, but the fund itself is almost out of money. 
Third, an insolvent Yamaichi would also be declared bankrupt, allowing the courts to seize control of its and clients' assets. That might make already jittery investors panic and could delay the settlement of deals still in the works, snarling up payment and settlement systems. 
Other securities firms have indulged in similar practices to Yamaichi's. Many are probably as "solvent' as Yamaichi proved to be. "It will not be the last to fail," says the finance ministry official. Indeed, if Yamaichi hid losses of such magnitude, investors reasoned, other firms may also have something nasty in the woodshed. On November 25th, the first day of trading after Yamaichi's collapse, the Nikkei zs average fell by 854 points, or 5.1%. Shares in all but the strongest financial institutions fell sharply again the next day. Although Daiwa Securities, Japan's second-largest broker, said on November 26th that it had no offbalance sheet losses, that did not stop its shares from falling by 20% more. Those in Nikko, the third-biggest broker, fell by almost as much. 
Dramatic as they are, the problems at Japan's brokers are insignificant compared with those of banks and life-insurance firms. Stockbrokers hold only a small amount of investors' savings, as shares account for only 4.5% of household financial assets. In contrast, 15.9% of household assets are on deposit at banks, and io% are invested in insurance policies. 
About those guarantees. . . 
Thirteen of the 19 biggest banks expect to report losses this year as a result of writing off bad loans. This week several big banks claimed yet again that the worst of their bad debt problems are behind them. Given the opacity of the banks' accounting, however, the markets do not trust this. The bigger, healthier banks will survive: shares in Tokyo-Mitsubishi, for example, have suffered little in the recent carnage. But investors are now dumping shares in any bank that has the remotest whiff of risk-particularly because the failure of Hokkaido Takushoku has made it clear that the finance ministry's "guarantee" of the top 20 banks applies only to depositors and creditors, not to shareholders. 
Even creditors are now none too sure about the worth of the ministry's guarantee. This has pushed up the banks' cost of borrowing. The "Japan premium", the extra rate at which Japanese banks must borrow in dollars compared with their healthier foreign counterparts, has risen to between half and one percentage point this week. For Nippon Credit Bank, it reached four percentage points. Some weaker Japanese banks are finding it prohibitively expensive to borrow even in yen. Few, if any, foreign banks will give them credit lines, and healthy domestic banks are refusing to lend to their weaker brethren. Nobody wants to buy the debentures issued by any of the long-term credit banks. The weaker banks can get cash only from the Bank of Japan, which now has Y3.6 trillion in loans to the banking system compared with just 373 billion at the end of October. 
Small wonder that shares in troubled banks have tumbled. Those in Yasuda Trust, which is part of the same keiretsu as Yamaichi, fell by 28% on November 25th as its debt was downgraded to junk by Standard 8 Poor's, a credit-rating agency. Shares in other big and deeply troubled banks such as Nippon Credit Bank, Long-Term Credit Bank and Daiwa Bank, fell as much. And they all fell further the next day. The market capitalisation of some of the weakest halved in two days. "The markets are engineering the shutdown of banks. . . and that is very dangerous," says James Fiorillo, an analyst at ING Barings. 
Mutual life insurers are in similarly dire straits. Not only are they the biggest holders of bank shares, but life insurers have given some Y434 billion in subordinated loans to brokers, and a whopping 14 trillion to banks. Subordinated loans are not covered by the finance ministry's guarantee. Should more banks and brokers go bust, life insurers are unlikely to get this money back. 
They are anyway in a pickle. Andrew Smithers, an independent London-based economist, reckons that, taken as a whole, the life-insurance industry is insolvent. Big companies, such as mighty Nippon Life, are reasonably robust. The smaller ones are anything but. One, Nissan Life, has already folded this year. Low interest rates, a mass cancellation of policies (which eats into cashflow) and a sinking stockmarket (which eats into unrealised gains on their equity portfolios), already mean that they are suffering a severe shortage of available funds. Some insurers own large amounts of American Treasury bonds, and there are fears in America that they will dump these to raise cash. This seems unlikely: firms that hope to survive have no choice but to hold on to their Treasuries, their most highyielding assets at present. 
The jitters of politicians and bureaucrats are understandable. For the first time since the beginning of 1996, when the finance ministry pushed through a highly unpopular package to liquidate seven huge mortgage companies, there is talk of using public money to solve the financial crisis. Politicians feel that the public fright over financial failures will override objections to bailing out the banks. 
The form that such public money would take is still undecided. One option is to set up a version of America's Resolution Trust Corporation, which inherited and sold off the assets of failed savings and loan associations in the early 199os. A second option, increasingly favoured by the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, is to inject funds into the Deposit Insurance Corporation. Where it would get the money is unclear. One possible source is bonds guaranteed by the government. These would be bought by the finance ministry's trust-fund bureau, which manages*400 trillion of deposits in the postal savings system. A seemingly more favoured option is to get money directly from the Bank of Japan. 
How the money is injected is, in some ways, academic. The Deposit Insurance Corporation would not have the power to investigate banks and shut down those it deemed insolvent. It would only be able to dispose of banks' assets once they had gone bust. This creates a problem more serious than the one it purports to solve. Without clarity as to whether bad institutions will be closed, the capital markets will force all but the strongest of banks to pay a huge premium to borrow money. That may drive even relatively healthy banks to the wall. In a sign of just such a development, shares in Fuji Bank-by no means the worst-ofi of Japan's banking giants-did not trade for two days this week, so concerned has the market become about its health. 
Worse, politicians, whatever their newfound commitment to using public cash, seem content to fiddle while Rome burns. The details of the Liberal Democratic Party's scheme will not be announced until December ioth. Nothing is likely to become law until mid-January. Without huge injections of money from the Bank of Japan, a lot of institutions could go bust by them.

The bigger , healthier banks will survive : shares in Tokyo - Mitsubishi , for example , have suffered little in the recent carnage . But investors are now dumping shares in any bank that has the remotest whiff of risk - particularly because the failure of Hokkaido Takushoku has made it clear that the finance ministry 's " guarantee " of the top 20 banks applies only to depositors and creditors , not to shareholders . 
 Even creditors are now none too sure about the worth of the ministry 's guarantee . This has pushed up the banks ' cost of borrowing . The " Japan premium " , the extra rate at which Japanese banks must borrow in dollars compared with their healthier foreign counterparts , has risen to between half and one percentage point this week . For Nippon Credit Bank , it reached four percentage points . Some weaker Japanese banks are finding it prohibitively expensive to borrow even in yen . Few , if any , foreign banks will give them credit lines , and healthy domestic banks are refusing to lend to their weaker brethren . Nobody wants to buy the debentures issued by any of the long - term credit banks . The weaker banks can get cash only from the Bank of Japan , which now has Y3.6 trillion in loans to the banking system compared with just 373 billion at the end of October . 
 Small wonder that shares in troubled banks have tumbled . Those in Yasuda Trust , which is part of the same keiretsu as Yamaichi , fell by 28 % on November 25th as its debt was downgraded to junk by Standard 8 Poor 's , a credit - rating agency . Shares in other big and deeply troubled banks such as Nippon Credit Bank , Long - Term Credit Bank and Daiwa Bank , fell as much . And they all fell further the next day . The market capitalisation of some of the weakest halved in two days . " The markets are engineering the shutdown of banks . . . and that is very dangerous , " says James Fiorillo , an analyst at ING Barings . 
 Mutual life insurers are in similarly dire straits . Not only are they the biggest holders of bank shares , but life insurers have given some Y434 billion in subordinated loans to brokers , and a whopping 14 trillion to banks . Subordinated loans are not covered by the finance ministry 's guarantee . Should more banks and brokers go bust , life insurers are unlikely to get this money back . 
 They are anyway in a pickle . Andrew Smithers , an independent London - based economist , reckons that , taken as a whole , the life - insurance industry is insolvent . Big companies , such as mighty Nippon Life , are reasonably robust . The smaller ones are anything but . One , Nissan Life , has already folded this year . Low interest rates , a mass cancellation of policies ( which eats into cashflow ) and a sinking stockmarket ( which eats into unrealised gains on their equity portfolios ) , already mean that they are suffering a severe shortage of available funds . Some insurers own large amounts of American Treasury bonds , and there are fears in America that they will dump these to raise cash . This seems unlikely : firms that hope to survive have no choice but to hold on to their Treasuries , their most highyielding assets at present . 
 The jitters of politicians and bureaucrats are understandable . For the first time since the beginning of 1996 , when the finance ministry pushed through a highly unpopular package to liquidate seven huge mortgage companies , there is talk of using public money to solve the financial crisis . Politicians feel that the public fright over financial failures will override objections to bailing out the banks . 
 The form that such public money would take is still undecided . One option is to set up a version of America 's Resolution Trust Corporation , which inherited and sold off the assets of failed savings and loan associations in the early 199os . A second option , increasingly favoured by the ruling Liberal Democratic Party , is to inject funds into the Deposit Insurance Corporation . Where it would get the money is unclear . One possible source is bonds guaranteed by the government . These would be bought by the finance ministry 's trust - fund bureau , which manages*400 trillion of deposits in the postal savings system . A seemingly more favoured option is to get money directly from the Bank of Japan . 
 How the money is injected is , in some ways , academic . The Deposit Insurance Corporation would not have the power to investigate banks and shut down those it deemed insolvent . It would only be able to dispose of banks ' assets once they had gone bust . This creates a problem more serious than the one it purports to solve . Without clarity as to whether bad institutions will be closed , the capital markets will force all but the strongest of banks to pay a huge premium to borrow money . That may drive even relatively healthy banks to the wall . In a sign of just such a development , shares in Fuji Bank - by no means the worst - ofi of Japan 's banking giants - did not trade for two days this week , so concerned has the market become about its health . 
 Worse , politicians , whatever their newfound commitment to using public cash , seem content to fiddle while Rome burns . The details of the Liberal Democratic Party 's scheme will not be announced until December ioth . Nothing is likely to become law until mid - January . Without huge injections of money from the Bank of Japan , a lot of institutions could go bust by them .

text:
AS RECENTLY as September, Ryutaro Hashimoto was enjoying great popularity, both with his party, the Liberal Democrats (LDP and with the public. The prime minister had crushed the opposition in a general election, and was being applauded for his attempts to curtail the bureaucrats and slash government spending. Then he allowed himself to be arm-twisted by the party into appointing Koko Sato, a convicted bribe-taker, to his cabinet. Ever since, Mr Hashimoto has been on the defensive. 
Before the present session of the Diet (parliament) ends on December 12th, Mr Hashimoto will come under enormous pressure to compile a pork-laden supplementary budget for the LDP'S special friends in the building industry and down on the farm. This is the kind of wasteful spending that Mr Hashimoto's fiscal reform bill, passed on November 28th, was supposed to stop. Thanks to a decade of splurging on needless public works, the government's accumulated debt-some Y475 trillion ($3.7 trillion) or 95% of GDP is now one of the highest among industrial countries. The reform bill aims to reduce Japan's budget deficit from 7% of GDP today to less than 3% by 2003. The bill also requires the government to stop issuing deficit-covering bonds within five years-and to start by cutting public-works spending by 7% next year. 
To add to his woes, the prime minister's plans for administrative reform have been mutilated. Mr Hashimoto's biggest climbdown has been over post-office privatisation. No one seriously expected mail delivery to be turned over to the private sector. But privatising the postal savings and insurance business was seen as the best way to wrestle these vast funds away from the finance ministry's Trust Fund Bureau. The ministry has used this money to finance two "off-budget budgets" for its own purposes. Between them, the fiscal investment and loan programme and the 30-odd special budgets for specific undertakings (eg, road building) add up to more than the national budget. Much of the money goes into maintaining some 90 public corporations whose main function these days is to provide cushy retirement jobs for officials. 
With the present turmoil in Japan's financial industry, the LDP has started demanding that public money be used to halt the rot that has caused four big banks or securities firms to collapse over the past month. Only a few weeks ago Mr Hashimoto said that no public money would be used to deal with a financial crisis brought on by reckless lending and shoddy management. He has now had to make a u-turn (see page 81). He will soon have to make another on fiscal reform. The supplementary budget being thrust on him by his party may inject Y5 trillion into the economy through tax breaks for small businesses and farmers and yet more spending on disaster protection and public works. 
The party's criticism of Mr Hashimoto has turned personal. A parliamentary committee has questioned him about his relationship some years ago with a female Chinese government official who is now thought to have been a spy. Clearly, moves are afoot to put an end to the prime minister's second term of office. 
The plotters in the LDP do not yet have a suitable replacement as party leader. Mr Hashimoto will carry on for now as the prime minister more by default than design. But it is just possible, too, that he could surprise everyone by making a stand over his reforms. The fickle public would be applauding him again-and the party would then have to back him too.

text:
HAVING had eight years in which to ponder a festering financial crisis, Japan's politicians and bureaucrats might have thought long and hard about a solution. Even if they had not, a stalled economy, a spate of bankruptcies at banks and brokers, and the spread of banking crises and stockmarket collapses across East Asia might have galvanised Japan's leaders into action. 
If only. Politicians do, at long last, recognise the need for public money to solve the financial system's woes. Also, the ruling Liberal Democratic Party has set up a committee chaired by Kiichi Miyazawa, a former prime minister and a political heavyweight, to study how that public cash should best be used. But that is as far as the reaction goes. Japan's politicians now recognise that they need to do something about the problem. But resolving it is still not a matter of urgency. This displays timidity and stupidity in equal measure. The politicians are loth to offend Mrs Watanabe, the archetypal Japanese housewife who controls the family's purse-strings. She was outraged last year, when the government pushed through a bill to liquidate seven mortgage companies, known as jusen, with 685 billion ($6.3 billion at the time) of tax money. The government of Ryutaro Hashimoto, the prime minister, is now at pains to persuade her that insolvent banks, brokers and insurance companies must be bailed out But honest estimates of the cost start at io trillion-nearly $80 billion-and run to Y30 trillion or more. Someone has to tell Mrs Watanabe that she faces a whopping bill, but no one wants to face her ire. Better, then, not to get into the painful details 
Japanese politicians have a good template to study: the resolution of America's savings-and-loan (s&L) debacle at the beginning of the decade. The s&L crisis was tiddly compared with the one facing Japan. But they share some similarities. For one, the regulator for American housing lenders, the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, was widely felt to be part of the problem, much as Japan's finance ministry now bears the onus for the collapse of institutions that it regulates. For another, America's regulator, like Japan's, was geared more to revising s&Ls' accounts than to dealing with the assets owned by insolvent institutions. These simply piled up, just as troubled Japanese institutions today sit with their balance sheets brimming with dubious assets. In America, two important steps turned the situation around. The first was restor ing credibility. A different agency, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, in effect took charge of finding out which thrifts were solvent and which were not. In 1989, it shut down 262 institutions in little more than six months; by 1993 it had closed 747. Depositors, creditors and investors were left in no doubt what would happen if an s&L ran low on capital. The other main reason for America's success was the creation of the Resolution Trust Corporation, also in 1989. Resolution Trust's job was to take over failed institutions' finances, pay off depositors immediately and sell the assets as quickly as possible. It was given a tight time-frame and freedom from normal bureaucratic constraints; its staff even received bigger bonuses for selling assets quickly. This was made easier because they held property from many S&Ls, allowing them to pull together, say, shopping centres from several different portfolios and sell them in bulk to a single investor. Between them, a tougher regulator and an efficient asset-sales agency quickly brought the problem under control. As a result, the final cost to American taxpayers, about $91 billion, was far less than many original estimates. 
Japanese politicians seem not to have studied this example. They still see opacity as a virtue not a vice. One of their proposals would "save" the banking system by injecting equity into weaker banks. This would allow the government to portray its action as an investment rather than a bailout. Never mind that propping up duff banks by injecting fresh capital would prolong the industry's overcapacity and thus hurt Japan's healthier banks, as well as leaving the "rescued" institutions stuffed with dubious assets that had yet to be written down to their true market value. This would not bolster confidence in the banking system. 
A second plan has more echoes of the American solution. This is to expand the role of Japan's Deposit Insurance Corporation (DIC). It would be able to borrow money, with a government guarantee, either from the Bank of Japan or from the finance ministry's trust-fund bureau, which manages postal-savings money. Any shortfall would be made up out of the government's budget in 2001. 
In fact, this provides only a quarter of a solution. It postpones (again deliberately) the issue of using taxpayers' cash directly. And it would do nothing to restore public confidence, since the DIC would act only as a receptacle for banks that regulators declared to be bad. It would not clear up doubts about which banks were dodgy in the first place. Moreover, nothing has been said about whether the DIC would be able to seize banks' assets; or how they would be sold; or if there would be a ceiling on the amount of the liabilities that the DlC could absorb. Nobody is prepared to come out with numbers. 
The worst of it all is this: politicians do not seem to have realised that neither depositors nor the capital markets will believe in a solution overseen by the finance ministry. Its bureaucrats have spent much of the past decade concocting preposterous lies about the health of the finance industry. In mid-1995, the then finance minister, Masayoshi Takemura, said, after the closure of Hyogo Bank, that no other big banks would go bust Even last week the present finance minister claimed that Yamaichi, the country's fourth-largest stockbroker, was still solvent, even though the firm has said it will close. 
Betsy Daniels, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, argues that the clean-up job should be given to the Bank of Japan, whIch, unlike the finance ministry, still has some degree of credibility. That, coupled with a vIc empowered to seize and sell assets, may well be the best solution-and, despite its up front costs, in the long run it would probably be the cheapest.

text:
AM very, very angry and very, very anxious," says Shoichi Royama. His feelings are understandable Mr Royama, a professor at Osaka University, is also an adviser to the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's Financial System Stabilisation Panel, which is supposed to be finding ways to restore health to Japan's rapidly failing financial system. A sub-committee of this panel was supposed to come out with proposals on December loth. It was then due to present these proposals to the LDP two days later, so that the party could include them in a package of measures to be announced on December i6th. It didn't. The sub-committee's meeting was delayed by a day. It is now unclear whether the rest of the timetable will be kept. 
The meeting was postponed ostensibly because Japan's opposition parties had proposed a no-confidence vote in the coalition government, which is dominated by the LDP, for the following day, the last of this year's Diet (parliament* In reality it was shifted because many of the committee's members were cross that Ryutaro Hashimoto, Japan's beleaguered prime minister, had ignored the committee and lent his support to a proposal from Seiroku Kajiyama, a former chief cabinet secretary. 
This proposal comes in two parts. The first involves the package's financing. Mr Hashimoto is committed to reducing public debt. Only two weeks ago, the Diet passed a law committing the government to reduce the government's budget deficit to 3% of GDP and eliminate the issuing of deficit-financing bonds by 2003. Issuing lots of government bonds now to pump money into the financial system would have gone against the spirit if not the letter of the law. 
Step forward Mr Kajiyama. He proposed a way for the government to raise io trillion-worth ($78 billion) of bonds without, miraculously, seeming to increase the general government debt. This was to use the government's remaining shares in Nrr, Japan Tobacco and other companies as collateral for the bonds. Backed by collateral, such borrowing would not show up in the general government borrowing figures. But in many ways the proposal is a deceit, for the net indebtedness of the government still rises. "It is only a policy for accountants," fumes Mr Royama. 
The second point of the proposal-what Mr Kajiyama wants done with the money is just as controversial. Like much else in the debate about how to use public funds, this is murky. For one thing, it was not clear that all of the money would be spent on propping up banks and other financial firms; though later in the week Mr Hashimoto was claiming that it would be spent only on doing something about Japan's financial system. 
Mr Kajiyama seemingly wants to inject public money into moribund financial institutions. This would be lunacy. There is certainly a good argument for injecting public money into.healthy banks that take over the sound assets of failed institutions. However, to inject it into unsound ones rewards the weak, penalises the strong and creates a huge moral hazard. Moreover, such a policy would do nothing to restore the confidence of either depositors or the capital markets, for both would be rightfully wary of any bank that felt the need for an infusion of capital. And it would do nothing at all about the banks' bad debts. 
Just as bad is the fact that Mr Kaj iyama's entry into the debate has created unnecessary delay and confusion. His proposals for raising money will probably be adopted even if his ideas for spending it are not: the wheeze allows the prime minister to save face. But no details have been thrashed out and time is running out fast Mr Royama and others are likely to find the coming week a very fretful one indeed.
